persName.note: James Anderson (1739-1808) was a Scottish farmer and writer on agricultural improvement and political economy, and editor of the periodicals The Bee, or Literary Weekly Intelligencer (1791-1794) and Recreations in Agriculture (1799-1802). Significant works by Anderson include Enquiry into the Nature of the Corn Laws (1777) and The Interest of Great Britain with Respect to the American Colonies (1782). Anderson was at one point an associate of Jeremy Bentham and the latter's famous plan for the Panopticon, a new model of penitentiary, was printed in The Bee. Unpaid subscriptions and a run-in with the authorities over the printing of politically radical materials contributed to the cancellation of The Bee in 1794. Anderson Married Margaret Seton in 1768 and took over the running of the family farm of Monkshill. He later moved to Edinburgh and then London, dying in Essex in 1808. ; Aberdeen University Library, MS 2787/4/4/8, Papers of James Anderson.

note.note: Benjamin Heath Malkin (1769-1842), lawyer, antiquarian and schoolmaster, was educated at Harrow and Cambridge. He married Charlotte née Williams, in around 1794. During the 1790s the Malkins moved in radical circles, their acquaintances including William Godwin, Anna Laetitia Barbauld, Henry Fuseli and William Blake. Blake engraved the frontispiece of Malkin's A Father's Memoir of his Child (1806), written in remembrance to the Benjamin and Charlotte's son, Thomas, who had died in 1802. Malkin was made a Doctor of Civil Law by the University of Oxford in 1810. Malkin served as the University of London's first professor of History from 1829, having worked as a grammar school master for the previous two decades. Malkin published a number of written works in his lifetime, including The Scenery, Antiquities and Biography of South Wales (1804). ODNB.

persName.note: William Markham (bap.1719, d.1807) was born in Cork, educated at Westminster School and Christ Church, Oxford, and appointed archbishop of York in 1776. Markham's rise reflected his close relationship with several powerful figures, including the duke of Newcastle and Lord Mansfield, which had led him to the post of tutor to the prince of Wales and Prince Frederick. After a sermon he gave in 1777, Markham came to be seen by some as a monarchist and enemy of dissenters, leading to a withdrawal from political life, though he supported the administrations of Lord North and subsequently Pitt the Younger. ODNB.

James Sharp (1618-1679) was born at Banff Castle and moved to England as a young man to pursue a career in the clergy. He returned to Scotland where he subscribed to the national covenant and became embroiled in the complex ecclesiastical politics of the Civil War. In 1661 Sharp became a supporter of episcopacy and subsequently became archbishop of St Andrews. After a period of declining influence and reputation, Sharp was murdered by a band of covenanters while en route to St Andrews through Fife in 1679. ODNB

William Auld (fl.1766-1775) was an Edinburgh printer, and publisher of Lachlan Shaw's History of Moray (1775). From 1766-1771 he was part of a printing and publishing partnership with John Balfour and William Smellie. Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).

Bailey (bap. 1751, d. 1819) was a mathematician, land surveyor and engraver, who produced plates for William Hutchinson. Bailey engraved the Map of Scotland and the Hebrides that was to accompany the 1776 edition of Pennant's Tour in Scotland in 1772, though the map itself was not published until 1777. Bailey was a prominent agriculturalist, publishing an Essay on the Construction of the Plough in 1795, and contributing to reports on the counties of Cumberland, Northumberland and Country Durham. ODNB.

Sir James Balfour of Denmiln and Kinnaird (1600-1657), historian and herald, was author of The Annals of the History of Scotland form Malcom III to Charles II, posthumously published in 1824-5. Some of Balfour's numerous other works of Scottish history remain in manuscript in the Advocates' Library in Edinburgh. ODNB.

Sir Joseph Banks (1743-1820) was a naturalist and landowner, and President of the Royal Society from 1778-1820. A Linnaean botanist, Banks accompanied Constantine Phipps to Labrador and Newfoundland in 1766, and rose to national prominence as a member of James Cook's voyage to the South Pacific on the ship Endeavour between 1768-1771. A public dispute with the Admiralty saw Banks withdraw from Cook's Resolution expedition in 1772, leading him to organise his own voyage to Iceland in the same year. Accompanied by the naturalist Daniel Solander, the linguist Uno Von Troil and the artists John Cleveley and James and John Frederick Miller, Banks sailed to Iceland via the Western Isles of Scotland, where he visited Fingal's Cave on Staffa. Banks gifted the visual and written record of the island's basaltic columns made on his voyage to Thomas Pennant, who visited the Hebrides later in the summer of 1772 but was unable to land on Staffa. On his return from Iceland Banks landed in Orkney, where the clergymen George Low acted as a guide to the archipelago's antiquities and natural history. Banks's account of Staffa later appeared verbatim in Pennant's A tour in Scotland, and voyage to the Hebrides (1774) and was the only part of his Iceland journal to be published within his lifetime. Pennant acknowledged Banks's generosity with a glowing dedication in the same volume, though his relationship with Banks was later soured over Pennant's unauthorised purchase of drawings by one of Banks's artists for use in his Arctic Zoology. Banks's London home at 32 Soho Square became a centre of study and meeting-place for European naturalists, while he used his presidency of the Royal Society to promote natural history (at the expense, his rivals felt, of the mathematical sciences), particularly where it served the interests of the British empire. ODNB; John Gascoigne, Joseph Banks and the English Enlightenment : useful knowledge and polite culture (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press 1994).

persName.addName: Barber, barber artist, barber painter, Mr Kaye, Edinburgh barber

note.note: John Kay (1742–1826), portrait etcher and miniature painter, worked as a barber in Edinburgh for seven years, thereby earning the nickname used for him throughout Pennant's correspondence with Richard Bull. In December 1777 he purchased the freedom of the city and was able to start a business of his own, whilst an annuity granted in 1785 allowed him to give up his work as a barber and concentrate on creating caricature portraits, which he sold from his shop. Plans for publishing his work, which amounted to almost 900 plates, of which only 362 survive, were incomplete at the time of his death, but it was published posthumously in monthly parts by Hugh Paton, as A series of original portraits and caricature etchings (1837–8, with subsequent editions in 1842, 1877 and 1885). Kay's work favoured liberals but was broad in its scope and its witty portrayal of Edinburgh society. ODNB; Hilary and Mary Evans, John Kay of Edinburgh: Barber, miniaturist and social commentator 1742–1826 (2nd edn., Edinburgh: Paul Harris, 1980).

persName.note: William Borlase (1696-1772) was an antiquary and naturalist, born in Cornwall. Borlase was a collector of minerals as well as a student of Cornwall's ancient sites, to many of which he ascribed druidic origins. Borlase's Observations on the antiquities historical and monumental, of the county of Cornwall. Consisting of several essays on the first inhabitants, Druid-superstition, and remains of the most remote antiquity, in Britain, and the British Isles, was first published in 1754, and followed in 1756 by Observations on the Ancient and Present State of the Islands of Scilly. Borlase's Natural History of Cornwall was published in 1758.

Mark Catesby (1683-1749) was an English naturalist, influenced by his uncle's acquaintance with John Ray. Catesby journeyed to Virginia in 1712, where he stayed with a relative, and continued on to Carolina and the West Indies before returning to England in 1719, having amassed significant natural history collections. He returned to America in 1722 with assistance from the naturalist Hans Sloane, and once back in England began to publish The Natural History of Carolina, Florida, and the Bahama Islands (1729-1747). The work went through several editions and translations. Catesby also garnered attention as an ornothologist following an important paper on migrations given to the Royal Society in 1747. ODNB.

John Hope (1725–1786) was Regius Keeper of the Royal Botanic Garden in Edinburgh and professor of botany at the University of Edinburgh. Hope trained in medicine at Edinburgh and Glasgow and studied botany in Paris. He was a founding member of the Select Society alongside Adam Smith and David Hume, and of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. Hope was a proponent for the foundation of a natural history museum in Edinburgh, and with the support of Joseph Banks, was instrumental in establishing a new botanic garden away from the original, polluted site in the centre of the city. Hope was an important Scottish proponent of Linnaean systematic botany, training multiple apprentices (including James Robertson) to conduct surveys in the Highlands. While keen to document Scotland's native flora, Hope, like Linnaeus, also championed the introduction of exotic species to northern climes, seeing them as a potential source of commercial and environmental enrichment. Fredrik Albritton Jonsson, Enlightenment's Frontier: The Scottish Highlands and the Origins of Environmentalism (New Haven; London: Yale University Press, 2013); ODNB.

John Murray (1737-1793) [formerly McMurray] was born in Edinburgh and served in the navy during the Seven Years' War. In 1768 he purchased William Sandby's stock and bookshop on Fleet Street. Although he may have changed his name to further his career in the metropolitan booktrade, Murray maintained strong links with Edinburgh (sending his son and successor to school there) and with his fellow Scottish booksellers in London. He aligned himself with Edinburgh, rather than London booksellers during the literary property dispute of 1774, favouring the abolition of perpetual copyright, which allowed him to produce cheap editions of older works. He primarily copublished works of Scottish authorship with Edinburgh booksellers such as William Creech, John Bell and Charles Elliot, including John Millar's Essay on the Distinction of Ranks. By his death in 1793 Murray had built up a considerable fortune and book business; his son, also called John Murray (1778-1843), would go on to become one of the most important publishers of the early nineteenth century. ODNB; Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).

note.note: Moses Griffith (1747–1819) watercolour painter and engraver, born in Caernarvonshire. He was employed as member of the household by Thomas Pennant from 1769 and continued to receive patronage from the Pennant family even after the death of Thomas Pennant. He accompanied Pennant on his 1772 Scottish tour, his illustrations published in A tour in Scotland and voyage to the Hebrides in 1774, and was also the illustrator for his Welsh tours. Moses Griffith married Margaret Jones on 9 January 1781, and they had two children, Moses and Margaret. ODNB; and for blogs on Curious Travellers, see here; and here.

persName.note: Roger Mostyn (1734–96), 5th baronet, of Mostyn, Flintshire, and Gloddaeth, Caernarvonshire. He married Margaret, daughter of Revd Hugh Wynn, Bodysgallen and Berthddu, and his wife, Catherine. He was a vice-president of the Welsh Charity School in London, and his Welsh cultural interests are signalled by the fact that Evan Evans dedicated his Some Specimens of the Poetry of the Antient Welsh Bards (1764) to him. In December 1792 he became a member of the Loyalist Flintshire Association promoted by his brother-in-law, Thomas Pennant. Mostyn's relationship with Pennant is evinced in the latter's correspondence by Pennant's frequent use of franks in his name. DWB; Hist P.

John Campbell (c.1703-1777), son of Colin Campbell of Ardmaddy, worked at the Royal Bank of Scotland from 1727 and was cashier during the Jacobite occupation of Edinburgh in 1745. Campbell was called on by Charles Edward Stuart to withdraw gold from the bank's reserves to honour notes held by the prince. Campbell retreived the gold from Edinburgh Castle where it had been placed for safekeeping during the hostilities. In later years, Campbell was a patron of James Macpherson and supporter of the Gaelic language. He was painted in full Highland dress by William Mosman, (1759). (http://heritagearchives.rbs.com).

George Clerk-Maxwell [formerly George Clerk] (1715-1784) was a landowner, agriculturalist, king's remembrancer in the exchequer from 1761, commissioner of the customs in Scotland from 1763 and trustee for the improvement of fisheries and manufactures of Scotland. He was educated at Edinburgh and Leyden, and contributed an essay on shallow ploughing to the Edinburgh Philosophical Society. Clerk-Maxwell was also an able draughtsman and produced several views of Scottish scenery. He assumed his wife's name (Maxwell) and later succeeded his brother James as fourth baronet of Penicuick (or Pennycuik) in 1782. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.
William Jackson (c.1721-1804) Secretary to the General Post Office, Edinburgh. Obit., The Scots Magazine and Edinburgh Literary Miscellany, v.lxvii., (1805), p.486.

Archibald Menzies (d.1777) was appointed a Commissioner of Customs in Scotland in 1770. The Correspondence of Adam Smith, Ernest Campbell and Ian Simpson Ross, eds., (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1987, repr.2001).
Robert Oliphant of Rossie, appointed Deputy Postmaster-General for Scotland in 1771. T. B. Lang, An Historical Summary of the Post Office in Scotland (Edinburgh: 1856).

persName.addName: Mr Shairp of the R:Bank, Sharp,
persName.note: Thomas Shairp (d.1785), Secretary to the Royal Bank of Scotland, Edinburgh. The Gentleman's Magzine, vol. lv., 5:1 (1785), p.406.
Robert Ramsay of Blackcraig (d.1778) was appointed to the first Chair of Natural History at Edinburgh University in 1770.

Dr John Stuart of Killin and later Luss (1743-1821), Gaelic scholar and botanist. Stuart was the son of Dr James Stuart (1700-1789) minister of Killin and translator of the New Testament into Scottish Gaelic for the SSPCK (1767), and Elizabeth Drummond. He was educated at Edinburgh university, licenced as a minister in 1771, presented first to the parish of Arrochar (1773), then Weem, Perthshire (1776), and finally Luss (1777). Stuart accompanied Thomas Pennant on his 1772 Scottish Tour, and maintained a correspondence with him, supplying him with information about Scottish natural history, antiquities, and Gaelic: many of these letters are held in Warwick County Archives. Trained in Linnaean botany at Edinburgh University, he botanised with Dr John Walker as well as Edward Lightfoot, author of Flora Scotica (1777) who also accompanied Pennant. Stuart completed his father's Bible translations and published his own translation of the Old Testament in 1801. He was also responsible for editing and publishing the songs of the great Gaelic poet Duncan Ban Macintyre of Glenorchy, some of which had been earlier transcribed by Rev Donald MacNicol of Lismore. In 1792 Stuart married Susan Macintyre, daughter of Dr Joseph Macintyre, minister of Glenorchy: the couple had four children. Stuart established a botanical garden at the manse in Luss, contributed a description of the Parish of Luss to the First Statistical Account of Scotland, and was an important contributor to the network of Gaelic speaking ministers who constituted the 'Gaelic enlightenment'. He is buried in the graveyard of Luss Kirk. (See ODNB: article by George Stronach, rev. by Roderick Macleod.)
(fl.1772) Apparently an artist at one Dr Blacklock's in Edinburgh, he was rejected by Pennant as a replacement draughtsman for his 1772 tour of Scotland.
Author and draughtsman of a 'Description of the Blunt-Head Chachalot', Phil.Trans., 1770, 60, 321-324.

note.note: Benjamin White (c.1725–94), younger brother of Gilbert White, author of Natural History of Selborne (1789), to whom he introduced Pennant. He published eight of Pennant’s books before his retirement in 1792. ODNB.

persName.note: (fl.1772) A Newcastle carrier or courier employed on Pennant's behalf, apparently based in Edinburgh.
Mr Bell (fl.1772) is mentioned in a letter from Pennant as the intended recipient of a box sent via Manchester.

Sir Alexander Fraser of Philorth (d.1623), founder of the castle and royal burgh of Fraserburgh, favourite of James VI. He was the subject of up to two portraits by the Scottish painter George Jameson, one of which was seen by Pennant at Craigston Castle in 1769. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Sir Benjamin Heath Malkin (1797-1837), eldest surviving son of Benjamin Heath and Charlotte (née Williams) Malkin. He was a friend of the economist and politician Thomas Babington Macaulay (1800-1859), fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge, and supreme court judge in Calcutta. ODNB.

William Morris (1705–63) was the third son of Morris Prichard and his wife Marged Morris, and the younger brother of Lewis and Richard Morris. After spending ten years living and working in Liverpool, in 1737 he returned to his native Anglesey where he secured posts as deputy comptroller of the customs and comptroller of the coal duties at Holyhead. His lively correspondence with his brothers reveals his engagement in circles of natural historians and his particular interest in botany, as well as his endeavours to copy and create collections of Welsh manuscript poetry. ODNB; Dafydd Wyn Wiliam, Cofiant William Morris (1705–63) (Llangefni: Yr Awdur, 1995); Ffion Mair Jones, 'William Morris a Thomas Pennant: Cysylltiadau Cyffredin', THSC (2020), 23–48.
James Yorke (1730-1808), Bishop of St David’s and later Ely.

Anna Blackburne (bap. 1726, d.1793) was a botanist and natural history collector. Blackburne's father was the horticulturalist John Blackburne (bap. 1694, d. 1786), and she was heavily involved in the tending of his famous garden and hothouses at the family seat near Warrington. Blackburne corresponded with Linnaeus and was familiar with his classificatory system; her associates included Peter Simon Pallas, Johann Reinhold Forster and Thomas Pennant, who named species of plant and bird after her. ODNB.
John Blackburn[e], described by Pennant as a Liverpool Merchant in 1779. He may be the son of John Blackburne the horticulturist (bap. 1694, d. 1786), who became mayor of Liverpool. ODNB.

James Boswell (1740-1795) was a diarist and biographer of his friend Dr Samuel Johnson. Born in Edinburgh, Boswell was heir to the Auchinleck estate in Ayrshire. He rejected the legal career followed by his Calvinist father to pursue literature and society in London. Boswell accompanied Dr Johnson on his celebrated Scottish tour in August-November 1773, and the journal he kept was an important source for Johnson's Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland published in 1775. Boswell published his own Journey of a Tour to the Hebrides with Samuel Johnson, LL.D in 1785, after Johnson's death: prepare with assistance from Edward Malone, it was partly intended as a first step towards his monumental Life of Johnson (1791), but also represented an excercise in damage limitation, given the negative reaction to Johnson's book in Scotland. Boswell was no admirer of Pennant, given the latter's Whig principles and antipathy to Jacobitism, a cause dear to Boswell's heart.

John Campbell (bap.1696, d.1782), Lord Glenorchy (1725) and third earl of Breadalbane on succeeding his father (1752); elected MP of Saltash (1727 and 1734) in which role he was a supporter of Walpole's government. Keeper of the privy seal of Scotland (1765-6) and appointed vice-admiral of Scotland in 1776. ODNB

Thomas Ellis (1711–92) was curate at Holyhead from 1737 to 1759. His activities in the parish included the establishment of a circulating school sometime before February 1750. He also aided in the preparation of a new Welsh version of the Bible, published by the SPCK in 1746, and was vehemently opposed to the spread of Methodism, as evinced in his pamphlet ODNB'Byrr grynhôad o'r grefydd Gristianogol ynghyd a gair o gyngor ag addysg mewn perthynas i'r Schismaticiaid sy'n ymneillduo oddiwrth Eglwys Loegr' (2nd edn.; [?Dublin], 1747). Ellis was a keen gardener, and cultivated one garden in Holyhead alongside William Morris. He was appointed to the parish of Nutfield, Surrey, in 1759. DWB; Cofiant William Morris (1705–63) (Llangefni: Yr Awdur, 1995), pp. 25, 81, 131, 158–62.
Mr Ellis of Diserth, Denbighshire, has not been identified.

James Bruce of Kinnaird (1730-1794), later known for his travels in Africa, dropped out of his legal studies at Edinburgh University and moved to London where he married Adriana Allan, the daughter of a wine merchant. After Adriana died from consumption in Paris in 1754, Bruce embarked on a European tour, returning on the death of his father to the family estate of Kinnaird, the coal mines of which would provide him with income to pursue his interest in travel. Bruce served briefly as consul-general at Algiers, before visiting the Roman ruins at Algiers and Tunis with his artist Luigi Balugani. He subsequently made further travels in North Africa and Syria, before making for Abyssinia where he hoped to discover the source of the Nile. After several eventful years in Africa, Bruce returned to Europe in 1773, was feted at the royal courts of France and Italy, but was met with a more sceptical reception in Britain. Bruce'sTravels to Discover the Source of the Nile did not appear in print until 1790, but became an international bestseller. He died after falling down the stairs in 1794; many contemporaries and later travellers questioned the authenticity of his account of Abbysnia. ODNB.

David Steuart Erskine, eleventh earl of Buchan (1742–1829), was an antiquary and political reformer, and founded the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1780. Buchan was educated at the universities of St Andrews, Edinburgh and Glasgow, at the latter of which he also studied drawing, etching, and engraving under the Foulis brothers. Buchan subsequently produced drawings of antiquities on Iona which were published in the Transactions of the Antiquaries of Scotland (vol. 1, 1792). Buchan allied himself to reformist political causes domestically, and supported American independence; during the 1790s he joined the London Society of the Friends of the People. Buchan's political interests ran parallel to his antiquarian activities and patronage of Scottish writers, reflecting a brand of patriotism that saw in elements of Scotland's pre-1707 past and figures such as William Wallace, the symbols of an ancient constitutional liberty. ODNB

George Buchanan (1506-1582) was a scholar and politician born in Killearn, Stirlingshire. He studied at St Andrews and Paris, and was appointed tutor to a son of James V. Buchanan later returned to teach in France, where he wrote several plays. Returning from the continent in the 1560s, he was admitted into the privy council of Mary Stuart, but following her abdication and imprisonment he joined her opponents. Buchanan was subsequently tutor to James VI. In 1579 he published the political dialogue De jure regni, a defence of the principle that the subjects of the realm were entitled to depose bad monarchs. 1582 saw the publication of Rerum Scoticarum historia, a work that conformed to the constitutional politics of De jure regni, and chronicled the reigns of Scotland's mythical Fergusian kings. ODNB

John Woodward (1665/1668– 1728), born in Derbyshire, was a physician, antiquary and natural historian. A member of the Royal Society from 1693, he had a particular interest in fossils, which drew him into controversy with other leading natural historians such as Edward Lhuyd, John Ray and Martin Lister, all of whom opposed his theory about the connection between the survival of fossil specimens and the biblical flood, as expressed in his Essay toward a Natural History of the Earth (1695). He was equally engaged in collecting antiquarian materials and kept a museum, frequented by contemporaries from Britain and abroad. ODNB

Thomas Cadell (1742-1802), bookseller, was born in Bristol and entered the book trade as an apprentice and later partner to Andrew Millar. On Millar's death in 1768, Cadell assumed control of the business and entered into an enduring (though never legally formalised) partnership with the printer William Strahan. Cadell and Strahan purchased many of Millar's former copyrights to works by Scottish authors such as Adam Smith, and expanded their stock and selling and printing operations with new works such as Smith's Wealth of Nations, the poetry of Robert Burns, and Johnson's Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland. Like many London booksellers of Scottish ancestry or birth, Cadell and Strahan fostered strong links with the Edinburgh trade, and figures such as Charles Elliot, John Balfour and Alexander Kincaid. By his death Cadell was a wealthy man; his book business was taken over by his son, Thomas Cadell the younger, and run as Cadell and Davies from 1793. ODNB; Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).

note.note: Edward Lhuyd (1659/60?–1709), born in Shropshire, became a seminal figure natural history circles during the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries. Study at Jesus College, Oxford, from 1682, led to his involvement with a scientific group established by the keeper of the Ashmolean museum, Robert Plot; Lhuyd submitted papers to this group, the Oxford Philosophical Society, on a regular basis. His travels through Wales, northern Ireland, the Scottish highlands, Ireland and Brittany, were a gargantuan effort to gather information on about the 'Celtic' countries on a wide range of topics, ranging from language to antiquarian monuments and natural history. The results of these researches appeared in the form of his Glossography, the first volume of Archaeologia Britannica, giving some account additional to what has hitherto been publish'd, of the languages, histories, and customs of the original inhabitants of Great Britain: from collections and observations in travels through Wales, Cornwal, Bas-Bretagne, Ireland and Scotland (1707). ODNB; and for Lhuyd's correspondence, see here [accessed 15 June 2020].

persName.note: James Cook (1728-1779) was born in Yorkshire, the son of a day labourer, and became an apprentice in the North Sea coal trade. He joined the navy in 1755 and served during the Seven Years' War. Cook's reputation as a skilled surveyor and seaman saw him assigined to Newfoundland in the 1760s, and soon after his return was appointed by the Admiralty as commander of the Endeavour voyage to the South Pacific, to observed the transit of Venus. Joined by Joseph Banks, Cook's Pacific voyage took the endeavour to Tahiti, New Zealand and eastern Australia; their findings were scientifically and geographically important and marked a crucial moment in the spread of European colonialism in the South Pacific. Cook undertook two further Pacific voyages on the ship Resolution, reaching Hawaii and eventually the north-west coast of North America. In 1779, Cook was killed in a dispute with the Hawaiians, having returned to the island for repairs. ODNB.

note.note: Owen Holland (b. 1721) of Plas Isa, Conwy, was the son of Edward Holland and his wife Elizabeth. He matriculated at Jesus College, Oxford, in 1738, aged 17, and was included in the first list of members of the Cymmrodorion Society in 1755 as a corresponding member. R. T. Jenkins and Helen M. Ramage, The History of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion and of the Gwyneddigion and Cymreigyddion Societies (1751–1951) (London, 1951), p. 251; Ffion Mair Jones, 'William Morris a Thomas Pennant: Cysylltiadau Cyffredin', THSC (2020), 23–48.

persName.note: Charles Duncan (fl.1786–92), naval officer, explorer and fur-trader. Duncan sailed by the mouth of the Juan de Fuca Strait and made a map and sketch of the entrance, dated 15 August [1788], as part of a series of voyages in the merchant marine undertaken during 1786–8. His Sketch of the entrance of the Strait of Juan de Fuca was published by Alexander Dalrymple in 1788. Dictionary of Canadian biography at http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/duncan_charles_4E.html [accessed 18 September 2018].

note.note: Francis Stuart, 8th earl of Moray (1737-1810). He was a peer and enthusiastic improver, planting several million trees on his estates. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

persName.note: Adam Mansfeldt de Cardonnel [formerly Adam Cardonnel] (1746/7–1820), was an antiquary with a particular interest in numismatics, or the study of coins and medals. His father Mansfeldt de Cardonnel (1696/7–1780) was a commissioner of the customs in Scotland, suggesting the root of his connection with George Paton, a customs clerk and correspondent of Thomas Pennant. Adam trained and briefly practised as a surgeon but devoted most of his time to his antiquarian interests. He was a fellow and curator of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland. In 1786 he published the self-illustrated Numismata Scotiæ, or a series of the Scottish coinage, from the reign of William the Lion to the Union. His Picturesque antiquities of Scotland (1788-93) evinced his skill and interest in drawing Scottish scenery, and from Pennant's correspondence with Paton, it seems that some of Cardonnel's work had found its way into Pennant's hands as early as 1773. Cardonnel assisted his fellow antiquarian Francis Grose during the latter's tour of Scotland, and in 1789 he received letters on Grose's behalf from the poet Robert Burns. ODNB.

Owen Holland (b. 1721) of Plas Isa, Conwy, was the son of Edward Holland and his wife Elizabeth. He matriculated at Jesus College, Oxford, in 1738, aged 17, and was included in the first list of members of the Cymmrodorion Society in 1755 as a corresponding member. R. T. Jenkins and Helen M. Ramage, The History of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion and of the Gwyneddigion and Cymreigyddion Societies (1751–1951) (London, 1951), p. 251; Ffion Mair Jones, 'William Morris a Thomas Pennant: Cysylltiadau Cyffredin', THSC (2020), 23–48.

The Danish antiquarian and natural historian Erich Pontoppidan (1698–1764) was appointed bishop of Bergen in Norway in 1747 and his study of the natural history of Norway (1753–54) was published in an English translation in 1755. He corresponded and exchanged specimens of minerals and fossils with Thomas Pennant from 1755 until his death in 1764. R. Paul Evans, ‘The Life and Work of Thomas Pennant (1726–1798)’ (unpublished PhD thesis, University of Wales, Swansea, 1994), pp. 362–4; Erich Pontoppidan, The natural history of Norway: containing a particular and accurate account of the temperature of the air, the different soils, waters, vegetables, metals, minerals, stones, beasts, birds, and fishes; together with the dispositions, customs, and manner of living of the inhabitants (London: A. Linde, 1755).

Donald McNeill, 3rd Laird of Colonsay (c. 1662- before 1773 - reported dead by John Stuart in 1773). McNeill was the son of Malcolm McNiell, 2nd of Colonsay, and Barbara Campbell. He married Grizel MacNeil of Belfast in 1710. Their son Sir Archibald, 5th Laird (1773-1809) raised the Argyll Fencibles in 1798 and served in the Napoleonic Wars. His brother Alexander McNeill was laird of neighbouring Oronsay.

note.note: Macquarrie, Lachlan (MacQuary), c.1715-1818, 16th laird of Ulva, who played host to Boswell and Johnson 16-17th Oct 1773. 'Macquarry is proprietor both of Ulva and some adjacent islands, among which is Staffa, so lately raised to reknown by Mr Banks'. (Dr Johnson, Journey to the Western Islands, (ed. Ronald Black), p. 361. He informed the vistors that the ancient mercheta mulierium ('droit de seigneur') still pertained in a watered down form. His debts forced him to sell Ulva (which his family had owned since the 13th century) to Capt Dugald Campbell of Achnaba in 1777 for £9,080. In 1778, short of money, he enlisted in the army at the age of 63 and served in the American war, and returned to live in penury near Ulva to the ripe old age of 103. 'As a chieftain he failed his people, as a husband he failed his wives, and as a father he failed his children'. (Jo Curry, Mull, p. 96) His famous son Lachlan Macquarie (1762-1824) was 5th governor of New South Wales from 1810-1821.

persName.note:
Colonel William Roy (1726-1790) was born in Lanarkshire, the son of an estate factor. Following the Jacobite rebellion of 1745, Roy was employed by the Board of Ordinance as a surveyor and draughtsman to produce an accurate contemporary map of the Highlands of Scotland for military use. Commissioned in 1747 by George II at the request of William Augustus, duke of Cumberland, the king's son and the commander of the Hanoverian forces at Culloden, the Roy Military Survey was completed in 1755. Roy also turned his skills as a surveyor and draughtsman to antiquarian research, resulting in his posthumous
Military Antiquities of the Romans in North Britain
(1793). NLS.

persName.addName: Commissioners of Customs and Excise in Scotland
persName.note: The Universal Scots Almanack for 1772 lists the following individuals as the Commmissioners of the Customs in Scotland: Mansfeldt Cardonnel, Basil Cochrane, Will[iam] Nelthorpe, G[eorge] Clerk-Maxwell and Arch[ibald] Menzies. The Universal Scots Almanack (Edinburgh: 1772), p.116.

William Constable of Burton Constable (1721-1791) was a landowner and natural history collector, noted for commissioning Lancelot 'Capability' Brown to dramatically redesign the grounds of his ancestral home in the 1770s.
Elizabeth Cook (née Batts; 1740/41-1835), wife of Pacific explorer Captain James Cook. ODNB.

Charles Cordiner (1746?–1794), minister of St Andrew’s Chapel, Banff, and author of Antiquities and Scenery of the North of Scotland, in a Series of Letters to Thomas Pennant (1780) and Remarkable ruins and romantic prospects of north Britain, with ancient monuments and singular subjects of natural history (2 vols., 1788–95). The latter originally appeared in numbers, with Cordiner providing images, engraved by James Basire and others. Pennant considered the Antiquities and Scenery to be an extension of his own 1769 and 1772 Scottish tours. ODNB; Murdo MacDonald, ‘Towards Celtic Revival Art in Scotland: The Visual Background to Revival in the 18th and 19th Centuries’, in Paddy Lyons, Willy Maley and John Miller (eds.), Romantic Ireland: From Tone to Gonne: Fresh Perspectives on Nineteenth-Century Ireland (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2013), pp. 160–9, esp. p. 162.

The archaeologist and patron Ignazio Paternò-Castello, fifth prince of Biscari, of Catania, Sicily, corresponded with Thomas Pennant between 1754 and 1758 on matters relating to natural history. Parcels of mineral specimens were exchanged as part of this contact. Biscari, a freemason, was a figure of note as an archaeologist, both within Italy and further afield. Foreign academies sought relations with him, among them the Society of Antiquities in 1762. R. Paul Evans, ‘The Life and Work of Thomas Pennant (1726–1798)’ (unpublished PhD thesis, University of Wales, Swansea, 1994), pp. 241–3; and for further biographical details, see here [accessed 15 June 2020].

James 'the Admirable' Crichton (1560-1582) was a rhetorician and soldier born in Dumfriesshire. His father was Robert Crichton, Lord Advocate of Scotland and a supporter of Mary Stewart. James travelled extensively in Italy, where he achieved significant celebrity through his erudition and skill as a debater. Crichton was fatally stabbed during a dispute with a court rival in Mantua. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869). Thomas Pennant included an account of him 'some years ago printed at Aberdeen' in A tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd edn., 1774), pp. 313–28; see also ibid., plate XL.

Siôn Owen offered assistance to William Morris in his work as a collector of specimens, including fossils and coins. He was dubbed 'Siôn Dwyran' probably because he was an inhabitant of the village of Dwyran in the south west of Anglesey. Ffion Mair Jones (ed.), 'William Morris at Thomas Pennant, 14 Ionawr 1756', in 'Tlysau'r Hen Oesoedd', no. 40 (October 2016), 7 n. 3.

David Beaton (1494?-1546) was cardinal and archbishop of St Andrews and ambassador to France under James V. Beaton's repression of protestant preachers and scheming against Scotland's apostate neighbour, Henry VIII's England, probably contributed to his murder at the hands of a group of Fife noblemen in 1546. He fathered eight children with his mistress, Marion Ogilvy. Two of their daughters,Margaret and Agnes, would marry David Lindsay of Crawford and George Gordon of Gight respectively. ODNB
David Dalrymple (1726-1792) was a judge and historian, author of the Annals of Scotland (1776).

note.note: David Pennant (1763–1841), son of Thomas Pennant by his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer). Following study at Christ Church, Oxford (1781–4), David Pennant undertook three tours of the continent, in 1785–6, 1787–8 and 1791–2. His father's involvement in these tours is evinced in correspondence to David at Yverdon, Paris and Rome, and in the grateful recognition of David's assistance in Literary life. Travels in Britain were recorded in accounts of tours to the Lake District and from London to Chester in 1789 and 1792 respectively (NLW 2423B), and records of travel in Yorkshire and Derbyshire, c.1792–1800, Cheltenham and the Wye in 1792, and to Burley on the Hill [Rutland] in 1800 (WCRO CR 2017/TP73). David Pennant edited and published posthumously his father’s A journey from London to the Isle of Wight (1801); A tour from Downing to Alston-Moor (1801); and A tour from Alston-Moor to Harrowgate and Brimham Crags (1804). He also arranged the publication of four volumes of Pennant's 'Outlines of the Globe', the third and fourth of which he edited himself. David became JP for Flintshire in 1787, captain of the Loyal Holywell Volunteer Corps in 1797, and High Sheriff of Flintshire in 1799. On 12 December 1793 he married Louisa, second daughter of Sir Henry Peyton, settling at Rose Hill on the outskirts of Erbistock near Wrexham. ODNB; AO, III, p. 1093Literary life, pp. 42–3; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 68–71; idem, 'The Flintshire Loyalist Association'.

persName.note: Columba (c.521-597) was the founder of the monastic order on Iona, which became a centre of Christianity in early medieval Scotland. Columba was born of a royal lineage in Ireland, and maintained links between there and the community on Iona. ODNB
Mr Denman (fl.1784), a tenant of Thomas Pennant.

Michael Lort (1724/5-90), an antiquary and clergyman born in Pembrokeshire. A fellow of the Socety of Antiquaries and Royal Society, Lort corresponded with Horace Walpole, Bishop Percy and Richard Gough among others, and published pieces in Archaeologia and the Gentleman's Magazine, together with occasional sermons and polemics. He died on 5 November 1790 from injuries sustained after a fall from his carriage earlier that year. His collections were auctioned in May 1791. ODNB.

MacQueen, Donald, c.1715-1785. Rev Donald MacQueen was Presbyterian minister of Kilmuir in Skye, and according to the Fasti, 'probably the best known and most distinguished minister in the Highlands in his time'. We don't know which university he attended, but he was ordained in 1740, and his first wife was Betsy Martin, a neice of the celebrated Skye author Martin Martin. Although as a minister he sought to purge his parishioners of superstitious beliefs, Macqueen was a considerable authority on Gaelic history, folklore and antiquities, and in 1760 assisted James Macpherson to collect Ossianic fragments. Dohmnall Uilleam Stuibhart writes that while McQueen could certainly read Gaelic orthography, and owned old manuscripts, later donated to the Society of Antiquaries, he was 'one of the last educated generation to write Gaelic with English orthography...[causing] headaches for his Gaelic speaking correspondents'. MacQueen missed Pennant when he visited Kilmuir in 1772, but soon established an important correspondence with him, much of which survives in the Warwick County Archives and in the NLW. Above all he furnished him with an important 'Dissertatation on the Government of the People in the Western Isles', published as an appendix to Pennant's Tour in Scotland 1772, as well a information on local superstitions, notably second sight and the 'Gruagach' or brownie. In Sept 1773 he spent three weeks travelling around Skye with Johnson and Boswell, furnishing them with antiquarian information, and was the butt of Johnson's desire to prove the inauthentiticy of Ossian. (Macqueen refused to give the Doctor satisfaction on this matter.) Boswell described him as 'a decent minister, an elderly man with his own black hair, courteous and rather slow of speech, but candid, sensible, and well-informed, nay, learned'. Johnson is recorded by Boswell as saying 'this is a critical man, sir. there must be as great vigour of mind to make him cultivate learning so much in the Isle of Skye, where he might do without it. It is wonderful how many of the new publications he has'. [TH, p. 153] From 1777 to his death Macqueen corresponded with Rev John Stuart of Luss, commenting on his Gaelic translations of the Bible.

note.note: James Gray schooled the children of the poet Robert Burns. In the early 1810s he formed a literary coterie in Edinburgh which included the writer and shepherd, James Hogg, with whom he founded a debating society known as the Edinburgh Forum. See Gillian Hughes, James Hogg: A Life (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007), p.93.

persName.note: An unidentified Miss Hall (fl.1814) of Bury St Edmunds, the travelling companion of Charlotte Malkin on her 1814 tour of Scotland.

note.note: Samuel Johnson (1709–1784), was born at Lichfield, son of a bookseller, and educated at Pembroke College, Oxford. His most famous work was the English Dictionary of 1755. As essayist, critic, poet, dramatist, editor and lexicographer, he was the dominant figure (the 'Grand Cham') of mid 18th century English literature. In 1773 he made a 100 day tour of Scotland with James Boswell, and in 1775 published A Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland, which caused much offence in Scotland, and was unfavourably compared by reviewers to Pennant's Tours. Despite his hostility to Macpherson's Ossian and his frequently Scotophobic comment, Johnson was a sponsor for the SSPCK's Gaelic translation of the Bible. As a Tory in politics and a high Anglican in religion, he famously commented on Thomas Pennant: 'He's a Whig, Sir: a sad dog ... But he's the best traveler I ever read; he observes more things than anyone else does'.

persName.note: James Hogg (bap. 1770, d. 1835) author and shepherd, was born in Ettrick Forest, in the Scottish Borders. Hogg was greatly influenced by the region's oral tradition, and his career as a writer was catalysed in part by his patron Walter Scott's Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border. Hogg's early published works took the form of contributions to The Scots Magazine, where he developed the Ettrick Shepherd persona later caricatured in Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine. Having relocated to Edinburgh to pursue a career as a writer, Hogg's reputation as a poet was cemented by the success of his verse narrative The Queen's Wake. Hogg's involvement with the Tory Blackwood's set after 1817 saw the publication of numerous prose tales alongside a collection of Jacobite songs. A series of bold if not always well received novels followed in the 1820s, and Hogg's modern reputation has largely tended to rest on his 1824 masterpiece, The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Justified Sinner. Hogg continued to contribute to periodicals as well as holding the lease of more than one farm, although he was bankrupted in 1830. He died in 1835. Hughes, Gillian, James Hogg: A Life (Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2007).
Dr Blacklock of Edinburgh (fl. 1772).
Minister at Dundee who provided Pennant with information on his parish.

Reverend Dr Richard Burn (1709-1785) was a legal writer from Orton Westmorland. Alongside Joseph Nicholson of Hawksberry, Burn is acknowledged in Pennant's Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester 1774), iv, for providing information on Westmorland and Cumbria. Burn and Nicholson later collaborated as authors of The History and Antiquities of the Counties of Westmorland and Cumberland (London: 1777).

note.note: Johan Reinhold Forster (1729–98), a Lutheran pastor in the Polish part of Prussia, travelled to Russia in 1765, in the hope of fulfilling an ambition to work in a scientific field. He later moved to London, where he sought to engage with the British science community. From 1768 he worked as a tutor at the Warrington Academy, then accompanied Cook on his second voyage around the globe (between 1772 and 1775). He worked closely with Pennant, who supported his efforts to publish translations of travel writing including Peter Kalm's Travels into North America and Peter Osbeck's A Voyage to China and the East Indies (1771). In his translation work, Forster was aided by his son, Georg Adam Forster (1754–94), although this is not generally acknowledged. Forster's A Catalogue of the Animals of North America (1771) was the completion of work begun by Pennant. Pennant and Forster's relationship is documented in eighteen manuscript letters (September 1768 – March 1786), which include communications written during the latter's time abroad the 'Resolution'. ODNB; Evans, 'The life and works of Thomas Pennant', pp. 287–301.

Norman Macdonald (d.1823) held the tack of the island of Scalpay, Skye, from MacDonald of Sleat. His wife was a daughter the Jacobite heroine Flora Macdonald, and her husband Allan Macdonald of Kingsburgh. Several of their children held high posts in the military and colonial administration, including Sir John Macdonald, Adjutant-General of the British army. The Macdonalds hosted the traveller Sarah Murray of Kensington on Scalpay. Alexander Cameron, The History and Traditions of the Isle of Skye (Inverness: 1871), pp.155-56; New Statistical Account of Scotland (Edinburgh: 1845), vol. 14, p.307; ODNB.

persName.note: Dr James Lind (1736-1812) was a Scottish-born physician and astronomer who accompanied Joseph Banks to Iceland in 1772, having already visited China and contributed a paper on the transit of Venus to the Philosophical Transactions (1769). Lind was elected fellow the Royal Societies of Edinburgh and London and moved to Windsor where he became a physician to the royal household. Pennant acknowledges Lind's contribution of the latitude of Islay and a map of the island in a note to A Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774), p.261.

note.note: Matthew Macdonald (fl. 1814) was a son of John Macdonald, a tacksman on Scalpay. Along with his brother Charles, he acted as guide and travelling companion to Charlotte Malkin on her 1814 tour of Scotland. He later took the name Hume. Alexander Cameron, The History and Traditions of the Isle of Skye (Inverness: 1871), pp.155-56; New Statistical Account of Scotland (Edinburgh: 1845), vol. 14, p.307; ODNB.

persName.note: William Robertson (1721–1793) was a historian, Church of Scotland minister and, with David Hume, Adam Smith, Lord Kames, Hugh Blair and others, a member of the Select Society and Poker Club. His intellectual reputation was established by his 1759 The History of Scotland during the Reigns of Queen Mary and James VI. In 1762, Robertson was elected principal of Edinburgh University, and in 1763 moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland, cementing his place as a key figure in eighteenth-century Scottish civil society. His History of America was published in 1777. ODNB.

Charles Macdonald (fl. 1814) was a son of John Macdonald, a tacksman on Scalpay. Along with his brother Matthew, he acted as guide and travelling companion to Charlotte Malkin on her 1814 tour of Scotland. Unlike several of his brothers, there is little record of Charles after this time. Alexander Cameron, The History and Traditions of the Isle of Skye (Inverness: 1871), pp.155-56; New Statistical Account of Scotland (Edinburgh: 1845), vol. 14, p.307; ODNB.

Alexander Webster (1707–1784) was a Church of Scotland minister and demographer, awarded DD by Edinburgh University c.1760. Along with the Reverend Robert Wallace, he devised a scheme for the relief of the widows of Scottish clergymen, based on a precisely calculated rate of contribution. Webster was responsible for an important parish survey of Scotland's population in 1755. In a letter of 12 November 1773 to George Paton, Thomas Pennant writes: 'I beg my best compliments [to Webster] though unknown to him'. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.

John Campbell (1723-1806) became the fifth duke of Argyll on succeeding his father the fourth duke, also John Campbell, in 1770. He held the rank of field marshall in the army and was the first president of the Highland Society of Scotland. In 1759 he married Elizabeth, widow of the sixth duke of Hamilton.
John Murray (1729-1774) third duke of Atholl. Murray's father was attainted for his part in the Jacobite rebellion of 1745, but he was allowed to succeed his uncle as duke in 1764.

Alexander Gordon, fourth duke of Gordon (1743-1827) succeeded his father in 1752. He was made captain of the 89th Gordon Highlanders and later raised fencible infantry regiments during the American War of Independence and the French Revolutionary War. The ancestral home at Gordon Castle was rebuilt under his orders. ODNB.

note.note: Mrs Mackinnon (fl.1814), wife of Lachlan Mackinnon of Coirechatacan.

persName.note: James Duff (1729-1809), second earl of Fife after the revival of that title in the Irish peerage, was MP for Banff from 1754 and succeeded his father as earl in 1763. He considerably expanded the family property in north-east Scotland where he was a zealous agricultural improver and encourager of arts and commerce. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

persName.forename: David, earl of Leven and Melville
persName.note: David, sixth earl of Leven and fifth earl of Melville (1722-1802) was an army officer until succeeding his father in 1754. He was a lord of the police from 1773-1782 and high-commissioner to the the General Assembly 1783-1801. He married Wilhelmina daughter of William Nisbet of Dirleton in 1747. He was succeeded by his son, Alexander. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

note.note: Susannah Macdonald (d.1820), wife of Norman Macdonald, tacksman of Scalpay. Her grandmother was the Jacobite heroine Flora Macdonald. Alexander Cameron, The History and Traditions of the Isle of Skye (Inverness: 1871), pp.155-56

persName.note: Joseph Edmondson (bap. 1732, d. 1786), herald and coach-painter, who made his name among the nobility following the publication from 1764 of an updated version of theBaronagium genealogicum, a manuscript collection of the pedigrees of peers, initially in numbers. Further works included the notable two-volumeA Complete Body of Heraldry (1780). Edmondson died on 17 February 1786. His library, of which the British Library holds a printed catalogue, was sold in 1788. ODNB.
Miss Francis Macdonald (fl.1814), daughter of Norman Macdonald, tacksman on Scalpay, Skye, and his wife, Susannah.

Francis Douglas (c.1719-c.1790) was a writer, bookseller and farmer originally from Aberdeenshire. In the 1760s Douglas wrote in support of the controversial but highly popular 'Douglas Cause' of Archibald Douglas, who claimed inheritance of the lands of the Douglas dukedom, against the powerful duke of Hamilton to whom they had passed. He was apparently rewarded for his services with an extensive farm at Abbots-Inch near Paisley. Francis Douglas's works included The History of the Rebellion in 1745 and 1746, a Life of James Crichton of Clunie, Commonly Called the Admirable Crichton (1760) and A General Description of the East Coast of Scotland from Edinburgh to Cullen (1782). In a letter to the London Chronicle in 1778, he defended Thomas Pennant's account of the massacre of the Colquhouns against accusations of bias made by descendants of the MacGregors. ODNB.
Cecil Brownlow (1791-1868), Tory politician and second Marquess of Exeter.

Robert Foulis (1707-1776), Glasgow printer and bookseller with his brother, Andrew (1712-1775). The Foulis brothers established themselve as importers of continental editions of classical authors, serving Glasgow University. They later began to print their own volumes of classical texts, as well as contemporary works such as those of the philosopher Francis Hutcheson, and Robert was appointed to the post of University printer. As partners, the Foulis brothers also produced high quality editions of English authors such as Milton and Pope, and established an Academy of Fine Arts in Glasgow. ODNB.

note.note: Lachlan Mackinnon (fl. 1773-1814), a son of Lachlan Mackinnon, tacksman of Coirechatacan, who had hosted Pennant and Johnson and Boswell during their respective tours. According to the traveller Sarah Murray, in the 1803 version of her Companion he was 'born about two hours after Dr. Johnson entered his father's house, and I can bear witness the son has not degenerated from his father in the points of hospitality and attention to strangers.' A Companion and Useful Guide to the Beauties of Scotland (Hawick: Byways Books, 1982), p.191.

persName.note: Son of James Freebairn, teacher of French in Edinburgh. The younger Freebairn practised in Edinburgh. He undertook various jobs in Perthshire, including designing Innerpeffray Library in 1739. In 1756 he was elected a member of the Royal Company of Archers and in 1763 to the Canongate Kilwinning Masonic Lodge. In 1761 he was admitted a burgess of Edinburgh by right of his father when he was described as a wright by trade. In the early 1770s he was a 'tacksman' of the mines in Islay and was involved with the sale of their lease. He died probably in 1781 as a meeting of his creditors was called in January 1782 at which point he is described as 'the deceased Charles Freebairn, late architect in Edinburgh' (see here). Freebairn also has interests in mines in the Ochil Hills, in Loch Fyne, and was a projector of the Crinan Canal. He entertained Pennant on 1st-2nd July 1772, at his home of Freeport, near Port Askaig on Islay, and showed him round the lead mines, which he had managed since 1763, as tacksman of Daniel Campbell of Shawfield, proprietor of Islay. He was also visited by Joseph Banks and his party the following month, en route for Iceland on 5th August 1772. Banks described his house as 'situated in a very romantick spot under an almost overhanging clift close by the sea side here not above an English mile in breadth...Near his house is a very good air furnace at which he smelts the lead produced by his mines'. There is a painting of his house and mine by Banks's artists Cleveley and the Miller brothers in the King's Topographical Collection, British Library.

Born in Normandy, Louis Gold (1717–1785) served Pennant for over twenty years, accompanying him on travels, including the tour of Scotland in 1773. See LL, pp. 32–4; HPWaH, pp. 103–105. FRO, Thomas Pennant's extra-illustrated copy of HPWaH, includes a portrait of Gold, delineated by Moses Griffith.
Marjory Murray, née Cathcart (d.1842), second wife to the fourth Duke of Atholl.

John Golborne (1716-?) and his son James (1746-1819) were civil engineers from Cheshire involved in the deepening of the Clyde at Glasgow for navigation purposes between 1770-75. Pennant visited Golborne and his works during his 1772 tour.

note.note: The publications of the antiquary Richard Gough (1735–1809) included an edition of Camden’s Britannia (1789), which was achieved using a network of antiquarian friends and correspondents. His Sepulchral Monuments (2 vols. and later introduction, 1786, 1796, 1799), was intended to illustrate the ‘history of the Families, Manners, Habits and Arts from the Norman conquest’, and valued chiefly for its illustrations, engraved by James Basire. Director of the Society of Antiquaries (1771–97), fellow of the Royal Society (1775–95) and regular correspondent with the Gentleman's Magazine, Gough was enabled to commit himself unreservedly to his own antiquarian researches and to helping other antiquaries from a position of independent fortune, conferred upon him on the deaths of his parents in 1751 and 1774. ODNB.

persName.note: Francis Grose (bap. 1731, d. 1791) popularized the field of antiquarianism. Known as 'Captain Grose' following his promotion to captain in the Surrey regiment of the militia in 1765, Grose had shown an early interest in sketching. In 1772 he published the first number of The Antiquities of England and Wales, a work in an innovative format offering a series of engravings alongside descriptive text, the latter sometimes taken (with acknowledgement) from published books or from fellow antiquaries, at other times from material collected through correspondence. Tours in 1788, 1789 and 1790 lead to the publication of The Antiquities of Scotland, but Grose died in Dublin before he had made much progress on a companion study, The Antiquities of Ireland. ODNB.
Mr Butter (fl.1814), proprietor of Faskally estate in the parish of Moulin, Perthshire.
A secretary to Charles Edward Stuart who accompanied him in his escape after Culloden in 1746. Narrative of the Several Passages of the Young Chevalier, 4th edn. (London: 1765), p.5.
W Hixon (1735-1802) was a London copper plate printer, employed by Pennant, Bartolozzi and the Royal and Antiquarian Societies.
Mr Archibald Macdonald (fl. 1773), an associate of Reverend Donald MacQueen who may have been in London in 1773.
Possibly Beaumont Hotham (1737-1814), MP for Wigan on the interest of William Henry, third duke of Portland. (History of Parliament Online).

note.note: Henry Hughs (or Hughes) was a Fleet Street printer involved in the printing of the first edition of Pennant's two-volume A tour in Wales in 1778, 1781 and 1783, together with Supplemental plates to the tours in Wales in 1781 and an edition subtitled Supplemental corrections and additions to the first volume of the Welsh Tour in 1784. He was the printer of Arctic zoology (2 vols.; 1784, 1785); The view of Hindoostan (1798); and a second edition of Indian zoology ('for R. Faulder', [1790/1]). He may be the 'Hughes' named alongside 'West', from no. 40, Paternoster Row, as sellers of Pennant's posthumously-published A tour from Downing to Alston-Moor and A journey from London to the Isle of Wight (both in 1801). Pennant’s references to his base in Turnstile, Holborn, suggests a relation with John Hughs (d.?1771 /1774), printer to House of Commons, of the same address. In 1796 he gave his address as King's Road, Bedford Row. Jerry White, A Great and Monstrous Thing: London in the Eighteenth Century (London 2012), p. 263; Francis Cecil Doherty, A Study in Eighteenth-century Advertising Methods: The Anodyne Necklace, p. 390; Evans, ‘Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant’, 274; WCRO, CR 2017/TP260/1–3 [correspondence with Pennant, dated 22 December 1795, 31 March 1796, 21 April 1796].

persName.note: Mr Sheffield, who appears to have been a contact of John Jones at Oxford, has not been identified.
John Glynn, M.P. Franker of several of Pennant's letters to George Paton.

James Saunders (1718 -1778), Banff physician and author of ‘An Account of the Effects of Electricity in Different Diseases’ in the Medical Commentaries of Edinburgh, Vol. 3. cullenproject.ac.uk/people/596/
John Walsh (1726-95) fellow of the Royal Society and MP for Worcester; he franked Pennant's letters.

John Frazer (d.1702) was minister of Tiree and Coll from 1676, in which role he was styled Dean of the Isles. He was reputed by Pennant and others to have inherited from his father a volume of inscriptions copied from monuments around the Abbey and Nunnery of Iona that had been destroyed in the Reformation. The inscriptions were supposedly given to the earls of Argyll and subsequently lost. The source of this anecdote is likely William Sacheverell's Account of the Isle of Man with a Voyage to I-Columb-Kill (London: 1702). See also Pennant, Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774), p.285 and David Laing, On the Present State of the Ruins of Iona and their Preservation: In a Letter to the Honourable Lord Murray. Read to the Society of Antiquaries in Scotland 11th December 1854. (Edinburgh: 1854), p.12.
Clement V (c.1264-1314), Pope from 1305 to 1314.

Sir James Dalrymple, first baronet of Borthwick (1650-1719) was an antiquary and advocate. He was principal clerk of the court of session from 1693 and a baronet of Nova Scotia from 1698. Dalrymple's Collections Concerning the Scottish History (1705) refuted a politically charged claim that the Church of Scotland was once under the archdiocese of York, placing him in the company of contemporary patriotic Scottish scholars such as Robert Sibbald. Dalrymple's later Vindication of the Ecclesiastical Part of Sir James Dalrymple's Historical Collections (1714) addressed criticisms of his prior publication. ODNB.

Flora MacDonald (1722-1790) was the daughter of a tacksman on South Uist. Following the Jacobite defeat at Culloden in 1746, MacDonald accompanied Charles Edward Stuart, disguised as her maid, on his crossing to Skye from the Outer Hebrides, pursued by government forces. Following Charles Edward's escape to France, MacDonald was detained, questioned, and sent to London. She returned to Skye in 1747, where she later married Allan MacDonald of Kingsburgh, with whom she had seven children. The MacDonalds were visited by Johnson and Boswell in 1773, and a year later they emirated to America, where their loyalty to the government during the revolution led to Allan's imprisonment and their eventual return to Skye, where they remained for the rest of their lives. ODNB.
Mrs Macleod (fl.1814), a daughter of the Jacobite heroine Flora MacDonald.
An unidentified Dr Burt of Edinburgh, mentioned by Charlotte Malkin in her 1814 tour.

Alexander Runciman (1736–1785), artist and brother to John Runciman. Runciman was known as a landscape painter and for his decorative paintings in the Penicuik house of Sir James Clerk; the Episcopalian Chapel, and the Theatre Royal and Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh. He was a member of Henry Fuseli's circle in Rome in the 1760s, and exhibited works at the Royal Academy in London. ODNB.
John Scott of Gala.
An unidentified Mrs Burt of Edinburgh, mentioned by Charlotte Malkin in her 1814 tour.
Mr Elder of Ornsay, Sleat (fl.1814).

note.note: Lady Mary Campbell (née Gavin), wife of John Campbell, first Marquess of Breadalbane.

persName.note: Henry Home, Lord Kames (1696-1782), Scottish advocate, judge, and agricultural improver; his works included Elements of Criticism (1762), and Gentleman Farmer (1776).

Sir Patrick Murray of Ochtertyre (1771-1837) was the Member of Parliament for Edinburgh from 1806-1812, under the interest of his kinsman Henry Dundas, Lord Melville. He also held offices at the Exchequer. History of Parliament Online.

note.note: George Keith (1692/3-1778), Jacobite army officer and son of William Keith, ninth earl Marischal. He joined the earl of Mar's Jacobite uprising in 1715, for which he was forfeited and forced to flee to Spain via the Hebrides. He was later a canditate to lead the Jacobite army in1745, but ultimately took no part in the rising. He later served as a Prussian diplomat, and despite recovering the Keith estates around Dunnottar in 1764, left Scotland permanently soon after, dying in Potsdam in 1778. ODNB.

persName.note: Mr Drummond (fl.1814), tenant of the Dundas-owned property of Dunira according to Charlotte Malkin.

Jean Armour (1765-1834) was the wife of the poet Robert Burns, and subject of several his poems and songs. Their initial union was heavily disapproved of by Armour's father, and the couple were not legally married until 1788, several years after the birth of their first children. At Robert's death in 1796, Jean was left to care for six of his children, and her precarious financial situation was cited as the charitable motivation behind Dr James Currie's 1800 edition of the poet's works. Armour was frequently sought out by Romantic-period authors and tourists due to the fame of her deceased husband, with the Wordworths unsuccessfully attempting to meet her in their tour of 1803. ODNB.

Lawrence Dundas (1712-1781), became wealthy as an army commissary for the duke of Cumberland, first in Scotland after the defeat of the Jacobite rising in 1746, and then in Flanders. Dundas purchased the estate of Kerse in Stirlingshire and used his wealth to ensure his election as MP for Linlithgow in 1747. Complaints of electoral corruption from the duke of Argll and prime minister Henry Pelham led to Dundas losing his seat a year later. Dundas's business as a supplier to the army brought him further riches as a result of the Seven Years' War, allowing him to purchase more land in Scotland, England and Ireland, as well as a baronetcy and seat in Parliament. Dundas also purchased slave plantations in Dominca and Grenada. Dundas's vast wealth and property earned him the nickname 'the Nabob of the North.' At the same time, he built a political power base around his Edinburgh seat, allying himself to Lord North, though in the 1770s he faced a concerted challenge from a different branch of the Dundas family, led by Henry Dundas, lord advocate of Scotland and later Viscount Melville. Due to their possession of considerable lands in Orkney, Dundas and his son Thomas were approached on behalf of the naturalist George Low, who sought preferment as minister for the parishes of Birsay and Harray, a scheme discussed in Thomas Pennant's letters to George Paton. ODNB.

James Lautie (d.1791) was minister of Fordyce in Banffshire. He corresponded with Pennant and provided him with the drawing of an 'Urn found near Bamff' which appears in the in the third edition of the Tour in Scotland 1769 (Warrington: 1774), plate XXI, p.159.
A Mr William Aston of London (fl.1814), mentioned by Charlotte Malkin. Apparently an associate of Robert Owen.
A Mr Grahame of Glasgow (fl.1814), mentioned by Charlotte Malkin. Apparently an associated of Robert Owen.
Eleanor of Castile (1241-90), Spanish-born first wife of Edward I and queen consort of England between 1272 and 1290.
Skinner (1761-1832) was an American-born member of the British Navy, and from the 1790s onwards a master on packet ships crossing the Irish Sea between Holyhead and Dublin.

Thomas Parker, viscount Parker, then third earl of Macclesfield (1723–95), was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society, to whom he read a paper on an earthquake felt on 1 November 1755 at Shirburn. Alongside his father, George Parker, second Earl of Macclesfield, and grandfather Thomas Parker, first earl of Macclesfield, he built an impressive library at the family home of Shirburn, Oxfordshire, acquired by the latter in 1716. Parker represented the constituencies of Newcastle Under Lyme, Oxfordshire, and Rochester in parliament between 1747 and 1764. Hist P; Paul Quarrie, 'The Scientific Library of the Earls of Macclesfield', Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London, vol. 60, no. 1 (2006), 5–24.

note.note: John Lightfoot (1735–1788), Church of England clergyman and naturalist. One early preferment was to the living of Shalden, near Alton in Hampshire (1765–77), where he came to know Gilbert White of Selborne and, from 1767, he worked as chaplain for Margaret Cavendish-Bentick, dowager duchess of Portland. The duchess introduced him to naturalists and scientists including Joseph Banks, Solander and Pennant. He accompanied the latter on his 1772 tour of Scotland, a journey which led to the publication of his Flora Scotica (1777), at Pennant's expense. In 1773 he went on a botanical tour of Wales in the company of Banks, and in the August and September of the following year he toured Devon and Cornwall to learn about the flora of that area. He died on 21 February 1788, after falling ill the previous day whilst shopping at his hometown of Uxbridge. ODNB.

persName.note:
The Swedish naturalist and taxonomist Carl Linnaeus (1707–1778) studied medicine at the universities of Lund and Uppsala, and the Dutch university of Harderwijk, before moving to Leiden, where he made the acquaintance of the doctor and botanist Johan Gronovius. His first publication,
Systema naturae
, appeared in 1735, and the following year Linnaeus travelled to England, where his binomial nomenclature and sexual system for classifying plants was accepted by eminent physicians and horticulturists, including Sir Hans Sloane and Philip Miller, although only hesitantly and reluctantly so. In spite of this initial coolness Linnaeus maintained contact with over forty British correspondents once his reputation had been firmly established. By 1738 he had returned to Sweden and in 1741 he took up the medical professorship at Uppsala University. His Species plantarum (1753) and Systema naturae (in its tenth edition by 1758) are considered the starting point of modern botanical and zoological nomenclature. Twenty-three letters from Pennant to Linnaeus are held at The Linnean Society of London. ODNB.
Thomas Major (1720–1799), engraver. In 1752 he moved to Chandos Street, off lower St Martin’s lane. ODNB.
Engraver.

note.note: Peter Mazell was the son of French Huguenots parents living in Dublin, and worked as a painter and engraver from various London addresses during c. 1761–97, including at Portland Street (1783) and Covent Garden (1791). An exhibitor of paintings of landscapes and flowers, his engravings of natural history subjects was a notable part of the productions of authors including John Walcott, Thomas Pennant and Pennant's protégé Charles Cordiner.

persName.note: Engraver.

John Jeffreys of London matriculated at Christ Church college, Oxford, in 1737, aged 18, and by 1769 had qualified as a bachelor and a doctor of divinity. His posts included those of rector of St Nicholas Cole Abbey with St Nicholas Olave (1745–92), chaplain to the Princess of Wales (during 1751), and vicar of Great Berkhampstead (1756–98). He held the latter post alongside that of rector of Whitford, Flintshire, from 1761. He died on 20 November 1798. AO, II, p. 746; Clergy of the Church of England Database, here [accessed 10 July 2020]. For accounts kept by Jeffreys during 1757–98, see Hertfordshire Archives and Local Studies, DP19/3/3.
Thomas Longman (1730–1797) represented the second generation of the London publishing dynasty established by his uncle, which he further consolidated and expanded. ODNB.

John Stuart, third earl of Bute (1713–92), was son of James, second earl of Bute, and Lady Anne Campbell, daughter of Archibald, first duke of Argyll. He was educated at Eton and the University of Leiden, and became adviser and tutor to the future George III. Bute's influence over the latter, following his accession, together with his rise to the office of prime minister during 1762–3, earned him the distrust of much of the press and public. He was a patron of several writers including Tobias Smollet and Samuel Johnson, and of the anatomist William Hunter. He was also a keen botanist and patron of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew. ODNB.

Ann Brydges (née Wells, former married name Jeffries; d. 1759), formerly a chamber maid in Newbury, Berkshire, became the second wife of Henry Brydges, second duke of Chandos (1708–81), in 1744. According to a report in the Gentleman's Magazine in 1832, the duke saw her being ill-treated by her ostler husband, and 'bought her for half a crown', going on to educate her and then to marry her after her husband's death. Hist P; Notes & Queries, 4th Series, vol. 6 (1870), 179, here [accessed 15 July 2020].
A Mr Sidebotham of the Antelope inn in Holywell, Flintshire, has not been identified.

Born at Nantwich, Cheshire, John Gerard was apprenticed to a surgeon of the Barber-Surgeons' Company in London in 1562, and may have travelled as far as Scandinavia and Russia before his appointment as curator of a physic garden established by the College of Physicians in 1586. His involvement with the Barber-Surgeons' Company was furthered with his election to their court of assistants in 1595, although no real progress was made in response to his suggestion that they should keep a garden for studying medicinal plants. His most important publication was The Herball, or, Generall Historie of Plants Gathered by John Gerarde of London, which appeared in 1597, dedicated to Lord Burghley. It included more than 1800 woodcuts, although the vast majority were reproduced from the work of Bergzabern, Eicones plantarum, procured from Nicolas Bassaeus of Frankfurt by Gerard's publisher, John Norton, the queen's printer. A new edition by Thomas Johnson appeared in 1633, reprinted in 1636, in which illustrations were taken from the stock of the Antwerp printer Plantin. ODNB.

Born in 1566/7, John Parkinson joined the Society of Apothecaries upon its instigation in 1617 and was instrumental in its efforts to regularize the profession by helping to create a schedule of the medicines apothecaries should keep for their use. His love of his garden at Long Acre provided the inspiration for 'Paradisi in sole paradisus terrestris, or, A Garden of All Sorts of Pleasant Flowers ... with a Kitchen Garden ... and an Orchard', published in 1629 and containing descriptions of almost a thousand plants. A contemporary claimed that Parkinson's second publication, 'Theatrum botanicum' (1640), plagarized the work of Matthias L'Obel, but it was praised by John Ray, who made good use of it in his own work. Born in 1566/7, John Parkinson joined the Society of Apothecaries upon its instigation in 1617 and was instrumental in its efforts to regularize the profession by helping to create a schedule of the medicines apothecaries should keep for their use. His love of his garden at Long Acre provided the inspiration for Paradisi in sole paradisus terrestris, or, A Garden of All Sorts of Pleasant Flowers ... with a Kitchen Garden ... and an Orchard', published in 1629 and containing descriptions of almost a thousand plants. A contemporary claimed that Parkinson's second publication, Theatrum botanicum (1640), plagarized the work of Matthias L'Obel, but it was praised by John Ray, who made good use of it in his own work.
Philip IV (1268-1314), King of France from 1285 until his death.

note.note: Thomas Wynn, 1st Baron Newborough (1736-1807), landowner, and MP for (variously) Caernarfon, St Ives and Beaumaris between 1761 and 1807.

persName.note: Simon Fraser, twelfth Lord Lovat (1667–1747) was a Jacobite landowner, executed for his support of the Pretender in the rising of 1745. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Kenneth Mackenzie (1744-1781) purchased his grandfather William's estates from the crown, those having been forfeited in the rebellion of 1715. He was created Baron Ardelve and Viscount Fortrose in 1766 and earl of Seaforth in 1771. He raised a regiment, the 78th or Lord Seaforth's Highlanders, and died in 1781 while accompanying them to the East Indies as colonel. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

George Low (1747-1795) was a Church of Scotland minister and naturalist, educated at Marischal College Aberdeen and the University of St Andrews. In the late 1760s he became tutor to a merchant family in Stromness, Orkney, and later the minister of Cairston; he became an ardent observer of the archipelago's natural history and antiquities. Low became the local guide to Joseph Banks and his party when they visited Orkney on the return leg of their voyage to Iceland, and it is likely that this meeting catalysed his introduction to an increasingly fashionable culture of northern antiquarianism and natural inquiry in which Thomas Pennant, Richard Gough and others were fellow participants. Pennant patronised Low's tour of Orkney and Shetland in 1774, intending for him to write and publish on a region which Pennant had not reached in either of his two tours of Scotland. Shortly after, Low became minister of Birsay and Harray through the patronage of Sir Laurence Dundas. Low married in 1775, but his wife Helen (née Tyrie) died the following year. Low continued to work on an expansive body of work relating to Orkney and Shetland, comprising a History, Fauna, and Flora of the islands, alongside his tour, undertaking further travels to complete his research. Pennant had been unable to secure a publisher for Low's tour though much of his writing was shared with Pennant and Gough, who made liberal use of it in their Arctic Zoology (1784-87) and British Topography (1780) respectively. Low's health declined in the 1780s,and he died in 1795, having contributed a description of Birsay to Sinclair's Statistical Account (1791-99). The manuscripts of Low's 'Tours', 'Flora Orcadensis', and 'History of Orkney', are now held variously at Edinburgh University Library, the National Museums of Scotland, and the National Library of Scotland, with further descriptions comprising parts of collections of Pennant's correspondence. ODNB.
John Macgowan (d.1805) was an Edinburgh antiquary and subject of a John Kay caricature. He was employed as an Assistant Solicitor to the Customs Office of Scotland.

MacIntyre was ordained as minister of Glenorchy Parish, in Dalmally, in 1766 and retired in 1824: he is commemorated by a plaque in the west wall of the new kirk, built in 1810 during his long incumbency. He married Christian MacVean (1747-1797), daughter of the previous incumbent, John MacVean. Pennant visited Dalmally in 1769 and described MacIntyre's manse as 'neat, and his little demesne is decorated in the most advantageous places with seats of turf, indicatig the content and satisfaction of the possessor of the lot Providence has given him': MacIntyre is thanked by name in the advertisement to Tour in Scotland in 1769, 3rd ed. Pennant describes the medieval gravestones in the churchyard. MacIntyre contributed an account of the Parish to the first Statistical Account, and began keeping parish records. Pennant's travelling companion in 1772, John Stuart of Killin, may have been recommended to him by Macintyre. Stuart married Macintyre's daughter Susan, and his own sister was married to Rev James Maclagan of Blair Atholl, exemplifying the strong family links connecting 18th century Highland ministers.

Murdoch Mackenizie senior (1712-1797) was a cartographer and hydrographical surveyor born in Orkney.
