His Orcades, or, A Geographical and Hydrographical Survey of the Orkney and Lewis Islands was published in 1750 under the patronage of the earl of Morton and with subscriptions from the East India Company, and earned him an Admiralty commission to survey the west coast of Scotland. This work produced A Maritim Survey of Ireland and the West of Great Britain, A Nautical Description of the West Coast of Great Britain and Nautical Descriptions of the Coasts of Ireland (1776). Mackenzie was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1774. ODNB.
John Maclean (d. c. 1774), minister of the parish of Kintail.

William Maitland (c.1693–1757), historian and topographer, born in Brechin. He travelled widely in Europe due to his first profession as a hair merchant, before arriving in London where he began work on his History of London, from its Foundation by the Romans to the Present Time, published in 1739. He resigned from the London Society of Antiquaries and returned to Scotland to continue his projects, which included a failed attempt to gather topographical descriptions of Scottish parishes by writing to ministers, anticipating the methods of Thomas Pennant and John Sinclair. He published a
History of Edinburgh, from its Foundation to the Present Time
in 1753, and his two-volume
History and Antiquities of Scotland
, based partly on his own travels through the country, appeared posthumously in 1757. ODNB.

note.note: George Clifford (1685– 1760) was an Anglo-Dutch merchant and a director of the Dutch East India Company. Between 1735 and 1737, his garden at Hartekamp in the north of Holland was visited by Carl Linnaeus, who used his observations to draw up the first scholarly classification of an English garden. Illustrated by Georg Dionysius Ehret, it was published under the title Hortus Cliffortianus in 1737. Clifford's herbarium, containing over 3,000 specimens collected by him, is now housed at the Natural History Museum in London. See here and here [accessed 17 July 2020].

persName.note: The topographer and county historian Charles Smith (c. 1715–1762), born in county Waterford, Ireland, was, alongside Walter Harris (1686–1761), the author of The Antient and Present State of County Down (1744), a publication which he envisaged would lead the way to producing further histories of Irish counties. The founding of the Physio-Historical Society during the same year was a means to this end, and led to the publication of Smith's The Antient and Present State of County Waterford and The Antient and Present State of the County and City of Cork in 1746 and 1750 respectively. Smith's corresponding publication on county Kerry appeared in 1756, after he had resigned from the Physio-Historical Society, and in the year in which he and others founded the Medico-Philosophical Society in Dublin. ODNB; Rachael Scally, 'The Correspondence of the Dublin Medico-Philosophical Society, here [accessed 23 July 2020].

The first child of Thomas Pennant and his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer), named after his father, was born on 7 January 1760, but died on 24 March the same year. Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 39, 109 n. 109.
1743-90, ornithologist, elected FRS 1771, author of Ornithologia Britannica, known associate of Pennant (DNB)

William Henry Kerr (c.1712-1775), fourth marquess of Lothian (also variously titled Lord Jedburgh and earl of Ancrum) was an army officer and aide-de-camp to William, duke of Cumberland, in whose service he was wounded at Fontenoy. He was a cavalry commander at the battle of Culloden and his forces ran down and killed a significant number of retreating Highlanders. He was MP for Richmond. ODNB.

note.note: Brochfael Ysgithrog was king of Powys during the sixth century. Although sources relating to Powys in this period are difficult to reconcile, historians suggest that he was the son of Tudglyd, daughter of Brychan, and husband of Arddun, daughter of Pabo Post Prydain. He is also considered to have been the father of St Tysilio of Meifod. He may have been named in the inscription on the ninth-century Pillar of Eliseg near Valle Crucis abbey in Denbighshire. ODNB.

persName.note: Thomas Marshall of Perth (fl.1773), correspondent of Thomas Pennant.

Samuel Salter (bap. 1713, d. 1778), was a Church of England clergyman, son of the archdeacon of Norfolk, and tutor and later chaplain to Philip Yorke, earl Hardwicke. Through Yorke's patronage Salter held a clutch of church appointments, in addition to his role as preacher and later master of Charterhouse School. He appears to have franked at least one of Thomas Pennant's letters. ODNB.
Mr Middleton of Liverpool (fl.1772), business associate or carrier of Thomas Pennant.
Griffri son of Cyngen was killed by his brother Elise, king of Powys, in 814, in an effort by the latter to tighten his hold on the kingdom of Powys. Maund, The Welsh Kings, p. 38.

Elise ap Cyngen, king of Powys, was the dedicatee of the Pillar of Elise (or Eliseg), erected by his grandson, also named Cyngen (d. 855). The inscription on the Pillar suggested that Elise drove the English out of his Powys kingdom. The date of this triumph is uncertain, and may predate the invasions of the 820s. Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 18, 34, 38.

John Monk (1741-1799) was a bookseller and printer in Chester. Among his publications were the first editions of Pennant's Tour in Scotland 1769 (1771) and Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (1774).

James Graham, third duke of Montrose (1755-1836), was MP for Richmond, Yorkshire and Chancellor of the University of Glasgow from 1780, and MP for Great Bedwyn, Wiltshire from 1784. As a politician he was generally active in causes relating to Scottish issues: he raised an unsuccessful motion for the establishment of a Scottish militia and supported the repeal of the act banning Highland dress; he opposed the East India Bill and in the late 1770s was a critic of the government's handling of the American War of Independence. ODNB

Cadell ap Brochfael (d. 808) succeeded his father Brochfael ap Elisedd as ruler of Powys in c. 773. His death is mentioned in the Annales Cambriae (although this source does not name him as a son of Brochfael) and on the Pillar of Elise (Eliseg), where it is given in the form 'Cattell'. Maund The Welsh Kings, p. 34; Gwilym Peredur Jones, 'Notes on the political history of early Powys', Archaeologia Cambrensis, vol. LXXV, part I (1930), 131–43, esp. 133, 137; Wikipedia, here [accessed 24 September 2020].
Nest daughter of Cadell, king of Powys, was the wife of Merfyn Frych and mother of Rhodri Fawr. ODNB s.n. Rhodri Mawr (b. before 844, d. 878).

note.note: Peter Burrell III, first Baron Gwydir (1754–1820) of Langley Park, Beckenham, Kent, was the only son of Peter Burrell II. He was knighted 6 July 1781, succeeded his uncle Sir Merrick Burrell as second Baronet on 6 April 1787, and was created Baron Gwydir on 16 June 1796. He was known to Horace Walpole and Anthony Morris Storer as a fortunate and wealthy man. Hist P; ODNB s.n. White Conduit cricket club (act. c.1785–1788).

persName.note: Cyngen (d. 856), king of Powys, is credited with having erected the monument known as the Pillar of Elise (or Eliseg) in the mid-ninth century. He died in exile in Rome. The marriage of his daughter Nest to Merfyn Frych (d. 844) of the house of Gwynedd did not herald peace between the two competing dynasties. ODNB s.n. Merfyn Frych (d. 844); Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 18, 34, 40, 41.
A Mr Thomas appears to have worked alongside John Price at the Bodleian Library. He is portrayed in Pennant and Price's correspondence as unreliable, probably due to a tendency to drink heavily.

John Balfour (1715–1795), Edinburgh bookseller and printer, entered into a partnership with Gavin Hamilton in 1737, having begun work as his shop clerk in 1733. The Hamilton-Balfour firm was among eighteenth-century Edinburgh's most commercially and intellectually ambitious, publishing Hume's History of England (1754), the first Edinburgh Review (1755-56) , and Macpherson's Ossianic Fragments of Ancient Poetry. After Hamilton's death in 1767, Balfour continued as one of Edinburgh's leading publishers into the 1780s, entering partnerships with William Smellie and the printer William Auld. ODNB; Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).

Robert Barclay of Urie (1732-1797), known as Barclay-Allardice after his marriage to the heiress Sarah-Anne Allardice in 1777, was an agricultural improver and landowner responsible for the building of a modern village adjacent to Stonehaven. He was returned as MP for Kincardineshire in 1788. Pennant visited Barclay on the second leg of his 1772 tour of Scotland. History of Parliament Online; William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
A Dr Wynn is mentioned by Thomas Pennant in a 1775 letter to John Price. He appears to have been based at Oxford.
A Mr Pugh of Yale is mentioned by John Price in a 1776 letter as a possible informant for Pennant's work on Llangollen for A tour in Wales 1770 [1773].

John Bell of Antermony, Stirlingshire (1691-1780), was a diplomat and traveller in Russia and Asia. He was sent to Esfahan on behalf of Tsar Peter I in 1715 and later to Beijing. After another misson to Persia in 1722 he returned to Scotland, but came back St Petersburg in 1734. Subsequent diplomatic missions took him to Constantinople, where he settled for some time, before marrying the Russian Mary Peters in 1746 and returning to his family estate at Antermony. There he wrote his Travels from St Petersburg in Russia to Various Parts of Asia, published by the Foulis brothers of Glasgow in 1763.

James Bisset (fl. 1775), minister of Caputh, Perthshire. He provided Pennant with an account of traditions and discoveries relating to the Romans in his parish. See
A tour in Scotland 1772, part II
(1776), p.70.

Servant to Alexander Macleod, an Aide-de-camp who assisted Charles Edward Stuart in his escape after Culloden in 1746. Narrative of the Several Passages of the Young Chevalier, 4th edn. (London: 1765), p.5.

John Callander of Craigforth (c.1721-1789) was an an advocate and later fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland. He published a small selection of works related to literary and antiquarian commentary and projected major pieces on Scottish language and music, which were never fulfilled. ODNB.
An unidentified Mr Campbell (fl.1774) appearing in letter from Thomas Pennant to George Paton, 23 January 1774.

Henry Fiennes Pelham-Clinton (1720–94) was the second son of Henry Clinton, seventh earl of Lincoln; he inherited this title after his elder brother's death in 1730, becoming the ninth earl of Lincoln. In November 1768 he succeeded his maternal uncle Thomas Pelham-Holles to the title of second duke of Newcastle under Lyme. Although active in opposition to the Pitt-Newcastle coalition in 1757, Pelham-Clinton favoured country life to involvement in politics, and took pleasure from the estates which he had inherited from his uncle in Nottinghamshire. ODNB.

Alexander Donaldson (1727-1794) was an Edinburgh printer and bookseller. After ending his partnership with Alexander Kincaid in 1758, Donaldson opened his own bookshop and a separate print shop in Edinburgh, where he focused on producing cheap reprints of older English authors such as Milton and Pope. With his brother John, Donaldson opened a shop in London as an outlet through which he sought to undercut local monopoly with his low-cost product. This earned Donaldson the ire of the London booksellers, and led to a decisive legal case in 1774, in which the House of Lords ruled in Donaldson's favour and against the principle of perpetual copyright. Reflecting his continued links with the Scottish print world, Donaldson founded the Edinburgh Advertiser newspaper in 1764. Donaldson retired to Broughton Hall near Edinburgh, where he died in 1794, leaving a considerable fortune to his son James. ODNB; Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).

George Scott c.1721–80) was a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries. A letter addressed to him was read before the society on 28 March 1776 and published in the Philosophical Transactions under the title 'An extraordinary cure of wounded intestines'. See here [accessed 28 September 2020].

Charles Elliot (1748-1790) was an Edinburgh bookseller, unusual among his peers for purchasing expensive literary properties in multi-volume medical and scientific works by Scottish authors, including books by William Cullen and William Smellie's Philosophy of Natural History. Elliot operated from a shop in Parliament Square and in 1787 opened a premises in the Strand in London, from which he primarily sold Scottish medical works. Elliot was savvy in forming alliances with other booksellers in London and Newcastle, as well as becoming involved in businesses in Dublin and Philadelphia. Pennant's correspondence with George Paton documents Elliot's efforts to position himself as Pennant's primary bookseller in Scotland, though the letters also suggest that the returns from this venture were commercially dissapointing. Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006).
author of A collection of voyages and travels, some now first printed from original manuscripts, others now first published in English. In Six Volumes.
(c.1670-1749), Jacobite army officer and poet; died at Rannoch; some works printed in The History and Martial Atchievements of the Robertsons of Strowan (1785)
Unidentified Mull Clergyman (fl. 1773); acquaintance mentioned by John Stuart.

Robert Gordon (1580-1661) was educated in Aberdeen and Paris. He is best known as a map-maker who collaborated with Joan Blaeu and Timothy Pont, contributing significantly to the former's 1654 Atlas of Scotland. There is much evidence however that Gordon's cartographic ambitions extended beyond his work with Pont and Blaeu. The National Library of Scotland holds 65 unpublished manuscript maps by Gordon, which Jeffrey C. Stone suggests are unrelated to his involvement with Blaeu, and indicate a separate design of unknown origins and aims. maps.nls.uk/atlas/blaeu/biogs/straloch.html
Physician employed by the Duke of Hamilton c.1772; his duties apparently included trips to Arran to tend to Hamilton's tenants on the island.
Mr Ker (fl.1794); possibly an Edinburgh Bookseller.
Mr Kincaid (fl.1773), described as a relative to William Henry Kerr, fourth marquess of Lothian.
Unidentified Mr Lindsay of Orkney (fl.1775).

Born in Cornwall, the antiquary John Anstis (16 69–17 44) qualified as a lawyer and periodically acted as member of parliament for various Cornish seats between 1702 and 1722. From 1718 until his death he held the office of Garter king of arms, a position which enabled his pursuit of antiquarian interests and an involvement in the creation of a new order of chivalry based on historical precedents, outlined in a Observations Introductory to an Historical Essay on the Knighthood of the Bath (1725). Anstis corresponded extensively with other antiquarians, including Thomas Hearne and Humfrey Wanley, and left papers now held at the British Library, the Bodleian Library and All Souls College, Oxford. ODNB; Hist P.
McNiel, Alexander: (fl. 1772) Tenant of Oransay, brother to another Mr McNiel, proprietor of Colonsay, who was dead by 1773. Brother to 0052 Donald McNeill, 3rd Laird of Colonsay.

note.note:
John Mackenzie (d.1778) of Delvine in Perthshire. Pennant visited Mackenzie during the second leg of his 1772 tour of Scotland and later corresponded with him concerning the remains of a Roman camp at Inchtuthil. Mackenzie was Principal Clerk of Session and a Writer to the Signet. Ronald Black notes that in 1751, Mackenzie purchased large swathes of land on Skye as a trustee of Sir James Macdonald of Sleat (To the Hebrides p.499). Mackenzie's father was an antiquary who had corresponded with Alexander Gordon, author of Itinerarium Septentrionale
(1726).

persName.note: Henry Somerset, fifth duke of Beaufort (1744–1803), son of Charles Noel Somerset, succeeded to his father's title in October 1756. A graduated of Oxford University, where he gained the degree of D.C.L. in 1763, he was Grand Master of the Freemasons from 1767 to 1772. Further offices included that of Lord-lieutenant of Monmouthshire (from 1771) and of Brecknockshire (from 1787), both held until his death. See here [accessed 30 September 2020]; and for the dukes of Beaufort's Badminton home, see here [accessed 30 September 2020].
Comptroller of Customs, Port Glasgow, 1772. The Universal Scots Almanack (Edinburgh: 1772), p.117.
Mr Oswald of Kirkcaldy (fl.1776).

Son of Robert Penny of Castle Cary, Somerset, Robert Penny (d. 1809), matriculated at Oriel College, Oxford, in 1755, graduating BA, MA and DD in 1755, 1757 and 1774 respectively. He was ordinated deacon in 1758 and priest in 1760. He was vicar of Evercreech with the Chapel of Chesterblade, Somerset, from 1765, and rector of Woolastone with Alvington and Lancaute, Gloucestershire (1769), before being appointed rector of Wollaston (1769) and Cromhall (1774), also both in Gloucestershire, and various Welsh livings including Troy St Michael with Cwmcarvan from 1782, Crickhowell from 1794 and Llan Fihangel Cwmdu from 1796. His connection with the Somerset family of Badminton is indicated by his appointment as domestic chaplain to Henry Charles Somerset, sixth duke of Beaufort and marquess of Worcester (1766–1835). AO, III, p. 1095, notes that he was vicar of Badminton, too (dates not provided). He was included on the list of workers to whom wages were paid by the Badminton Estate from 1772 (as Revd Mr Penny). His will was proved on 6 September 1809. See here Badminton Estate Accounts and financial papers: D2700/QB3/3/19 here; and Will of Reverend Robert Penny, Doctor in Divinity of Badminton, Gloucestershire: PROB 11/1503/58, here [accessed 15 October 2020].
neighbour

Born in Aberdeen, David Skene (1731-1770) trained in London, Edinburgh and Paris before returning to his alma mater at Marischal College where he taught and practised medicine. Like Pennant, he was a keen naturalist, and Carl Linnaeus is said to have thought him ‘the brightest star of enquiry in North Britain’. Skene’s acquaintance with Pennant seems to have commenced when Pennant paid a visit to the former’s cabinet of natural history specimens while passing through Aberdeen during his 1769 tour of Scotland, and they afterwards corresponded, largely on matters relating to natural history and specimen exchange. Skene was a member of the Aberdeen Philosophical society along with Thomas Reid and James Beattie and was Dean of Faculty at Marischal College, Aberdeen from 1767 to 1770. Skene's other correspondents included Linnaeus; Henry Home, Lord Kames (whom he provided with a 'reciept for a moss dunghill'); Lord Buchan and the botanists Dr John Hope and John Walker of Moffat. Skene seems to have suffered from poor health and his correspondence with Pennant was cut short by his death in 1770. Abedeen University LIbrary Special Collections, MS 483; Colin A. McLaren, ‘Reports and surveys of archives in northern Scotland’ in Northern Scotland: A Historical Journal, Volume 1, Number 1, December 1972, ed. by Malcom Gray and Donald J. Withrington (Published by the Centre for Scottish Studies, University of Aberdeen), pp.115-125.
Unidentified Mr Simpson (fl.1775).

note.note:
John Williams (c.1732–1795) mineral engineer and archaeologist, born in Montgomeryshire. After being working in copper mining in Anglesey, Williams joined Roy's military survey of Scotland from 1747-1752. The Board for the Annexed Estates then employed Williams to search for coal and minerals in Sutherland. Although his prospecting for resources was largely unsuccessful , Williams's surveys did bear antiquarian fruit in the form of his
Account of Some Remarkable Ancient Ruins
(1777), which described vitrified forts in northern Scotland, and linked them to Fingalian legend. He later wrote a major geological treatise, the Natural History of the Mineral Kingdom, which refuted the recent theories of James Hutton. ODNB. See Fredrik Albritton Jonsson, Enlightenment's Frontier: The Scottish Highlands and the Origins of Environmentalism (New Haven; London: Yale University Press, 2013), pp.167-87.

persName.note: Unidentified Mr Brodie (fl.1771).

note.note: Richard Morris (1703–79) was the second child of Morris Prichard and his wife Marged, and a brother of the poet Lewis Morris and the antiquary William Morris. Richard moved to live in London at the early age of nineteen, and spent the remainder of his life there, working from 1748 as a clerk at the Navy Office. Alongside his brother Lewis, he established the London-Welsh Cymmrodorion Society in 1751, and was appointed its first president. He was editor of impressions of the Welsh Bible and Book of Common Prayer (1746, 1752), and closely involved in the publication of Pennant's British zoology (1766), which the Cymmrodorion published in their own name as 'a blind' to conceal Pennant's involvement in publication from his family. After the death of Lewis Morris in 1765, Richard ensured the preservation of letters and manuscripts which were eventually deposited in the British Library. ODNB; Dafydd Wyn Wiliam, Cofiant Richard Morris (1702/3–79) (Llangefni: O. Jones, 1999); Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 144–151.

persName.note: Mr McIver (fl.1810), part of the Liverpool shipping firm of McIver, McViccar and McCorquodale, based in Pownall Street. Gomer Williams, History of the Liverpool Privateers and Letters of Marque, with an Account of the Liverpool Slave Trade (London: 1897), p.403.

Elizabeth Pennant (née Falconer, d. June 1764) was the daughter of James Faulkner of Chester, Lieutenant, and his wife Elizabeth (née Inge). Pennant married her in April 1759. She was the mother of Thomas (who died at two months in 1760), Arabella and David.
Unidentified Mrs Fordyce (fl.1771).

note.note: Paul Panton (1727–97), born in Bagillt, Flintshire, to an old Welsh family of noble descent, was educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and entered Lincoln's Inn in December 1744. Through his marriage in 1756 to Jane, daughter and heir of William Jones of Plas Gwyn, Pentraeth, Anglesey, he became the owner of a substantial estate and a contributor to public life in Anglesey. He continued to interest himself in his native Flintshire, becoming involved in particular in its increasing industrialization. As an antiquarian, he was interested in Welsh history and literature and, notably, patronized the impoverished clergyman, Evan Evans (Ieuan Fardd). He died on 22 May 1797. ODNB.

persName.note: George Paton (1721–1807), antiquary and bibliographer, was the son of John Paton, an Edinburgh bookseller. Paton worked as a customs house clerk in Edinburgh from 1760 and was an avid collector of rare books, manuscripts and prints. Paton was a dilligent supporter of other researchers, including Pennant, Richard Gough and George Low, and much of his correspondence survives in the Advocates Library collection at the National Library of Scotland. Paton's bibliographic collections were sold at auction in 1809.
Unidentified (fl.1773).
Unidentified printer (fl.1773). Possibly associated with London Bookseller Alexander Donaldson, who was frequently under fire for flouting copyright laws.

Thomas Pennant (1726–98) was a naturalist, writer and antiquarian well known for his published accounts of pioneering tours throughout the British Isles. He was born and lived at the family estate, Downing Hall near Whitford, Flintshire, in north-east Wales. He was educated in Wrexham and Oxford.He was the son of David Pennant (d. 1763), landowner, and a member of the Pennant family who owned the estate centred upon an ancient house at Bychton since Norman conquest. Pennant's mother was Arabella, (d. 1744), 3rd daughter of Richard Mytton, of Halston, Shropshire. Pennant’s publications on natural history include such works as British Zoology, the History of Quadrupeds, and Arctic Zoology. He was a fine observer in the field, and collected specimens of plants, minerals, birds and animals. But his knowledge of the natural world also came from a wide international network of leading scientific figures of his day – his correspondents included figures such as Linnaeus, Joseph Banks and Gilbert White of Selbourne. He was a passionate antiquarian, with an interest in the Roman remains and artefacts around Chester and a deep curiosity about the British past. An enthusiast for economic improvement and a champion of burgeoning industry (he opened a lead-mine on his own estate) Pennant was politically conservative, becoming more reactionary in the decade of unrest after the French Revolution. His writings nonetheless reveal a thoughtful and generous-spirited man with a social conscience, who was deeply moved by the conditions of poverty he encountered on his travels. Pennant published accounts of tours in several parts of Britain, but he is best known for two consecutive Tours in Scotland made in 1769 and 1772, and the Tour in Wales, published in parts between 1778-1784. He travelled on horseback, on foot, and, in the Western Isles, by boat, and it is this immediacy of experience combined with his many and varied interests which make these tours such fascinating reading. Hugely influential on later travellers to Wales and Scotland, they are rich in observations and descriptions which bring the vibrant complexities of eighteenth-century Britain to life. His long-standing patronage of the artist Moses Griffith and others such as John Ingleby and Paul Sandby ensured that these written descriptions were matched with a superb range of landscapes and miniatures, many painted directly into lavish extra-illustrated versions of the tours. He was married twice, in 1759 to Elizabeth Falconer (d. 1764), and in 1778 to Ann Mostyn of Mostyn Hall, the adjacent estate to Downing. He had two children from each marriage, and his eldest son David inherited the estate. When he died at the age of seventy two he was a recognized literary figure – and had become, by a nice irony, a ‘feature’ on the itinerary of his own Tour. ODNB.
Pennant’s 'very antient aunt', Possibly Elizabeth (d.1775). See Thomas Pennant, Whiteford and Holywell.

Arabella Pennant (1761–1828) was the daughter of Thomas Pennant by his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer). As a young woman she divided her time between Downing and the home of her aunt, Catherine Pennant, at Upper Grosvenor Street in London, and upon the latter's death appears to have inherited a substantial sum of money. Her financial independence is signalled by her contribution of £25 to the fund for setting up 'The Loyal Holywell Volunteers' in March 1797, and by her decision to marry, against her father's wishes, Edward, son of Sir Walden Hanmer, in November 1797. Her father's will of February 1798 offered her a limited settlement, but a codicil in August of the same year granted her additional sums, alongside her husband and any children (of which there were none). ODNB; Burke, III, p. 34; Evans, 'The Flintshire Loyalist Association and the Loyal Holywell Volunteers', 62; idem, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 71–3.
Sarah Pennant (1779–94) was the daughter of Thomas Pennant and his second wife, Ann (née Mostyn). She died at Brighton on 16 April 1794. ODNB; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 73–4.
First-century Jewish religious leader. Christian Messiah and Islamic prophet.

note.note: Catherine Pennant (1729–97) was one of Pennant's younger twin sisters. She lived for some time with her twin, Sarah (1729–80), at an address in St James's, Westminster, to which Pennant frequently referred his London acquaintance, and later at Upper Grosvenor Street, Mayfair. Catherine was reputed for her generosity to her brother. Burke (1836), III, p. 34; Thomas Pennant to [?Samuel Lysons], 6 January 1793, NYkPL, Pforz MS (MISC 0470); Peltz, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', p. 208, nn. 74, 77; W. S. Lewis (ed.), The Yale Edition of Horace Walpole’s Correspondence, II (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1937), pp. 266, 267, here [accessed 12 July 2018].

persName.note: Ann Pennant (née Mostyn) (c.1739–1802) was the elder daughter of Sir Thomas Mostyn and his wife Sarah (née Western), and a sister to Sir Roger Mostyn, 5th baronet. She became Thomas Pennant's second wife, marrying him at Whitford, Flintshire, in January 1777. Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 58–9.

Subject of a portrait 'a full length in armour' at Gordon Castle, seen by Pennant in the Tour in Scotland 1769, 3rd edn. (Warrington: 1774), p.195. The portrait is not mentioned in the first edition of 1771.

note.note: The genealogist Philip Yorke (1743–1804) was born at Erddig, near Wrexham. His interest in things Welsh began following his second marriage in 1782 to Diana, daughter of Piers Wynne of Dyffryn Aled, who was descended from Marchudd, lord of Uwch Dulas. In 1795 Yorke issued seventy copies of a genealogical history of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn, Tracts of Powys, which was dedicated to Thomas Pennant and contained letters from Lewis Morris to William Vaughan and others as an appendix. A revised and expanded edition of the Tracts, completed with the assistance of Walter Davies (Gwallter Mechain), appeared under the title of The Royal Tribes of Wales in 1799. A diffident parliamentarian, Yorke held the seats of Helston (1774–81) and Grantham (1781–92). Hist P; ODNB.

persName.note: William Pitt the Elder (1708–1778), Whig Prime Minister of Great Britain (1766-68).

Reverend Alexander Pope of Reay, Caithness (d.1776). Pope was an accomplished antiquarian in his own right, and a correspondent of Pennant: he provided the account of Caithness in
A tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd edn., 1774), pp.336-66; his description of Dun Dornaigil appeared in Archaeologia, v (1779), p.216. Pope also translated at least part of the works of the Icelandic historian Thormodus Torfæus. Pennant had access to the translation and provided it to James Cordiner. One anecdote records that Pope travelled to London by pony in 1732 to visit his namesake, the poet Alexander Pope. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)
William Ogilvie (fl.1769-74), Aberdeen University professor.
9th Duke of Hamilton and 6th Duke of Brandon (1740-1819)

Referred to as Mr Menzies' shipmate. [FMJ: Educated at St John's College, Cambridge, the botanist Samuel Dickenson was appointed rector of Blymhill, Staffordshire, in 1777. Desmond King-Hele, 'Erasmus Darwin's Life at Lichfield: Fresh Evidence', Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London, vol. 49, no. 2 (1992), 231–243, esp. 242, note 6. For letters from Dickenson to Pennant see WCRO CR2017/TP213/1–5 (1773–1795); and CR 2017/TP33/11-13 (1788–1790). These give accounts of his travels in north Africa and the Mediterranean and show his shared interest with Pennant in China and in African plants and animals.]
Reverend Parish of Carlisle (fl.1774).

note.note: Revd Henry Parry was associated with the church at Holywell, probably as a curate, before his appointment on 21 May 1798 as vicar of Llanasa, Flintshire. He subscribed to the second edition of William Owen Pughe's A Dictionary of the Welsh Language ... to which is prefixed, A Welsh grammar (Denbigh; Thomas Gee, 1832), I, and corresponded with Pennant's son, David. His correspondence with Pennant provided information incorporated into HPWaH. Pennant displayed his appreciation by recommending Parry to Lewis Bagot, Bishop of St Asaph, for the post at Llanasa; by inserting, in 1798, an additional paragraph in A tour in Wales, praising him as 'a cheerful and amiable companion, endowed with much knowledge of the history of our country, and with much classical reading'; and by his bequest of £20 to Parry upon his death. NLW 1626, part I, p. 208; Tours in Wales by Thomas Pennant, ed. John Rhys (3 vols., Caernarvon: H. Humphreys, 1883), I, p. vii; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant (1726–1798), pp. 83, 87, 122 note 274; idem, 'The writings of Thomas Pennant on north Wales', p. 75.

There is insufficient evidence to enable Ellis Richardson to be collated with another man named Richardson, described by Paul Panton as Pennant's 'Neighbor & Tent' in an undated letter, although the former might also be classed as someone who lives close by Pennant from the evidence of Hugh Davies's letter of 10 August 1795.

persName.note: Mr Ridgeway is introduced to George Paton by Thomas Pennant in a letter of 13 December 1779. According to the letter he was a student of surgery and a member of the local militia.

Robertson, James (1701-76): minister of Loch Broom, known as 'am Ministear Laidir'. Born in Atholl and licenced in the Presbytry of Dunkeld in 1736 and ordained in 1743. His wife was Anne Mackenzie (dates unknown): the couple had 6 sons and 2 daughters. Although not himself a Jacobite, Robertson travelled to London in 1746 and successfully pleaded for mitigated punishment for many of his parishioners who had served in Lord Cromartie's Regiment in the Jacobite army.

Walter Ruddiman (1719-1781) was an Edinburgh printer and publisher; proprietor of The weekly magazine, or, Edinburgh amusement (1768-1779). Until 1770 he was known as Walter Ruddiman Junior to distinguish him from his uncle of the same name, also an Edinburgh printer. Ruddiman's Weekly might be considered a more successful and longer-lived iteration of his earlier project, the Edinburgh Magazine (1757-1762). The Weekly was Edinburgh's best selling weekly publication, and alongside its extracts and digest of recent news and publications, it was also the medium of the poet Robert Fergusson's first printed work. From 1771 Ruddiman's son Thomas became a partner. After 1777 the Weekly was divided into two separate news and literary titles, to exempt the former from the stamp duty levied on newspapers: it continued under the new title of The Edinburgh magazine, or, Literary amusement from 1779 to 1782, the year after Walter Ruddiman's death. ODNB.

Elizabeth Mure of Rowallan was born to an Ayrshire landowning family and in 1348 became first wife of Robert, high stewart and later King Robert II of Scotland. Later historians including George Buchanan disputed the status of Elizabeth and Robert's marriage, which was only granted papal dispensation some time after the original ceremony and the birth of their children. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB; see also Colin Kidd, Subverting Scotland's Past (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1993), pp.90-91.
Unidentified person named in a note by Pennant on a letter from George Paton, 4 April, 1775.

Lachlan Shaw (1686?-1777) was a Church of Scotland Minister and author of the History of the Province of Moray (1775). He also contributed a substantial account 'Of Elgin and the Shire of Murray' to Pennant's Tour in Scotland 1769: see 3rd edn. (Warrington: 1769), Appendix II., pp.287-312. Pennant presented a manuscript of Shaw's 'Ecclesiastical antiquities of Murray' to the Society of Antiquaries of London (SAL/MS/32): see his covering letter to Daines Barrington, dated March 4th 1773.
Sir Robert Sibbald (1641-1722), geographer, physician and natural historian. He was made Geographer Royal for Scotland in 1682.

Sir Ashton Lever (1729–88), natural history collector. His collection of shells, minerals, stuffed animals and artefacts evolved into a museum, housed from 1773 in Leicester Square and open to visitors one day a week. The enterprise was beset by financial difficulties from 1783 and disposed of by a lottery in March 1786. Lever died of an apoplectic fit on 31 January 1788. A line engraving of him by W. Angus appeared in theEuropean Magazine in 1784, and a stipple portrait by W. Nutter, after S. Shelley, was published in 1787. ODNB.
Sir David Lindsay of the Mount (c.1490-c.1555), Lyon King of Arms and poet.

note.note: William Skinner (1699/1700-1780) was a military engineer, born on the island of St Kitts in the West Indies. He was involved in the construction of a number of fortifications, including St Philip's Castle, Menorca and Fort George near Inverness. He attained the rank of major-general. ODNB.

persName.note: John Slezer (d.1717) was a German-born army officer and draughtsman, who was appointed chief engineer in Scotland in 1671. His Theatrum Scotiae (1693) featured views of significant Scottish sites and buildings. Both the views in that work and many of his unpublished drawings were reproduced as prints or used as sources by other artists following his death. ODNB.

William Smellie (1740-1795) was an Edinburgh printer, editor and author, not to be confused with his distant relative William Smellie, the physician and midwife (1697-1763), though like his namesake, he had a strong interest in medical matters. As editor of the Scots Magazine, Smellie paid particular notice to matters of natural history and medicine, though ultimately the book trade won out over his earlier ambition to pursue his medical studies into a career. Smellie printed works for Charles Elliot, John Murray, William Strahan, William Creech, Peter Hill and others, as well as printing, editing and authoring several important medical books and periodicals. Smellie was commissioned as editor and contributor to the first Encyclopaedia Britannica (1768-71) and translated into English Buffon's Natural History (1780-85). Smellie was also the printer of Maria Riddell's Voyages to the Madeira and Leeward Caribbean Isles (1792); his own Philosophy of Natural History appeared in 1790. ODNB; Richard B. Sher, The Enlightenment and the Book (Chicago; London: The University of Chicago Press, 2006)

note.note: John Strutt (1727-1816), MP for Maldon in Essex from 1727-1816 and a committed Tory. History of Parliament Online.

persName.note: John Stuart, first marquess of Bute (1744–1814), diplomatist, was known in print collecting circles from the mid-1770s, often by the title 'Lord Mountstuart'. This was in recognition of his place of birth, Mount Stuart on the Scottish Isle of Bute, but also became his recognized title when he took the post of envoy to Turin for three years from August 1779. Son of John Stuart, third earl of Bute and prime minister during 1762–3, the first marquess inherited the south Wales estates of his wife's family of Windsor, and was created Baron Cardiff in 1776. In 1774, Stuart became the purchaser of Richard Bull's extra-illustrated version of Granger, A biographical history of England. Hist P;ODNB; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', 39–44.
Unidentified Mr Sympson or Simpson referred to in Pennant's letter to George Paton on 26 March 1776.
Unidentified T Philips of Edinburgh, possibly associated with John Clerk of Eldin or a distributor of his etchings.

Thomas Dundas (1741-1820), first Baron Dundas of Aske, only son of Sir Lawrence Dundas, was educated at Eton and St Andrews and toured Europe as a young man, before taking a seat in parliament as member for Richmond, Yorkshire, and later Stirlingshire. In parliament he supported the Rockingham Whigs. A supporter of Fox in the 1780s, Dundas switched allegiance to Pitt, perhaps in response to the violence of the French Revolution. His political influence gradually declined with the rise of his rival and distant relative, Henry Dundas. ODNB

Thomas Hunt (c. 1723–89), of Mollington, Cheshire, was MP for Bodmin from 1784 until his death at Chester on 11 October 1789. The Pennant-Bull correspondence shows that he spent time at an address in South Audley Street, Mayfair, and that he franked letters for Pennant. His anti-Pittite stance in Parliament would seem to make him a surprising friend to Bull and Pennant, but his Cornish and Cheshire connections may be seen as a reason for his acquaintance with them. Hist P; The European Magazine, and London Review, XVI (1789), 312.

George Hunt (1720?-1798) MP for Bodmin from 1753 until 1784, when he was succeeded in that office by his brother, Thomas Hunt. Like his brother, he used his parliamentary privelege to frank some of Thomas Pennant's letters.

Descended from the iconic figure of Catrin of Berain, 'Mam Cymru' ('Mother of Wales'), the writer Hester Lynch Piozzi (1741–1821) made an advantageous but unhappy marriage to the wealthy London brewer, Henry Thrale. The introduction of Samuel Johnson to Thrale's Streatham Park estate in 1766 lead to a sustained period of activity for Hester as the presider of the Streatham salon, famed as a magnet for writers and intellectuals. In 1784, three years after Thrale's death, Hester married the Italian musician Gabriel Mario Piozzi, with whom she travelled on the continent and, from 1795, retired to Brynbella, Denbighshire. ODNB.
An occasional franker of Thomas Pennant's letters. Possibly Walter Williams, London barrister, father of Thomas Walter Williams, a legal author.
Richard Wilbraham Bootle (1725-1796) was MP for Chester from 1761-1790. He franked some of Pennant's letters.

note.note: The antiquary Sir William Burrell, second baronet (1732–96), followed a legal career as advocate and was appointed chancellor of the diocese of Worcester in 1764. He succeeded his father-in-law to the title of baronet in 1788. Elected FSA in 1754, by 1770 he was working on the history of Sussex. Pennant, From Dover to the Isle of Wight (1801), p. 46, mentions him as the owner of ‘fine drawings’ of Herstmonceux Castle, East Sussex, which was dismantled in 1777, leaving only the outer walls standing. Pennant's regard for Burrell is apparent from the fact that he was one of the few for whom he produced an edition of A tour in Wales on large paper with original Moses Griffith paintings as illustrations. ODNB s.n. Sir William Burrell; Moses Griffith.

persName.note: William Hudson (1730-1793) was a botanist and apothecary. He was sub-librarian of the British Museum from 1757-1758 where his access to the Sloane herbarium allowed him to apply Linnaean systematics to the plants previously described by the British naturalist John Ray. Hudson was elected a fellow the Royal Society in 1761 and his Flora Anglica was published in 1762, marking an important moment in the adoption of the Linnaean methods by British botanists. ODNB.

Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (1500–58), also known as Charles I of Spain, abdicated parts of his empire between 1554 and 1556, eventually retiring to the monastery of St Yuste in Extremadura whence he continued to correspond widely and maintain his interest in the Empire.
Zachary Boyd (1585-1653), Scottish poet whose verse bible was held in the collections of the Glasgow College library and considered a literary curiosity.

note.note: Eberhard August Wilhelm von Zimmermann (1743–1815), German geographer and zoologist, was appointed professor of mathematics and natural sciences at the Collegium Carolinum in Braunschweig, Lower Saxony, in 1766. He travelled widely in Europe and published works spanning the fields of mathematics, natural sciences and travel, including Specimen Zoologiae Geographicae Quadrupedum (1777). Correspondence with Pennant, dated 14 August 1783, reveals Zimermann's relations with the naturalists Joseph Banks, Peter Simon Pallas and Johann Christian Daniel von Schreber, and shows that Pennant was in regular contact with him during that year. He later translated into German Pennant's Arctic zoology (2 vols.: Leipzig, 1787). Zimmermann to Thomas Pennant, 14 August 1783: WCRO, CR 2017/TP401.

persName.note: Unidentified Jamaica correspondent of George Paton who provided him with descriptions of birds (fl.1771).
Unidentified traveller to Shetland (fl.1771).
An unidentified Mrs Flemming (fl.1771); an acquaintance of George Paton.
Possibly a Newcastle courier (fl.1772).
A noted case of abstinence from 1772-73.
Mr Aberdeen (fl.1774); an acquaintance of George Paton.
Andrew Foulis (1712-1775), Glasgow printer and bookseller with his brother, Robert.

(1772-1835), watercolour painter and geologist. Underwood, who was born in London, became a draughtsman to the Society of Antiquaries in 1792, and was a member of the group of artists, also including J.M.W. Turner and Thomas Girtin, who met at the home of the art collector and physician Dr Thomas Monro in the 1790s. Along with Ker Porter, Underwood belonged to the Sketching Society, also known as ‘the Brothers’, founded in May 1799; this tour over the summer of 1799 was probably taken in order to sketch Welsh scenes from real life rather than literary sources, which was the usual practice at meetings of ‘The Brothers’ (see also references to the artists Louis Francia and [?John] Varley later in the text). No account of this tour by Underwood, who features throughout Ker Porter’s narrative, is known to exist, but several undated watercolours at the Tate, which include depictions of Caernarfon Castle, may be products of it. See for example http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/underwood-carnarvon-castle-t09273 and http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/underwood-carnarvon-castle-and-estuary-t09267
Unidentified master of a ship who failed to deliver a book from Paton to Pennant (fl.1774).
Minister of Dornoch (fl.1774).
A Mrs Campbell of Achalader (fl.1774) referred to by John Stuart.
A Mr Campbell of Achalader (fl.1774) referred to by John Stuart.

The son of Sir John Bull (c.1725–1805) and Elizabeth (née Turner) of Chipping Ongar, Essex, Richard Bull was educated at Westminster school and Trinity Hall, Cambridge. He held the parliamentary seat for the double member borough of Newport on the Isle of Wight between 1756 and 1780. His interest in print-collection and extra-illustration took shape from c. 1768–9, when he began working on Granger, A biographical history of England. The extra-illustration of this work was carried out in a close collaboration with the author, documented in a bound letterbook of their correspondence. Bull went on to extra-illustrate as many as sixty-seven works, including seven by Pennant, not all of which can now be traced. Hist P; ODNB; Evans, 'Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant'; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads'; Pinkerton, 'Richard Bull of Ongar, Essex'.

note.note: Flemish artist (1606-1669).

persName.note: Catherine, Countess of Desmond, was a reputed centenarian living in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, which Pennant found engraved from a painting in a Scottish collection in April 1773.

note.note: James Granger (bap. 1723, d. 1776), vicar of Shiplake, Oxfordshire, and a print collector and biographer, was renowned for his catalogue of engraved historical portraits, (1769), and a supplement which followed in 1774. Granger worked closely with other connoisseurs of art, including Joseph Gulston, Horace Walpole and Richard Bull, with whom he discussed and exchanged prints. So popular was his work that the practice of ornamenting printed works with portraits and other prints became firmly associated with him and his name was lent to a verb, 'to grangerize', intended to describe this fashionable amateur occupation. ODNB; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads'.

persName.note: Lady Kirkwall

note.note: A servant of Richard Bull.
Engraver and printseller at 134 New Bond Street from 1771 to 1799. See here [accessed 1 July 2019].

persName.addName: of Gwedir; old Sir John, the Historian

note.note: Sir John Wynn, first baronet (1553–1627), of Gwydir, Llanrwst. With a reputation, largely undeserved, as a harsh landlord, Wynn added lands in almost every county of north Wales to the family estate and combined the aims of strengthening his position as a landowner at home with that of serving the Tudor monarchy and the protestant church. He was a patron of prominent Welsh bards and an antiquary, and developed a notable library at Gwydir, whilst also producing a History of Penmaenmawr, The History of the Gwydir family and an annotated copy of the Record of Caernarvon. ODNB; Sir John Wynn, The History of the Gwydir family and Memoirs, ed. by J. Gwynfor Jones (Llandysul: Gomer, 1990).

John Jones (bap. 1746, d. 1827), son of Owen Jones and his wife Jane, was baptized on 24 October 1746 at Eglwys Fach, Denbighshire. He matriculated at Jesus College, Oxford, in 1765 and was elected a Scholar in August 1766. In 1770, he was ordained a deacon and then a priest, before being elected a Fellow of Jesus College on 22 October 1773, a post held until 1791. He had been instituted as a vicar at Shipston-on-Stour, a living owned by his Alma Mater, in 1789. Pennant acknowledged John Jones as 'indefatigable in furnishing me with extracts from the manuscripts of the university’ in the 'Advertisement' to A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), unpaginated. See further AO, p. 767; E. G. Hardy, Jesus College (London: F. .E. Robinson and Co., 1899), p. 244; Clergy of the Church of England Database, s.n. John Jones (1770–1827), here [accessed 23 September 2020]; and ex inf. Robin Darwall-Smith.

Paul Panton, junior (1758–1822), son of Paul Panton of Bagillt, Flintshire, and his wife Jane, daughter of William Jones of Plas Gwyn, Anglesey. He was admitted to Lincoln's Inn in 1775, began residing there in 1777 and kept his chambers there until 1794. He inherited his father's estates on the latter's death in 1797. Pennant notes that Paul Panton, junior, accompanied him on his tour of the Isle of Man in 1774. ODNB s.n. Paul Panton (1727–1797); DWB s.n. Paul Panton (1727–1797); Pennant, Literary life, p. 22.

John Ingleby (1749–1808) of Halkyn in Flintshire, a watercolour artist who worked on commission for Pennant from 1780 on north Wales views, largely urban, and as copyist of coats of arms and memorials. Pennant and Bull made greater use of Ingleby as illustrator following the death of his patron, Trench Chiswell, in February 1797. Evans, ‘Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant’, 275–6, 284–5; David Rowe, The A–Z of Curious Flintshire: Strange stories of mysteries, crimes and eccentrics (Stroud: The History Press, 2015); Paul Joyner, Artists in Wales c.1740–c.1851 (Aberystwyth, 1997); here [accessed 24 January 2018].

persName.note: in Vere Street Oxford Road

note.note: Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, fourth baronet (1749–89), owner of the north Wales and border county estates of Wynnstay in Denbighshire, Llanforda in Shropshire, Rhiwgoch in Meirioneth, and Llwydiarth in Montgomeryshire. He shared his time between London (where he sat as MP from 1772) and Wynnstay, where he had a theatre built. His 1771 expedition in north Wales in the company of Paul Sandby, Thomas Apperley and others is believed to have given rise to a fashion for the picturesque in landscape. Sandby’s Views in North Wales (1776) was published as a result of this journey. Williams Wynn died at his Westminster home on 29 July 1789. ODNB.

persName.note: James Robson (1733–1806), printer and bookseller, succeeded to the printing, bookselling and publishing business of his master, John Brindley, following the latter's death in 1758. The issuing of fixed-price and auction catalogues became a feature of his business, with his most notable auction, in conjunction with the Pall Mall bookseller, James Edwards, being that of the Pinelli collection in 1789 and 1790. ODNB.

Robert Faulder (1780–1805), bookseller and publisher whose shop was located on the corner of Maddox Street and New Bond Street (and features in Gillray’s print, ‘The Carrot Seller’, O’Shea Gallery, Mayfair). Several of his publications included maps. See 'Shops of London Map-Publishers', here [accessed 8 October 2018].

note.note: Messrs. Goslings' bank in Fleet Street was founded 1650. The firm was known from 1796 as Messrs. Goslings and Sharpe (Pennant refers to his bankers as Mess Gosling & Sharpe in January 1797) when John Charles Sharpe joined the partnership. British History Online, digitized version of Old and New London: Volume 1 (London, 1878), here [accessed 24 January 2019].

persName.note: Paul Sandby (bap. 1731, d. 1809), painter and engraver. Sandby's early career as a draughtsman to the military survey in Scotland gave him the opportunity to work on landscape drawings. Following a move to London in 1752 he became increasingly involved in landscape work, employing various techniques (including pioneering use of aquatint), and exhibited work regularly at the Society of Artists and its successor, the Royal Academy. He was chief drawing master at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, 1768–1796, and was drawing master to patrons including Sir Watkin Williams Wynn. Drawings by Sandby published following sketching tours in Wales in 1771 and 1773 and two further series of aquatints of Welsh subjects published in 1777 and 1786 helped to make Wales a popular destination for touring. ODNB.

Elizabeth Bull (1749–1809) was the elder of the two daughters of Richard Bull and his wife Mary (née Ash). Described by a contemporary as 'deeply interested in her fathers favourite pursuit', she shared Bull's passion for print collecting and was actively involved in pasting and decorating his volumes of engraved portrait heads and other extra-illustrated titles. Alongside her younger sister, Catherine, she inherited a substantial fortune through the death of Sir Humphry Morice, a fact which possibly made a single life both possible and attractive to her. Hist P; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 128; eadem, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', esp. pp. 500–11; and eadem, 'The extra-illustration of London: the gendered spaces and practices of antiquarianism in the late eighteenth century', in Myrone and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1. For a contemporary account of Elizabeth and Catherine by their friend, Louisa Clarges, see Philip Olleson, The Journals and Letters of Susan Burney: Music and Society in Late Eighteenth-Century England (London: Routledge, 2016), p. 125.

Anthony Morris Storer (1746–99), politician and collector, was the son of a wealthy West Indies merchant. He sat in Parliament as member for Carlisle, Cumbria (1774–80), and for Morpeth, Northumberland (1780–4), and was appointed by the Fox-North coalition as secretary of the embassy at Paris on 21 September 1783. The post of minister-plenipotentiary to which he was appointed on 13 December that year, was held only very briefly before the fall of the coalition, and Storer failed to be re-elected to parliament after 1784. He was an active collector of prints and books, and an important figure in the world of extra-illustration. Although his fervour for such activity was dampened in the early 1780s by financial difficulties, following his father's death in 1793 he inherited a substantial fortune. His collections were bequeathed to Eton College Library, and included copies of several extra-illustrated versions of Pennant's works: The journey from Chester to London; Some Account of London (2nd ed., 1791); A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784); and A Journey to Snowdon (1781). He died of a ‘deep decline’ after years of poor health. Hist P; ODNB; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', 3–5; and ex inf. Lucy Peltz.

note.note: John Lloyd (1733–93), son of John Lloyd (d. 1756), Bodidris, became curate at Caerwys, Flintshire, in 1761 and was appointed rector there in 1778. Pennant relied heavily on Lloyd for translations of Welsh manuscript material, for his extensive knowledge of Welsh history, and for commentary on and correction of the early drafts of the Welsh tours, and acknowledged his debt to him in the 'Advertisement' to A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), where he described him as 'my constant companion in these excursions'. Lloyd was known to others, too, for his erudition: Iolo Morganwg visited him in 1772, Evan Evans in 1786, and he corresponded with Philip Yorke of Erddig, who shared his interest in genealogy. When he died on 22 May 1793, Pennant organized a fund to aid his widow Martha (née Williams, d. 1810). DWB; Paul Evans, 'Reverend John Lloyd of Caerwys (1733–93): Historian, Antiquarian and Genealogist', FHSJ, 31 (1983/1984), 109–24.

persName.note: Mother of Jesus according to the New Testament.

Catherine (d. 13 October 1795) was the younger daughter of Richard and Mary Bull. She was involved alongside her elder sister Elizabeth in helping Richard Bull with extra-illustration, and also shared with Elizabeth an inheritance granted at the death of Sir Humphry Morice. Hist P; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 128; eadem, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', esp. pp. 500–11; eadem, 'The extra-illustration of London: the gendered spaces and practices of antiquarianism in the late eighteenth century', in Myrone and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past; W. P. Courtney, 'Richard Bull', Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 7 (March 1913), 170–1; Philip Olleson, The Journals and Letters of Susan Burney: Music and Society in Late Eighteenth-Century England (London: Routledge, 2016), passim.

first duke of Norfolk (1366–1399). Pennant quotes the accounts of Froissart and Holinshed of the dispute between Mowbray and Henry Bolingbroke (later Henry IV) at some length in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 166–173, and includes a print of a challenge between him and the Duke of Hereford. See ar0032; ODNB.

Born in Florence, the engraver Francesco Bartolozzi (1728–1815) was considered as the best engraver in Italy by the 1760s. Having had some of his work published in London in 1763, he was invited there by the art dealer Richard Dalton in 1764 and spent the next 35 years working there. He exhibited with the Society of Artists and thereafter at the Royal Academy, and established a vogue for dotted prints or 'stipples'. Most of his work was commanded by printsellers and he had others working for him including Luigi Schiavonetti and John Keyes Sherwin. In 1801 he moved to Lisbon to reform the royal printing press but died at his workshop there in 1815. ODNB.

Margaret Clifford [née Russell], countess of Cumberland (1560–1616). Portrait(s) in oils, 1585, are found at Gorhambury, Hertfordshire. ODNB. For Pennant's account and a portrait, see The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 246–7, and ar0033.

Countess of Suffolk, Katherine Howard [nee Knyvett; other married name Rich] (b. in or after 1564, d. 1630). ODNB. In The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 228, Pennant describes her as having 'a great ascendancy over her husband' and as 'extremely rapacious', and includes a 'fine full-length' portrait (ar0034).

David Pennant (1685–1763), son of Peter Pennant and father of Thomas Pennant, inherited the estate of Downing in 1724, and went on to unite it with nearby Bychton, the estate of his own branch of the Pennant family, following his father's death in 1736. Active in the management of lead and coal mines owned by the family, David Pennant was a JP and served as High Sheriff of Flintshire. Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 25–6, 101, n. 28, 102, n. 19, 104, notes 47–9; HPWaH, p. 15.

note.note: Thomas Pennant's mother, Arabella, was the third daughter of Richard Mytton of Halston, Shropshire. She married David Pennant in December 1724, and had four children, of whom Thomas Pennant was the eldest. A second son (b. 1728) died in infancy, but twin daughters, Sarah and Catherine (b. 1729) survived into adulthood. Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', p. 26.

persName.note: Arnulf of Montgomery (b. c. 1066), member of the Norman aristocracy as the youngest son of the Marcher Lord Roger de Montgomery; see http://www.monasticwales.org/person/26

note.note: Margaret Griffith (née Jones), wife of Moses Griffith.

persName.note: Son of Moses Griffith and his wife Margaret (née Jones). Evidence that Moses Griffith, junior, was an able artist is found in an extra-illustrated copy of The View of Hindoostan. Vol. II. Eastern Hindoostan (London: J. White, M.DCC.XCVIII) (NLW 23413E), which contains a watercolour drawing of two horned cattle pulling a plough, led and goaded by a native Indian. Entitled 'Aryut at Plough', the drawing is signed 'Moses Griffith junior fecit 1798'.

Levinia Luther (née Bennett) (d. c.1807) was the daughter of Bennett Alexander Bennett and Mary (née Ash), of Ongar, Essex, but was raised from a young age by her mother's second husband, Richard Bull. She married John Luther (?1739–86), of Myles’s, near Ongar, in 1762, returning to her mother and step-father's home following the failure of the marriage in early 1764. She inherited the estate of Sir Humphry Morice (?1723–85), MP for Launceston and a close family friend, valued by a contemporary at £200,000, and appears to have lived at Morice's former home, the Grove, Middlesex. It is likely that she was involved alongside her half-sisters in Bull's collecting activity and in pasting material into his extra-illustrated volumes. Pinkerton, 'Richard Bull of Ongar, Essex', 46, 55; Peltz, 'The Extra-Illustration of London', pp. 503, 506–7, 507 n. 377; eadem, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 128; Courtney, 'Richard Bull'; Richard Watson, Anecdotes of the Life of Richard Watson, Bishop of Landaff (Philadelphia: Abraham Small, 1818), pp. 26–7; Devon Record Office, 47/9/2/32a-b.

note.note: Frederick North, second earl of Guilford, also known as Lord North (1732-1792). North was prime minister from 1770 to 1782, and his premiership was defined by the American revolutionary wars.

first Baron Herbert of Cherbury and first Baron Herbert of Castle Island (1582?–1648). He was born at Eyton-on-Severn, Shropshire, home of his maternal grandparents, Sir Richard (d. 1570) and Lady Margaret Newport. ODNB.

Richard Herbert (c. 1557–96), of Llysyn, Blackhall and Montgomery Castle, was the elder son of Edward Herbert and his wife Elizabeth (née Price). He served as a substitute MP for the Montgomery Boroughs from 1581, and sat for Montgomery between 1584 and 1586, nominated by his father for the latter seat. A combative and disgruntled figure in a local context, he was restrained from bullying neighbouring gentry by the Privy Council on two occasions. Hist P.

Magdalen Herbert (d. 1627), wife of Richard Herbert of Llysyn, Blackhall and Montgomery Castle, was the daughter of Sir Richard Newport of High Ercall and Eyton in Shropshire and his wife Margaret (née Bromley). Hist P.

persName.note: George Bridges Rodney, first Baron Rodney (1719–92), naval officer and politician. ODNB; Hist P.
Francesco Albani (1578-1660), seventeenth-century Italian painter.
Matthew Prior (1664-1721), poet and diplomat.
Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington (1694-1753)

note.note: Elizabeth I (1533-1603); reigned 1558-1603.

persName.note: Mackinnon, Lachlan, (1710-89) "Corrie": Sir Alexander Macdonald of Sleat's convivial tacksman at Coirechatacan in Skye. Hosted Pennant's party in 1772 and Johnson and Boswell in 1773. Boswell described Dr Johnson discussing Bonnie Prince Charlie with his wife, a Jacobite sympathiser, and jokingly announced that 'she was in love' with the Doctor. He also claimed that she possessed 'second sight'. The couple had nine children.

note.note: John or Lachlan Mackinnon, 'Young Corrie', the son of Lachlan MacKinnon of Coirechatacan, who accompanied Thomas Pennant up Ben na Cailleach in 1772. Young MacKinnon is also mentioned numerous times in Samuel Johnson and James Boswell's accounts of their 1773 tour of the Hebrides, during which they were hosted by the family.

persName.note: Unidentified Town Clerk of Campbeltown, Kintyre (fl.1772).
Colonel Campbell of Kintyre (fl.1773).
MacNeil: Proprietor of Gigha c.1772. One of the MacNeills of Taynish. The island was sold in 1780 to the MacNeills of Colonsay.

Daniel Campbell of Shawfield 'the Younger' (1737-77) Glasgow ‘tobacco lord’, MP for Lanarkshire and a political ally of the Duke of Argyll, principal proprietor of Islay. Died a bachelor aged only 40. Continued his grandfather's 'improvements' on Islay, establishing a flax weaving cottage industry, and constructing the village of Bowmore in 1768, one of the earliest planned villages in the Highlands. Played host to Pennant 2-6th July 1777, who described the 'uneven development' of Islay in that year, including the rural squalor of a 'weaver's cottage on Islay' printed in his Tour 1772.

Eleazar Albin (d. 1742?), naturalist and watercolour painter, was probably of German origin, but had adopted the surname Albin by 1708, by which time he lived in Piccadilly. His three-volume publication, A Natural History of Birds (1731–8) involved the study of exotic birds owned by Thomas Lowther, duke of Chandos, and by the silk weaver and naturalist Joseph Dandridge, as well as of birds acquired at Newgate market and from sea captains and foreign merchants. It includes 306 plates, some of which may have been painted by Albin's daughter, Elizabeth (b. 1708). ODNB.

Lewis Bagot (1740–1802) was bishop of Bristol, Norwich and, from 1790, St Asaph, where he rebuilt the Bishops Palace, declaring his intention to spend most of his time in the diocese. Renowned for his high-church views and strong conservatism, he evinced anger and vitriol from dissenters. He was a friend of Pennant, with whom he corresponded and for whom he franked some of the letters in the Pennant/Bull correpondence. ODNB; NLW 15421C (L: St Asaph to Thomas Pennant, 30 September 1790); and WCRO CR2017/TP165/1 and /4 (14 August 1795 and n.d.).

note.note: Jean-Nicolas-Paul-François, vicomte de Barras (1755–1829), served on the Directory throughout its rule. He was particularly instrumental in bringing about the Fructidor coup of 4 September 1797, which led to a series of purges and the instigation of radical policies until early 1798. He was eventually forced out of politics by Napoléon. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, pp. 50, 51, 318.

persName.note: James Basire (bap. 1730, d. 1802) was the eldest son of a printmaker and draughtsman whose publishing company he took over. His training included a period spent in Italy from 1749, alongside the artist, engraver, and antiquarian Richard Dalton. Back in London from late 1752, he began on a successful career as an etcher and engraver, one of the highlights of which was his appointment in succession to George Vertue as engraver to the Society of Antiquaries in 1759. This post led to constant employment, including work on plates for Charles Cordiner'sAntiquities and Scenery of the North of Scotland (1780), and pioneering work on an engraving of the sixteenth-century painting known asThe Field of the Cloth of Gold. In 1770 Basire was appointed engraver to the Royal Society. ODNB.

Richard Henry Alexander Bennett (?1742–1814), of North Court, Shorwell, Isle of Wight, was the son of Bennett Alexander Bennett and his wife Mary (née Ash), and the step-son of Richard Bull following his mother's marriage in 1747. He had one son, also named Richard Henry Alexander Bennett, and two daughters by his wife Elizabeth Amelia, daughter of Peter Burrell (1723–75), and was MP for Newport, Cornwall, from 1770 to 1774. Hist P; Courtney, 'Richard Bull', 170.

note.note: Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (née Lady Margaret Cavendish Harley), duchess of Portland (1715–85), daughter of Edward Harley, second earl of Oxford, was a collector of art and natural history specimens, and a patron of the arts and sciences. Rousseau joined her on an expedition to the Peak District in 1766, and she botanized with her friend Mary Delany, especially from 1768, following the death of her husband. She also collected shells, art and virtu, and created a museum of natural curiosities at her London home in Privy Garden, Whitehall. ODNB.

persName.note: Lady Georgiana Charlotte Bertie (1764–1838), daughter of Peregrine Bertie, third duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, and Mary Panton. She married George James Cholmondelay, first marquess of Cholmondelay, on 25 April 1791, thereafter taking his name. See here [accessed 1 October 2018].

John Boydell (1720–1804), engraver and printseller, was born Dorrington, Shropshire, but moved with his family to Hawarden, Flintshire, as a child. He was inspired to become an engraver after seeing a print of Hawarden Castle and the surrounding countryside and became apprenticed in 1741, aged twenty, for a firm of engravers in Holborn. He returned to Wales in 1748 to marry his sweetheart, Elizabeth Lloyd, and spent the honeymoon drawing views of Snowdonia, Welsh castles and the High Peak. He became an alderman in 1782, and was referred to after that as Alderman Boydell. ODNB.

James Brudenell, fifth earl of Cardigan (1725–1811), was a member of parliament for various constituencies in Dorset, Sussex and Wiltshire between 1754 and 1780. On 18 April 1781, at the age of 65, he married for the second time. His bride was the 32-year-old Lady Elizabeth Waldegrave (1758–1823), daughter of John, third Earl Waldegrave. Hist P; and here [accessed 1 October 2018].

note.note: Samuel Buck (1696–1779), topographical draughtsman, engraver, and print publisher, and his brother Nathaniel (fl.1724–1759) published 428 engravings of monasteries, abbeys, castles, and other ruins, three signed engravings of Fountains Abbey, two town plans, an engraving of Bristol high cross, and 87 long prospects of English and Welsh towns. Copper plates for printing these antiquities and the principal town prospects were acquired by the Fleet Street printer Robert Sayer, who reissued prints as single sheets or bound in three volumes as Buck's Antiquities in 1774. ODNB.

persName.note: Nathaniel Buck (fl. 1724–1759), for whom see his brother Samuel Buck

note.note: William Camden (1551–1623), historian and herald. His Britannia was published in 1586 with successive, enlarged editions in 1587, 1590, 1594, 1600 and 1607, and a translation in 1610. ODNB.

George Carter (bap. 1737, d. 1794) entered the Royal Academy Schools in 1770, and travelled to Rome in 1774, returning to England by 1776. He exhibited at the Royal Academy in the late 1770s and again in the mid-1780, probably spending the years between 1779 and 1784 visiting Gibraltar and St Petersburg. An exhibition in Pall Mall, London, in 1785, showed his enterprise insomuch as it claimed that its contents had been 'painted without commission' and was on offer to 'any nobleman or gentleman who may wish to possess either the whole or a part of them'. It was not a success, but engravings after the pictures were received more positively. He sailed for India in December 1785, and auctioned some of his pictures there between November 1786 and January 1787. ODNB says that he left India 'about a year later'.

persName.note: John Carter (1748–1817), draughtsman and architect. He was employed in 1780 by the Society of Antiquaries to do drawing and etching work. His patrons included Richard Gough and Horace Walpole. ODNB.

François-Xavier de Belsunce de Castelmoron (1671–1755), Jesuit bishop of Marseille from 1709, was celebrated for his courage during the plague of 1720. A picture of him at the town-hall, giving benediction to the dying and dead, commemorates his devotion to his people during this time. He died at Marseille on 4 June 1755 and was granted a magnificent burial.

Richard Muilman Trench Chiswell (1735–97), merchant banker and antiquary. He was known as Richard Muilman until December 1773, when he took the arms and names of his maternal grandparents. An avid collector of antiquarian books, Chiswell's library included four volumes of Pennant’s A tour in Wales, containing original coloured drawings and prints. He kept journals of tours in Derbyshire, in the Lake District and Scotland, and in Wales, undertaken between 1794 and 1796, and visited Pennant at Downing during the latter journey, also corresponding with him in 1794 and 1797. On 3 February 1797 he committed suicide at his home, Debden Hall, Essex, overcome by financial difficulties relating to his estates in West India. His copy of Pennant's The journey from Chester to London (1782), illustrated in four volumes, large-paper quarto, is housed at the Yale Centre for British Art, New Haven. ODNB; ex inf. Lucy Peltz.

George James Cholmondelay (1749–1827), fourth earl of Cholmondelay and, from 1815, first marquess of Cholmondelay. He held numerous offices and titles during his career including those of Lord-Lieutenant of Cheshire between 1779 and 1783, and Chamberlain of the same county from 1770 until 1827. In 1783 he was admitted to the Privy Council and was, between April and December of the same year, captain of the Yeomen of the Guard. He married Lady Georgiana Charlotte Bertie, daughter of Peregrine Bertie, third duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, on 25 April 1791. See here [accessed 1 October 2018].

Born in Montrose, Thomas Christie (1761–96) abandoned a career in medicine for life as a political writer. He met Pennant at Downing during a tour of Britain in 1787, an account of which he wrote in a series of unpublished letters. His wide-ranging interests in several branches of literature led to the establishment of the Analytical Review, a review of books to which he contributed many of the articles in the initial volumes. Six months spent in Paris in early 1790 ensured his firm support of the Revolution and, in 1792, he returned to work on the English part of the new French constitution. ODNB; Nichols, Literary anecdotes, IX, pp. 369–83.

Louisa Clarges (née Skrine; b. c.1755, d. 1809), was known as the daughter of William Skrine and his first wife Jane Sumner, although Skrine's parentage has been questioned. In 1777 she married Sir Thomas Clarges, 3rd baronet (1751–82). After his death she made frequent visits to Italy, before settling in England in 1799. The children of the marriage included Thomas, who succeeded to his father's title on coming of age on 25 December 1802; Louisa (d. 1806, aged 27); and William (1782–1807), but the Bull-Pennant correspondence suggests that there was another son, killed in naval service in 1794 (see 1226). Portraits of Lady Clarges were painted by Thomas Gainsborough and John Downman). On her relationship with Richard Bull's daughters, see Elizabeth Bull. Hist P s.n. Sir Thomas Clarges, 3rd Bt.; William Skrine; Edward A. Bloom and Lillian D. Bloom (eds.), The Piozzi Letters: Correspondence of Hester Lynch Piozzi, 1784–1821 (formerly Mrs. Thrale). Volume 4 1805–1810 (London and Toronto: Associated University Presses, 1996), pp. 95, n. 29, 251–2, n. 5.

Richard Clarke of Newport, Isle of Wight, died in 1817, aged 80. He subscribed to books of sermons published in 1757 and 1786 and was included in a list of the governors and officers of the 'Asylum for the Support and Education of the Deaf and Dumb Children of the Poor', dated 1817. His connection with the leading Isle of Wight antiquarian of his day is shown by a bookplate, 'Given me by Sir Rd. Worsley', in Lincolnshire Archives (1 WORSLEY 10A). Pennant and his son David enjoyed his companionship on their visit to the Isle of Wight in 1787, and Clarke's account of the tides around the island were included by Pennant in From Dover to the Isle of Wight (1801). Further relations are evinced by undated answers to queries and by a letter from Clarke to Pennant, 6 December 1793 at WCRO, CR 2017/TP89/9; /50. Gentleman's Magazine, LXXXVII, part 2 (1817), 89; Pennant, From Dover to the Isle of Wight (1801), pp. 189–90, 197–200.

Sir Henry Clinton (1730–95), an army officer, was raised to the rank of commander-in-chief during the American War of Independence. He returned to England in June 1782, where he found himself widely held responsible for the British defeat. Through the offices of influential friends from the time of the American war he was thereafter found a seat in parliament, where he had already served between 1774 and 1784, this time to represent Launceston (1790–4). Friends also secured him the post of governor of Gibraltar for 1794–5, but he died on 23 December 1795 before leaving Britain. He had three sons and two daughters from his marriage to Harriet, daughter of Thomas Carter, as well as five children with a mistress from the period of the American war, and another illegitimate daughter. Hist P; ODNB.

Richard Clough (d.1570), known by Welsh contemporaries as Rhisiart Clwch. The son of a Denbigh glover, he developed a career as a merchant and agent for the House of Gresham, under its royal agent, Thomas Gresham. A grant of leaseholds in Wales in 1564 enabled him to complete the building of two properties in his native county of Denbigh, Bachegraig and Clough Hall (Plas Clough), by 1567.

Sir George Cornewall, 2nd Bt. (1748–1819), of Moccas Court, Herefordshire, represented his home county in parliament during 1774–96 and 1802–7. He was the son of a London merchant, Sir George Amyand, from whom he inherited a share in a banking firm, but assumed the name of his wife Catherine, daughter and heir of Velters Cornewall. Hist P.

James Edwards (1756–1816), book collector and bookseller, was established in business at Pall Mall, London, from 1784. He purchased and sold at auction the private libraries of English collectors and antiquaries, later expanding his interest to continental libraries through several trips abroad. In 1788 he purchased the Pinelli Library in Venice, producing a catalogue entitled Bibliotheca Pinelliana in advance of its sale in March 1789. ODNB.

Thomas Erskine, first Baron Erskine (1750–1823), lord chancellor. He was involved in the trial of William Davies Shipley for seditious libel at the Shrewsbury Assizes in August 1784, where he managed to arrest judgement in the case on the grounds that the indictment was defective. In the 1790s, Erskine became an enthusiast for the French Revolution and lawyer for the defence in the treason trials of 1794, where he argued that the London Corresponding Society sought parliamentary reform through constitutional means. In 1770 Erskine married Frances (d. 1805), daughter of Daniel Moore, with whom he had four sons and four daughters. Hist P; ODNB.

William Faden (1749–1836), engraver and cartographer. His entry into map making came in 1773 through a partnership with the family of Thomas Jeffreys, St Martin's Lane. During the years of the American War of Independence he produced accurate maps and atlases of historical note. In 1783 he was appointed 'Geographer in Ordinary to his Majesty' and through contact with mapmakers throughout Europe he was able to supply government departments with maps and to commission new surveys. Faden published twenty-five maps of English counties during 1749–96. ODNB; COPAC.

note.note: The Revd James Falconer (1737–1809), archdeacon of Derby and prebendary of Lichfield, was brother-in-law to Thomas Pennant through his first marriage to Elizabeth (née Falconer). James and Elizabeth were children of James Faulkner of Chester, Lieutenant, and his wife Elizabeth (née Inge).

Thomas Fitzmaurice (1742–93), MP and industrialist, of Lleweni Hall, Denbighshire. He held the parliamentary seats of Calne, Wiltshire (1762–74), and Chipping Wycombe, Buckinghamshire (1774–80), and was sheriff of Denbighshire in 1781–2. In 1776 he purchased Lleweni, where he established a bleaching factory (for a contemporary engraving of the works, see here [accessed 5 April 2019]). His new calling as a linen merchant was an attempt to save himself from financial difficulties brought on by unprofitable estates in Ireland. A contemporary, Richard Twining, wrote that ‘The buildings which he has erected, and the machines and apparatus which he has placed in them are really astonishing’, and mentioned the shop which Fitzmaurice opened in Chester to sell the bleached linen. Hist P.
