persName.note: John Fitzpatrick, second Earl of Upper Ossory (1745–1818) and, from 1794, Baron Upper Ossory of Ampthill, Bedfordshire. In 1763 he travelled to Italy where he bought old paintings by the masters and commissioned further works from the Scottish history painter Gavin Hamilton. He was MP for Bedfordshire, 1767–94, and associated with Whig politicians including Horace Walpole and Charles James Fox. Hist P; Ilaria Bignamini and Clare Hornsby, Digging and Dealing in Eighteenth-Century Rome, Volumes 1 and 2 (London: Yale University Press, 2010), pp. 334–5.

George, Prince of Wales, later George IV (1762–1830), was the far-from-dutiful eldest son of George III. ‘[R]ather too fond of wine and women’, he had numerous affairs and constant debts. His refurbishing of his mansion, Carlton House, and work on the Marine Pavilion in Brighton were carried out at great expense, and his marriage to Mrs Maria Fitzherbert, a Roman Catholic, in December 1785 without the king's consent was illegal. George III's illness, which steadily worsened from the latter part of 1788, led to the Regency Bill of 12 February 1789, but the king was on the mend before his son needed to take over. George married his cousin Caroline, daughter of the duke of Brunswick, on 8 April 1795, with a view to settling his debts. ODNB.
Asaf was a medieval bishop and saint associated with north-east Wales, where the city of St Asaph and a number of other places bear his name.

John Greenwood (1727–1792), portrait painter and auctioneer. Born in Boston, Massachusetts, Greenwood worked in the Dutch colony of Surinam from 1752, at Amsterdam from 1758 and, from 1763, settled in London, where he became a respected and successful auctioneer, and an early member and, later, a director of the Incorporated Society of Artists of Great Britain. ODNB.

Joseph Gulston (1744/5–1786), book and art collector and connoisseur. A halfhearted politician, he twice held the parliamentary seat for Poole (1765–8 and 1780–4), but his main passion was book- and print-collecting, which he was enabled to do on inheriting a fortune of £250,000 in funds following the death of his father in 1766. Together with his wife, Elizabeth (née Stepney), an artist and etcher, he built a collection of books and prints, including 23,500 British and 18,000 foreign portraits, earning a reputation for rapaciousness. His extravagance gradually led to financial ruin, which he attempted to counteract by the sale in 1775 of his home, Ealing Grove in Middlesex (lavishly transformed into an Italianate villa following his marriage), and of his book and print collections (in 1783/4 and early 1786 respectively). He died on 16 July 1786. Hist P;ODNB; Gentleman's Magazine, LVI, part the second (1786), 622.

The diplomatist James Harris, first earl of Malmesbury (1746–1820), was responsible for British foreign policy from late 1786 and involved in negotiations relating to the Dutch Patriot Revolt of 1787. In February 1788 he became an ambassador, but his support of Fox during the 1789 Regency crisis briefly put him out of favour with Pitt. During the 1790s he was entrusted with several weighty diplomatic missions, however, including that to Paris from October 1796 and Lille between early July and mid-September 1797. ODNB.

Warren Hastings (1732–1818), appointed governor of Bengal in 1772, was a good linguist and showed an appreciation of Indian culture. He retired in 1785 but was impeached on 10 May 1787 largely due to the efforts of Edmund Burke, who held him responsible for the rapacious policies of the East India Company in its provinces, its exploitation of its allies, and its wars. The prosecution closed its case on 30 May 1791 but further prosecution speeches were delivered in 1794 before a large majority of the Lords voted ‘not guilty’ the following year. ODNB.

Jacob van Heemskerk (1567–1607), Dutch explorer, then admiral in command of the Dutch fleet at the 1607 battle of Gibraltar. In this battle, he successfully led an unexpected attack on the Spanish fleet, anchored at the Bay of Gibraltar, but was killed by a cannon ball wound to his leg.

C. Hoare & Co was founded by Sir Richard Hoare (1648–1719). His grandson, Henry Hoare (1705–1785) succeeded his father, also named Henry Hoare (1677–1725), as a partner of Hoare's Bank in 1726, but, in settling his Stourhead estate in Wiltshire on his grandson, Colt Hoare, stipulating that every contact between the latter and the bank be severed. The bank instead went to Colt's father, Richard Hoare. ODNB; Victoria Hutchings, Messrs Hoare, Bankers: A History of the Hoare Banking Dynasty (London: Constable, 2005).

Hans Holbein, the younger (1497/8–1543), artist, was born in southern Germany but had moved to Basel in Switzerland by 1515. Here, he was appointed town painter, and worked on wall paintings, notable for their representation of moving figures, as well as designs for Basel's printers, including his seriesDance of Death (1520s; published in the 1530s). He spent two periods in England, between 1526 and 1528, and again from 1531/2 to 1543, working on his second visit as painter to Henry VIII and for other patrons, including German Hanseatic merchants resident in London. The Hanseatic community commissioned two large canvas works from Holbein, The Triumph of Riches and The Triumph of Poverty, which are preserved only through seventeenth-century copies by Lucas Vorsterman. ODNB.

The etcher Wenceslaus Hollar (1607–77) was born in Prague, Bohemia, but lived in London between 1636 and 1644, and again from .1651. His English patrons included the publisher John Ogilby and the antiquary and herald Sir William Dugdale, and his work included etchings of women's costumes, including muffs; copies of paintings and drawings by artists such as Holbein and Leonardo da Vinci; topographical prints and maps; and drawings made during his a period spent at Tangier in 1669. ; Richard Pennington, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Etched Work of Wenceslaus Hollar 1607–1677 (Cambridge, 1982).

note.note: Samuel Hooper (d. 1793), bookseller, kept shops in the Strand, Ludgate Street, and then in High Holborn. Well-known as the publisher of Francis Grose’s The Antiquities of England and Wales, he hosted meetings between contemporary literary characters. Gentleman’s Magazine (February 1793), 'Obituaries', 190; Julie Coleman, ‘The Third Edition of Grose’s Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue: Bookseller’s Hackwork or Posthumous Masterpiece?’ in Julie Coleman and Anne McDermott, Historical Dictionaries and Historical Dictionary Research: Papers from the International Conference on Historical Lexicography and Lexicology, at the University of Leicester, 2002 (Tübingen, 2004), pp. 71–82, esp. pp. 78–9.

persName.note: Pennant took into his service as secretary, Thomas, son of 'Roger Jones, our parish clerk', on 1 January 1790. Jones also lent his services to Bull, through Pennant. See Literary life, p. 39; 1135, 1136. Bull mistakenly refers to Jones as 'J. Jones' in 1135.

Andrew Kippis (1725–95), Presbyterian minister and biographer. Born and brought up in the East Midlands, Kippis was appointed minister of the Presbyterian congregation at Princes Street, Westminster, in 1753 and remained there until his death. His biography of Cook, The life of captain James Cook was published in London in 1788. (Note that ODNB gives a publication date of 1778). ODNB.
Sir Henry Lee (1533–1611), courtier.

Charles Lennox (1735–1806), third duke of Richmond, third duke of Lennox, and duke of Aubigny in the French nobility. He followed a military career until 1760 and retained his interest in the military thereafter through his involvement from 1763 in the Sussex militia. He had a particular interest in art and created a sculpture gallery in his home, open to painters, carvers, sculptors and other artists ‘to whom the study of statuary might be useful’. ODNB. Lennox held the post of master-general of the Ordnance between 1782 and 1783 and again from 1784 to 1795.

Daniel Lysons (1727–1800), physician, born in Gloucestershire. Educated at Oxford from 1745, he was licensed as a physician in 1756, and worked at Gloucester before moving to Bath in 1770. His experience as physician to the infirmary in Gloucester preceded an appointment to the Bath General Hospital in 1780. Lysons's publications on the treatment of fevers, both of which ran to second editions, were entitled An essay upon the effects of camphire and calomel in continual fevers: Illustrated by several cases. To which is added, an occasional observation upon the modern practice of inoculation. And from the whole is deduced an argument in support of the opinion, that the alimentary canal is the principal seat of a fever (London: E. Reeve, in the Savoy, 1771; 2nd edn., 1773) and Practical essays upon intermitting fevers: dropsies, diseases of the liver, the epilepsy, the colic, dysenteric fluxes, and the operation of calomel (Bath: S. Hazard, 1772; 2nd edn., 1783). Married, he had no children, and left his fortune to his nephew of the same name, the topographer, Daniel Lysons (1762–1834). ODNB; COPAC.
Lives 2 miles from Mold.

George Macartney, Earl Macartney (1737–1806), diplomatist and colonial governor. His numerous diplomatic posts involved work as envoy to Russia, Chief Secretary in Ireland, Governor of Madras, an embassy to Peking, a mission to Verona to the exiled Louis the 18th, and the post of governor of the Cape. The embassy to China was undertaken for the joint purposes of the East India Company and the government, who wished to improve conditions for trade with China. A party of 94, including many experts, sailed on the Lion on 26 September 1792 with samples of the best of British manufactures, which were presented to the Emperor of China on 14 September 1793. Macartney was unable to ensure a treaty of trade and friendship and was handed his dismissal on 3 October 1793. Nonetheless, he was raised to an earldom in the Irish peerage in 1794 following his return via the southern Chinese province of Canton. ODNB.

Humphrey Minchin (1727–96), of Holywell, Droxford, Hampshire. He served the borough of Okehampton, Devonshire, on the interest of Lord Spencer until 1790, but was obliged to renounce his seat at the dissolution of parliament in that year, following an earlier decision to support Pitt against his patron's wishes. Later that year he was returned for the borough of Bossiney, also in Devonshire. Minchin repeatedly (but without success) applied for an Irish peerage, noting his connections and property in Ireland. More profitably he was granted military posts, including that of lieutenant-colonel of the North Hampshire militia from 1793 until his death. Hist P.

Politician and art collector Humphry Morice (1723–85) inherited from his second cousin, Sir William Morice, third baronet, a picture collection including paintings of recent British heroes, commissioned from Venetian and Bolognese artists. The inheritance also brought the boroughs of Launceston and Newport in Cornwall under his control, but much of his time was spent in Naples, where he worked on enlarging his art collection and where he died on 18 October 1785. Hist P;ODNB.

note.note: Sir Thomas Mostyn, sixth baronet (1776–1831) of Mostyn, Flintshire, and Gloddaeth, Caernarvonshire. The only son of Sir Roger Mostyn, 5th baronet, he succeeded his father on 26 July 1796. In the election to represent Flintshire, held on 8 November 1796, he defeated John Lloyd and Lloyd Kenyon by 52 to 30 and 10 votes respectively; but was replaced by John Lloyd on petition on 12 June 1797. On 8 November 1799 Lloyd vacated his seat and was replaced by Sir Thomas Mostyn, who continued to represent Flintshire until 17 April 1831. Born on 20 October 1776, Mostyn would have been 20 years old when he first entered Parliament, and therefore not of age, as Pennant mentions in 1196. Hist P. Correspondence relating to Mostyn's election in 1796 is found in NLW, Glynne of Hawarden, letters dated 3, 7, 11 August 1796.

Sir William Musgrave, sixth baronet (1735–1800), administrator, print collector and antiquary. Active in both the Royal Society and the Society of Antiquaries, he was known as one of the foremost collectors of engraved British portrait prints, with a collection to rival that of Horace Walpole. It was this collection, alongside those of Walpole and James West, that formed the bases of Granger, A biographical history of England. Musgrave also compiled lists and indexes, including a ‘General catalogue of engraved portraits both British and foreign’. ODNB.

Treadway Russell Nash (1725–1811), Church of England clergyman and antiquary. He lived at Bevere near Worcester from 1758 and published Collections for the history of Worcestershire, containing many engravings, mostly by James Ross of Worcester, in two volumes in 1781 and 1782. He bequeathed paintings and engravings collected on his grand tour (1749–51) to Worcester College (where they remain), and personal papers to Eastnor Castle, but eight grangerized volumes of the Collections, sold in 1901, were subsequently destroyed in a house fire. Pennant's close relationship with him is evinced from several references to visits to him at Bevere in the Pennant-Bull correspondence. ODNB.

persName.note: John Nichols (1745–1826), printer and writer. He became proprietor of the printing house of William Bowyer on the latter’s death in 1777. He purchased a share in the Gentleman’s Magazine in 1778 and by 1792 held entire editorial control. Under his editorship the magazine doubled in size and increased its emphasis on biographical material. ODNB s.n. Nichols family.

Louis Philippe Joseph duc d’Orléans (1747–93) led a dissipated life but became interested in politics in the late 1780s. He was a critic of the first Assembly of Notables in 1787 and of the second Assembly in 1788. Elected to both the Estates General and the National Convention, he voted for the execution of Louis XVI, before presumed links to Dumouriez led to his own arrest and execution. He was sent on a mission to Britain between October 1789 and July 1790, where he enjoyed a friendship with George, Prince of Wales. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 376; Tom Ambrose, Godfather of the Revolution: The Life of Phillippe Égalité, Duc D'Orléans (London: Peter Owen, 2008).

John Palmer (1742–1818), theatre proprietor and postal reformer. Theatre work between London and Bristol convinced Palmer of the need for improved communications, involving the replacement of the post boy with a small cart by mail coaches equipped with a box watched over by an armed guard and able to ensure the prompt dispatch of mail. The coaches were exempt from tolls and granted priority over other vehicles so that the momentum of their journeys was sustained. There were differences with the post office, but Palmer shouldered the cost of the reform, in which Pitt had shown an interest. In August 1786, the post office appointed him on suitable terms but his position was not confirmed until July 1789. Pennant was infuriated by the issue of the mail coaches, and expressed his views in A letter ... on mail-coaches (1792). ODNB.

note.note: Richard Pennant, Baron Penrhyn (c.1737–1808), a slate manufacturer and politician, who shared with Thomas Pennant descent from a fifteenth-century abbot of Basingwerk. Both Richard Pennant's parents inherited substantial plantations in Jamaica, and Richard added to the family wealth the Penrhyn estate in Caernarvonshire, through his marriage to Anne Susannah Warburton (1745–1816) in 1765. A member of parliament for Liverpool (1767–80; 1784–90), he opposed William Wilberforce’s campaign for the abolition of slavery in 1787, and the following year spoke in the House of Commons in defence of slave traders and planters. In 1782 the medieval Penrhyn Hall was remodelled by Samuel Wyatt. For correspondence between Richard Pennant and Thomas Pennant see WCRO, TP 328 /1–3, c.1796–8; and NLW 2594E, Carnarvonshire [sic] folder.

Thomas Pennant, junior (1780–1845), the son of Thomas Pennant and his second wife, Ann (née Mostyn). He became rector of Weston Turville, Bucks, married Caroline, daughter of Thomas Griffith of Rhual, and died without issue. ODNB; Burke (1836), III, p. 34.

persName.note: Charles Rainsford (1728–1809), of Soho Square, Middlesex, was a professional army officer, who also held three different parliamentary seats during his career, including that of the borough of Newport in Cornwall between 1790 and 1796. He made several promotions through the ranks, from brigadier-general (1762) to major-general (1777), lieutenant-general (1782) and general (1796). During his career he saw service at home, including the office of governor of Chester, 1776–96, as well as service abroad, notably in Gibraltar between 1793 and March 1795. He was a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries and the Royal Society, and left a substantial number of manuscripts, including papers and letters related to his time in service abroad. Hist P; ODNB .

William Richardson (fl. 1778–1812), known as 'William Richardson Junior', probably followed his father into trade as a print dealer and publisher. Alongside John Thane, he became a leading specialist in portrait prints, and his series of facsimiles of rare early British portraits were highly valued by extra-illustrators. The title of his catalogue, Richardson’s Catalogue. A Collection of English and Foreign Portraits, topography and historical prints … with prices affixed (London, 1791), corroborates Pennant's favourable impression of him (see 1118). COPAC; http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=109975 [accessed 24 September 2018].

John Keyse Sherwin (bap. 1751, d.1790), designer and engraver, was the son of a shipyard labourer. His talent for drawing was discovered by William Mitford, on whose estate near Petworth, Sussex, Sherwin worked as a gardener in 1769. This led to study in London, where he was taught to engrave by Francis Bartolozzi, with whom he stayed until 1774. Contemporaries mention his ‘vanity’ and ‘impudent assurance’. He died in straitened circumstances on 20 September 1790. ODNB.

Pitt appointed George John Spencer, second Earl Spencer (1758–1834), to the post of first lord of the Admiralty on 17 December 1794. He was particularly influential and successful in his choice of commanders for significant theatres in the war against Revolutionary France. ODNB.

William Davies Shipley (1745–1826), son of Dr Jonathan Shipley, Bishop of St Asaph, was appointed Dean of the cathedral of St Asaph in 1774. Through his marriage to the daughter and heiress of Ellis Yonge, Bryn Yorkin, near Wrexham, his family became one of the wealthiest in north Wales. In December 1784 he was tried for seditious libel after publishing an edition of a reformist pamphlet by Sir William Jones but, following a hearing and a trial at Wrexham and Shrewsbury, was exonerated at the King's Bench in December. He arrived home to a rapturous welcome from the people of north-east Wales, but was viewed with suspicion by Government sympathisers, including Pennant, thereafter. ODNB; Michael J. Franklin, ‘Sir William Jones, the Celtic Revival and the Oriental Renaissance’, in Gerard Carruthers and Alan Rawes (eds.), English Romanticism and the Celtic World (Cambridge, 2003), pp. 20–37; A. Cynfael Lake, ‘Rhai Ystyriaethau Pellach Ynghylch Awduraeth Yr Anterliwt Goll’, NLWJ, XXVII, no. 3 (1992), 337–49.

Thomas Skinner (1737–1806) became alderman for the ward of Queenhithe in the City of London in 1785 and was appointed lord mayor of London in 1794. He was active in reforming the conditions of prisons and some aspects of the inhumane treatment of convicted criminals in London. His lucrative career as an auctioneer began in the late 1750s and, in spite of a lack of powers of eloquence and rhetoric, an obituary noted that he achieved 'an unprecedented degree of celebrity, and ... acquired more wealth than any other individual in that profession'. The monthly magazine and British register, XXI, Part I (1806), 177–9.

Benjamin Smith (d. 1833) may be the engraver to whom Pennant and Bull refer in letters 1110 and 1118. Possibly a pupil of Bartolozzi, he worked for John Boydell, for whom he produced, among other things, engravings of paintings by British artists for (London: Boydell & Co., 1802). He was based at various addresses in Somers Town, London. .

Benjamin Stillingfleet (1702–71), botanist and writer. His close friendship with Pennant is attested by the fact that he left a small number of his manuscripts to him, although the majority were ordered to be burnt. ODNB. His correspondence with Pennant between 1761 and 1771 is found at WCRO, CR 2017/TP367/1–17.

E. Stringer, an artist active in the Lichfield area in the 1780s. His work includes 'A Perspective View of a part of the City of Lichfield', and 'View near Lichfield, with large Willow Tree', both dated 1785. He is recommended to Richard Gough by Richard Greene, writing from Lichfield on 3 December 1786, and referred to again by the latter in a letter of 9 July 1787 to Gough, where his work on 'drawings of the tombs in Bromsgrove Church' is mentioned. Nichol, Illustrations of the Literary History of the Eighteenth Century, VI, p. 325; Catalogue of Maps, Prints, Drawings, Etc. Forming the Geographical and Topographical Collection Attached to the Library of His Late Majesty King George the Third, and Presented by his Majesty King George the Fourth to the British Museum (2 vols., London: British Museum, 1829), I, p. 616; John Britton, Historical and Descriptive Account of the Cathedrals of Winchester, Lichfield, and Oxford; With Numerous Engravings: forming Volume III. of The Cathedral Antiquities (London, 1836), p. 69.

John Thane (1747?–1818), dealer in prints, medals and manuscripts. He began publishing regular catalogues of his retail stock of prints during the early 1770s, but was also an important collector in his own right. His three-volume British autography: a collection of facsimiles of the handwriting of royal and illustrious personages, with their authentic portraits was probably published during 1788–93. ODNB; Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 78.

John Turton (1735–1806), physician, began studying medicine in 1761 at Leiden and graduated BM from University College, Oxford, in 1762 and DM in 1767. Elected fellow of the Royal Society in 1763 and of the Royal College of Physicians in 1768, he settled in London from 1767 and soon had a large practice, including the queen's household, the queen herself and, from 1797, the king and the prince of Wales. ODNB.

note.note: George Vertue (1684–1756), engraver and antiquary. He was official engraver to the Society of Antiquaries from 1717 until his death, a researcher into the history of art in Britain, and an independent print publisher. ODNB; Martin Myrone, 'Graphic antiquarianism in eighteenth-century Britain: the career and reputation of George Vertue (1684–1756)', in idem and Peltz (eds.), Producing the Past, pp. 35–54.

Horatio [Horace] Walpole, fourth earl of Orford (1717–97), of Strawberry Hill, Middlesex, author, politician and patron of the arts. He was son of the Whig politician and prime minister Sir Robert Walpole, first earl of Orford, and held parliamentary seats between 1741 and 1768. From 1746 he made his home in a small house at Windsor, which he transformed into a 'little Gothic castle', under the name of Strawberry Hill, adding new rooms, including a library, in 1754. His interest in portraiture was sparked by his acquaintance, from 1743, with George Vertue, and led to the publication of Anecdotes of Painting in England (2 vols., 1762; vol. 3, 1764), a work which he prized highly among his oeuvre. Hist P; ODNB.

persName.note: John Wingrave (1729–1807) worked as a bookbinder from various London addresses, mostly in Fleet Street, c. 1767–1805. He was an acquaintance of the freed slave Ignatius Sancho, who wrote several letters to him and to his wife and son. Exeter Working Papers in Book History https://bookhistory.blogspot.com/2017/04/london-1775-1800-w-z.html [accessed 4 September 2018]; Brycchan Carey, 'Ignatius Sancho's Friends and Family' http://brycchancarey.com/sancho/friends.htm [accessed 4 September 2018].

Sir Richard Worsley (1751–1805), seventh baronet of Appuldurcombe House, near Wroxall on the Isle of Wight. Worsley completed The History of the Isle of Wight (1781), begun by his father and grandfather. He sat as MP for Newport on the Isle of Wight intermittently between 1774 and 1801, resigning in 1784 to travel to the continent, whence he returned in 1788. Whilst abroad, he acquired a collection of statues, reliefs and gems, including Greek marbles, bringing it back to Appuldurcombe and publishing an illustrated description of it in Museum Worsleyanum (2 parts; 1798, 1802). He spent another period abroad as envoy to the Venetian republic, 1793–7. Hist P; ODNB.

note.note: Henry Penruddocke Wyndham (1736–1819), topographer. He set out on the grand tour in 1765, aged 29. Convinced of the superiority of the English way of life, he toured Wales in 1774, publishing an anonymous account of this journey, A Gentleman’s Tour through Monmouthshire, and Wales, the following year. He revisited Wales in 1777, accompanied by the Swiss watercolour painter Samuel Hieronymous Grimm, and in 1781 published Tour through Monmouthshire and Wales. He was elected a fellow of the Society Antiquaries in 1777 and of the Royal Society 1783, and was member of Parliament for Wiltshire, 1795–1812. ODNB; Hist P.

persName.note: An Italian painter whose early work included a painting at Florence of the whole history of the Passion, a work completed alongside his brother Taddeo, also an artist, in just four days. In 1574, having left Rome, where he worked for pope Gregory XIII, Zucchero reached England. Work carried out there included portraits of Elizabeth I and of Mary, Queen of Scots, later engraved by George Vertue, together with a self-portrait. He also copied 'The Triumphs of Riches and Poverty', two large pictures painted in distemper by Hans Holbein, the younger, in the hall of the Easterling merchants at the Hanseatic League's Steelyard in London. Horace Walpole, Anecdotes of painting in England (London: Thomas Farmer at Strawberry Hill, 1762), I, pp. 83, 140–3.
George Vanden Bempde (1720–92), 3rd Marquess of Annandale, owner of Hackness Hall, a country house a few miles west of Scarborough. He was declared a lunatic by an inquest in Chancery in 1748.
Mary Hartley (c. 1738–1803), Bath-based artist and bluestocking correspondent, and daughter of David Hartley,
Sir Henry Carr Ibbotson (d. 1825), of Denton Park, Otley.

Hugh Percy [formerly Smithson] (bap. 1712, d. 1786), first duke of Northumberland and Whig politician, influential on account of extensive possessions and a large income income (largely derived from coal mining). He married Elizabeth Percy [née Seymour], who inherited the barony of Percy. Percy's close association with John Stuart, third earl of Bute, was viewed with suspicion by some contemporaries, with one angrily dubbing him 'Bute's Lieutenant'. He died on 6 June 1786, with an income of c. £50,000 per annum, and was succeeded to the dukedom by his eldest son, also named Hugh. ODNB.

Elizabeth Percy (née Seymour; 1716–1776), duchess of Northumberland and diarist. She married Hugh Percy, first duke of Northumberland in 1740 and inherited the barony of Percy from her father in 1750. She was a lady of the bedchamber to Queen Charlotte and was a powerful political host and patron of artists and writers. ODNB.
Gabriel Piozzi (1741–1809), musician. Second husband of Hester Thrale (nee Salusbury).

John Ker, 3rd Duke of Roxburghe (1740–1804). Ker was born in London; his mother was Essex Ker (d.1764), daughter of Sir Roger Mostyn, third baronet. Roxburghe held several court positions and was a friend of George III, however his first concern seems to have been his hobby as a book collector. ODNB.

Macleod, Norman, 20th of Dunvegan, Skye landowner, soldier, and Chief of Clan Macleod. (1754-1801) Educated at St Andrews and Oxford Universities, brought up by his mother in England, before being sent to lodge with his unsavoury grandfather near St Andrews (also Norman Macleod, 19th of Dunvegan, An droch dhuine, 1706-72) , who had nearly bankrupted the family. In 1771 he returned to Skye with his mother and sought to redress the crisis on his estates, earning the popularity of his tenants and impressing visitors like Pennant (1772) and Dr Johnson (1773). in 1775 married Mary Mackenzie and purchased an army commission, sailing to America and later India where he served in the Black Watch with distinction in the campaign against Hyder Ali. In 1789 he returned to Britain and entered parliament as MP for Invernessshire. In 1791 he broke with Pitt and Dundas and became a Foxite Whig reformer, joining the Friends of the People and becoming a spokesman for the Scottish reform movement. But he was increasingly frustrated and lost the fortune he had made in India, dying in drunken penury in 1801 in Guernsay and leaving the Dunvegan estates heavily indebted.

Sir Alexander Macdonald of Sleat (1744-95): Skye landowner, chief of the Macdonalds of Sleat having succeeded his brother Sir James in 1766. In 1776 he was made Lord Macdonald in the Irish Peerage. Educated at Eton, he served in the Coldstream Guards and married Elizabeth Bosville of Gunthwaite in Yorkshire, implementing an ambitious programme of improvement on his estates in Skye and North Uist and raising the rents, thereby causing widespread emigration. Macdonald hosted Johnson and Boswell at his house in Armadale in 1773, although the visit was not a success. In his original journal, Boswell wrote that he and Johnson were 'full of the old Highland spirit, and were dissatisfied at hearing of racked rents and emigration; and finding a chief not surrounded by his clan'. They satirically dubbed him 'Sir Sawney'. Although Boswell expunged most of his more offensive remarks from his published Tour, Sir Alexander wrote him an offensive letter in November 1785 which nearly led to a duel between the two men.

MacLeod, John, 11th Laird of Raasay (1714-86), m. Jane McQueen, fathered 10 daughters and 3 sons. Entertained Johnson and Boswell in Sept 1773. Of Raasay Johnson said 'This is truly the patriarchal life. This is what we came to find'. [TH, p. 154] Macleod corresponded with Boswell and Johnson over the latter's claim that he acknowledged Maclean of Dunvegan as his Chief: in fact, the Macleods of Raasay were a different branch of the clan, which Johnson acknowledged in a letter to the Edinburgh press, and corrected in subsquent editions. Raasay was pleased and later dined with Johnson in London.

Dr James Stuart (1700-1789) minister of Killin and translator of the New Testament into Scottish Gaelic for the SSPCK (pub. 1767), married to Elizabeth Drummond. Father of John Stuart of Killin and Luss, Pennant's friend and correspondent.
Arthur Murphy (1727-1805), actor, playwright and journalist, who introduced Samuel Johnson to the Thrales in 1765.

Reverend Professor John Walker (1731-1803), Church of Scotland minister of Moffat and Regius Professor of Natural History at Edinburgh (1779–1803). Walker toured the Hebrides in 1764 to produce a report for the Society in Scotland for the Propagation of Christian Knowledge, and completed four subsequent journeys by 1786. He was a correspondent of Linnaeus and Pennant, and expanded the collections of the natural history museum at Edinburgh, though almost all of his significant works were published posthumously. ODNB.
The Scottish lawyer and writer Henry Mackenzie (1745-1831) published his landmark novel of sensibility, The Man of Feeling, in 1771.
Henry Dundas (1742-1811), Viscount Melville, Scottish lawyer and Tory politician.
Sir John Clerk of Penicuik (1676-1755), lawyer and musician.

David Riccio (d.1566), originally from Savoy, was a musician and confidant of Mary Stuart, queen of Scots. He was murdered by members of the Scottish nobility as part of a plot to destabilise Mary's reign. ODNB.

Henry Stuart, duke of Albany (1545–67), styled Lord Darnley until 1565, was a consort of Mary, queen of Scots and oldest surviving son of the earl of Lennox. He married Mary in 1565 and was murdered in 1567. The identity of Darnley's killer has never been discovered; he was unpopular both among the Scottish nobility and within the queen's household. ODNB.
William Forbes, (c.1670-1745), first regius professor of Law at Glasgow University, author of The Institutes of the Law of Scotland (1772-1730).
Heretor at Luss c.1773, assisted Stuart with his Gaelic Bible translations.
Signatory of a poem about Ben Lomond, engraved on a window pane in the inn at Tarbet, often commented on and transcribed by travellers.

Lord Frederick Campbell of Ardencaple, (1729-1816). Second son of 4th Duke of Argyll, MP for Glasgow Burghs (1761-1780) and Argyllshire (1780-1799). Married Mary Meredith of Coombe Bank in 1770 (Lady Frederick Campbell, after whom Pennant's ship was named.)
Unidentified; engaged to Robert Ramsay in 1774.

Willielma Campbell, Viscountess Glenorchy (1741-1786) was a benefactor of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge. She endowed a chapel at Strathfillan at the request of John Stuart of Killin, as well as several other churches around Scotland and England. After her husband's death in 1771 she resided at Holyroodhouse, returning to Taymouth during the summer. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr Campbell of Lochdochart (fl.1774).
George III (1738–1820), king of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and king of Hanover.
Farmer, proprietor of Achessan in Breadalbane (fl.1774).
Agricultural improver and resident at Auchlyne, Glendochart (fl.1774).
Involved in the preservation of the roe deer population in Glenlyon.
Wife to Reverend McIntyre of Glenorchy (1747-1797).
Fowler who accompanies Pennant on the 1772 Voyage to the Hebrides, name unknown.
Groom who accompanies Pennant on the 1772 Voyage, name unknown.

note.note: Henry Seymour Conway, referred to by contemporaries as General Conway (1719–1795), showed outright opposition to the war against the American colonies from its beginning, presented motions in favour of peace on 27 February 1782, and argued in November 1782 that the provisional articles made with America should make independence unconditional. ODNB; Horace Walpole, The correspondence of Horace Walpole, with George Montague, esq., [and others] (new edn., 3 vols: London: Henry Colburn, 1837), III, p. 306.

George Augustus Eliott (1717–1790), was the steady and capable leader of a small garrison at Gibraltar from May 1777 until Spain and France abandoned their efforts to capture the territory and lifted their siege of it on 5 February 1783. Eliott was made a knight of the Bath in 1783 and first Baron Heathfield of Gibraltar on 14 June 1787. ODNB.

persName.note: Sir Thomas Urquhart of Cromarty (1611–60), author and translator reputed for his translation of Rabelais. Pennant, who describes Urquhart as 'a second Rabelais, and the best translator of that extravagant author', refers to and quotes from his work in his account of 'The Life of James Crichton, of Clunie, Commonly Called the Admirable Crichton', A tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd edn., 1774), appendix no. III, pp. 315–16, 321, 324–6.

Richard Gibson (1605/1615?–1690) was known as Dwarf Gibson because of his diminutive height. A miniature painter himself, he was the subject of several portraits, including a double portrait with his wife in oils by Peter Lely, c.1650–1660, formerly at Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, Texas; further oils after Peter Lely, at NPG; and a self-portrait in chalk, c.1658, at the British Museum. ODNB.

Robert Dudley, first Earl of Leicester (1532/3–1588), a favourite of Elizabeth I. Sixty-five portraits of Dudley are lodged at the National Portrait Gallery. See https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp02686/robert-dudley-1st-earl-of-leicester?search=sas&sText=robert+dudley [accessed 4 July 2018].
(1745–1820), poet and biographer. ODNB.
John Harris (fl. 1700–1740), Northamptonshire-born engraver and draughtsman. ODNB.

note.note: Pennant's uncle, John Mytton of Halston (1737–83), was the son of John Mytton and Mary-Elizabeth, daughter of Henry Davenport of Davenport House, Shropshire. He married Rebecca, daughter of Robert Piggott, Chetwynd. John Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Commoners of Great Britain and Ireland (London, 1835), II, p. 522.

persName.note: (1661–1725), army officer and historian. ODNB.
Frances Crewe's coachman in Bala

note.note: William Petty, second earl of Shellburne and first marquess of Lansdowne (1737–1805), was prime minister from 4 July to 2 April 1783. He was brother to Thomas Fitzmaurice. ODNB; Hist P.

persName.note: Charles James Fox (1749-1806), whig statesman. Although he spent almost his entire career in opposition, Fox's political influence both on his contemporaries and after his death was significant, to the extent that his allies and followers frequently identified as foxite rather than whig. Fox's views tended to be radical in the whig sense: he supported the cause of American Independence and was an enemy of George III, whom he perceived to be a would-be tyrant bent on strengthening his executive powers at the expense of the legislature and constitution.
‘Peter Goodwin, of Llanrwst’ listed as a ‘Shopkeeper, Dealer and Chapman’, as well as leadmine shareholder, in a bankruptcy notice in The London Gazette, July 1806.

Lady Jane Stuart (1742–1828), daughter of John Stuart, third earl of Bute, and Mary Wortley Montagu, Baroness Mount Stuart of Wortle. She married George Macartney in 1768. ODNB s.n. George Macartney, Earl Macartney.

note.note: Sir Eyre Coote (1726–1783), army officer who served with the British forces in India between 1755 and 1762, subsequently taking up parliamentary seats for Leicester, 1768–74, and Poole, 1774– 80. He later returned to military service, and died on 27 April 1783 at Madras. ODNB; Hist P.

persName.note: Sir William Draper (1721–1787), army officer, was involved in the War of the Austrian Succession from 1744 to 1748, as lieutenant-colonel commandant in the East Indies in 1758, in a strike against the Spanish base at Manila during the Seven Years' War, and as lieutenant-governor of Minorca, shortly before its invasion by French and Spanish forces in August 1781. Controversy between him and his senior on the island lead to the end of his career following a general court martial between November 1782 and January 1783. He was in debt by £6000 at his death. ODNB.

Thomas Gage (1719/20–1787), army officer, was appointed military governor of Massachusetts in 1774. After his failure to control the American militias at the battles of Lexington and Concord in April 1775, he left for England, but failed to command a fitting reward from the government there in spite of his twenty years service in colonial America. ODNB.
French painter of Labours of Hercules mentioned by Paton and Pennant, possibly mentioned by Horace Walpole.
Dr Steedman (fl.1775).
A chief of the Colquhouns, Humphry was killed in 1592 while trying to repel an incursion by the Macgregors and Macfarlanes.
from "The picturesque beauties of Shakspeare, being a selection of scenes, from the works of that great author: engraved under the direction of Charles Taylor "

note.note: William Shakespeare (1564-1616), playwright and poet.

persName.addName: Owen Glendower, Glendower, Glendwr, Owen Glendowe

note.note: Owain Glyndwr (c.1359–c.1416), Welsh ruler and the last native Welshman to hold the title Prince of Wales.

persName.note: Rev. Hope Wynne Eyton (1754–1824) of Leeswood, was vicar of Mold. John Burke and John Bernard Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Landed Gentry of Great Britain & Ireland (London: Henry Colburn, 1847), I, p. 392.

note.note: Margaret (née Roberts), daughter of a Shropshire clergyman, was the god-daughter of Margaret, wife of Roger Wynne of Tower, Flintshire. She took the name Roberts Wynne on inheriting Tower c. 1780. On 10 November 1783 she married Hope Eyton, who, in his turn, added 'Wynne' to his name, as the new owner of Tower. See John Burke and John Bernard Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Landed Gentry of Great Britain & Ireland (London: Henry Colburn, 1847), I, p. 392; and here [accessed 17 June 2019].

persName.note: The last Queen of Cyprus, reigning from 1474 to 1489. Portraits of her were painted by Durer, Titian, Bellini and Giorgione.

note.note: For letters patent relating to Benjamin Wright[e] issued in the name of Queen Anne in 1705, instructing that his person be put in the custody of Sir Benjamin Hudson and his estate in the management of the latter and of his son Nathan Wright[e], see Wellcome Library, MS 7467, at here [accessed 17 June 2019].

persName.note: Son of his namesake, first earl of Chatham, and his wife Hester (née Grenville), William Pitt, the younger (1759–1806), was first elected to Parliament in 1781. The following year he was appointed chancellor of the exchequer, but he refused an offer to lead the ministry, repeatedly made to him by George III during the early months of 1783, choosing instead to resign from office and focus his efforts on parliamentary reform. In the general election held at the beginning of 1784, he won a majority, which ushered in his first premiership, lasting until 1801. He was reinstated as prime minister during 1804–6 but, according to a contemporary, ‘Nothing ever was more disastrous in every way than the second career of Mr Pitt—as much so as his first was brilliant’. Hist P; ODNB.

Mutton, Sir Peter (1562?–1637), lawyer and politician, was the only son of John Mutton (d. 1566), head of a gentry family established in Rhuddlan, Flintshire, since the fourteenth century, but hailing originally from Shropshire. His mother was Annwen (d. after 1593), daughter of Griffith ap Ieuan ap Llewelyn Vaughan of Llanerch, in the township of Lleweni, near St Asaph, Denbighshire. Most of Mutton's legal career was spent rising through the Welsh courts. ODNB; D. Jenkins, ‘Llythyr Syr Peter Mutton, 1565–1637’, NLWJ, 5/3 (1948), 220–1.

note.note: Sir Benjamin Rudyerd or Rudyard (1572–1658), politician and poet. A contemporary remarked of his contributions to parliamentary debate that, although he showed 'no want of affection to be eloquent, ... his expression was thought languid as the conclusion was inept.' Hist P; ODNB.

Constantine John Phipps, second Baron Mulgrave in the peerage of Ireland and Baron Mulgrave in the peerage of Great Britain (1744–92), naval officer and politician, served in parliament between 1768 and 1790. Phipps was an old schoolfellow of Joseph Banks, with whom he visited Newfoundland and Labrador in 1766. Hist P; ODNB.

persName.note: Thomas Merrick or Meyrick (dates unknown), owner of Bush House near Pembroke Dock.

Archibald James Edward Douglas [formerly Stewart], Baron Douglas (1748-1827) was born in Paris to Sir John Stewart of Grandtully and Lady Jane Douglas. He was nephew and heir of Archibald Douglas, duke of Douglas and thus to the Douglas estates which had passed to the seventh duke of Hamilton. Douglas's successful litigation against the duke of Hamilton in pursuit of his inheritance became known as the Douglas Cause, and became one of the most famous legal affairs of the eighteenth century, enjoying massive popular support in Scotland. Douglas later became MP for Forfarshire, and suffered financial losses in the collapse of the Douglas-Heron of Ayr bank in 1772. ODNB
Rosemund Mountain (c.1768–1841), nationally famous singer and actor. She was primarily associated with Covent Garden but made several tours of theatres in Britain and Ireland.
James Colquhoun (1774-1836) of Rossdhu, succeeded his father as third baronet of Luss in 1805. He was husband to the writer Janet, née Sinclair.
(1615-1673) Italian Painter of allegories and landscapes, whose neo-classical depictions of place shaped the late eighteenth-century taste for the picturesque.
Sir Alexander Livingston-Campbell of Ardkinglas (d.1810).

John Dyer (bap. 1699, d. 1757) was a Welsh-born poet chiefly known for his Pindaric ode 'Grongar Hill' (1726) and The Fleece (1757), a georgic poem describing the wool industry from field to imperial commodity.

Lady Mary Lockhart Ross (1777-1842), proprietor of Bonnington, Lanarkshire, her estate encompassed the Falls of Clyde and were frequently visited by travellers. Lady Ross constructed a viewing gallery and other amenities to enhance enjoyment of the falls.
(fl. 1807) Possibly resident at the house and estate of Bonnington.
Travelling companion of the author of a 'Diary of a trip from Edinburgh to Iona, 1807', (National Library of Scotland, Acc. 8625).

Matthew Gregory Lewis (1775-1818), was a poet, playright and novelist often called 'Monk' Lewis in reference to his 1796 gothic novel, The Monk. He was a frequent visitor to John Campbell, fifth Duke of Argyll, at Inveraray Castle and was a friend of his daughter, Lady Charlotte Campbell. In later life he visited his plantations in Jamaica and toured Europe, visiting Byron and Shelley in Geneva. ODNB; D. L. Macdonald, Monk Lewis: A Critical Biography, (London, Buffalo, Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2000).

Lady Charlotte Susan Maria Campbell, later Bury (1775–1861), daughter of John Campbell, fifth duke of Argyll, was a novelist and diarist, known for Flirtation (1827). Her circle included writers such as Walter Scott, Susan Ferrier and Matthew Lewis. In early life she was resident at the family seat at Inveraray Castle. ODNB.
Chamberlain of the Duke of Argyll from 1792.
(fl. 1807) Described as an English baronet who visited the Hebrides in 1807.

Erasmus Darwin (1731-1802), physician and naturalist; author of the poetic works The Loves of the Plants (1789), The Botanic Garden (1791), and The Economy of Vegetation. He was a founding member of the Lunar Society of Birmingham. ODNB.
(fl.1807) Resident at Glasgow and possibly connected to the College there. A Professor Anderson is also mentioned by Boswell.
(fl. 1807) Resident at Glasgow.
Thomas Robert Hay-Drummon, eleventh earl of Kinnoull.
Landlord of Ulva, acted as guide for trips to Staffa and Fingal's Cave.

The unnamed Schoolmaster at Iona, who also acted as a guide for tourists. Boswell described him as 'a stupid fellow' who 'calls himself the descendent of St Columba's cousin'. His family had until recently held 10 acres of land on Iona rent free, till it was lately taken from them by the Duke of Argyll.
Thomas Carmichael, fifth earl of Hyndford.

Mary Stewart, queen of Scots (1542–1587), was born in Linlithgow Palace to James V of Scotland and Mary of Guise. As a condition of French military aid against the English, Mary was sent to France in 1548 to be betrothed to the dauphin, later François II. She lived with the French royal family for thirteen years, and was married to François in 1558, two years before his death. Mary returned to Scotland in 1561, where, as a Catholic of predominantly French upbringing, she faced resistance from the newly protestant establishment. In neighbouring England, tensions arose around Mary's apparent position as successor to Elizabeth, and efforts were made to prevent her from strengthening her dynastic claim through marriage. She eventually married Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley, another claimant to the English crown, who was murdered by unknown hands in 1567. Mary was subsequently abducted by the earl of Bothwell whom she then married. The marriage worsened Mary's standing among an already restless Scottish nobility, who forced Bothwell into exile and imprisoned Mary in Lochleven Castle, where she was forced to abdicate. Mary escaped in 1568 but the forces of her supporters were defeated at the Battle of Langside and she fled to England, where she was again imprisoned until her execution for treason in 1587. ODNB.
(1739–1806) Founder and proprietor of the cotton-manufactory and village at New Lanark.

John Hunter (1728-93), surgeon and anatomist, was brother to the founder of the Hunterian Museum, William Hunter (1718-83). He was appointed Surgeon to King George III in 1776 and Surgeon General in 1789.
Soldier posted at Dumbarton Castle c.1795, who is also mentioned as having acted as a tour guide.

note.note: (1700-1759) Governor of Dumbarton Castle between 1737 and 1759. www.thepeerage.com.

persName.note: (1516–1571) Regent of Scotland and keeper of Dumbarton Castle. ODNB.

note.note: James I (born June 19, 1566, Edinburgh Castle, Edinburgh, Scotland—died March 27, 1625, Theobalds, Hertfordshire, England). He was king of Scotland (as James VI) from 1567 to 1625 and, following his accession as first Stuart king of England in 1603, he styled himself “king of Great Britain.” ODNB.

persName.note: John, 5th Lord Fleming (1533/4-1558) was a Scottish nobleman and cousin and supporter of Mary Stewart. He was governor of Dumbarton Castle until its capture by the forces of the Regent, Matthew Stewart, earl of Lennox. ODNB.

Thomas Crawford, or Crauford (fl. 1570), led an attack on Dumbarton Castle in 1571 on behalf of the earl of Lennox, successfully capturing it from forces loyal to queen Mary. Crawford recorded an account of the attack in a letter to John Knox. ODNB; William Anderson, The Scottish Nation, (Edinburgh: 1868), i, p.705.

Tobias Smollett (1721–1771), author, born at Dalquhurn, near Renton, Dunbartonshire. After studying medicine at Glasgow University, Smollett was apprenticed as a surgeon but enlisted as a surgeon's mate on board a man-of-war before completing his apprenticeship. He served in the Caribbean against the Spanish, and his experience of war may have informed his novel, Roderick Random, as well as his Complete History of England (1757-8). Smollett subsequently settled in London where he authored several major novels, distinguished by their often satirical or sceptical view of contemporary manners and human character: Roderick Random (1748), The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle (1751) and Ferdinand Count Fathom (1753). Smollett's Complete History of England (1757-8) cemented his reputation as one of the preeminent writers of the age. Smollett's final novel The Expedition of Humphry Clinker, published shortly before his death in 1771, depicts the Welsh gent Matthew Bramble and his household on a tour of Scotland. ODNB. See http://curioustravellers.ac.uk/en/in-search-of-dr-john-stuarts-luss-hog-backs-dawn-redwoods-and-gaelic-bibles/ for a description and photograph of the Smollett memorial at Luss.

James Smollet of Bonhill, sheriff depute of Dumbartonshire and commissary of Edinburgh (d. 1775), who lived at Cameron House, near Balloch. He was a cousin of Tobias Smollet, who erected the Smollet Monument in Renton.

Robert MacGregor (bap. 1671, d.1734) was a cattle farmer, outlaw and descendant of the proscribed Gregor clan, known as Rob Roy due to his red hair. Rob later took his mother's maiden name Campbell in response to the renewal of laws banning the name MacGregor, and to curry favour with the Campbells of Breadalbane, to whom he looked for protection from the Murrays of Atholl, whose cattle he was in the practice of stealing. In the early 1700s Rob gradually acquired modest property in the Trossachs and southern Highlands, including the estates of Glengyle and Craigrostan. After enjoying moderate success as a cattle raider and trader, he was denounced as a bankrupt by his creditor, the marquess of Montrose and forced into hiding. Rob Roy and his followers skirmished with goverment forces in the wake of the Jacobite rising of 1715, and he was accordingly deemed a traitor, pursued by Montrose whose estates he continued to raid, and who retaliated through the construction of a garrison at Inversnaid. Rob Roy was eventually pardoned after submitting to General George Wade in 1725, who had been sent north to reach a settlement with the remaining rebels of 1715. Rob Roy was celebrated by some in his own lifetime, but his modern reputation (and his fame during the Romantic period and later nineteenth century), largely rests on Walter Scott's fictionalised account of his deeds in his novel Rob Roy (1817). ODNB.
Colin Campbell of Glenorchy (c.1395–1475) was a influential figure in the Campbell clan, and builder of Kilchurn Castle. ODNB.

note.note: Fionn mac Cuhhaill. Mythical Celtic warrior, whose exploits with his band the Fianna formed the late iron age Fenian Cycle, narrated by Fionn's son, the blind bard Oisin. These descended into Gaelic oral tradition in Ireland, Scotland, and the Isle of Man. Many place names in the Irish and Scottish Gaidhealtach allude to Fionn or his associates. 'Fingal' was James Macpherson's version of his name in his highly doctored 'translations' of Fenian ballad material published as the Poems of Ossian in the early 1760's, a work which enjoyed enormous global popularity but the authenticity of which was questioned, most famously by Dr Johnson.

persName.note: Under a royal grant made by James III in 1487, the Dewars of Glendochart were the heredity keepers of the crozier of Fáelán Amlabar (St Fillan) — which was reputed to have healing powers — and the Coigreach, a decorative reliquary that incased it. In 1785, William Thomson, a student at Oxford, wrote to the earl of Buchan, informing him that in 1782 he had seen the 'Quigrich', in the possession of one Malice Doire (Dewar), a day labourer from Killin, and inclosing a drawing. Thomson notes that Dewar's son, then nineteen, appeared to be mortally ill. In 1819, Archibald Dewar, then the heriditary keeper, emigrated to Ontario, taking both the crozier and Coigreach with him, although they were later returned to Scotland. Archaelogia Scotia: or Transactions of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, vol. iii, pp.289-91.

Fáelán Amlabar, or St Fillan (641/2-724), abbot of Iona, buried at Strathfillan where a chapel and village bear his name. His relics, a bell and crozier are in the collection of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, the crozier having spent several centuries in the hands of its hereditary keepers, the Dewars. According to a tradition probably originating with Boece, the saint's arm acquired divine properties and was carried by Robert the Bruce at the head of his army. Having been removed for safe-keeping, the arm mirarculously found its way back into its silver cask on the night before the battle of Bannockburn, auguring Bruce's victory. The Chapel of St Fillan and its environs were popularly associated with the healing of the insane and visited by pilgrims into the eighteenth-century. ODNB.
Robert I, king of Scots (1774-1329).
Travelling companion of the anonymous author of 'Tour in Scotland 1794'. NLS, MS.29491.
Henry Seymour Conway (1719–1795), army officer, politician and friend of Horace Walpole. ODNB

note.note: (1604/5–1682) French-Italian landscape painter.

persName.note: John Murray (1755-1830), fourth duke of Atholl on succeeding his father in 1774.

John Graham of Claverhouse, first Viscount Dundee (1648-89), nobleman and soldier who died leading the Jacobite forces to victory against the Williamite army led by Hugh Mackay at the battle of Killicrankie.
Commander of Williamite forces at the Battle of Killiecrankie.
Fought on the Jacobite side at the Battle of Killiecrankie
Duncan king of Scots (d. 1040), killed in battle by Macbeth. ODNB

note.note: Macbeth [Mac Bethad mac Findlaích] (d. 1057) king of Scots, and probable nephew of Malcom II. Initially the ruler of Moray, he expanded his kingdom to incorporate more of Scotland, but was met with resistance from his rival, Malcom Canmore (later Malcom III), who in 1054, with Northumbrian backing, defeated him in a battle at Dunsinane, and killed him three years later. Shakespeare's famous Tragedy of Macbeth was based on the accounts of later chroniclers, such as Hector Boece and Ralph Holinshed. ODNB.
French military engineer (1633-1707).

persName.addName: The Wolf of Badenoch, Lord of Badanoch,
persName.note: Alexander Stewart (c.1345–1405). He was known as 'the wolf of Badenoch' and burned the town of Elgin and its cathedral.

William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland (1721–1765), was an army officer and son of George, prince of Wales (later George II). Cumberland commanded the Hanoverian troops at the Battle of Culloden on 16th April 1746, and subsequently oversaw the violent repression of the Jacobites and their sympathisers in the Highlands. Cumberland's actions earned him the sobriquet 'the Butcher', an association which contributed to his unpopularity and hampered his political career. ODNB.
Ossian: Oisin, son of Fingal, blind bard of Gaelic legend.

James Macpherson (1736–1796), a native Gael, was born in Badenoch and witnessed the bloody termination of the Jacobite Uprising as a boy. Educated at Aberdeen University, his ideas of epic poetry were influenced by Thomas Blackwell. Encouraged by John Home, he produced a number of poems translated from Gaelic, later published as Fragments of Ancient Poetry (1760). Hugh Blair and other members of the literati encouraged him to embark on a tour of the Gaidhealtachd collecting Ossianic verse. The fruits of this tour were published in the form of the 'translated' epics Fingal (1761) and Temora (1763). Widely championed by Blair and the literati, they promoted Scottish cultural nationalism and Gaelic culture at a time of low ebb for both: Macpherson courted more controversy by dedicating Fingal to the Marquis of Bute, the unpopular Scottish prime minister. Macpherson was attacked by Irish, English and Welsh antiquarians and most notably by Dr Johnson in his Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland (1775), but the poems were enormously successful and effectively created a popular taste for Highland tourism. Macpherson's subsequent career as a historian, journalist, colonial administrator and politician (he became MP for the rotten burgh of Camelford in 1780) made him a great deal of money. He built a lavish mansion at Belleville near his birthplace in Strathspey, and died unmarried in 1796.

note.note: Charles Edward (1720–1788), born in Rome, was claimant to the thrones of England, Scotland and Ireland. He landed at Eriskay on 23 July, accompanied by his close supporters, 'the seven men of Moidart', instigating the Jacobite uprising of 1745. Although Charles Edward had been unable to secure the hoped-for level of military support from France, he was eventually joined by the forces of several Highland chiefs. Marching south, the Jacobite forces took Edinburgh on 17 September, while counter-attacking Hanoverian forces under Cumberland and Wade assembled in the north of England. The Jacobite advance on London was reversed after a council of war at Derby, where many expressed their doubts at the army's ability to take the capital. In early 1746, the Jacobites slowly retreated northwards, despite a victory at Falkirk, and a final defeat by government troops led by the duke of Cumberland took place at Culloden, outside Inverness. Charles Edward fled westward with the help of Jacobite loyalists, including the famous Flora MacDonald, and on 20 September left Lochaber on a French ship. While further Jacobite risings were planned, none came to fruition, and Charles Edward died in exile in at Rome. ODNB.

persName.note: Jacobite soldier who assisted Charles Edward Stuart's escape from the field at Culloden.
George II (1683–1760), king of Great Britain and Ireland
Mythical inhabitant of Cruachan and creator of Loch Awe in a Gaelic poem.
Character in a poem or song relating to Fraoch Eilean, Loch Awe.
Character in a poem or song relating to Fraoch Eilean, Loch Awe.

John Adair (ca 1650–1718) was a surveyor and cartographer of Scottish counties in the late 1680s. He may have been the first Scottish map-maker to make use of triangulation. Few of his maps reached publication during his lifetime, with a selection being printed in the 1730s. While twelve of Adair's manuscript maps are still extant, the rest were destroyed in a fire in 1811. ODNB; http://maps.nls.uk/counties/info.html.
Surveyor (fl.1776).
A keeper of the Register Office in Edinburgh c.1776. Mentioned by George Paton in his letter to Pennant on 25 March 1776.
A keeper of the Register Office in Edinburgh c.1776. Described as 'lazy' by George Paton in his letter to Pennant on 25 March 1776.
Wodrow (1679-1734) was a Scottish church historian, author of The History of the Sufferings of the Church of Scotland (2 vols., 1721–2).

David Gibson (fl.1787) was a miniaturist and engraver in Edinburgh, married to Ann Gibson. He died of consumption leaving his son David Cooke Gibson (1827-1856), who became a portrait painter in Edinburgh and later London.

John Brown (1749-1787) was a draughtsman and painter of miniatures who spent time among artistic circles in Rome, where he was associated with the artist Alexander Runciman. He accompanied Charles Townley and William Young as a draughtsman on their tour of Italy in 1772. He was later commissioned by David Steuart Erskine, Earl of Buchan, to produce small portraits of members of the Society of Antiquaries in London. He died of the malaria he had contracted during his travels in Italy. ODNB.
William (c.1142–1214), king of Scots.
James Cook (1694-1779), a day labourer, and his wife Grace Pace (170/2-1765), were parents of the Pacific explorer Captain James Cook. ODNB.
Unidentified friend of George Paton (fl.1774), possibly resident near Blair Atholl, who provides information on the Gaelic name for the bagpipes.
Artist who drew the plates for the first edition of Pennant's British Zoology.

Lady Charlotte Murray (1731-1805), Duchess of Atholl and wife of John Murray (her cousin), 3rd Duke of Atholl. On the death of her father in 1764 she inherited the English Barony of Strange and sovereignty over the Isle of Man.

Possibly Captain (later lt.-gen.) James Murray of Strowan, Perth (1734-94). Murray was the son of Lord George Murray and brother of John Murray, 3rd Duke of Atholl. Murray fought in the seven years' war and in the Americas, before becoming MP for Perthshire in 1773. History of Parliament Online.

William Tomkins (c.1732–1792) was a landscape painter who exhibited at the Free Society of Artists in 1761 and the Society of Arts in 1763. He was known as a painter of gentlemen's seats in the North of England, but was also patronised by James Duff, second Earl of Fife. His works were engraved for William Angus's and William Watt's views of seats of the nobility and gentry (1779-1787). Several of his Scottish landscapes were engraved for Pennant's Tour in Scotland in 1769. ODNB

Thomas Falkner (1707-1784) was a Jesuit missionary who spent a significant time in South America among the inhabitants of Patagonia. The Jesuits were expelled from Córdoba in 1767 and Falkner returned to England, where he published A Description of Patagonia (1774). Pennant's Of the Patagonians (1788) names Falkner as its source, Pennant having visited Falkner after his return to England.

(fl. 1772) School master near parish of Comrie, Perthshire, who assisted Pennant in excavating what were thought to be graves. See A tour in Scotland, and voyage to the Hebrides; MDCCLXXII. Part II (London: 1776), p.98.

Charles Steuart, landscape artist, was a native Gaelic speaker from Perthshire, patronised by the Duke of Atholl and the Earl of Bute. His most famous paintings (of waterfalls and other landscape features on the Atholl estates) survive in the Green Drawing room at Blair Castle. He regularly exhibited views of noblemen's parks and houses at the Society of Artists of Great Britain 1764-1790, of which he was elected president in 1783. His view of Dunkeld appears in Pennant, Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 Part II, (London: 1776), Plate VI, p.61. His better known brother George (c.1730-1806) was a house painter turned architect who worked in London for Robert Adam. They may have been connected to the Steuarts of Dalguise.

Thomas Hay, ninth earl of Kinnoull (1710–1787) was an MP for Scarborough and later Cambridge, and commissioner for the revenues of Ireland. He held prestigious administrative offices under the governments of Walpole, Pelham, and Newcastle, reflecting his Whig allegiances, despite a familial association with Jacobitism. After succeeding to the Earldom of Kinnoul in 1758 he served as chancellor of the University of St Andrews, funded local infrastructure projects, and was elected president of the Society in Scotland for the Propagation of Christian Knowledge. On his death he was succeeded by his nephew, Robert Auriol Hay Drummond. ODNB.
Robert Hay Drummond (1711–1776), archbishop of York.

Dr Thomas Livingstone (d.1785), who wrote his name 'Levinstone' was midwife to the Duchess of Gordon in 1768, and to Catherine Gordon of Gight (George Gordon, Lord Byron's mother), during the time she lived in Aberdeen. Ella Hill Burton Rodger, Aberdeen Doctors, at Home and Abroad: The Narrative of a Medical School, (Edinburgh; London: William Blackwood and Sons, 1893), p.30.

persName.addName: George Skene of Careston, Skene of Skene,

persName.note: Archibald Grant (fl.1769).
(fl. 1770) Tailor in St James's Street, London.

John Ellis (c.1710–1776) was a naturalist and linen merchant, particularly known for his work on zoophytes and corals, partly in collaboration with Daniel Solander. He published important works on the subject, including Natural History of the Corallines (1755) and the posthumous Natural History of Zoophytes (1786). He later wrote on and promoted the use of tropical plants in colonial agriculture, including coffee and breadfruit, and was an early contributor to the study of micro-organisms. He was a fellow of the Royal Society. ODNB
Messrs Hopkins (fl. 1770). Likely from context to be a courier business.
Lady Caroline D'arcy (d.1778), later marchioness of Lothian through her marriage to William Henry Kerr, fourth Marquess of that title.
Van Dyck (1599-1641), Flemish artist who rose to fame as the court painter of Charles I.
Daniel Mytens [Mijtens] (c.1590-1647) was court artist to Charles I from 1625 to 1633, when Anthony Van Dyck returned to England. ODNB.

Sir Thomas Urquhart of Cromarty (1611-1660) was an author, translator and courtier of Charles I, educated at Kings College Aberdeen, and known for his eccentric poetry and prose works on diverse subjects, as well as his important English translation of Rabelais. ODNB

Daines Barrington (1727/8-1800) was an antiquarian, naturalist and judge, born in Berkshire and educated at Queen's College, Oxford. He held a number of high profile offices, including second justice of Chester from 1778 and commisary-general of the stores at Gibraltar. His first major publication was a work of legal history: Observations on the Statutes, Chiefly the More Ancient (1766). He became a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries and Royal Society in 1767. He contributed twenty-four pieces to the Society of Antiquaries' journal Archaeologia, beginning with a work on Welsh castles in 1770, and several papers on natural history to the Philosophical Transactions, one of which formed an appendix to a volume of Pennant's British Zoology. Barrington's initially anonymous The Naturalist's Journal, published from 1767 attempted to record systematic observations of the natural world on the basis of Baconian principles, and influenced the work of Gilbert White of Selborne, to whom the Journal was transmitted by Pennant. At the Royal Society Barrington was a proponent of the voyages of Phipps in 1773 and Cook in 1776, believing firmly in the existence of a navigable Arctic passage. ODNB.
Gilpin (fl.1773), may have been an artist or draughtsman, and is mentioned by Pennant in a covering letter to Daines Barrington, 4th March 1773.

Charles I (1600–49) of England, Scotland, and Ireland was born in Dunfermline Castle, son of James VI (subsequently James I of England) and his wife, Anne. His reign saw the Civil Wars of England, Scotland and Ireland (1641-6). He was executed by the Parliamentarians at Whitehall in 1649. ODNB.
Princess Henrietta Maria of France (1609–1669), later queen of England, Scotland, and Ireland through her marriage to Charles I.
Companion at court to queen Henrietta Maria and her husband, Charles I.
Father of Robert Ramsay.
(fl.1526-1574) Clergyman, genealogist and topographer of the Western Isles.
James Graham first marquess of Montrose (1612–1650), was a royalist army officer noted for several victories over the covenanters in 1644-45. He was executed in Edinburgh in 1650. ODNB
(fl.1780) Baron of Preston, possibly a Dr James Schaw.

note.note: Sir John Wynn, fifth baronet (1628–1719), of Watstay near Ruabon in Denbighshire, was the only son of Henry Wynn (1601/2–1671) of Rhiwgoch, Merioneth, and the last baronet of the direct line of Gwydir. In 1657 he married the heiress of the Watstay estate. DWB s.n. Wynn family, of Gwydir, Caerns.; Wynn (family), Wynnstay; Hist P s.n. Henry Wynn (1601/2–1671).

persName.addName: Sir W. Williams, the son of the speaker

note.note: Sir William Williams, second baronet (c.1665–1740), of Glascoed, Llansilin, Denbighshire, was the eldest surviving son of Sir William Williams, first baronet. His first wife was Jane (d. 1706), daughter and co-heiress of Edward Thelwall of Plas y Ward, Denbigh. Hist P; DWB.

Sir William Williams, first baronet (c.1634–1700), of Glascoed, Llansilin, Denbighshire, was the only son of Hugh Williams, DD, rector of Llantrisant and Llanrhyddlad, Anglesey, and his wife Emma, daughter and heir of John Dolben of Caeau Gwynion, Denbighshire. He represented Chester, the Montgomery boroughs and Beaumaris in Parliament, serving as speaker of the House between 21 October 1680 and 28 March 1681. Hist P; DWB.

persName.addName: daughter, and heiress of Edw. Thelwal of Plas y ward

note.note: Jane Williams (née Thelwall) (d. 1706), daughter and heiress of Edward Thelwall of Plas y Ward, and first wife of Sir William Williams, second baronet, was great-granddaughter to Sir John Wynn, first baronet, of Gwydir. DWB s.n. Wynn (family) Wynnstay; Hist P.

The Edward Thelwall whose daughter Jane (d. 1706) married Sir William Williams, second baronet, was probably the holder of the office of the sheriff of Denbighshire in 1669. See The London Gazette (8 November 1669); and for the Thelwall family of Plas y Ward, DWB.

Robert Wynne (1690–1762) of Bodyscallen, Caernarfonshire, son of Robert Wynne and his wife Elin, daughter and heiress of Robert Wynne of Plas Mawr, Conwy, sat for Caernarvon Boroughs between 1754 and 1761. Hist P.
William Bodvell (1694–1759) of Madryn, Caernarfonshire, sat for his home county between 1741 and 1754, and for the Montgomery Boroughs from 1754 to 1759. Hist P.

persName.addName: Dr. Gabriel Goodman, Dean of Westminster

note.note: Gabriel Goodman (1528–1601), second son of Edward Goodman of Ruthin, was appointed dean of Westminster in 1561, a post which he held until his death. In 1590 he founded Christ's Hospital in Ruthin, later adding a grammar school to the establishment. His patronage of William Camden may have begun during the latter's early twenties, and Goodman was certainly supportive of him by the late 1570s and early 1580s, when Camden began research and travel for his Britannia. ODNB; DWB.

persName.note: Godfrey Goodman (1583–1656), second son of Godfrey Goodman, formerly a clerk at Westminster Abbey, and his wife Jane (née Croxton), was born in Ruthin, Denbighshire, and educated as a chorister and queen's scholar at Westminster School. His uncle, Gabriel Goodman, was dean there, and William Camden headmaster. Godfrey was appointed to the sea of Gloucester, then considered the poorest bishopric in England, in 1624. ODNB.

note.note: Richard Powell was a member of the family of Powell, listed by Pennant in HPWaH as descendants extinct or in the female line of the fourth Royal Tribe of Wales (that of Ethelystan Glodrydd). Pennant further noted that Richard, a poet, was 'author of the Pentarchia, a short history, in coarse Latin verse, of the royal tribes of Cambria, and their descendants ... composed about the year 1623' and dedicated to the Prince of Wales, later Charles I. Philip Yorke also refers to (and quotes from) the 'Pentarchia' in The Royal tribes of Wales, praising it for its factual accuracy, but expressing regret that he was unable to find more information about its author. HPWaH, p. 288; Philip Yorke, The Royal tribes of Wales (Wrexham: John Painter, 1799), pp. 133–4.

David Powel [Powell] (1549x52–98), was named vicar of Ruabon prior to his graduation from Jesus College, Oxford, in 1570. He was appointed rector of Llanfyllin, Montgomery, the following year, and vicar of Meifod in the same county in 1579. Powel was the author of the first printed history of Wales, The Historie of Cambria, now called Wales (1584), which continued to be a major source for medieval Welsh history until the early 19th century. ODNB.

persName.addName: Blethyn ap Confyn; Bledyn ab Kyvyn Tuysawc Powys; Bleddyn ab Cynvyn

note.note: Bleddyn ap Cynfyn (d. 1075), king of Gwynedd and of Powys. ODNB s.n. Bleddyn ap Cynfyn.
Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (1547–1616), author of Don Quixote (1605, 1615).

persName.note: A figure of Greek myth who was said to have fought in the Trojan war.

note.note: Jonathan Swift (1667–1745), poet, satirist and dean of St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin.

Dr Reverend Richard Cust (1728-83), dean of Lincoln, may perhaps be identified with Richard Cust, brother to Sir John Cust and uncle to Philip Yorke's first wife, Elizabeth. See Eric Griffiths, Philip Yorke I (1743-1804) Squire of Erthig (Wrexham: Bridge Books, 1995), pp. 17, 30; and https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/dr-the-very-reverend-richard-cust-17281783-dean-of-lincoln-176215# [accessed 4 July 2019].

Like Philip Yorke, Sir Brownlow Cust, fourth Baronet (1744–1807), of Belton, Lincolnshire, was educated at Eton and Corpus Christi college, Cambridge, both men matriculating at Cambridge in 1762. He was member of Parliament for Ilchester and Grantham (1768–74 and 1774–76 respectively) and was created Baron Brownlow of Belton in recognition of the services of his father, Sir John Cust, on 20 May 1776. Yorke's first wife, Elizabeth (1749–79), whom he married on 2 July 1770, was the sister of Brownlow Cust. Hist P; ODNB s.n. Philip Yorke.

The son of the architect and gardener, William Kent (bap. 1686, d. 1748), and his mistress, the Drury Lane actress, Elizabeth Butler. Kent bequeathed a sum of £1,200 to Butler and their two children, George and Elizabeth. ODNB s.n. William Kent (bap. 1686, d. 1748); Tim Mowl, William Kent: Architect, Designer, Opportunist, p. 118; Margaret Jourdain, The Work of William Kent: Artist, Painter, Designer and Landscape Gardener (London: Country Life, 1948), p. 89.

persName.addName: Rodoricus Magnus; Rodericus Magnus; Roderick the Great

note.note: Rhodri Mawr (b. before 844, d. 878), king of Gwynedd from 844 until his death. Rhodri may also have ruled Powys from c. 855, and he annexed Ceredigion in 872. His numerous sons, by several wives, ensured that he was a progenitor of most of the Welsh rulers of the tenth century and beyond, among them his grandson Hywel Dda ap Cadell. In spite of his successful expansion within Wales, he had difficulties in relations with Viking, Irish and English rulers, and was killed, apparently by Mercian warriors, alongside his son, Gwriad, in 878. ODNB.

persName.note: Offa (d. 796) was king of the Mercians from 757, and became the most dominant leader in England during his reign. By 772 he had absorbed the territories of lesser local kings in Sussex into his Mercian kingdom; by c.780 had established direct rule over the west midlands kingdom of Hwicce; and by 785 he was in control of Kent. In 778 and 784 he carried out hugely destructive assaults on Welsh kingdoms; the dyke named after him (which runs from the north east coast of Wales to the mouth of the river Wye in the south) may have aided these military ends, but also stood as a symbol of his power. ODNB.

persName.addName: Race of the Plantagenets; Angevin Family

note.note: The House of Plantagenet (also known as the house of Anjou or the Angevin dynasty) was created through the marriage in 1127 of Geoffrey, count of Anjou (d.1151) and Matilda (1102–1167), daughter of Henry I, king of England and lord of Normandy. Plantagenet kings reigned between 1154 and 1485. ODNB; here [accessed 15 October 2017].

persName.note: Henry VIII (1491–1547), king of England and Ireland.

note.note: Merfyn may be considered among the historically more certain of the numerous alleged sons of Rhodri Fawr. ODNB s.n. Rhodri Fawr.

Maredudd (d. 1132), son of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn, possibly by Haer, daughter of Gillyn. Unlike his brother Cadwgan, he was imprisoned for his support of Robert de Bellême, earl of Shrewsbury, in a revolt of 1102 against other Norman lords, but on the death of his uncle Owain ap Cadwgan in 1116, he took over the leadership of the his father's line, eventually becoming king of Powys. He was succeeded by Madog ap Maredudd, one of his three sons by his wife Hunydd, daughter of Einudd. ODNB s.n. Maredudd ap Bleddyn.

Cadwgan (d. 1111), son of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn, inherited a part of Powys after his father's death. He was able to keep his hold on land in Powys and Ceredigion following the fall of Robert de Bellême, earl of Shrewsbury, whose revolt against other Norman lords he had supported. He built Nannau, Llanfachreth, Merionethshire, early in the twelfth century, and can be considered the founder of the House of Nannau. He was murdered by Madog ap Rhirid in an ambush near Welshpool. ODNB s.n. Cadwgan ap Bleddyn; Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 82–91; here [accessed 14 March 2019].

Madog ap Maredudd (d. 1160), son of Maredudd ap Bleddyn, became sole ruler of his father's kingdom of Powys on the latter's death in 1132. The claim that Madog died at Winchester, made in a version of Brut y tywysogyon in NLW, Peniarth MS 20, has been questioned. All versions of the Brut state that he was buried at a pre-Norman church at Meifod in Montgomeryshire. ODNB.
Gruffudd ap Maredudd, son of Maredudd ap Bleddyn, predeceased his father, and the latter's kingdom of Powys fell to his younger brother, Madog, who became its sole ruler. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.
Susanna, daughter of Gruffudd ap Cynan and his wife Angharad (d. 1162), daughter of Owain ab Edwin of Dyffyn Clwyd, married Madog ap Maredudd. ODNB s.n. Gruffudd ap Cynan.

persName.addName: Gruffydh ap Conan; Griffith ap Conan

note.note: Gruffudd ap Cynan (c.1055–1137), king of Gwynedd, was the son of an exile in Ireland, Cynan ap Iago, and Rhagnell, a member of the royal house of Scandinavians at Dublin. Having sailed to his father's land in 1075, the year of the death of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn, he secured the rule of Gwynedd, but was forced to retreat to Ireland following a battle against Trahaearn ap Caradog, king of Arwystli, at Bron-yr-erw near Clynnog. A successful attempt at regaining Gwynedd followed in 1081, but Gruffudd was soon after captured at Rug near Corwen and imprisoned at Chester for up to sixteen years, during which time the Normans made inroads into Gwynedd. In the last years of the eleventh century, he retreated once more to Ireland (1098), then returned to rule Anglesey (1099), his rule there this time sanctioned by the Normans.
