A tradition links Gruffudd with a statute relating to the eisteddfod held at Caerwys in 1523, perhaps based on a memory that he brought influential bards and musicians with him into Gwynedd from Ireland. DWB.

Gruffudd Maelor (d. 1191) was the son of Madog ap Maredudd and, according to late medieval genealogists, his wife Susanna. He became ruler of northern Powys following his father's death in 1160. He married Angharad, daughter of Owain Gwynedd (d. 1170), and was succeeded by his son Madog. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd; Madog ap Gruffudd Maelor.

Owain Fychan (d. 1187), a son of Madog ap Maredudd and, according to late medieval genealogists, his wife, Susanna. He was one of three of Madog ap Maredudd's sons who inherited the kingdom of Powys after their father's death. He may be identified with the 'Owen ap Madawc' named by Philip Yorke in his letter of 3 December 1776 to Pennant, 1355. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.

Owain Brogyntyn (fl. 1160–1215), an illegitimate son of Madog ap Maredudd, whose name derives from Porkington, a village near Oswestry later known in Welsh as 'Brogyntyn'. He inherited land in 1160, following the death of both his father and his half-brother Llywelyn. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd; Owain Brogyntyn.

persName.note: See Gruffudd Maelor.

persName.addName: Owen Gwynedh Prince of North Wales

note.note: Owain Gwynedd (Owain ap Gruffudd, d. 1170), was the second son of Gruffudd ap Cynan and his wife, Angharad. On his father's death in 1137, he succeeded to the kingdom of Gwynedd, going on both to consolidate and expand it. Thomas Becket excommunicated him for his marriage to Cristin, a first cousin, and the struggle between his numerous sons and grandsons for the control of Gwynedd perpetuated for close on thirty years. ODNB.

Madog ap Gruffudd Maelor (d. 1236) succeeded his father in 1191. Although he joined King John in a campaign against Llywelyn ap Iorwerth (d. 1240) in 1211, by 1215 he was apparently supportive of the latter and became a staunch ally. He was the founder of Valle Crucis, a Cistercian abbey near Llangollen in Denbighshire. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Gruffudd Maelor.

Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield) (d. 1269), son of Madog ap Gruffudd Maelor, a ruler in Powys, whose main seat was the castle at Dinas Brân, Llangollen. His wife, Emma, was the daughter of Henry Audley, and they had four sons: Madog, Llywelyn, Owain, and Gruffudd Fychan. He was among a group of Welsh lords who paid homage to Henry III. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.

persName.addName: Emma the daughter of James Lord Audley

note.note: Emma, the sister of James Audley (d. 1272), married Gruffudd Maelor. ODNB s.n. Audley [de Audley] family. Note that she is described as James's daughter by Philip Yorke and said to have married Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield).

persName.surname: ap Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield)

note.note: The elder son of Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield) and his wife, Emma (née Audley). ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.

persName.surname: ap Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield)

note.note: A son of Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield) and his wife, Emma (née Audley). ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.

persName.surname: ap Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield)

note.note: Gruffudd Fychan (d. 1289), son of Gruffudd ap Madog (d. 1269), was able to counter the losses of his family at the Edwardian conquest of 1282 by recovering Glyndyfrdwy in Edeirnion. His successors also obtained the territory of Cynllaith Owain. He was great-great-grandfather to Owain Glyn Dŵr. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Gruffudd. See also pe0643.

persName.surname: ap Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield)

note.note: A son of Gruffudd ap Madog (Gruffudd of Bromfield) and his wife, Emma (née Audley). ODNB s.n. Madog ap Maredudd.
Edward I (1239–1307), king of England from 1272.

Following Edward I's conquest of 1282 most of the native Welsh lords of northern Powys were dispossessed. Maelor Gymraeg and Iâl in the north of the dynasty were transformed into the lordship of Bromfield and Yale and granted to John de Warenne, sixth earl of Surrey. ODNB s.n. John de Warenne, sixth early of Surrey; Madog ap Gruffudd Maelor
William (V) de Warenne (d. 1286), son of John de Warenne, sixth earl of Surrey. ODNB s.n. John de Warenne, sixth earl of Surrey; John de Warenne, seventh earl of Surrey.

Alice, daughter of William (V) de Warenne, granddaughter of John de Warenne, sixth earl of Surrey, and sister to the seventh earl, married Edmund Fitzalan, second earl of Arundel (1285–1326) in 1305. ODNB s.n. Edmund Fitzalan, second earl of Arundel.

persName.note: See Alice, daughter of William (V) de Warenne.

Edmund Fitzalan, second earl of Arundel (1285–1326), was executed during the revolution of 1326, led by Isabella of France, consort of Edward II, and her lover, Roger (V), first earl of March (1287–1330). Fitzalan was succeeded by his son Richard (II) Fitzalan, third earl of Arundel and eighth earl of Surrey (c.1313–1376) in 1330; followed by the latter's eldest son, Richard (III) Fitzalan, fourth earl of Arundel and ninth earl of Surrey (1346–1397); and the latter's second son and heir, Thomas Fitzalan, fifth earl of Arundel and tenth earl of Surrey (1381–1415). ODNB. See also Alice, daughter of William (V) de Warenne.

persName.roleName: third earl of Arundel and eighth earl of Surrey

note.note: See Edmund Fitzalan.

persName.roleName: fourth earl of Arundel and ninth earl of Surrey
persName.note: See Edmund Fitzalan

persName.addName: Thomas Earl of Arundel; Thomas Earl of Arundel and Warren

note.note: Thomas Fitzalan, fifth earl of Arundel and tenth earl of Surrey (1381–1415), inherited the estate of Edmund Fitzalan, second earl of Arundel, his great-grandfather. He had no legitimate children, and his estate passed to his three sisters: Elizabeth, who married John (V) Mowbray, duke of Norfolk, Joan, Lady Bergavenny, wife of William (V) Beauchamp, first Baron Bergavenny (c.1343–1411), and Margaret, wife of Sir Rowland Lenthal. ODNB s.n. Thomas Fitzalan, fifth earl of Arundel and tenth earl of Surrey; William (V) Beauchamp, first Baron Bergavenny.

note.note: The cartographer John Evans (1723–1795) was born at Llwyn-y-groes, Llanymynech, on the Montgomeryshire-Shropshire border. His map of north Wales on a scale of almost one inch to a mile and published in sheets in 1795, was a worthy precursor to the Ordnance Survey one-inch maps. A smaller-scale edition was posthumously published in 1797. Pennant recorded his indebtedness to John Evans for correcting a generally-held misconception regarding 'Wat's ditch' near Holywell, in A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, pp. 21–2. He also noted here the latter's work on 'a large map' of the area in question, a project 'extremely worthy of public encouragement'. DWB.

persName.note: John Somers, Baron Somers (1651–1716), a Whig politician whose proposal for the repeal of the Scottish Act of Security in 1705 was a precursor to the passing of the 1707 Act of Union between England and Scotland. ODNB.
See Thomas Fitzalan, fifth earl of Arundel and tenth earl of Surrey.

note.note: Henry IV (1367–1413), also known as Henry Bolingbroke, king of England between 1399 and 1413.

persName.roleName: Earl of Pembroke; Duke of Bedford

note.note: Jasper Tudor, duke of Bedford (c.1431–1495), the second son of Owen Tudor and Catherine of Valois, and uncle to Henry VII. Henry VI granted Jasper the constableship of the castles of Aberystwyth, Carmarthen, and Carreg Cennen in 1457, but following the defeat and execution of his father, Owen Tudor, at the battle of Mortimer's Cross in February 1461, Jasper fled from Wales. He spent time periodically in Brittany, France and Scotland, and made several abortive efforts at invading and recapturing power in the name of the Lancastrian family during the 1460s, 70s and 80s, before the success of August 1485. Pennant notes that Jasper was created earl of Pembroke in 1452; the title duke of Bedford was created for him by his nephew, Henry VII, and awarded on 28 October 1485. ODNB; A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), II, p. 257.

Vaughan family of Corsygedol, parish of Llanddwywe, Merionethshire. Genealogists, including Lewis Dwnn, who visited Corsygedol in 1588, usually noted the beginnings of this family at the union of the heiress of the family, a ward of Llywelyn ap Iorwerth (Llywelyn Fawr), with Osbwrn Wyddel (Osborn the Irishman, fl. 1293). DWB s.n. Vaughan family of Corsygedol; Osbwrn Wyddel ('Osborn the Irishman').
Gruffudd Vaughan of Cors-y-gedol, a defender of Harlech castle. Dwnn, Heraldic visitations of Wales and part of the marches, ed. by Samuel Rush Meyrick (Llandovery: W. Rees, 1846), p. 219 n. 19.

persName.note: James I (1566—1625), king of Scotland (as James VI) from 1567 to 1625 and first Stuart king of England, reigned both countries as 'king of Great Britain and Ireland' between 1603 and 1625.

A cyclops and son of Poseidon and Thoosa in Ancient Greek mythology. In Homer's account, Polyphemus is blinded by Odysseus and his men as they escape his cavern. In some traditions Polyphemus is associated with pastoral poetry due to his depiction as a herdman and lyricist.
Talmudic commentator (d.1315) who lived in Montpellier, France.
Giles Rousselet, a seventeenth-century Parisian engraver. For examples of his work see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Gilles_Rousselet [accessed 12 September 2018].

James Livingstone (?1719-1788) took the name Campbell on succeeding his brother as heir to the Baronetcy of Ardkinglass, near Cairndow, Argyll. He was an army officer and M.P. for Stirlingshire (1747-1768). History of Parliament Online.
Figure of Greek myth punished by Zeus.
Figure of Greek myth.
Christian martyr who according to one tradition was grilled to death.

note.note: Sydney Thelwall (née Wynn), was a granddaughter to Sir John Wynn, first baronet, of Gwydir. The second wife of Edward Thelwall, Plas y Ward, she was the mother of Jane (née Thelwall). John Askew Roberts, Wynnstay & The Wynns, A Volume of Varieties (Oswestry: Woodall and Venables, Bailey Head and Oswald Road, 1876), p. iv.

Philip Yorke's reference to Lady Prendergast in his letter of 19 July 1791 to Pennant may refer to Penelope (d. 1746), daughter of Henry Cadogan of Liscarton, co. Meath, and wife of the Jacobite Sir Thomas Prendergast (c.1660–1709); or to Anne (d. 1770), daughter and heir of Sir Griffith Williams, sixth baronet, of Marle, Caernarfonshire, who in 1739 became the wife of Sir Thomas's son, Sir Thomas Prendergast, second baronet (bap. 1702, d. 1760). ODNB.

Foote Gower (1725/6–1780), Church of England clergyman and antiquary, was the son of a physician of the same name from Chester. Although he qualified as a physician in 1757, his professional life appears to have centred on the church, which he served as rector to several Essex parishes near his home at Chelmsford from 1761 until his death. In 1771 he published A Sketch of the materials for a new history of Cheshire, in a letter to Thomas Falconer. It appears that John Price, librarian at the Bodleian in Oxford, withheld information about Cheshire from Thomas Pennant in 1770 lest it should frustrate Gower's progress with this work. Correspondence between Pennant and Gower, dated 1770, c.1772, 1776, 1777 and 1778, suggests that Pennant benefitted from information supplied by Gower, although he was clearly cautious regarding conflicting interests. ODNB; Cheshire and Chester Archives and Local Studies Service; Foote Gower Papers (D 4784/12, /16, /41, /42, /43); NLW 2594E (Merionethshire folder).

Pennant visited the town of Maryport in May 1772, noting that it was 'another new creation, the property of Humphry Senhouse, Esq., and so named by him in honor of his lady', and providing a lengthy account of its Roman antiquities. He notes that Senhouse had since provided him with 'an account of other discoveries'. A tour in Scotland 1772, part I (1774), pp. 59–64. Papers relating to the estate of Netherhall, Maryport, Cumbria, together with family correspondence, dated 1259–1958, are held at Cumbria Archive Centre, Carlisle (DSEN), and include a letter from Thomas Pennant relating to Roman antiquities at Maryport, enclosing a sketch, apparently dated 1773 (Cumbria Archive Centre, Carlisle, D SEN 5/5/1/8/36); a letter recommending Philip Howard and Captain Thomas, 1778–9 (ibid., D SEN 5/5/1/8/45); and a letter regarding problems in the turnpike road Act of Parliament, 1791 (D SEN 5/5/1/8/9). Further on Senhouse's involvement in local government, see The Cumberland Chronicle or Whitehaven Intelligencer, 19 November 1776, here (accessed 2 October 2017), where his nomination for the office of sheriff of Cumberland is mentioned.

The line of the ancient Denbighshire family of Edwards or Edwardes of Chirkland, Denbighshire, descended from Tudor Trevor, came to an end in 1685, and their Chirkland estate was passed by marriage to the Puleston family. DWB.

Catherine, daughter and heir of William Edwards of Chirk Hall, Denbighshire, married Sir Roger Puleston (c.1663–1697) in 1684, but died the following year, bringing to an end the Edwards line. Hist P.

Sir Roger Puleston (c.1663–1697) was the first son of Roger Puleston of Emral, Flintshire, and his wife Jane, daughter of Sir Roger Mostyn, first Baronet. He married Catherine, the daughter and heir of William Edwards of Chirk Hall, Denbighshire, in 1684. Their only son died in his father's lifetime. DWB; Hist P.

Thomas Puleston (1694–1735) was the only son of Sir Roger Puleston (c.1663–1697), by his second wife, Martha (d. 1726), daughter of Sir William Ryder. After a rancorous suit in Chancery Thomas Puleston obtained a private Act enabling him to sell the Chirk estate which his father had acquired through his first marriage, in order to meet the latter's substantial debts. The remainder of the family's estate was passed on to John Puleston of Pickhill. DWB; Hist P s.n. Sir Roger Puleston (1663–1697); NLW, Puleston Family Records, here [accessed 19 October 2017].

Magdalen (d. 1750), daughter of Revd Francis Roe, curate at Penrhos, Montgomeryshire, between 1683 and 1706, and his wife, Mary Reynolds, granddaughter of John Edwards of Plas Newydd (New Hall), Chirk parish. In 1735 she became the third wife of Canon Edward Parry, vicar of Oswestry (d. 1737). W. M. Myddelton (ed.), Chirk Castle Accounts, A.D. 1666–1753 (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1931), p. 430.

Simon Yorke (1771–1834) was the eldest son of Philip Yorke from his first marriage to Elizabeth, daughter of Sir John Cust. He sat as member of Parliament for Grantham between 1793 and 1802, a seat kept warm for him by his father, pending his coming of age. Hist P; ODNB.

persName.note: The antiquary Peter Newcome (1727–1797) was vicar of Shenley, Hertfordshire, from 1752, and sinecure rector of Darowen, Montgomeryshire, from 1766. ODNB. Letters from Newcome to Philip Yorke, dated 1792, are held at Herefordshire Archives and Local Studies, D/ECd (Add)/E7.
George Wilkinson was apparently an antiquarian with interest in heraldic matters. See a letter from him to Pennant, dated 1 March 1778 from Chester, at WCRO CR2017/RP391/1–4.

note.note: Madog ap Gruffudd Fychan (c.1275–1304/6). The information given by Philip Yorke in his letter of 1 November 1777 on Madog grupul corresponds to that found in the 1716 work of John Davies, A display of herauldry, where he is named as the son of Griffith, y Barwn Gwyn (Gruffudd Fychan), and his wife Margaret, daughter of Griffri ap Cadwgan. He is said to have inherited the moiety of the estate of Cynllaeth from his father. This descended from him through Madog Vaughan, Griffith of Rhuddallt, and Griffith Vaughan, to Owain Glyndŵr, making him great-great-grandfather to the latter, as stated by Yorke. Modern scholarship, conversely, names Gruffudd Fychan as Glyndŵr's great-great-grandfather and heir. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Gruffudd; Davies, A display of herauldry, pp. 20–1.
Reigned 1327–77.

persName.note: Reigned 1216–1272

note.note: Roger Mortimer (d.1326), a younger member of the Mortimer family, was granted the south-eastern commotes of Maelor Gymraeg following the Edwardian conquest of 1282, and was subsequently known as Mortimer 'of Chirck'. ODNB s.n. Madog ap Gruffudd.
Margaret, daughter of Griffri ap Cadwgan, was the mother of Madog grupl (Madog ap Gruffudd Fychan) according to Davies, A display of herauldry, p. 20.

persName.note: See Margaret, daughter of Griffri ap Cadwgan.

note.note: Madog ap Llywelyn ap Griffri (also known as Madog Eton) was a descendant of the house of Tudor Trefor. He died in 1331 and was buried at Gresford. Dwnn, Heraldic visitations of Wales and part of the marches, p. 360.

The House of Powys Fadog comprised of two dynasties. The first descended from Cadell Ddyrnllug (fl. 5th century), and ended with the death in 854/5 of Cyngen ap Cadell, in exile in Rome and without any apparent successor. A second dynasty was founded through the marriage of Angharad, daughter of Maredudd ab Owain (d. 999), ruler of Deheubarth, and widow of Llywelyn ap Seisyll (d. 1023), and the Powysian nobleman, Cynfyn ap Gwerystan. Their son, Bleddyn ap Cynfyn (d. 1075) went on to found a new royal line. ODNB s.n. Cadell Ddyrnllug; Cyngen ap Cadell; Gruffudd ap Llywelyn; Bleddyn ap Cynfyn; Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 40–1, 61, 75.

persName.note: A son of Griffri ap Cadwgan, unidentified.

note.note: Robert Myddelton (1678–33) purchased Plas Newydd (New Hall) estate near Chirk together with lands in Chirk and Llangollen from Thomas Puleston in 1721, and succeeded to the estate of Chirk Castle in 1722. Hist P; NLW, Puleston Family Records, here [accessed 6 November 2019].
Richard Myddelton (1726–1795) succeeded to the Chirk Castle estate in Denbighshire on his father's death in 1747. Hist P.

Robert Davies (1616–1666) of Gwysane, Flintshire, son of Robert Davies (1581–1633) and his wife Anne, daughter and heir of John Haynes. DWB. For details of Robert Davies's marriage to Anne, daughter of Sir Peter Mytton, and of the marriages of his daughters, see John Reynolds, The Scripture genealogy, beginning at Noah and his three sons ... (Chester: Roger Adams, 1739), pp. 151–3 and esp. p. 152; Burke (1835), II, pp. 277–8.

George Edward Henry Arthur Herbert, second earl of Powis (1755–1801).
Tucker (1713–99), an economist and political writer born at Laugharne, Carmarthenshire, was dean of Gloucester from 1758 until his death. ODNB.

Lady Mary Duncan (1723–1806), wife of Sir William Duncan, and daughter of Sackville Tufton of Newbottle, Northamptonshire, and Lady Mary Saville. She is sitter in two portraits at NPG. See https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp64103/lady-mary-duncan?search=sas&sText=mary+duncan. Her Welsh connection is not clear. Hist P.
For the Stanley family of Knowsley, see http://knowsleyhallvenue.co.uk/our-story/family-history/ [accessed 2 August 2018].

The de Salis family included at this date Jérome de Salis, 2nd Count de Salis-Soglio (1709–94), FRS from 1741, and his son Peter de Salis, 3rd Count de Salis (1738–1807), educated at Chur / Coire in the Grisons, then at Eton.
Bishop of Coire (or Chure), capital of the Swiss canton of Grisons.

note.note: For Treadway Russell Nash's wife, Margaret (née Martin; 1733–1811), see here [accessed 25 March 2019].

Margaret (1760–1831) was the only child of Treadway Russell Nash and his wife Margaret. On 19 March 1785 she married John Cocks, first Earl Somers (1760–1841), of Castleditch, Herefordshire, with whom she had three sons and a daughter. Hist P; here

Thomas Foley (1716–1777) of Stoke Edith, Herefordshire, and Witley, Worcestershire. Created Baron Foley on 20 May 1776, he represented both Droitwich and Herefordshire in parliament. He died on 18 November 1777. Hist P.

Henry Payne, 'for many years the principal manager of the extensive business of the late Mr. Benjamin White in Fleet-street, where, from his diligence and abilities, he was very highly respected; but in an evil hour commenced business, on his own account, with a borrowed capital: which terminating unsuccessfully, he became a bankrupt; and died soon after'. Nichols, Literary anecdotes, III, p. 660.

A 'Miss Monington', named in Treadway Russell Nash's letter to Thomas Pennant, dated 25 July 1777 (1305), may be identified as Ann Teresa Monington (1735–94), of Sarnesfield Court, Herefordshire, daughter of Edward Monington (d. 1741) and his wife Bridget. In February 1780, she entered the Franciscan Convent of English Ladies at Bruges, where she remained until forced to leave in 1794 on account of upheavals connected to the French Revolution. She then moved to the Abbey House at Winchester, where she died. As a member of the Sarnesfield branch of the Monington family, Ann Teresa Monington would be a descendant of Hugh Monington II, son of Hugh Monington I, and brother to Sir Richard Monington of Lawton's Hope, Canon Pyon, Herefordshire. It was the latter who married one of the daughters of Owain Glyndwr, probably Sioned. Ann Teresa would not therefore be a direct descendant of Glyndwr, but a memory of him may have been kept in the related Sarnesfield branch of the Monington family, and could perhaps account for the information she had about his pedigree, according to Nash's letter. Hereford Journal, 3 December 1794; 'Monumental inscriptions at Sarnesfield, County Hereford', here [accessed 13 May 2019]; Gruffydd Aled Williams, Dyddiau Olaf Owain Glyndŵr (Talybont, Ceredigion: Y Lolfa, 2015), p. 76.

The elder son of John Somers Cocks by his first wife, Margaret Cocks (née Nash), was Edward Charles Cox (1786–1812). He was MP for the borough of Reigate, Surrey, between 1806 and 1812 but also followed a military career which ended with his death at the siege of Burgos on 8 October 1812. Hist P.

The second son of John Somers Cocks and his first wife, Margaret Cocks (née Nash) was John Somers Cocks, junior (1788–1852), born on 19 March 1788. He represented both Reigate and Hereford as MP, and held military offices, including that of lieutenant-colonel of the Herefordshire militia. Hist P.

persName.note: Stephen Lightfoot (1707–1769), father of John Lightfoot, was a yeoman farmer. ODNB.

note.note: Mr Vaghan [sic] Pughe has not been identified.

persName.note: unidentified

note.note: Walden Hanmer (1717–1783) of Simpson, Buckinghamshire, MP for Sudbury between 1768 and 1780, succeeded his father to the Hanmer estates in Flintshire in 1739. Hist P s.n. Walden Hanmer (1717– 83), of Simpson, Bucks; Flint Boroughs 1754–1790.

Thomas Hanmer was the son of Walden Hanmer of Simpson, Buckinghamshire. He issued an address for the Flint Boroughs in 1777 but did not stand for election. Hist P s.n. Walden Hanmer (1717– 83), of Simpson, Bucks; Flint Boroughs 1754–1790.

persName.note: Martha (d. 1810), daughter of Francis Williams, a surveyor of excise, married John Lloyd, Caerwys, on 31 January 1769. They had eleven children, only one of whom died an infant. Martha died on 24 February 1810, aged 63. A Latin inscription for her and her husband is found on the north wall of Caerwys Church. NLW 23944C.
unidentified
Mr Mostyn may be identified as one of the five sons of Sir Thomas Mostyn, fourth baronet, and a brother to Sir Roger Mostyn, fifth baronet. History of Parliament.

note.note: Frances Mostyn (b. c. 1767, d. 1827), of Bodysgallen, daughter of Sir Thomas Mostyn. Her charitable works included founding and endowing a school for the poor at Llanrhos, near Llandudno. Fiona Richards, 'Llanrhos School', here [accessed 4 April 2019); Robert Williams, The history and antiquities of the town of Aberconwy and its neighbourhood (Denbigh: printed for the author by Thomas Gee, 1835), pp. 120, 122.

Kenrick Eyton (d. 11 February 1780) of Eyton, Denbighshire, is named by Pennant in the 'Advertisement' to A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, p. ii, among 'the gentlemen I am chiefly indebted to for information respecting the present work'. See also Jeremiah Finch Smith (ed.), The admission register of the Manchester school with some notices of the more distinguished scholars (Chetham Society, 1866), I, pp. 177–8.
Richard Mutton of Rhuddlan, husband of Elen Conway. A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), II, p. 45.
Elen Conway was the daughter of John 'Aer Conwy Hen' and married Richard Mutton of Rhuddlan. A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), II, p. 45.
Jonet, daughter of Edward Stanley of Hooton, was the second wife of John 'Aer Conwy Hen'. DWB.

persName.note: Edward Stanley of Hooton.
John 'Aer Conwy Hen' (d. 1487), of Botrhyddan.

note.note: Bryan Saxton became the beneficiary of the forfeited estates of Hywel Gwynedd, which were bestowed upon him by Henry IV after the execution of Hywel. Pennant, A tour in Wales 1770 [1773](1778), I, p. 82

Hywel Gwynedd (d. 1406), a descendant of Edwin ap Gronw (d. 1073), prince of Tegeingl, was ambushed and killed on Moel y Gaer during Owain Glyndwr's revolt. DWB; Pennant, A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, pp. 82, 83; Davies, The Revolt of Owain Glyn Dŵr, p. 123.

Robert Powell Vaughan (1591/2–1667), associated with Hengwrt near Dolgellau, Merioneth, although he did not live there before his marriage (of which the date is unknown). He published British Antiquities Revived (1662), translated Brut y Twysogion (sic) for James Ussher, and had some part in the creation of Memoirs of Owen Glendowr associated with Thomas Ellis. ODNB.

Cynric Efell, baron of Eglwyseg, is named as the antecedent of the Eytons of Leesood; the Wynnes of Tower, and the Davieses of Gwasane, among others, in HPWaH, p. 315. There is no mention of his being a bastard son of Madog ap Maredudd in ODNB.

John Salusbury (d.1677), of Erbistock. His most notable work (lost in a fire at Wynnstay in 1858 but preserved in a copy by Joseph Morris, Wynnstay) is a hugely valuable source for the pedigrees of north-east Wales in the seventeenth century. Daniel Huws, 'A Repertory of Welsh Manuscripts and Scribes' (forthcoming), 'Scribes', pp. 173–4.
On the descent of this family from Cynric Efell, baron of Eglwyseg, see HPWaH, p. 315.
On the descent of this family from Cynric Efell, baron of Eglwyseg, see HPWaH, p. 315.
On the descent of this family from Cynric Efell, baron of Eglwyseg, see HPWaH, p. 315.
Son of Llywarch Hen, the sixth-century British prince.

persName.note: Llywarch Hen (supp. fl. late 6th century), a descendant of Coel Hen and a first cousin to the historical Urien Rheged. He was the subject of a cycle of Welsh saga poetry, most of which probably dates from the ninth century. ODNB; Ifor Williams (ed.), Canu Llywarch Hen (Caerdydd: Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru, 1935).
A king of Lydia, 6th century BC, renowned for his wealth.

note.note: John Foulkes of Merton, vicar of Holywell. See HPWaH, p. 52; rental, accounts and papers dated 1772–1815, Flintshire Record Office, D/DM/1192.

Son of Ynyr Fychan, Meurig Fychan is commemorated by a sepulchral effigy in Dolgellau church. He was grandfather to Hywel Sele, supposed traitor against Owain Glyndwr. DWB s.n. Nanney (Nannau) family.
Son of Ynyr Hen, Ynyr Fychan claimed to have assisted in the capture of Madog ap Llywelyn, a rebel against Llywelyn ap Gruffudd (d.1282). DWB s.n. Nanney (Nannau) family; Madog ap Llywelyn.

Nannau was built by Cadwgan ap Bleddyn ap Cynfyn in the early twelfth century and the family were staunch supporters of the Welsh poets as late as the seventeenth century. See here [accessed 14 March 2019].
Ynyr ap Meurig, also known as Ynyr Hen (fl.1200–50). DWB.

Owain ap Cadwgan was a grandson of Bleddyn ap Cynfyn. He supported his father in his efforts to hold on to Powys, but modern scholars have disputed the claims of his heroism made in the medieval Welsh chronicles. By 1111 he was acknowledged as king of Powys. He left no sons. Maund, The Welsh Kings, pp. 85, 87–92.
