note.note: The landholder of Nannau after the death of his father, his own sons included Hywel Selau and Dafydd. See here [accessed 14 March 2019].

An example of transcription work in the hand of Sir John Powys (fl. c.1514) is found in NLW 3032B, which includes a genealogical compilation, 'Ystoria achoedd brenhinoedd a thywyssogion', in his hand. See Daniel Huws, Repertory of Welsh Manuscripts and Scribes (forthcoming).

John Luther (?1739–86), of Myles's, near Ongar, Essex, married Levinia (née Bennett) in 1762, but had left her by 1764. Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, and admitted to the Middle Temple in 1755, he was MP for Essex from 1763 to 1784. Neither of Luther's two children survived their father, and he bequeathed his Essex estate to a nephew and a large Sussex estate to Richard Watson, Bishop of Llandaff, with whom he had had a thirty-year-long friendship and who had supported him at the time of his marital breakdown. Hist P; ODNB s.n. Richard Watson, bishop of Llandaff; Richard Watson, Anecdotes of the life of Richard Watson, Bishop of Landaff, written by himself at different intervals, and revised in 1814, rev. by Richard Watson, junior (London: Cadell and Davies, 1817), p. 28.

persName.note: A son of the horticulturalist John Blackburne (bap. 1694, d. 1786) and his wife Catherine (née Ashton; 1701–40), Jonathan Blackburne had 'a valuable and vast collection of prints, which was sold in London, March 1786'. SeeODNB s.n. John Blackburne;Gentleman's Magazine, XCIV, pt. I (March 1824), 210.
Baron Seymour of Sudely (b. in or before 1509, d. 1549), was appointed lord high admiral in 1547.
Margaret Bingham (née Smith), countess of Lucan (c.1740–1814), miniature painter, praised by Walpole for her skill in copying and reproducing miniatures. ODNB.

George Nugent-Temple-Grenville, first marquess of Buckingham (1753–1813), son of George Grenville, prime minister during the 1760s, sat in parliament for a Buckinghamshire seat from 1774 to 1779 and held the post of lord lieutenant of Ireland during 1782–3 and again in 1787–9. Hist P;ODNB.

Anthony Henley (1666/7–1711), wit and politician, was the subject of portraits in oils by G. Kneller, together with two mezzotints (1688 and 1694) by J. Smith, and a portrait by W. C. Edwards, n.d., all after Kneller. ODNB.

note.note: Humphrey Llwyd (1527–68), Welsh antiquary and map maker, whose feats included an English translation of the Welsh Brut y tywysogyon ('chronicle of the princes') completed in 1559, and maps of Wales and of England and Wales, published by Abraham Ortelius in 1573. ODNB.

persName.note: William Hogarth (1697–1764), painter and engraver.

note.note: Bell Lloyd (1724–1793), of Pontruffydd in the Vale of Clwyd, receiver-general for Flintshire, became the owner of the Bodfach and Glan Meheli estates, Montgomeryshire, and the Boultisbrook estate in Radnorshire on his marriage in 1758 to Anne, daughter and heiress of Edward Pryce of Bodfach. He predeceased his uncle, Sir Edward Lloyd (?1710–1795), first baronet, who was to have left him his property. He died on 6 May 1793 while attending the court of King's Bench prison as a debtor, having borrowed £37,000 to buy additional estates in Montgomeryshire and Cardiganshire. DWB; Murray Ll. Chapman, 'The development of Llanfyllin as a market town and the 1789 Llanfyllin Market House Act', Montgomeryshire Collections, 85 (1997), 23–49, esp. 44; 'A brief history of Bodfach Hall, Montgomeryshire' @ here [accessed 14 March 2019].

persName.note: The Llwyd family of Cwm Bychan, Merionethshire.

note.note: Grandson of Meurig Llwyd of Nannau, Merionethshire, Hywel Sele was reputedly a traitor against Owain Glyndwr. DWB.

persName.note: Dai Llwyd of Cwm Bychan, Merionethshire (fl. 1485). DWB.

The historical Owain ap Thomas ap Rhodri (Owain Lawgoch; d. 1378) played a notable part in the struggles of the Hundred Years' War. After his death he featured in the tradition of Welsh prophetic poetry, drawing support for resistance which contributed to the success of Owain Glyndwr's revolt early in the fifteenth century. ODNB.

note.note: Richard III (1452–85).

Dafydd or David Owen (Dafydd y Garreg Wen; 1711/12– 1741), of Ynyscynhaearn, Caernarfonshire, known as a harpist, is the reputed composer of several famous Welsh tunes, including 'Dafydd y Garreg Wen' (David of the White Rock), but at least some of the attributions are now considered erroneous. DWB; Gwyddoniadur Cymru, p. 262.

Revd Benjamin Conway, of Efenechtyd, Denbigshire, was Warden of Ruthin and vicar of Northop, Flintshire. He married Elizabeth, daughter and heir of John Conway (d. 1680) of Soughton, Flintshire, and was grandfather to John Lloyd, Hafodunos and Wigfair. Pennant refers to an observation on swallows communicated to him by Conway, in British zoology, II (1768), p. 502. DWB; description of 'Soughton Hall estate, SOUGHTON HALL ESTATE PAPERS, 1449-1965. Flintshire Record Office / Archifdy Sir y Fflint. GB 208 D-SH' on the Archives Hub website here [accessed 3 September 2019].

persName.note: Apparently an aunt of John Lloyd, Hafodunos and Wigfair, on either side of his family (since the maiden name of his mother, Phoebe (d. 1760) was also Lloyd).

note.note: John Lloyd (1750–1815), of Hafodunos and Wigfair in Denbighshire and Tyddyn in Flintshire. Known as 'The Philosopher' on account of his interests in the natural sciences, he had a substantial library, which included scientific apparatus as well as books and manuscripts. His wide network of correspondents included Joseph Banks and the astronomer Frederick William Herschel as well as antiquaries with Welsh interests such as Philip York and Daines Barrington. DWB; Hist P. For the papers of the Wigfair family, which include a large number of letters to and from John Lloyd, see NLW 12401–12513D.

The engraver and publisher Theodor de Bry (1528–98) was born in Liège, but settled at Frankfurt. His works included India Orientalis and America, both published in multiple parts. The latter included images of Native Americans, some displaying their savage cannibalism, others depicting peaceful relations between them and communities of European settlers. COPAC; here [accessed 3 September 2019].

persName.note: unidentified

note.note: The archivist Thomas Astle (1735–1803) devoted his life to collecting manuscripts, of which he had amassed more than 250 at the time of his death. His most notable acquisitions included pre-conquest charters and an eleventh-century 'Liber vitae' of Hyde Abbey, Winchester (all of which are now among the Stowe manuscripts at the British Library). He was appointed chief clerk of the record office in the Tower in 1775, a post to which he was well qualified in view of his experience reporting on the records in the state paper office and work on publishing the rolls of parliament. ODNB.

persName.note: Sarah (1729–80) was the twin sister of Catherine Pennant. See Catherine Pennant.

note.note: Edward Haistwell (1736–1783), antiquary. His correspondence with Richard Gough at the Bodleian Library is dated between 8 May 1760 and 31 December 1782, with further letters undated. See here [accessed 3 September 2019].

persName.addName: Archbishop of Grenada in Gil Blas

persName.note: Arthur Chichester, fifth earl of Donegall (1739–99), MP for Malmesbury in Wiltshire between 1768 and 1774. Hist P.

Lord Algernon Percy (1750–1830), second son of Hugh Percy, first duke of Northumberland, represented Northumberland in parliament, 1774–86, but was of an indifferent state of health, and by disposition little suited for the bustle of the political world. Hist P;ODNB.

note.note: Elizabeth Falconer (née Inge; d. 1775) was Pennant's mother-in-law from his first marriage to Elizabeth Falconer.
Pennant's account of the tomb of Sir William Manwaring of Over Pever and Badely, with 1399 supplied as a date of death, is found in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 21–2.
Daughter of Sir Henry Peyton, Louisa Peyton married David Pennant in December 1793.

Venetia Digby (née Stanley), Lady Digby (1600–33), daughter of Sir Edward Stanley (d. 1629?) and his wife, Lady Lucy Percy. She and Sir Kenelm Digby married abroad and in secret, probably during 1624. Renowned for her beauty, Venetia was painted twice by Van Dyck, firstly as the allegorical figure Prudence and secondly on her deathbed. A version of the former drawing was seen by Pennant at Gothurst, and is described in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 335–6. See further ODNB; here [accessed 3 September 2019]. For the 'Bust of Lady Venetia Digby', see The journey from Chester to London, p. 337.

Sir Kenelm Digby (1603–65), of Gayhurst in Buckinghamshire, was the son of Sir Everard Digby, executed in 1606 for his part in the Gunpowder Plot. A natural philosopher, Digby's magnum opus, Two treatises, in the one of which the nature of bodies, in the other the nature of man's soul is looked into was partially written in prison, where he had been committed at the beginning of the civil war, and was first published in Paris in 1644. As a noted student of chemistry, Digby was among the earlier members of the Royal Society. The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 334–5; ODNB.

Gothurst was sold by the husbands of two of Sir Kenelm Digby's granddaughters to George Wright, eldest son of the lord keeper Sir Nathan Wright (1654–1721). ODNB; The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 333–4.

Pennant (using 'the famous genealogy of the Digbys of Tilton' lent to him by Sir Watkin Williams) notes that the Digby family was descended from Saxon roots, taking their name from a village and parish in Lincolnshire. They held the manors of Tilton, Leicestershire, from the thirteenth century, and of Stoke Dry in Rutland from the fifteenth century, before Gayhurst (or Gothurst) became their main seat through the marriage of a sole heiress of the Mulshos family, then its owners, to Sir Everard Digby in the early seventeenth century. ODNB s.n. Sir Kenelm Digby; Pennant, A journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 326–8. On the portraits remaining at Gothurst after the sale of the house to George Wright, see ibid., pp. 334–8.

This refers to the successors of the Derbyshire industrialist John Smalley (d. 1782), who established cotton works at Holywell, erecting what became known as the 'Old Cotton Mill' in 1777. HPWaH, p. 203.

persName.note: Christopher Smalley, eldest son of John Smalley, and a partner in the Cotton Twist Company of Holywell, Flintshire. In a letter of 11 August 1795 to Pennant he gave particulars about the buildings, employees and workings of the mill of the company. Smalley was involved in the campaign for improving the condition of the roads in Flintshire, embraced by Pennant in January 1792, and in the setting up of the Flintshire Association on 20 December 1792. WCRO, TP20/13; A letter to a member of parliament, on mail-coaches (London: printed for R. Faulder, MDCCXCII), p. 24; LL, pp. 135–40, esp. 136; HPWaH, pp. 215-17.

note.note: Roger Clough (1759–1833), son of Hugh Clough (1709–60). He settled in Denbighshire as a Church of England clergyman, was presented to the livings of Gwyddelwern in 1791 and Corwen in 1797, and sold his wife's Sussex estate to buy Bathafarn near Rhuthun. He was made a JP c.1794, and was involved in suppressing riots at Denbigh the following year. DWB s.n. Clough of Plas Clough, Glan-y-wern, Bathafarn, and Hafodunos.

Revd Thomas Clough (1756–1814) was appointed alderman of Denbigh in 1794 and became rector there in 1797. Like his younger brother Roger he participated in the suppression of anti-militia riots at Denbigh in 1795. DWB s.n. Clough of Plas Clough, Glan-y-wern, Bathafarn, and Hafodunos.

persName.note: King of France from 1774 until the abolition of the monarchy on 21 September 1792. He was guillotined on 21 January 1793.
The Somerset family to which John Perceval, second earl of Egmont, belonged.
Willem V (1748–1806), Prince of Orange, and stadtholder of the Dutch Republic.
Maria Anne Fitzherbert (1756–1837), whom the Prince of Wales secretly and illegally married on 15 December 1785. ODNB.

Beatrix (c.1386–1439), the natural daughter of John the Bastard, king of Portugal, is commemorated by an altar tomb at the chapel of Arundel, West Sussex. Pennant 'place[s] next to the Countess her woman Agnes, wife of Thomas Salmon', and provides the Latin inscription on her tomb. From Dover to the Isle of Wight, p. 92.
Edward VI (1537-1553), king of England and Ireland.
Countess of Somerset
Earl of Essex
Wife of Sir Richard Worsley
Sir Henry Neville (1561/2–1615), diplomat and courtier. Hist P;ODNB.

Cornelius Johnson (bap.1593, d.1661), son of an exile from Antwerp, was baptized in London. He produced portraits of gentry, professional and court sitters throughout 1620s, moved to Kent in the 1630s, possibly as a result of the arrival of Anthony Van Dyck at the English court, and left for the Netherlands in 1643, possibly on account of the English civil war. ODNB.
The Infanta Isabella Clara Eugenia (1566–1633), Archduchess of Austria.

Francesco Zuccarelli (1702–1788), an Italian painter famed for his Arcadian landscapes. He visited England during 1752–62 and 1765–71, becoming one of the founding members of the Royal Academy of Arts on his second visit. Michael Levey, 'Francesco Zuccarelli in England', Italian Studies, vol. XVI, issue 1 (1959), 1–21.
The seat of Newtown, Isle of Wight, was held by Mark Gregory (d. 1793) between 30 August 1784 and 1790. Hist P.

Sophia Burrell (née Raymond), Lady Burrell (1753–1802), eldest daughter of banker Charles Raymond of Valentines, Ilford, Essex. She was a poet and playwright and also published one novel. She and William Burrell had five sons and two daughters. ODNB.

The Dutch sculptor and printmaker Simon van de Passe (1595–1647) was the second son of Crispijn van de Passe, the elder. See http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=112174 [accessed 14 August 2018].
Philip Edmondson (b. 1756?), elder son of Joseph Edmondson, continued his father's prosperous coach-painting business. ODNB.

note.note: Diana, daughter of William, Lord Burghly. Pennant describes her tomb of in a mausoleum erected in her honour at Maulden church, Bedfordshire, by her husband Thomas Bruce, Earl of Elgin: 'On it is a sarcophagus ... out of which rises a miserable figure of the countess in her shroud: on whom the country people, by a very apt similitude, have bestowed the title of The lady in the punch-bowl'. The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 382.

persName.note: On the tomb of Wiliam, Lord Parr, see Horton church.

Joseph Avery (fl. 1727–44) was the author of author of several hydrographic surveys, mostly conducted by the order of government. They included work on lochs in the Highlands of Scotland as well as on the coasts of Sussex and Dorset. See COPAC.

note.note: The Mostyn family was associated with the Flintshire land on which the present Mostyn Hall stands as early as the fifteenth century. Both the Pengwern estate in Denbighshire and that of Gloddaeth, Caernarfonshire, later came to their possession. See DWB s. n. Mostyn family of Mostyn Hall, Flintshire; and here [accessed 4 September 2019].

persName.note: Thomas Yeakell (fl. 1776–95), a surveyor and engraver whose collaborative work included a map of Sussex, a survey of the Sussex coast and of estates in the county. He was also involved in the creation of a survey of Jersey published in 1795, the likely year of his death. See COPAC.
A surveyor who worked alongside Thomas Yeakell and others, mainly on work relating to the county of Sussex. See COPAC.
author ofThe seats of the nobility and gentry.

Richard Henry Alexander Bennett, junior (c.1771–1818), was the son of Richard Henry Alexander Bennett and his wife Elizabeth Amelia. He served in the Royal Navy, obtaining the rank of post-captain in 1796, and later the command of the frigate Tribune. He was still active as a naval captain until late in 1810, in spite of his election as MP for Launceston, Cornwall (1802–1806, July 1807–1812) and, briefly in 1807, for Enniskillen in County Fermanagh. Hist P; Notes & Queries, 11th Series, 1 (March 1910), 238; (May 1910), 371.
unidentified member of the Mostyn family; presumably dead.

Lady Mary Ker died intestate in March 1818. Her sister, Lady Essex Ker, with whom she was the co-heir of the Duke of Roxburghe and entitled to estates in Scotland, became her heiress and administratrix. Reports of Cases Decided in the High Court of Chancery, XV, p. 295.
widow of person pe0850
Princess Elizabeth (1635–50), daughter of Charles I and his wife, Henrietta Maria.
(1744–1826), historian, author of Elements of the science of ethics, on the principles of natural philosophy (1786). ODNB.
unidentified; object of an artwork by Moses?
unidentified; object of an artwork by Moses?

John Fielding of Paternoster Row was named among others as printer of A Voyage to the Pacific Ocean (London, 1784), and as sole printer of the same in a version which appeared in 1784–5. Various abridgments of Captain Cook’s third and last voyage to the Pacific Ocean were printed by him solely in 1785 and jointly with John Stockdale of Piccadilly in the same year.
author of A voyage towards the North Pole undertaken by His Majesty’s command, 1773 (1774).
author of An account of several late voyages & discoveries to the south and north: . . . Also towards Nove Zembia, Greenland or Spitsberg

note.note: Brownlow Cecil, Lord Burghley (1725–93), was the son of Brownlow Cecil of Burghley House, Stamford, Lincolnshire, who became eighth Earl of Exeter in 1722. The younger Bronlow was educated at St John's, Cambridge, from 1744 and held the parliamentary seat of Rutland in the East Midlands between 1747 and 1754. He relinquished the seat on his succession to his father's title, becoming ninth Earl of Exeter in November 1754. Hist P.

persName.note: author of Travels through Spain: in the years 1775 and 1776: in which several monuments of Roman and Moorish architecture are illustrated by accurate drawings taken on the spot
Alfonso de la Cueva-Benavides y Mendoza-Carrillo, marqués de Bedmar (1574–1655).
Carlos Francisco de Croix, marqués de Croix (1699–1756), viceroy of New Spain between 1766 and 1771.
Don Rodrigo Calderón, Count of Oliva (b. 1580s, d. 1621).

Francisco Gómez de Sandoval, Marquis of Denia and Duke of Lerma (1553–1625), a favourite of Philip III of Spain. The Oxford Dictionary of the Renaissance s.n. Lerma, Francisco Gomez di Sandoval y Rojas at here [accessed 29 August 2018].
Juan Fernández de Velasco, fifth Duke of Frías (c.1550–1613).
José de Gálvez y Gallardo, marqués de Sonora (1720– 1787), was appointed minister for the Indies in 1775 and held the post until 1787.
Pedro Téllez-Girón, third Duke of Osuna (1574–1624).
Maximilien de Béthune, first Duke of Sully, Marquis of Rosny and Nogent, Count of Muret and Villebon, Viscount of Meaux (1560–1641).
Archbishop of Toledo in 1599. He appears to have been the uncle, not the brother, of Francisco Gómez de Sandoval, first Duke of Lerma

persName.surname: Gómez Suárez de Figueroa y Córdoba
persName.note: Gómez Suárez de Figueroa y Córdoba, first Duke of Feria (1520?–1571)
Philip II of Spain
The 'duke of Gandía' was a hereditary Spanish title created in 1399.
The 'Conde de Lemos' is a title in the Spanish nobilty, which came into being in 1456.
Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros (1436–1517), known as Ximenes de Cisneros.
Thomas Falconer's nephew
"beggar", "captain", and "beau" who has "gone off" with the daughter of Sir Henry Clinton

Anna Maria Bowes (1770–1832), daughter of John Bowes (previously Lyon), ninth earl of Strathmore, and his wife Mary Eleanor Bowes. She eloped with her lover Henry James Jessop, barrister at law, 'late of Quebec', and married him on 28 January 1788. Gentleman's Magazine, LVIII, no. 2, part I, 177.
Thomas Plymley's brother.

Pennant gives an account of Chirk castle inA tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), I, pp. 285–8, but no mention is made here of Myddelton's Jacobite steward. Accounts relating to Jacobites in Wales mention neither Myddelton of Chirk Castle nor his steward. See Donald Nicholas, 'The Welsh Jacobites', THSC (1948), 467–74; Herbert M. Vaughan, The Welsh Jacobites (London, 1909); R. Russell Roberts, 'The Welsh Jacobites', Country Quest (August 2002), 24.
John Myddelton (1685–1747), of Chirk Castle, Denbighshire. Hist P.
"mademoiselle Bowes" daughter of the first Earl of Gowrie of Ruthven House in the Highlands of Scotland

note.note: Sir Roger Newdigate, fifth baronet (1719–1806), of Arbury, Warwickshire, and Harefield, Middlesex, architect and member of Parliament for his home county in 1742–7 and 1751–80. A prize, designated 'The Newdigate Prize for Poetry', was established in 1806 following a bequest to the University of Oxford by Newdigate. Hist P; ODNB.

Josiah Wedgwood (1730–95) was born in Burslem, Staffordshire, to a family with a long-standing association with the pottery trade. In 1766 he bought an estate of 350 acres near Newcastle under Lyme, Staffordshire, where he built a pottery factory, calling it Etruria. Strategically placed on the path of the planned Trent and Mersey Canal, the factory (operated jointly by Wedgwood and Thomas Bentley) was officially opened in June 1769, and became noted not only for its innovative products but also for the enlightened treatment afforded to its workers. ODNB.

persName.note: Joseph-Antoine Crozat, marquis de Tugny (1696–1751), magistrate and collector of French art.

A Revd J. Poulter is named alongside Richard Bull as a contributor on Hampshire to J. Norris Brewer, Introduction to the Original Delineations, Topographical, Historical, and Descriptive, Intituled The Beauties of England and Wales (London, 1818), p. xxxv.

note.note: Charles III (1716-88), king of Spain and the Spanish Indies (1759-88) and styled Charles VII of Naples and V of Sicily before his abdication of the latter two titles in favour of his son Ferdinand in 1759.

persName.note: The Amazonian queen who, according to the collections of legends depicting the exploits of Alexander the Great, known as 'The Romance of Alexander', brought a group of 300 women with her to visit Alexander, hoping to breed a race of children sharing his virtues.

Edwin Sandys (1726–97) of Ombersley, Worcestershire, succeeded his father, Samuel Sandys, as Lord Sandys in 1770. He was MP for the boroughs of Droitwich, Bossiney and Westminster successively between 1747 and 1770. Hist P.

Henry Walther (fl. c.1775–1815), one of a group of German binders who came to England in the late eighteenth century. British Library 'Database of Bookbindings', at https://www.bl.uk/catalogues/bookbindings/LargeImage.aspx?RecordId=020-000001528&ImageId=ImageId=40369&Copyright=BL [accessed 4 September 2018]; Julie Gardham, rev., 'British Bookbindings: 16th–19th Century', at http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/exhibns/bindings/#walther [accessed 4 September 2018].
a "french correspondent" of Richard Bull's
Jacques Necker (1732–1804), French finance minister from 1777 to 11 July 1789.
archduke of Austria, king of Bohemia and Hungary (1780–20 February 1790).

Catherine II (Catherine the Great; 1729–96), Empress of Russia. She came to power in 1762, following the assassination of her husband, Peter III, which may have been the result of a conspiracy led by Catherine herself. In reference to this, Pennant calls her the ‘northern semiramis’ or ‘Semiramis of the North’, seeing her as a mirror of the belligerent historical Semiramis who succeeded her husband to the throne of Assyria.

Thomas Thornton (bap. 1767?, d. 1814), brother to the diplomatist Sir Edward Thornton, count of Cassilhas in the Portuguese nobility (1766–1852). Thomas Thornton was involved in commerce whilst still very young, and sent to work at the British factory in Constantinople in 1793. He published an account of Ottoman history and of contemporary Turkish politics and institutions, The Present State of Turkey, in 1807, with an enlarged second edition in 1809. ODNB.

John Wilkes (1725–97), although representing Middlesex as MP until 1790, lived at a property named ‘Villakin’ in Sandown, Isle of Wight from 1788 to 1797. His relationship with his wife Mary, daughter and heiress of John Mead of Aylesbury (d. 1784), a puritanical lady ten years his senior, broke down permanently in 1757. Their only daughter chose to live with her father after her parents' separation. Hist P; ODNB.
Mary Wilkes (b. 1750), daughter of John Wilkes and his wife Mary. She was known as Polly. ODNB s.n. John Wilkes (1725–1797).

Sir John Edward Swinburne (1762–1860), MP for Launceston, Cornwall, from 18 June 1788 to 1790, married Emilia Elizabeth Bennett, daughter of Richard Bull's stepson, Richard Henry Alexander Bennett. Their first-born was Edward (1788–1819), Bull's step-great-grandchild. Hist P.
Reverend Norman Macleod of Fiunary, Morvern (1745-1824).

Palomino De Castro Y Velasco (1655–1726), was appointed court painter in 1688. From 1699 he worked on frescoes in churches throughout Spain. Encyclopædia Britannica s. n. Palomino De Castro Y Velasco, at https://www.britannica.com/biography/Palomino-de-Castro-y-Velasco [accessed 4 September 2018].

José Moñino, first Count of Floridablanca (1728–1808), Spanish chief minister from 1777. He followed a reformist agenda, the achievements of which included university reform and greater press liberties.
author of A narrative of four journeys into the country of the Hottentots, and Caffraria: In the years one thousand seven hundred and seventy-seven, eight, and nine.

note.note: Born in Anglesey, the botanist Hugh Davies was educated at the free grammar school in Beaumaris and at Jesus College, Oxford. He returned to work as a cleric on Anglesey, before being promoted rector of Llandegfan with Beaumaris (1778–87) and subsequently of Aber in Caernarvonshire (a post which he resigned in 1816, due to ill health). Pennant first met Davies in July 1773; by the following August, Davies was accompanying Pennant and his party on a tour of the Isle of Man and, in June 1775, he returned there on Pennant's request 'to take a second review of its vegetable productions'. Davies further served Pennant by contributing information for a number of publications, and largely taking on the mantle of editor for the reappearance of Indian zoology in 1790. His own direct contribution to the study of botany in Wales came with the publication in 1813 of Welsh botanology. ODNB; Thomas Pennant to Daines Barrington, 4 July 1773, NLW 12440E, f. 64; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 278–83, 545, 547–8; Thomas J. Owen, 'Hugh Davies: the Anglesey botanist', TAASFC (1961), 39–52.

persName.note: Vasco da Gama (c.1460s–1524), Portuguese explorer who discovered the sea route around the Cape of Good Hope to India from Europe, landing in Calicut, India, in May 1498.

The Swiss engraver, publisher and art dealer Christian von Mechel (1737–1817) printed and possibly edited a volume of the work of Hans Holbein, the younger. See Oeuvre de Jean Holbein ou recueil de gravures d'après les plus beaux ouvrages de ce fameux peintre (Basel, 1780–95).
4th Earl of Chesterfield (1694-1773), author of the conduct book posthumously published in 1774 as Letters to his Son.
American artist (1738-1820)

(1764-1823), novelist whose fictional ruined castles and abbeys became a key component of late eighteenth-century Gothic aesthetics. See, for example, The Castles of Athlin and Dunbayne: A Highland Story (1789).

(1772-1839), a member of the circle of artists who gathered at Dr Monro’s house, and of ‘The Brothers’ sketching group. Francia exhibited ‘The pass leading to Pont Aberglaslyn from Beth Kellert’ at the Royal Academy in 1800 – see Peter Bishop, Vision and Revision, p. 141.

John Varley (1778–1842) was a watercolourist and teacher of art, and latterly astrologer. John accompanied his brother Cornelius on a Welsh tour in 1802; he had previously visited Wales in 1799, where he is mentioned in Robert Ker Porter's account of his Welsh tour of that year.
(1685-1759), German-born English composer.
Possibly the daughter of David Alves Rebello, a Hackney merchant. The death of a ‘Miss Rebello’ was widely noted in London periodicals in the summer of 1803.
5th Duke of Devonshire (1748-1811).
5th Duke of Rutland (1778-1857).

note.note: 1st Baron Scarsdale (1726-1804), owner of Kedleston Hall. He rebuilt the house and grounds in 1759, relocating an entire village to a new site outside the park.

persName.note: (1598-1677), clergyman and Oxford fellow, later Archbishop of Canterbury, who sponsored the construction of the Sheldonian Theatre.
(1610-88), 1st Duke of Ormond, elected Chancellor of Oxford University in 1669
(1632-1723), architect best known for his work in London, including St Paul’s Cathedral.
(1609-74), 1st Earl of Clarendon, wrote one of the earliest histories of the Civil War, The History of the Rebellion and Civil Wars in England, posthumously published between 1702 and 1704.
John Radcliffe (bap. 1650, d. 1714), physician and philanthropist. ODNB.

Rev. Joseph Plymley (later Corbett; 1759-1838), member of the network (also including the Darwin and Wedgwood families) that made up the Shropshire enlightenment and abolitionist, who became archdeacon of Shropshire in 1792.
(1682/3-1765) British Army officer, who bequeathed his collection of over 200 paintings and almost 2000 drawings to Christ Church, his former college.
Venetian painter (1518-94), known as Tintoretto.
(1728-79), German artist.

note.note: (1749-1804) Irish glass-painter who was commissioned to paint designs by Sir Joshua Reynolds (1723-92) for the west window of New College’s chapel in the 1770s. See http://www.therosewindow.com/pilot/Oxford-new-col/Ww-Frame.htm

persName.note: (1747–1808), British sculptor.
(1545-1613), a Fellow of Merton College and founder of the Bodleian Library.
(1746-1816), 2nd Earl of Warwick.
(1793-1858), nephew of Gabriel Piozzi and adopted son of Hester and Gabriel Piozzi.
(1778-1820), Viscount Kirkwall, M.P.
(née Blaquiere; d. 1843).
(1742–1815), Bishop of St Asaph between 1806 and 1815.
(née Thrale; 1777-1857), youngest sister of Sophia Hoare.
(1764-1830), 9th Baronet and M.P. for Caernarfonshire and later Beaumaris.

(1773-1828) landowner, agricultural improver and M.P., famous for having reclaimed hundreds of acres of marshland in the Afon Glaslyn estuary and constructed an embankment across the estuary near Porthmadog

note.note: (1750-1811), owner of Plas Tan-y-Bwlch and slate quarries in Blaenau Ffestiniog. Oakley acquired the estate through his marriage to the heiress Margaret Gryffydd.

persName.note: (1770-1856), banker and husband of Sophia Thrale (m. 1807). Half-brother to pe0942

Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, fifth baronet (1772–1840), of Wynnstay, Denbigshire. Member of Parliament for Beaumaris (1794–6) and Denbighshire (1796–1840), he succeeded to his father's title upon the latter's death on 29 July 1789. Hist P.
(1758-1838), 2nd Baronet, landowner, antiquarian and art patron. Half-brother to pe0940

(1747–1821), topographical writer and antiquarian. Proposed a new edition of Pennant's Tours, with illustrations by Sir Richard Colt Hoare, in 1808, but was unable to gain permission for this project from David Pennant.
(1752-1828), Cheshire landowner and industrialist, who owned the Vaynol estate.

Ednyfed Fychan (d. 1246), steward of Llywelyn ab Iorwerth (d. 1240) from about 1215. Llywelyn granted him lands and privileges in recognition of his services. The land at Penmynydd in Anglesey became the seat of Ednyfed's family, several of whom continued to work as stewards or administrators in the service of the native Welsh princes. ODNB.

note.note: Tudur ap Goronwy (d. 1367?), grandfather of Owen Tudor. His sister in law married Gruffudd Fychan of Glyndyfrdwy and was the mother of Owain Glyndwr, in whose revolt Tudur ap Goronwy's sons fought. ODNB s.n. Owen Tudor.

persName.note: Owen Tudor (c.1400–1461), the son of Maredudd ap Tudur ap Goronwy. His father was descended from Ednyfed Fychan and held the seat of Penmynydd in Anglesey. The circumstances of Owen's meeting with and subsequent marriage to Catherine of Valois, widow of Henry V, is shrouded in mystery and was the subject of much speculation by antiquarians and chroniclers in the years following his death. Three sons were born of the marriage, including Edmund Tudor, father of the future Henry VII. Owen was captured at the battle of Mortimer's Cross in February 1461, and beheaded at Hereford. ODNB.

Catherine of Valois (1401–1437), youngest daughter of Charles VI of France and Isabella of Bavaria. In an effort to bring about peace between England and France, it was suggested as early as 1408 that she should be a suitable bride to Henry V, but the marriage did not take place until 1420. Henry's death only two years later left her as the mother of the infant king Henry VI. Her attachment to Edmund Beaufort, the young nephew of chancellor Bishop Henry Beaufort, was frustrated by the enacting of a statute in parliament forbidding marriage to a queen without royal consent. She later married (under morganatic terms) Owen Tudor, although this was not known outside court circles until after her death. Children from the marriage included Edmund and Jasper Tudor, respectively father and uncle of the future Henry VII. ODNB.

Prince Frederick, duke of York and Albany (1763–1827), the second son of George III. His father's title of elector of Hanover enabled him to use his influence to bring about Frederick's election as bishop of Osnabrück, a post which he retained until 1803. He began a career in the army as a colonel in November 1780, and was active in Flanders during several campaigns alongside the Austrian army of the prince of Coburg in 1793–5. He later turned to military reform, but his reputation was compromised by his love of gambling and his ill-advised liaisons with women, especially Mary Anne Clarke. ODNB.

note.note: Madog Gloddaith ap Madog Fychan, of Gloddaith, Caernarvonshire. He was high sheriff of the county in 1325/6. Gloddaith eventually came to the possession of the Mostyn family, Flintshire. DWB s.n. Mostyn family of Mostyn Hall, Flints., etc.; Lewys Dwnn, Heraldic Visitations of Wales and Part of the Marches, ed. by Samuel Rush Meyrick (Llandovery: William Rees, 1846), II, p. 308.

The descent of north Wales men from Yswittan Wyddel is noted in 'Heraldry of Wales' (Hengwrt MS 359), an Elizabethan compilation. See G. T. C., 'Heraldry of Wales', Archaeologia Cambrensis, fourth series, no. XII (1872), 315–329, esp. 328. Pennant includes 'A variation of the arms of Yswittan Wŷddel' among a number of coats of arms displayed in HPWaH, plate IV.

persName.note: David Samwell (Dafydd Ddu Feddyg; 1751–1798), born at Nantglyn, Denbighshire, was a founder-member of the London-Welsh Gwyneddigion society, a keen supporter of its eisteddfodau, and a poet with a turn for satire. In his professional capacity as naval surgeon, he was present on Captain James Cook's third voyage (1776–1780), an experience which he documented in a detailed journal, later published as A narrative of the death of Captain James Cook . . . and observations respecting the introduction of the venereal disease into the Sandwich Islands (1786). Ill health and disillusionment with naval life led to his acceptance in 1798 of a post at Versailles attending British prisoners of war. ODNB.

Edward Williams (Iolo Morganwg; 1747–1826), stonemason, labouring poet and literary forger. Iolo brought his home county of Glamorgan to the attention of the literary world against a perceived bias for a north-Wales-based tradition among the London literati and others, and fought against the evils of kingcraft and priestcraft. ODNB; Geraint H. Jenkins, Bard of liberty: The political radicalism of Iolo Morganwg (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 2012); CIM.

(1739-1829), Irish diarist, letter writer and hostess. Member of the Ascendency Ormond family, and one of the two ‘Ladies of Llangollen’, where she lived with her life partner, Sarah Ponsonby, after they left Ireland in dramatic circumstances in 1778.
(1732-1808), 2nd Baronet of Hawkstone Hall, Shropshire, prominent Calvinist Methodist and Tory M.P.
(1768-1821), Princess of Wales, estranged wife of the future George IV.

(1755-1831), Irish letter writer and hostess. Member of a Protestant Ascendency Anglo-Irish family, and one of the two ‘Ladies of Llangollen’, where she lived with her life partner, Lady Eleanor Butler, after they left Ireland in dramatic circumstances in 1778.

Dr John Moore (1752-1820), was a physician and author, educated at Glasgow University. After serving as a surgeon's mate in the army, he attended William Hunter's lectures on anatomy at London and later studied in Paris. He returned to practice in Scotland where he attended the seventh duke of Hamilton before his death. He subsequently accompanied the eighth duke as tutor on the grand tour of the continent, later producing successful works based on his travels: A View of Society and Manners in France, Switzerland, and Germany (1779) and A View of Society and Manners in Italy (1781). His 1789 sentimental novel Zeluco achieved widespread popularity and established his reputation as an author of fiction. In 1792 he travelled to France where he witnessed the growing violence of the French Revolution, recorded in his journal during a residence in France from the beginning of August to the middle of December 1792 (1793-94). ODNB.

William, later William IV (1765–1837), third son of George III. In late 1788 he was called home by his elder brother, George, then Prince of Wales, due to his father's illness. He reached Spithead on 29 April 1789 and proceeded to London, by which time his father had recovered. William was made Duke of Clarence on 1 May 1789. ODNB; Roger Knight, William IV: A King at Sea (London: Allen Lane, 2015), p. 37.

James-Carstairs Bruce, of Balchristie. In 1799 he married Elizabeth-Cecilia, daughter of James, seventh lord Rollo. John Debrett, The Peerage of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, 2 vols. (London: 1814), ii, p.834.
Princess Augusta Sophia (1768–1840)

Author of An introduction to the history and antiquities of Scotland. Containing many useful and curious particulars relating to the Antiquities of Scotland, either little known, or entirely overlooked by other Writers (Edinburgh: printed for P. Anderson, MDCCLXXXII [1782]) Possibly the "Goodall" of letter ct1086

Elizabeth-Cecilia, daugher of James, seventh lord Rollo and Mary (née Aytoun). In 1799 she married James Carstairs Bruce of Balchristie. John Debrett, The Peerage of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, 2 vols. (London: 1814), ii, p.834.
"the Stone eater", nickname for a friend of Richard Bull's.

note.note: Baptized at Whitford Church, Flintshire, on 24 April 1715, Mary Bridget Mostyn was the third surviving daughter of Sir Roger Mostyn, third baronet, and his wife Lady Essex (née Finch). She was a sister to Sir Thomas Mostyn, fourth baronet, and an aunt to Pennant's second wife, Ann (née Mostyn). A spinster, Mary Bridget was buried at St Mary le Bone, London, on 14 July 1789. Lord Mostyn and T. A. Glenn, History of the family of Mostyn of Mostyn (London: Harrison and Sons, 1925), p. 160, n. 3.

persName.note: the 6 children of Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, who had three sons and three daughters from his second marriage.
Charlotte Grenville (1754–1832), daughter of George Grenville, was Sir Watkin Williams Wynn's second wife.They were married in 1771. ODNB.
Lady Henrietta Somerset (1748–69), daughter of Charles Noel Somerset, the deceased fourth duke of Beaufort (1709–56). She died after little more than two months’ marriage. ODNB.

Peter Delmé (1748–89), MP for Morpeth in Northumberland from 1774 until his death, was notorious for his profligacy. He died on 15 August 1789. Hist P; https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Howard-11085 [accessed 10 September 2018].
Amy Burrell (née Raymond) (1699/1700–1789) was the mother of the antiquary Sir William Burrell, second baronet. ODNB s.n. Sir William Burrell.
Yolande-Martine-Gabrielle de Polastron, comtesse, later duchesse de Polignac (1749–93), a favourite of Marie Antoinette. She went into exile in Switzerland following the fall of the Bastille.

Harriet Trevor (née Burton) (1750/51–1829) was the wife of the diplomatist John Hampden-Trevor, third Viscount Hampden, whose work took him to Turin between 1783 and his retirement in 1800. A letter from Trevor to the Duke of Leeds, dated 31 July 1789, recounted how his wife was mistaken for Madame de Polignac at Besançon, and imprisoned for several hours before her release. ODNB; H. Morse Stephens, A History of the French Revolution (New impression, London: Longmans, Green, and Co., 1910), I, p. 168.
Sir Brooke Boothby, seventh baronet (1744–1824), of Ashbourne Hall, Derbyshire, succeeded to his father's title on 9 April 1789. ODNB.

Charles Phillippe, comte d'Artois, later Charles X of France (1757–1836), emigrated on 16–17 July 1789, spending a brief period at Spa in the Austrian Netherlands (Belgium) before deciding on 3 August to proceed to Turin, from where he directed the French émigré movement. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 315; Bernard Michal (ed.), Les Grandes Enigmes du temps jadis.
Richard Bull's younger sister, Kitty (1732–85), married Revd Charles Smith, rector of West Stoke near Chichester. https://www.revolvy.com/page/Richard-Bull-(MP) [accessed 10 September 2018].
Sir John Hawkwood (d.1394), military commander, whose English companies of soldiers were active in northern and central Italy during the 1370s and 1380s. ODNB.

Thomas Rymer (1642/3–1713), literary critic and historian, was appointed as editor of Foedera , a work designed to transcribe and publish English alliances, treaties and confederacies with other countries. Begun in 1698, and running beyond Rymer's lifetime, the first of twenty volumes was published in 1704. ODNB.
William MacDonald (1732-1814) was the eldest son of James Macdonald of Ranathan, Perthshire. He moved to Edinburgh and was admitted as a Writer to the Signet 1762. http://ica-atom.tasglann.org.uk

Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette (1757–1834), supporter of the American colonists during the Revolutionary War, occupied an ambivalent position in relation to the rule of Louis XVI in the early years of the French Revolution, eventually retreating from the political scene at the overthrow of the monarchy in August 1792.

Henry Luttrell (1653/4–1717), served the Jacobite cause in Ireland from March 1689, but had changed sides to support the Williamites by October 1691. He was awarded the Luttrellstown family estates as a reward, his elder brother having been outlawed as a Jacobite. In 1704 Luttrell married Elizabeth, daughter of Henry Jones of Halkyn, Flintshire, with whom he had two sons. He was shot dead near his Dublin home: the motive for the killing appears to have been linked to adultery. ODNB.

Henry Lawes Luttrell, second earl of Carhampton (1737–1821), politician and army officer. He succeeded to the family titles and estates on the death of his father, Simon Luttrell, first earl of Carhampton, and Baron Irnham, in 1787. Hist P;ODNB.
Elizabeth (1665–1723), daughter of Henry Jones, Halkyn, Flintshire. There is no mention of her being Henry Luttrell's servant prior to her marriage to him in 1704. ODNB.

Anne (née Luttrell; other married name Horton), duchess of Cumberland and Strathearn (1743–1808), was the daughter of Simon Luttrell, first earl of Carhampton (1713–87), and his wife, Judith Maria Lawes. She married Christopher Horton (. 1741, . 1769) and, in 1771, Prince Henry Frederick, Duke of Cumberland and Strathearn (1745–90). .
Sir Robert Grosvenor, sixth baronet (1695–1755), of Eaton Hall, near Chester, MP for Chester 1733–1755.
Henry V (1386–1422), king of England and lord of Ireland, and duke of Aquitaine.
For a manuscript work by Hugh Alley (1556–1602), see two drawings of old London markets.

Honoré-Gabriel Riquetti, comte de Mirabeau (1749–91), dominant during the crisis of summer 1789, but less so as the events of 1790 unfolded. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, pp. 372–3.
Jean Xavier Bureaux de Puzy (1750–1806) was the president of the National Assembly from 2 to 16 February 1790.
Author of the Italian epic poemOrlando Furioso (1516; published 1532).
Owners of Goodwood, then alienated to Henry Walrond by John, Lord Lumley, and his wife, Jane Fitz Alan, in 1584.
Samuel Barrington (1729–1800), naval officer, was promoted admiral in September 1787, and was second in command to Lord Howe during the dispute with Spain over Nootka Sound in 1790. ODNB.

John Willett Payne (1752–1803), naval officer and royal official. A friend of George, Prince of Wales, he was in France on the prince's business in July and August 1791. Bull's reference suggests that he was there the previous year as well. ODNB.
Richard Fitzpatrick (1748–1813), army officer and politician, was a founder member of the Whig Club in 1784 and a staunch supporter of Fox's opposition to the ministry of William Pitt. ODNB.

persName.addName: Duc de Nivernois, Mr La Porte
persName.note: Louis-Jules-Barbon Mancini-Mazarini, duc de Nivernais (1716–1798).
This must be a satirical nickname for a French political character.
This must be a satirical nickname for a French political character.
Pennant's old secretary (before he took Thomas Jones into his employment) has not been identified.
Author of A Picturesque tour through Holland, Brabant, and part of France
(fl.1775) Unidentified franker of a letter written to George Paton from London on 12 January 1775. His signature is partially illegible so the correct spelling of his name is uncertain.
Velters Cornewall (?1697–1768), of Moccas Court, Herefordshire. Hist P.

William Perry (1714–1757), of Turvill Park, Buckinghamshire, Wormington, Gloucestershire, and Penshurst-place, Kent. He made the latter his residence, repairing it and bringing to it a large collection of pictures gathered on travels in Italy. Burke, A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Peerage and Baronetage of the British Empire (6th ed., 1839), p. 948; R. C. B. Oliver, 'The Shelleys and Radnorshire', Radnorshire Society Transactions, vol. 41 (1971), 8–21, esp. 9; Edward Hasted, 'Parishes: Penshurst', in The History and Topographical Survey of the County of Kent: Volume 3 (Canterbury, 1797), at British History Online http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-kent/vol3 [accessed 18 September 2018].

John Jervis, earl of St Vincent (1735–1823), naval officer. In 1790 he was involved in the dispute with Spain, and gained promotion as rear-admiral of the white on 21 September that year. He held parliamentary seats alongside his naval career between 1783 and 1794. Hist P; ODNB.

Thomas Cochrane (1691-1778) was a soldier, M.P. for the county of Renfrew (1722) and a commissioner of excise in Scotland (1730). Cochrane resigned from the excise on succeeding as Earl of Dundonald in 1761. He died at his seat at La Mancha, near Peebles and was succeeded as by his son, Archibald. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

George Bruce (c.1550-1625) was born to a landed family and became a successful industrialist with saltworks and coal mines near Culross on the Firth of Forth. His concerns were noted for their use of cutting-edge industrial technology, and his profits allowed him to build a large mansion in the town of Culross. ODNB

Donald Balloch MacDonald was cousin to Alexander MacDonald, twelfth earl of Ross and self-styled Lord of the Isles (d.1449). Alexander was arrested by James I for disputing the crown's claim to the earldom of Ross. While his cousin was imprisoned, Donald Balloch continued to defy James, defeating the royal forces at the Battle of Inverlochy in 1431. ODNB

Alexander Stewart (d.1435) son of Alexander, 'the wolf of Badenoch', gained the title and lands of the earldom of Marr by storming the castle of Isabella, countess of Marr, and forcing her to marry him. He led the royalist army against Donald of the Isles at Harlaw in 1411. Alexander Stewart died without an heir in 1435 and the earldom of Marr reverted to the crown. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Robert II (1316-1390), king of Scots.

Thomas Percy (1729–1811) was a clergyman and ballad collector. Percy's most famous work was his 1765 Reliques of ancient English poetry. While some doubted the extent to which Percy's work reflected a true ballad tradition (he heavily edited many of the pieces in the collection), it was nonetheless hugely influential on Romantic period writers such as Burns, Wordsworth and Scott. In addition to the Reliques he published several other translations and collections of supposedly antique literature, including Paul Henri Mallet's Northern Antiquities, which contained a translation of the Scandinavian verse epic the Edda. ODNB

Richard Rowlands (1548x50-1640), later known by his grandfather's surnname, Verstegan, was a writer and agent for the Catholic misson in England. Among his works was the Restitution of Decayed Intelligence in Antiquities (1605), an important contribution to the antiquarian discourse on the Anglo-Saxons. ODNB

John Toland (1670-1722) was a religious thinker and writer, known for his controversial work, Christianity not Mysterious (1696). Toland's liberal views attracted the patronage of the Country Party Whigs, including Shaftesbury, and he continued to write works of political and theological criticism, later aligning himself with the beliefs of Pantheism and Spinoza. The posthumously published A collection of several pieces of Mr. John Toland, now first publish'd from his original manuscripts: with some memoirs of his life and writings (1726), contained among other pieces, 'A Specimen of the Critical History of the Celtic Religion and Learning: containing an Account of the Druids, &c.' ODNB.

Hector Boece, Latinized as Boethius (c.1465-1536) was a historian and first principal of King's College, Aberdeen. He was educated in Dundee and Paris, Collège de Montaigu, where he met Erasmus. The influence of the burgeoning humanist tradition is evident in his most significant work, Scotorum historiae a prima gentis origine (Paris: 1527), which narrates the history of the Scottish people from their antique origins until the death of James I. Boece's Scotorum historiae was a major source for the later works of George Buchanan and others. Scotorum historiae was translated into Scots by John Bellenden, under the commission of James V, to whom Boece's original was dedicated. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.

Putative mistress of Robert II of Scotland and an ancestor of the Stewarts, earls of Marr and Buchan. She is mentioned by Pennant in A tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774) p.187. Pennant's source is James Dalrymple, Collections concerning the Scottish history (Edinburgh: 1705).

(Johann) Georg Adam Forster (1754–1794) was a Prussian traveller and naturalist, son of (Johann) Reinhold Forster (1729-1798). Georg accompanied his father on expeditions in Russian and later to London in search of a position as a naturalist. In 1772, Georg and Reinhold Forster joined James Cook's second circumnavigation aboard the Resolution. Georg afterwards published a work on the plants of the Pacific with his father, and A Voyage Round the World, in His Britannic Majesty's Sloop, Resolution (1777). The German translation of the latter was highly influential. In Britain, Forster's Voyage sparked a bitter public dispute with the Earl of Sandwich, over the publishing rights to Pacific journals. ODNB.
Duff, king of Scotland, son of Malcom I, succeeded Indulph in 961. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Malcolm III, or Malcolm Ceann Mòr (c.1024-1093) was the son of Duncan, king of Scots, who himself was killed by Macbeth in the events that inspired Shakespeare's play. He ruled over a turbulent but pivotal period in the history of medieval Scotland. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

James Ogilvy, sixth earl of Findalter and third earl of Seafield (c.1714-1770), was a landowner and agriculturalist. He encouraged industry in the north east of Scotland and established a bleachfield and linen factory on his lands at Deskford and Cullen respectively. He occupied posts as a trustee for the annexed estates and the improvement of fisheries and manufacturers, and a commissioner of customs in Scotland, resigning from the latter in 1761. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Sir Thomas Sheridan, baronet (1684-1746), was a supporter of the Jacobite cause both in the British Isles and on the Continent. He was a courier during the rising of 1715 and a tutor to Charles Edward Stuart in Rome. He later accompanied the Prince as one of the 'seven men of Moidart' who landed with the him in Scotland in 1745. He escaped after Culloden to France, where he died of a stroke. ODNB.
Alexander Mcleod, Aide-de-camp who assisted Charles Edward Stuart in his escape after Culloden in 1746. Narrative of the Several Passages of the Young Chevalier, 4th edn. (London: 1765), p.5.
Sir David Murray, Aide-de-camp who assisted Charles Edward Stuart in his escape after Culloden in 1746. Narrative of the Several Passages of the Young Chevalier, 4th edn. (London: 1765), p.5.
Allan Macdonald, Jacobite who assisted Charles Edward Stuart in his escape after Culloden in 1746. Narrative of the Several Passages of the Young Chevalier, 4th edn. (London: 1765), p.5.

Helgy (fl.c.927), according to some sources a general of Sigurd, earl of Orkney, after whom the town of Elgin was named. See John Sinclair, Statistical Account of Scotland 21 vols (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), v, p.2.
Sigurd, a Norwegian earl of Orkney who conquered Morayshire in the 10th century.

(d. 1847), from 1797 sub-governess to Princess Charlotte and companion to Queen Caroline. See Martin Thomas, My Dear Hamy – Insights and Intrigues at the Court of Caroline, Princess of Wales (Wrexham, 2016).
Elizabeth Emma Crewe (1780-1850), daughter of Frances Crewe.
(fl. 1345-97), Denbighshire poet whose most famous patron was Owain Glyndŵr.

note.note: 1st duke of Marlborough (1650-1722), general and courtier.

persName.note: (1672-1719), writer and politician.

(d. 949/50), Welsh king who ruled first over the kingdom of Deheubarth, and later most of Wales, in the tenth century. Literally ‘Hywel the Good’, his name is associated with the codification of Welsh customary law in this period.
(1768-43), member of a powerful Welsh gentry family and M.P. for Merioneth from 1792-1836. His estates at Hengwrt and Nannau held key collections of Welsh manuscripts.

Bartholomew de Fonte (fl.1640) was reputed to have made a voyage to the north-west coast of America during which a passage from the Pacific to the Atlantic ocean was discovered. An account published in Monthly Miscellany or Memoirs for the Curious (April and June 1708) is now judged to be an apocryphal account and there is no reliable evidence to authenticate the voyage or the existence of de Fonte. Dictionary of Canadian Biography, at http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/fonte_bartholomew_de_1E.html [accessed 18 September 2018].

Juan de Fuca (1536–1602), a Greek pilot in service of Philip II of Spain, explored the Strait of Anián, now Strait of Juan de Fuca, between Vancouver Island (now part of the British Columbia) and Olympic Peninsula (now in the north west of Washington State). William Guthrie, A new geographical, historical, and commercial grammar; And present state of the several kingdoms of the world (2nd American ed., improved, 2 vols., Philadelphia, 1815), p. 570.

note.note: (1742–1809), poet and correspondent. In the summer of 1795, Seward was making her own tour of north Wales, which she documented in her letters (posthumously published, edited by Walter Scott). Her Welsh tour resulted in the publication of Llangollen Vale, with other Poems, the following year.

persName.note: 1st Baron de Tabley (1762-1827) politician, amateur artist, and patron of the arts.
3rd Baron Grey de Ruthyn (c. 1362-1440), powerful marcher lord who was closely involved in the Glyndŵr rebellion on the English side.
Hywel ab Einion Llygliw (fl. c. 1330-70), poet who composed poems to Myfanwy Fychan
Myfanwy Fychan of Castell Dinas Bran, Llangollen, the subject of love poems by Hywel ab Einion

(1728-1808), English ironmaster and industrialist whose father, Isaac Wilkinson, moved to Bersham furnace near Wrexham in north Wales in 1753. John was a partner in Bersham from 1755, and in 1792 bought Brymbo Hall estate, Denbighshire. His sister Mary married Joseph Priestley in 1762 and Wilkinson shared Priestley’s early enthusiasm for the French Revolution. He made large investments in French assignats, using ‘countersigned assignats as a form of token payment at Bersham’, until stopped by Parliament in 1793. ODNB.

The antiquary Robert Thoroton (1623–78) was born in Nottinghamshire and, from 1667 devoted himself to the study of his county's antiquities. His focus was on uncovering the manorial history of each parish in the county back to Domesday. The work was published in 1677, to the acclaim of a fellow-antiquary and friend, Sir William Dugdale. ODNB.
(1747-1814), who acquired Old Gwrych in the late eighteenth century via his marriage to Frances Lloyd
(1752-95), inherited Old Gwyrch in the late eighteenth century, wife of Robert Bamford-Hesketh and sister to John Lloyd

A native of Montgomeryshire, William Worthington (1704–1778) was educated at both Oxford and Cambridge, and awarded the degrees of BD and DD from Oxford in 1742. He subsequently took up a string of appointments in the church in Shropshire, Denbighshire, Montgomeryshire, Flintshire and Merionethshire, finally settling at Llanrhaeadr-ym-Mochnant, Montgomeryshire, in 1745. He was visited at his enlarged vicarage in Llanrhaeadr by both Thomas Pennant and Samuel Johnson, and published several theological works, including The Evidence of Christianity (1769). His response to Hugh Farmer's 1775 Essay on Demoniacks was published in 1777 and posthumously in 1779. His interest in missionary work was reflected in his will, in which he left a legacy to the SPCK among other protestant missionary societies. DWB; ODNB; A tour in Wales (1778), II, p. 350.
(1751-1837), brother of Frances Crewe, who followed a naval career.
(d. 1806), margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach-Bayreuth, husband of the playwright and travel writer Lady Elizabeth Craven (née Berkeley).
William Murray, 1st earl of Mansfield (1705-93), Scottish-born politician and judge, best-known for his role in the move towards the abolition of slavery.
John Parry (1710?-82), also known as ‘Parry Ddall’ or ‘Blind Parry’. Well-known eighteenth-century harpist who performed on the triple harp (i.e. harp with three layers of strings).

Peter Broster (d. 1816) was a stationer, bookseller, printer and antiquary at Chester. He was made a freeman in 1766, and was the publisher of The Chester Guide and Directory in 1780 and in subsequent years. He held the offices of sheriff (1776) and mayor (1791) in the city. R. Stewart-Brown, 'The Stationers, booksellers and printers of Chester to about 1800', Transactions of the Historic Society of Lancashire and Cheshire, 83 (1932), 101–152, esp. 121–122.

Edward Thurlow, first Baron Thurlow (1731–1806), was lord chancellor in 1778–83 and again between December 1783 and June 1792. He was openly at variance with Pitt from 1788, and relations between him and Grenville in the House of Lords were strained, with Pitt warning George III on 20 November 1790 of impending difficulties on account of Thurlow's disposition. ; Michael J. Turner, Pitt the Younger: A Life (London, 2003), p. 118.

Sir James Eyre (bap. 1734, d. 1799), was knighted and made a baron of the exchequer in 1772, and chief baron in 1787. The Chelmsford Chronicle, 3 December 1790, reported that it was 'confidently asserted that baron Eyre is to be the Speaker of the house of lords, and to be immediately created a peer for that purpose'.
In November 1790 William Wyndham Grenville (1759–1834) was created Baron Grenville and nominated by Pitt leader (or speaker) of the House of Lords, a post which he held for almost ten years.

Ordained in 1568, William Morgan (1544/5–1604) was appointed vicar of Llanrhaeadr-ym-mochnant in 1578, and it was here that he worked on a translation of the Bible into Welsh, publishing it in 1588. Morgan was appointed bishop of Llandaff in 1595 and of St Asaph in 1601, but although he published a revision of William Salesbury's translation of the Book of Common Prayer in 1599, he died before he had completed a revision of his 1588 Bible, which suffered from numerous print errors. ODNB.
Constantine Maximus ('the Great'), Roman emperor from 306 to 337 AD.
Gerrit van Honthorst (Gherardo della Notte, 1590–66), Dutch painter of the Ultrecht school, which was influenced by the Italian painter Caravaggio.

Daughter of James Cecil, earl of Salisbury, Lady Mildred Corbett (d. 1726) was the wife of Sir Uvedale Corbett of Longnor, Shropshire. She later married the Yorkshireman Sir Charles Hotham. She was buried in Westminster Abbey alongside Elizabeth, her daughter by Sir Uvedale. Thomas Wotton, The English Baronets: being a genealogical and historical account of their families (London, 1727), p. 530; westminster-abbey.org [accessed 16 April 2018].

Elizabeth Corbett (described as Mrs ['mistress'] Corbett in Pope's 'Epitaph. On Mrs. Corbet, Who dyed of a cancer in her breast') was the daughter of Sir Uvedale Corbett of Longor and his wife Lady Mildred Cecil. See westminster-abbey.org [accessed 16 April 2018].
The antiquary Francis Leighton wrote to both Pennant and Daines Barrington regarding Shropshire history and antiquities. For his correspondence with Gough, dated 1784–1791, see NLW 6647D.

James, son of Richard Mytton of Halston, Shropshire, was the brother of Pennant's mother, Arabella. During his time as a pupil at Fulham school from 1740, Pennant suffered from smallpox and spent a period convalescing at his uncle Mytton's home in Richmond. He also visited Mytton's seat in Merionethshire during his boyhood and youth, and wrote to the fossilist Da Costa in 1752 of his intention to use his time there to gather specimens. A letter to Mytton describing an earthquake Pennant had felt at his home in Downing in April 1750 became his first publication when it was printed in the Royal Society's Philosophical Transactions (1750–1752) and it was Mytton who offered his nephew financial assistance following his first marriage in 1759. LL, p. 1; Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant (1726–1798)', pp. 26, 27–29, 141, 146–7, 267, 409; idem, MA, p. 45.
Katherine Plymley (bap. 1758, d. 1829).

Ann (1760–1829), daughter of Joseph Plymley (1716–1802) and sister to Joseph Plymley, junior. Educated at home, she studied botany and was later involved alongside her sister Katherine in the education of her brother's numerous children from two marriages. She died a few weeks before Katherine and both were buried at Leebotwood church. ODNB.

Sir Richard Corbet (d.1683), chairman of the Committee of Elections in the reign of Charles II, was the son of Sir Edward Corbet of Longnor and Anne Newport. He married Victoria, daughter and coheiress of Sir William Uvedale of Southton. Thomas Wotton, The English Baronets: being a genealogical and historical account of their families (London, 1727), p. 529.

Lady Margaret Manners (d. 1682), daughter of John Manners, 8th earl of Rutland, and wife of James Cecil, 3rd earl of Salisbury. History of Parliament online.
James Cecil, Viscount Cranborne (1748–1823), was created first Marquess of Salisbury in 1789. He held the office of lord chamberlain between 1783 and 1804. Hist P.
John Manners (1604–1679), of Haddon Hall, Derbyshire, parliamentary representative for his county in 1626 and 1640. History of Parliament online.

Lady Margaret Cecil, Countess of Ranelagh (bap. 1672, d.1728), married, firstly, John Stawell, Baron Stawell of Somerton, and subsequently Richard Jones, Earl of Ranelagh. ODNB; The Historical Register, vol. XIII (1728), p. 13.
First husband of Lady Margaret Cecil. The Historical Register, vol. XIII (1728), p. 13.

Richard Jones, 1st earl of Ranelagh (1641–1712), member of the Irish parliament of 1661–6 and holder of various seats in the British parliament between 1685 and 1703. He was appointed paymaster-general of the English forces by James II in 1685, a post which he retained during the reign of Queen Anne. Following the death of his first wife he married Margaret, daughter of James Cecil, earl of Salisbury. Portraits of Jones include work in oils by Peter Lely at the Royal Hospital, Chelsea. ODNB; History of Parliament online; The Historical Register, vol. XIII (1728), p. 13.

Sir Richard Corbet, 4th Bart (1696–1774), of Longnor, Shropshire, first son of Sir Uvedale Corbet, 3rd Bart, and Lady Mildred Cecil. He represented Shrewsbury in parliament in 1723–7 and 1734–54. History of Parliament online.
Sir Charles Hotham, 4th Bart (1663–1723), of Scorborough, near Beverley, Yorkshire. His second wife was Lady Mildred Cecil, widow of Sir Uvedale Corbet, 3rd Bart. History of Parliament online.

Sir Godfrey Kneller (1646–1723), born Gottfried Kniller at Lübeck in north Germany, began his career as a history and portrait painter working under the supervision of Rembrandt in Amsterdam. A desire to see Van Dyck's works led him to London in 1676, where he worked in the tradition of the latter and Peter Lely, becoming the foremost portrait painter in England by the mid-1680s. His association with the court of William and Mary resulted in his 'Hampton Court Beauties', painted at the request of Queen Mary during 1690–1. He continued to be patronized by royalty, working for Queen Anne and George I. ODNB.
Sir Peter Lely (1618–1680), painter and art collector. ODNB.

The Knights were a family of ironmasters associated with the iron industry in the midlands. Their connection with Bringewood in north Herefordshire began when Richard Knight (1659–1745) started to work its furnace and forge in 1698. A partnership at Bringewood and Charlcotte in Shropshire took control of the Bringewood forge until 1779, but the family's charcoal-fired furnaces had all ceased working by 1785. ODNB s.v. Knight family.

Thomas Addenbrooke wrote from Coalbrookdale near Shifnall, Shropshire, to George Washington on 16 December 1771, and again on 26 July 1773, claiming to share a kinship with the latter and asking Washington to assist him in tracing the estate left to his mother and her sisters through a family connection in Virginia. Founders Online, National Archives, last modified June 29, 2017, http://founders.archives.gov/documents/ Washington/02-09-0215; and ibid /02-08-02-0375. For Addenbrooke's correspondence with Pennant, see NLW 2594E, Montgomeryshire folder.

Thomas Howard, fourteenth earl of Arundel, fourth earl of Surrey, and first earl of Norfolk (1585–1646). A politician and art collector, he was the subject of numerous likenesses, by artists and engravers including Rubens, Van Dyck and Vertue. ODNB. For notices by Pennant, see The journey from Chester to London (1782), p. 232; Of London (1790), pp. 122, 143.

Aletheia Howard (née Talbot), countess of Arundel, of Surrey, and of Norfolk, and suo jure Baroness Furnivall, Baroness Talbot, and Baroness Strange of Blackmere (word. 1654), patron and collector of art. She married Thomas Howard, fourteenth earl of Arundel and fourth earl of Surrey in 1606. Numerous likenesses of her are extant, by artists and engravers including Van Dyck, Vorsterman (featuring her alongside her husband), Vertue and Hollar. ODNB.

A group of poachers, executed for murder and deer-stealing in 1723, were known collectively as the 'Waltham Blacks' on account of their practice of blacking their faces to prevent identification. http://www.exclassics.com/newgate/ng169.htm [accessed 25 September 2018].

Charles Howard, eleventh duke of Norfolk (1746–1815), supported Fox on several issues during the early 1780s, lending his support on opposition to the Anglo-American War and parliamentary reform and the East India Bill. Hist P; .

Stafford Prys (1732–1784), whose father was doctor from a Montgomeryshire family and mother a member of the Stradling family from Glamorganshire, began a career as a printer with an apprenticeship to Thomas Durston of Shrewsbury in 1750. By 1758 he had launched his own business in the same town. He printed a large number of Welsh material, ranging from books to ballads. DWB.

Joshua Eddowes (1724–1811), the son of a grocer from Whitchurch, Shropshire, began printing in partnership with John Cotton, c. 1749, which was the year in which he was also admitted a freeman of the Combrethren of Saddlers. The partnership lasted until 1765, Eddowes continuing as printer on his own and subsequently in partnership with his son. His work included an imprint of the classic Welsh prose text by Ellis Wynne, Gweledigaetheu y Bardd Cwsg (1768), and several almanacs by Gwilym Howell. DWB; LW, ii, p. 689.

William Eddowes (b. 1754) traded as a printer in Shrewsbury alongside his father, Joshua Eddowes, between 1788 and the latter's death in 1811. They published Welsh books and, from 29 January 1794, the Salopian Journal. DWB.

Francis Scott supplied Pennant with information while he was preparing his 'Outlines of the Globe'. Pennant quotes a letter from Scott, dated from Edinburgh, September 1790, in his manuscript of the 'Outlines', where he also notes that his correspondent was a younger brother of his 'worthy friend and ally Walter Scott esqr of Harden' and that he lived abroad [probably in India] between 1755 and 1768. Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant (1726–1798)', pp. 638, 689, n. 414, quoting NMM MS P/16/13/ff. 118–124, esp. 118. See also the undated material described as 'Mr. Scott's answers to Pennant's queries about India', at WCRO CR 2017/TP37/1.
William Craven, sixth baron Craven (1738–1791).
Elizabeth (1533-1603), only child of Henry VIII and his second wife Anne Boleyn, crowned queen of England and Ireland in 1558.

John Butler (1717–1802), bishop of Oxford from May 1777, then of Hereford from 1788 until his death. ODNB.
Charlemagne (c.742-814), Holy Roman Emperor and King of the Franks and Lombards.

Lucy Salusbury (d. 1745), grandmother of Hester Piozzi, lived at Offley Place, a late 16th/early 17th-century manor house near Hitchin in Hertfordshire.

David Hume (1711-1776) was a philosopher and historian, educated at Edinburgh University and with strong intellectual connections in Paris. Hume's A Treatise of Human Nature (1739-1740) was a landmark of eighteenth-century moral philosophy which attempted to place the study of the mind on the same empirical footing as the physical sciences and thus establish a 'science of man'. The commercial failure of the Treatise probably dettered Hume from attempting further philosophical works of such length. While hugely influential, Hume's sceptical empiricism was frequently attacked on religious grounds, and his perceived atheism probably tharted his attempts to secure a university chair in moral philosophy. Hume's most commercially successful work was his multi-volume History of Great Britain (1754), later re-titled The History of England. ODNB.

Hugh Blair (1718-1800), Scottish minister and, from 1762, Regius Professor of Rhetoric and Belles Lettres at the University of Edinburgh. Blair was a member of the Select Society of Edinburgh along with several other prominent members of the Scottish Enlightenment literati and was the author of the influential A Critical Dissertation on the Poems of Ossian (London: 1763). In his lifetime Blair also published four highly popular volumes of Sermons (1777-1794) and his Lectures on Rhetoric and Belles Lettres (1783).
William Wallace (d.1305), Scottish national hero and leader during the Wars of Scottish Independence, executed by Edward I.
William Graham (1712-90), 2nd Duke of Montrose.

(1714-82), Welsh landscape painter.

Sir Peter Paul Rubens (1577-1640), painter, born in Westphalia and appointed court painter at Brussels. Rubens's fame as a painter drew commissions and purchases from across the European nobility and royalty, and he was both an artist and diplomat for Charles I, receiving a knighthood in 1630. ODNB.

François de Salignac de la Mothe-Fénelon, commonly known as François Fénelon (1651-1715), a French Roman Catholic archbishop, theologian, poet and writer. Author of Les Aventures de Télémache (1699).

James Ashley was running his ‘London Coffee-House, Punch-house, Dorchester Beer and Welsh Ale Warehouse’ on Ludgate Hill, near St Paul’s Cathedral, in the 1730s. See Paul Jennings, A History of Drink and the English, 1500-2000 (Routledge, 2016) p. 41.
John Christian (later Christian Curwen; 1756-1828) landowner and MP, who built the neoclassical roundhouse on Belle Isle.

Alexander Christie (c.1721-1794) was Provost of Montrose over a number of different periods between 1765-1780. He was a successful merchant and philanthropist, constructing a bridge over the North Esk and founding, with Susan Carnegie of Charleton, Scotland's first lunatic asylum in 1781. His brother was the Unitarian preacher William Christie (1748-1832) and his son Thomas (1761-1796), became a prominent political writer and founder of the Analytical Review. ODNB.

William Eyres (1734-1809) was a printer born into a family with a long history in the Warrington book trade. Eyres and his brother inherited their father's printing business which was later buoyed by the presence of the intellectual community around the Warrington circulating library and dissenting Warrington Academy, the latter of which employed Eyres as its official printer. Eyres established a national reputation as a quality printer, producing works for Anna Laetitia Barbauld and William Roscoe among others. Eyres printed several of Thomas Pennant's works, including editions of his Tour in Scotland 1769 and British Zoology. ODNB.

Thomas Falconer (1736/7–1792) was prevented by ill health from following a career in the legal profession and lived for much of his life in his home town of Chester where he developed his interest in classical antiquities and became a patron of literature. He was described by Thomas Pennant as ‘my sensible and excellent friend, who possessed a great stock of useful knowledge which he was ever ready to communicate. His powers of memory were unrivalled’. ODNB; Warwickshire County Record Office, CR 2017/TP460 (outer cover of folder).

Alexander Gordon (c. 1692–1754?) was an antiquary and singer, educated at Aberdeen University. He travelled in Italy where he performed as an opera singer and toured classical and renaissance sites. On his return to Scotland he pursued his antiquarian interests by researching Roman remains in the country, attempting to trace the path of Agricola's campaigns. Gordon's Itinerarium septentrionale (1726) became a standard work for eighteenth-century antiquarians with an interest in Roman Scotland. Gordon left Britain for Carolina in 1741, where he died some years later. ODNB.
John Kyrle (1637-1724), the ‘Man of Ross’, was a philanthropist and landscape designer.
Lady Betty Duplin – Lady Constantia Dupplin (née Ernle; ?1717-53) left a bequest for a memorial to John Kyrle, a relative of hers, which was raised in 1776.

The writer Walter Savage Landor (1775-1864) bought an estate in the Black Mountains, which included the land around Llanthony Abbey, in 1808. For an account of Landor’s fraught but long-running relationship with Wales, see David Chandler, ‘Walter Savage Landor and Wales in the 1790s’, in Damian Walford Davies and Lynda Pratt (eds), Wales and the Romantic Imagination (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 2007), pp. 141-60.
Admiral John Gell (1740-1806), a naval officer who lived at Glanusk Villa, a house set on the banks of the River Usk.
Sir Charles Morgan (formerly Gould), 2nd Baronet (1760-1846), army officer and M.P.

Thomas Howard, fourteenth earl of Arundel, fourth earl of Surrey, and first earl of Norfolk (1585–1646), was an art collector and politician. ODNB.

George Villiers, first duke of Buckingham (1592–1628) was stabbed to death at The Greyhound inn, Portsmouth, on 23 August 1628.

Richard Norton II (c. 1666–1732), of Southwick, Hampshire, member of Parliament for Hampshire (1693–1700 and 1702–1705). In 1714 he drew up a will leaving an estimated £60,000 in ready money and £6,000 per annum for a fund dedicated to the 'poor, hungry, thirsty, naked strangers, sick, wounded and prisoners', with Parliament appointed as its executors in the first place. This was disregarded after his death. History of Parliament on-line. For a reference to the entertaining of George I at Southwick, see Samuel Lewis, A Topographical Dictionary of England: Comprising the Several Counties, Cities, Boroughs, Corporate and Market Towns, Parishes, Chapelries, and Townships, and the Islands of Guernsey, Jersey, and Man (London: S. Lewis and Co., MDCCCXXXI), IV, p. 136.

The fifth son of Sir Thomas Brooke, governor of Chester Castle, Pusey Brook was collector of customs at Portsmouth and surveyor-general of Hampshire and Dorsetshire. E. Kimber & R. Johnson, The Baronetage of England (London, 1771), II, p. 279. Pennant describes him as ‘the late Pusey Brook, Esq; my friend, and the friend of mankind’ in A tour in Scotland 1772, part I (2nd edn., 1776), p. 8.

William Seward (1747–99), anecdotist, who turned to collecting stories of notable persons as an antidote to ennui. He travelled both in the highlands of Scotland (1777) and in England, where he followed the 'western tour' (1788), was an acquaintance of Hester Lynch Piozzi, and suffered a period of insanity. .
William Locker (1731–1800), naval officer, whose mother Elizabeth was sister to Benjamin Stillingfleet. ODNB.
Thormodus Torfæus (1636-1719) was an Icelandic historian and author of Historia Vinlandiæ Antiquæ (1705); Grœnlandia Antiqua (1706); and Historia Rerum Norvegicarum (1711).
Egbert (d.839) was a king of Wessex who greatly expanded his domains by annexing Mercian territory in the south-east of England. ODNB.

William Duff (d.1763), Lord Braco of Kilbryde was created earl of Fife (revived in the Irish peerage) in 1735, in consideration of his putative descent from David Duff, one of the ancient earls of Fife and recipient of lands in Banffshire from Robert III. David Duff's existence was later disputed by genealogists. Duff succeeded his cousin, (also William) Duff of Braco in 1719 and was elected MP of Banffshire in 1727. William Duff was a supporter of the government during the Jacobite rebellion of 1745 and in 1751 he purchased the superiorities and church patronages of King's College Aberdeen from the crown, granting him rights of presentation over fifteen parishes in the region. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

Reverend Alexander Bryce (fl.1744-1778) was a mathematician, Church of Scotland minister and cartographer, who produced A Map of the North Coast of Britain (Edinburgh: 1744) for the Philosophical Society of Edinburgh.
