He is described as a friend by George Paton in a letter of March 14 1778, in which Paton also mentions that Bryce has visited Alexander Pope, minister of Reay in Caithness. On Bryce's map making activites see Charles W. J. Withers, 'The Social Nature of Map Making in the Scottish Enlightenment, c. 1682-c. 1832', Imago Mundi, 54 (2002), pp. 46-66, 48.
Mr Middleton of the Temple, London (fl.1778). Possibly John Middleton, admitted to the Inner Temple in 1747. Son of William Middleton of Denbighshire, Wales. www.innertemplearchives.org.uk
Mr Burk (fl.1778), an associate of Mr (?John) Middleton of the Temple, London.

note.note: Lady Mary O'Brien, daughter of Murrough, 5th Earl of Inchiquin [I], by Mary, s.j. Countess of Orkney. In 1777 she became the wife of Thomas Fitzmaurice of Lleweni, Denbighshire. She inherited her mother's title and her estate of Cliveden in 1790, and the couple settled in Buckinghamshire thereafter. Hist P.

persName.note: Elizabeth Carew (nee Southcott; 1568-1633).
Sir Richard Steele – (1672-1729), Irish-born writer and Whig politician.
George Rice (1724-79), politician and courtier, and owner of Newton House in Llandeilo.
John Vaughan (c. 1752-1804), landowner and politician, owner of the Golden Grove (in Welsh, Gelli Aur) estate in Carmarthenshire.
Rhys Prichard (?1579-1644), cleric and poet.
Roger Palmer (1634-1705), 1st Earl of Castlemaine
Richard Myddleton (1726-95), landowner and MP, and owner of Chirk Castle.
Sir Robert Salusbury Cotton (c. 1739-1809), landowner and MP.

John Smith (dates unknown), is noted as the blind harper at Conwy by George Cumberland in 1784 and Thomas Twinning in 1797, as well as Eleanor Butler and Sarah Ponsonby in 1778. See https://sublimewales.wordpress.com/material-culture/harpers/harpers-caernarfonshire/

Franz Joseph Gall (1758-1828), Viennese neuroanatomist who hypothesised that the brain housed a series of internal organs that controlled different mental functions, and that consequently an examination of the skull (which was, Gall believed, shaped by these organs) could reveal an individual’s character.
General Charles Fleetwood (c. 1618-92), army officer.
Bridget Ireton Fleetwood (née Cromwell; bap. 1624, d. 1662), eldest daughter of Oliver Cromwell.

Samuel Varley (1744-1822) was a watchmaker, jeweller, instrument maker, lecturer on natural sciences, and uncle to the watercolour painters John and Cornelius Varley. In 1794 Samuel Varley was one of the founders of the Chemical and Philosophical Society (a forerunner of the Royal Instutition), and from 1800 he worked for the radical peer Earl Stanhope at his country house, Chevening, in Kent, where he acted as consultant to Stanhope’s scientific and technical projects, among them the iron printing press and new uses for steam propulsion. See Matthew L. Jones, Reckoning with Matter: Calculating Machines, Innovation, and Thinking about Thinking from Pascal to Babbage (Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press, 2016), p. 193. For Cornelius Varley’s portrait of his uncle (1816), see http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=743723&partId=1&people=104477&peoA=104477-2-9&page=1
George Capel-Coningsby, 5th Earl of Essex (1757-1839), MP and patron of the arts.
Thomas Webster (1772-1844), Orkney-born architect, watercolourist and geologist.

Joshua Cristall (c. 1768-1847) was a watercolourist, raised in London with a Scottish-Cornish background. He was among the founder members of the Society of Painters in Water Colours (see notes to Cornelius Varley's Welsh tour for further information on the Society).
William Havell (1782-1857), landscape painter.
Second baron of Upper Ossory (c. 1535–1581), who from boyhood had a close friendship and, latterly, maintained a regular correspondence with Edward VI until the latter's death in 1553. ODNB.
Henry I (1068/9–1135), king of England and lord of Normandy, youngest son of William I and Matilda of Flanders.

The priory of Southwick in Hampshire was assigned to John White, a servant of Thomas Wriothesley, at the dissolution of the monasteries. 'Houses of Austin canons: Priory of Southwick, in A History of the County of Hampshire: Volume 2, ed. H. Arthur Doubleday and William Page (London: Victoria County History, 1903), pp. 164–8, at here [accessed 28 August 2016].

Thomas Wriothesley, first earl of Southampton (1505–50), appointed lord chancellor in April 1544. Note that Bull describes him as 'Lord Chamberlain' in 1129, misquoting Cox, (London, 1720), II, p. 892. .
Mr McLellan (fl. 1800), gravedigger on South Uist.
Henry V (1386–1422), king of England and lord of Ireland, and duke of Aquitaine.
For Elizabeth Brudenell (née Waldergrave), second wife of James Brudenell, fifth earl of Cardigan, see here [accessed 1 October 2018].
(fl.1807) Wife of pe0520.

Thomas Philip de Grey [formerly Thomas Philip Robinson; Thomas Philip Weddell], second Earl De Grey (1781–1859); son of Thomas Robinson, second Baron Grantham (1738–1786), and Mary Jemima Grey (1757–1830), daughter of Philip Yorke, second earl of Hardwicke. He succeede his father as third Baron Grantham on 20 July 1786. ODNB

William Dawson of Tadcaster (fl.1778-1806), land surveyor and youngest brother to the father of Eliza Fletcher (née Dawson), whom he accompanied on her 1786 tour of Scotland. Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.8.
Mr Richardson of Darlington, visited by Eliza Dawson and her party during their 1786 tour.
Mr Mowbray of Darlington, visited by Eliza Dawson and her party during their 1786 tour.
Mrs Mowbray of Darlington, visited by Eliza Dawson and her party during their 1786 tour.
Innkeeper at the Wheatsheaf in Durham, 1786, mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her tour of that year.

Mr Forster of Bolton in Northumberland. For a period the family lived in York where the daughters were educated at the Manor House School alongside Eliza Dawson. He seems to have provided letters of introduction for the Dawson's 1786 tour. Eliza, Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.23.
In her 1786 Tour of Scotland, Eliza Dawson writers that somebody called Reed was the former inhabitant of the Wheatsheaf Inn in Durham.
Biblical figure: youngest son of Jesse, a shepherd. David slew Goliath, the champion of the Philistines with a stone and sling, according to I Samuel 17.
Biblical figure: Goliath, champion of the Philistines was slain by the shepherd-boy David according I Samuel 17.

Cuthbert (c.625-687) bishop of Lindisfarne. His life was documented by an anonymous monk of Lindisfarne and later by Bede. His remains were buried at Durham Catherdral, where his shrine was the centre of an important medieval cult. ODNB.

Aldhun (d.1018), was the first bishop of Durham, having brought the body of St Cuthbert there from Chester-le-Street to protect it from the Vikings. The primary source for his life is Symeon of Durham's Libellus de exordio atque procursu istius hoc est Dunelmensis ecclesie (c.1104-1107). ODNB.

Antony Beck (c.1245-1311) was bishop of Durham and created partiarch of Jerusalem by Pope Clement V in 1306. He died in Kent and his remains were returned to Durham Cathedral, where they were the first to be buried since those of St Cuthbert in 1104. ODNB.
George Lumley-Saunderson (1753-1807), succeeded as 5th Earl of Scarbrough and 5th Viscount Lumley in 1782. From 1774 to 1780 he was M.P. for Lincolnshire. http://thepeerage.com.
Named as owner of the Old White Hart Inn by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland.
Inn keeper at Morpeth in Northumberland, mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her tour of Scotland in 1786.

The Loraines were tenants of Sir George Warren at Widdrington castle in 1786, according to Eliza Dawson in her tour of that year. The Town and Country Magazine reported the death of 'The Lady dowager Loraine, of Widdrington Castle, Northumberland' in April 1787.

The Loraines were tenants of Sir George Warren at Widdrington castle in 1786, according to Eliza Dawson in her tour of that year. The Town and Country Magazine reported the death of 'The Lady dowager Loraine, of Widdrington Castle, Northumberland' in April 1787.

Ewbanks of Bolton Percy, mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland: she writes in her autobiography that 'Mr. Ewbank, a man of good private fortune, was Curate of the parish, and lived at the Rectory. His wife was a truly devout and exemplary woman, of cultivated mind and great refinement of manners.' Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.24.

Sir George Warren (1735-1801). Between 1758 and 1796 Warren was successively M.P. for Lancaster, Beaumaris and Lancaster again. Under his ownership, Widdrington Castle in Northumberland was demolished, rebuilt, burnt down and rebuilt again to various designs. historyofparliamentonline.org.

Hugh Percy, second duke of Northumberland (1742–1817), elder son of Hugh Percy, first duke of Northumberland, succeeded his father to his title and estate on 6 June 1786. He was MP for Westminster 1763–76 and enjoyed a successful military career, serving in the American war during the 1770s. He married Lady Anne Stuart, daughter of John Stuart, third earl of Bute. Hist P;ODNB.
Mr Grey of Alnwick, mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. The Dawsons may have been introduced to Grey by a mutual friend, Mr Forster of Bolton, Northumberland.

Nathaniel Crew, third Baron Crew (1633-1721) was bishop of Durham. His second wife Dorothy was coheir to the heavily indebted estate of Bamburgh, along with her cousin the Jacobite Leader Thomas Forster. When the Forster's estates were sold to clear the debt they were purchased by Crew, who subsequently endowed them to a charitable trust in his will. Bamburgh Castle was repaired to provide a navigational aid to sailors. ODNB.

Mrs Brudenell of Hebburn and later Oxton (d.1807). In her Autobiography, Eliza Fletcher (née Dawson) relates that a friend of her mother's, a Miss Hebburn, married the Reverend Edward Brudenell, a relative of the earls of Cardigan. Mr Brudenell's conduct as a husband caused his wife to seek a separation, and she fled with the help of the Dawsons. Following her mother's death, Eliza Dawson's father offered Mrs Brudenell a cottage near the family home at Oxton, and she subsequently assisted in Eliza's early education. On her death, Brudenell left Eliza the family estate of Hebburn. Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), pp.4-6.

Robin Straughen was apparently an elderly former servant of the Hebburn family, whose daughter, later Mrs Brudenell, was a family friend of the Dawsons of Oxton. He was visited at Berwick by Eliza Dawson in her tour of 1786.

Captain and Mrs Hebburn of Hebburn, whose daughter, later Mrs Brudenell, was a family friend of Eliza Dawson. On Mrs Brudenell's death the estate of Hebburn passed to Eliza, by then Mrs Fletcher. Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.85.

The Wilkie family of Foulden, possibly including Captain James Wilkie of Foulden (d.1817), who is named as patron of the local presbytery in the entry for Sinclair's Statistical Account. The Wilkies were friends of Mrs Brudenell, and through her, of Eliza Fletcher (née Dawson). Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.84; John Sinclair, The Statistical Account of Scotland, 21 vols. (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xi, p. 120; thepeerage.com.
The Greys of Berwick, visited by Eliza Dawson and her family on their 1786 tour. They were introduced by a letter from their mutual friend Mr Forster of Bolton, Northumberland.
Mr Sanford of London or Berwick. He is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland.
Husband of Mrs Hall (née Grey) of Berwick who was dead by 1786.

John Dawson, son of William Dawson and cousin of Eliza Dawson. He accompanied his father and cousin on a tour of Scotland in 1786. Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.27.

Robert Fall (1724-1798), landowner and Provost of Dunbar from 1781. The Falls were a prominent local mercantile family, who held the position of Provost of Dunbar for three generations. When Robert Burns visited Dunbar in 1787 he dined with Provost Fall and his wife. The Falls were rumoured to be descended from the Faas or Faws, a family of Border Gypsies. A. Francis Steuart, 'The Falls of Dunbar and Their Descent from the Gypsies', in The Scottish Antiquary, Or, Northern Notes and Queries 16, no. 63 (1902): 127-32.

Mrs Fall (née Stephen) was the wife of Robert Fall, Provost of Dunbar from 1781 to 1798. The Falls dined with Robert Burns in 1787, who recorded that Mrs Fall was an able painter. A. Francis Steuart, 'The Falls of Dunbar and Their Descent from the Gypsies', in The Scottish Antiquary, Or, Northern Notes and Queries 16, no. 63 (1902): 127-32.
Mrs Hutchinson, hostess of private lodgings in Edinburgh, which were used by Eliza Dawson and her relatives during their 1786 tour of Scotland.

George Meliss of Rosemount, Perth (fl.1787-1798), was a cotton manufacturer and merchant, a proponent of the abolition of slavery and a prominent member of the burgh reform movement in the early 1790s. In 1785 Meliss married a Miss Stewart of Perth, and the following year they were visited at Rosemount by Stewart's friend, Eliza Dawson. In 1787, Meliss and fellow reformer Archibald Fletcher passed through Oxton on their way to a committee on borough reform in the Commons, thus introducing Fletcher to his future wife, Eliza Dawson. Bob Harris, The Scottish People and the French Revolution (London: Pickering and Chatto, 2008), p.83; Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.27, p.34.

Dorothy Jordan [real name Dorothy Phillips] (1761-1816), was an actor, born in London to Irish parents. Prohibited from using the name Phillips by the family of her estranged father, Dorothy began her acting career in Dublin, later moving to York to escape debt and an unhappy relationship. She then moved to Covent Garden, finding fame as a performer both in London and on the provincial circuit. ODNB.

Margaret Kennedy [née Doyle; other married name Farrell] (d.1793) was a London-born singer and actress of Irish descent. As Mrs Farrell, she joined the Covent Garden company in 1776, remarrying after her first husband's death and taking the name Kennedy in 1779. On stage she was known for performing a range of popular singing roles in her distinctive counter tenor, many of which she reprised during a stay in Edinburgh in the summer season of 1786. ODNB.

Sir James Hunter, first baronet Blair (1741-1787), was an Edinburgh banker, born in Ayr. In 1770 he married Jane Blair, heiriess of Dunskey House, Wigtownshire and assumed her surname. He was M.P. for Edinburgh from 1781-1784, and Lord Provost of that city from 1784, in which role he was responsible for the construction of the south bridge over the Cowgate. ODNB.

John Stewart, mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. He is probably related to Eliza's friend, Mrs Meliss (née Stewart) of Perth, who married the burgh reformer George Meliss in 1785. Eliza Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.27.

James V, king of Scots (1512–1542) acceeded to the crown at less than two years of age, following the death of his father James IV at the battle of Flodden. After a long rule by minority he attempted to consolidate his royal power and Scotland's 'auld alliance' with France by marriage to Mary of Guise in 1538. James died in 1542 following a series of battles against the forces of Henry VIII, who was anxious to secure England's northern border in advance of war against France. ODNB.

Henry Darnley, duke of Albany (1545/6-1567) was a consort of Mary, queen of Scots and oldest surviving son of the earl of Lennox. He married Mary in 1565 and was murdered in 1567. The identity of Darnley's killer has never been discovered; he was unpopular both among the Scottish nobility and within the queen's household. ODNB.

John, fourth earl of Dunmore (d.1809), succeeded his father in 1756. He was governor of New York in 1769 and then of Virginia, a post which he held until the American revolutionary war. In 1787 he was appointed governor of the Bahama Islands. He married Lady Charlotte Stewart, daughter of the earl of Galloway. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Douglas (1756-1799), fifth duke of Brandon and eighth duke of Hamilton on succeeding his brother in 1769. He undertook the grand tour of the continent with his tutor John Moore, who subsequently drew on their travels in his View of the Society and Manners in France and Italy (London: 1779). Hamilton raised a regiment of foot to fight in the American war, but resigned his captain's commission in 1779. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Alexander, 13th Lord Gray (1751-1786), officer in the first regiment of dragoon guards. He succeeded his father in 1782 and died at Edinburgh four years later, having left the army. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr Taylor (fl.1786) is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. He accompanied the party to view Hopetoun House on the south bank of the Forth.

John Hope (1704-1781), 2nd earl of Hopetoun. Lord of police in Scotland, lord-high-commissioner to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland. Married Lady Anne Ogilvy, daughter of James, 5th earl of Findlater in 1733. He later married Jean Oliphant, daugher of Robert Oliphant of Rossie, Perthshire. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)
Charles, Lord Hope (1740-1766), died at Portsmouth after returning from the West Indies. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

Nathaniel Dance [later Sir Nathaniel Holland, baronet] (1735–1811), was a portrait painter and MP. He was resident in Rome in the 1750s. In 1800 he was created baronet and took the name Holland, after the cousin of his wife. ODNB.
Andrew the Apostle, or Saint Andrew.
Brutus (85 BCE-42 BCE), Roman politician involved in the assassination of Julius Caesar in 44 BCE.
Sir Walter Bagot, 5th Baronet (1702-68), MP and landowner. Owner of a Welsh estate near Ruthin, Bachymbyd.
Henry de Lacy, 5th earl of Lincoln (1249-1311) who was awarded the Lordship of Denbigh in the 1280s.
Edward I (1239-1307), king of England between 1272 and his death in 1307.
Elis Prys (or Price; ?1512-?1594), Denbighshire-born MP and local administrator; see http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-PRYS-ELI-1512.html

Gavin Hamilton (1723-1798), painter, studied at Glasgow University before travelling to Rome where he trained in portrait painting at the Accademia di San Luca. He was influenced by classical art and culture, and visited Herculaneum and Pompeii while in Italiy. He moved to London where he found business producing portraits of the family of the duke of Hamilton, to whom he was distantly related, but his interest remained in classical subjects, of which he painted several grand figures and scenes. He later returned to Italy where he was renowned as both a painter and for his involvement in the excavation of Roman remains. ODNB.
William III (1650-1702), king of England between 1689 and 1702.
Willam Bentinck, 1st earl of Portland (1649-1709), diplomat and politician.

Mrs Meliss (née Stewart, first name unknown) was educated at the Manor School in York and returned to her native Perth in 1785 to marry the burgh reformer and cotton manufacturer George Meliss of Rosemount. Mrs Meliss had attended school at York alongside Eliza Dawson (later Mrs Archibald Fletcher after her marriage to the Meliss' friend and fellow reformer of that name) and Eliza's tour of Scotland in 1786 was made on the express purpose of visiting her friend and former classmate. Eliza, Fletcher [née Dawson], Autobiography of Mrs. Fletcher, ed. by Mary Richardson [née Fletcher] (Edinburgh: 1875), p.27.

James Beattie (1735-1803) was a Kincardineshire-born poet and interpreter of Thomas Reid's 'common sense' school of philosophy. His major works were The Minstrel (1771-1774), an influential account of the growth of the poet's mind in Spenserian stanzas, and his Essay on Truth (1770), which attacked the sceptical empiricism of David Hume on religious and moral grounds. Beattie held the chair of moral philosophy and logic at Marischal College, Aberdeen from 1760 until his death. ODNB.

Reverend George Chapman (d.1795) was minister of the parish of Kinfauns, near Perth, from 1765. He contributed a description of the parish to Sir John Sinclair's Statistical Account of Scotland, 21 vols. (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xiv, pp. 212-228.
A Mrs Rose (born c.1710) is described as being seventy-six years old and resident near Perth in Eliza Dawson's 1786 tour of Scotland.
Robert Price (1655-1733), MP and lawyer, born in Cerrigydrudion in north Wales; see http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-PRIC-ROB-1655.html

The Statistical Account of Scotland, 21 vols. (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xv, p.530, records that one Mr William McAlpine, a calico printer and son of a Glasgow clergymen, established a cotton mill and print field on the banks of the Almond in the early 1780s. He later expanded his concerns with a larger printing works in Scone, but was ruined by his speculation on the Manchester cotton industry which experienced a glut of the market. It is not clear whether McAlpine's works are the same as those mentioned elsewhere in the Statistical Account, xviii, p.515: 'established on the grounds of Thomas Graham, Esq. of Balgowan, under the firm of Meliss and Co'. The manufacturer and reformer George Meliss was the husband of Eliza Dawson's school friend (née Stewart) and hosted the Dawsons at Rosemount House near Perth during their tour.

Ludovic, 2nd duke of Lennox (1574-1624), ally of James VI of Scotland. Born in France, he held a number of offices under James, including those of governor of the east parts of the kingdom; hereditary great chamberlain; high admiral of Scotland; privy councillor and lieutenant of the north. He was involved in the rescue of James from the Gowrie conspirators in 1600, and following James's accession to the English throne, was created earl of Newcastle and duke of Richmond in the English peerage. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

James Stewart, 2nd earl of Arran (c.1545–1596), favourite of James VI, under whom he held the offices of gentleman of the bedchamber, privy councillor, captain of the guard, lord high chancellor and lieutenant of the kingdom. He was instrumental in the conviction and execution of the earl of Morton for involvement in the murder of Lord Darnley. In 1596, Stewart himself was murdered by Sir James Douglas of Parkhead, in revenge for the death of his uncle, the regent Morton. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

William Sandeman (d. before 1795) was a manufacturer and merchant, founder and proprietor of the Luncarty Bleachworks. The works were reputed to be among the most extensive in Britain. According to Eliza Dawson, who visited the bleachfields in 1786, Sandeman was the nephew or Robert Sandeman (1718–1771), founder of the Glasite or Sandemanian Protestant sect. John Sinclair, The Statistical Account of Scotland, 21 vols. (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xv, p.531.

Robert Sandeman (1718-1771), religious writer. Sandeman was influenced by John Glas, and founded a church in London based on his strict Protestant principles. Sandeman married Glas's daughter, Katharine, and was a vigorous promoter of his religious views through anonymous polemics published in the 1750s. Sandeman's commitment to Glas's views was such that the sect eventually became synonymous with him rather than its founder. ODNB.

In her 1786 tour of Scotland, Eliza Dawson names Andrew Keay ('Mr Key') of Stanley as a member of the partnership that established the cotton mill at Stanley in the mid-1780s. The company also included George Dempster, Graham of Fintry, William Sandeman, Patrick Stewart, William Marshall and the famous inventor and cotton mogul Sir Richard Arkwright (1732–1792), although Arkwright's involvement in the business was short lived. R.S. Fitton, The Arkwrights: Spinners of Fortune (Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1989), p.78.

Eliza Dawson, in her 1786 tour of Scotland records spending an evening with two Miss Andersons, presumably resident in the neighbourhood of Perth. No further information about this family is available.

The Wrights of Lawton are mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her tour of Scotland in 1786, where she mentions that Mrs Wright is a cousin of James Beattie, author of The Minstrel. The entry for Cargill in The Statistical Account names 'Mr Wright of Lawton' as the 'only residing heritor' in the parish, and names George Wright Esq. as the proprietor of the hill at Lawton. John Sinclair, Statistical Account of Scotland 21 vols (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xiii, p.537n, p.538.
A Miss Brandling, educated at Doncaster, is named by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. She was employed as governess by the Wright family of Lawton.

Miss Procter of Doncaster, apparently a tutor or head of a school there. She is mentioned in Eliza Dawson's 1786 tour of Scotland in relation to the education of Miss Brandling, then governess to the Wright family of Lawton.
A Mr Berriman is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. He accompanied the party on an excursion to Dunsinane Hill.

James Stuart-Mackenzie (1719-1800), politician and keeper of the privy seal of Scotland, second son of James Stuart, second earl of Bute. Stuart-Mackenzie inherited the estates and name of his great grandfather, Sir George Mackenzie. He married Lady Elizabeth Campbell (his cousin), daughter of the duke of Argyll. Stuart-Mackenzie was for a time an envoy to the king of Sardinia, an M.P. for various constituencies in Scotland, and keeper of the privy seal (with a short hiatus) from 1763 until his death. He was also a keen astronomer. Thomas Pennant stayed at Stuart-Mackenzie's seat at Belmont in Perthshire in 1772, and noted approvingly that 'Improvements in agriculture, and in making good roads, go on most prosperously under the auspices of the Lord Privy Seal.' Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 Part II, (London: 1776), p.175; William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Macduff [Macduib] (fl. 1057–1058). The Macduffs were earls of Fife between the eleventh and fourteenth centuries, and claimed descent from the tenth-century king Dubh [Duff]. Medieval chroniclers portrayed Macduff as a supporter of Malcom III against Macbeth in accounts that subsequently formed the basis of Shakespeare's Tragedy of Macbeth; modern representations of Macduff tend to originate with Shakespeare's depiction of the 'thane of Fife' in that play. ODNB.

note.note: John Williams (1700-87), attorney-general of the Chester Circuit and Chief Justice of the Brecon Circuit. The Bodelwyddan estate came into the Williams family by marriage. See here [accessed 24 September 2019].

persName.note: Henry II (1133-89), king of England between 1154 and 1189.
Terence Prendergast (d. 1776), British Army captain and owner (by marriage) of Marl Hall near Conwy in the 1760s and 70s.
Miss Read [possibly Reid] of Dundee. Eliza Dawson recounts delivering her a package from York in her 1786 Tour of Scotland.
A Dr Stewart is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland as a guest of a party hosted by a Mrs Rose of Perth.

note.note: Sir Richard Wynn, 2nd baronet (1588-1649), courtier and MP, and owner of Gwydir Castle. See https://biography.wales/article/s-WYNN-GWY-1300

persName.note: Captain and Mrs Stewart of Stillend, near Dupplin, Perth. Eliza Dawson described visiting them during her 1786 tour in Scotland.
Sir Nicholas Bayly, 2nd Baronet (1709-82), MP and owner of the Plas Newydd estate on Anglesey.
Lady Charlotte Murray (1754-1808), botanist and author of The British Garden (1799). She was the daughter of John Murray, 3rd duke of Atholl, and Charlotte Murray, duchess of Atholl.

note.note: John Carter (1748–1817), draughtsman and antiquary, employed from 1780 by the Society of Antiquaries to create drawings and etchings. In work on plans and drawings of English cathedrals Carter evolved as a pioneering recorder of the Gothic style. An association with Richard Gough led to involvement as a draughtsman for Gough's Sepulchral Monuments (1786), and to a contribution from Gough to the publication costs of Carter's own Specimens of Ancient Sculpture and Painting (2 vols., 1780–94). This was followed by Views of Ancient Buildings in England (1786–93) and The Ancient Architecture of England (2 pts, 1795–1814). Carter furthermore worked as an architectural journalist through his contributions to the Gentleman's Magazine between 1797 and 1817. ODNB.

persName.note: Evan Griffith (dates unknown), owner of Plas Tan y Bwlch in Snowdonia. He was high sheriff of Merioneth in 1770.

John Campbell (1762-1834), fourth earl of Breadalbane on succeeding his relative, the third earl, in 1782. He was later created Baron Breadalbane of Taymouth. The fourth earl raised the Breadalbane Fencible regiment in 1793, later incorporated into the regular service on which the earl was made colonel. Breadalbane devoted most of his time to the improvement of his estates through tree planting. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

A Captain Campbell mentioned at Tyndrum by Eliza Dawson in her 1786 tour of Scotland. Possibly Captain Campbell of Glenfalloch, who was involved in the recruitment of soldiers from the mining community at Tyndrum. See Andrew Mackillop, 'Military Recruiting in the Scottish Highlands 1739-1815: the Political, Social and Economic Context' (PhD thesis, University of Glasgow, 2013), p.269n.

Lady Augusta Campbell (b.1775). Daughter to John Campbell, fifth duke of Argyll and his wife, Lady Elizabeth (formerly widow of James, sixth duke of Hamilton). She married a General Clavering. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Sir Thomas Salusbury (1708-73), judge of the Admiralty and owner of Bachygraig near Denbigh, which he inherited from his brother John (father of Hester Thrale Piozzi) in 1762.

Lady Elizabeth Campbell (née Gunning), daughter of the Gunnings of Castle Coote, County Rosscommon, Ireland. She was first married to James, sixth duke of Hamilton and secondly to John, fifth duke of Argyll.

Elizabeth, countess of Derby (1753-1797), daughter of James, sixth duke of Hamilton. In 1774, Elizabeth married Edward Smith Stanley, twelfth earl of Derby (1752–1834), whom she left five years later for John Frederick Sackville, third duke of Dorset. Derby afterwards refused to grant his wife a divorce or access to her children and took the actress Elizabeth Farren as his mistress. ODNB.
A Madame Halliarde, originally from France, is named as a companion of Lady Elizabeth Campbell in Eliza Dawson's 1786 tour of Scotland.
Taby Mc.Darty, a child of around nine years of age resident on the banks of Loch Fyne is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in her tour of Scotland in 1786.
Possibly James Williamson (d.1795), Professor of Mathematics at Glasgow University from 1761 until his death. https://www.universitystory.gla.ac.uk/

A Mr Waud is mentioned in Eliza Dawson's journal of her 1786 tour of Scotland. Waud provided a letter of introduction to Dr Williamson at Glasgow University. A Miss Waud of Ilkley, presumably of the same family, is visited by Dason at Ilkley on the return leg of her tour.

Wife of the Dr Williamson of Glasgow mentioned in Eliza Dawson's journal of her 1786 tour of Scotland. Dawson notes that at the time of their meeting Mrs Williamson was around thirty, or half the age of her husband.

Sir William Hamilton (1731-1803) was a diplomat and art collector. He was appointed envoy to the Spanish court of Ferdinand IV at Naples in 1764, where he established himself as a prominent collector of Roman, Greek and Etruscan antiquities. Hamilton commissioned Baron d'Hancarville's Antiquités étrusques, grecques et romaines (1766-67), which was influential in establishing a taste for classical styles and decoration among the elite of eighteenth-century Europe. Hamilton's own collection of vases was purchased by the British Museum in 1772. The post at Naples also allowed Hamilton to develop an interest in volcanoes, and his observations and drawings were published in the Philosophical Transactions and Campi phlegraei: Observations on the Volcanoes of the Two Sicilies (1776). ODNB.
Plato (429?–347 B.C.E.), Athenian philosopher credited as one of the most influential figures in Western thought and literature. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/plato/

Aristotle (384–322 B.C.E.), Athenian philosopher and student of Plato. His wide-ranging body of work influenced Classical as well as Arabic and European Renaissance thought. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle/

Pythagoras (ca.570-ca.490 B.C.E.), Greek philosopher from Samos and later Croton in southern Italy. Pythagoras left no written work and thus many concepts may have been spuriously associated with his name by later traditions. While Pythagoras is now remembered primarily as a mathematician due to the theorem that has been given his name, his association with geometry and cosmography is probably a development of much later writers. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pythagoras/

Diogenes was an ancient Greek philosopher whose life and thought are known only in reported form, primarily through the third-century writings of Diogenes Laërtius. The former Diogenes was associated with the Cynics, a philosophical school based on a critical detachment from social convention. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-ancient/
Cromwell, Oliver (1599–1658), lord protector of England, Scotland, and Ireland, leader of the parliamentarian forces against Charles I in the wars of the three kingdoms.

Lady Jane Douglas (1698-1753) was the daughter of James Douglas, second marquess of Douglas (c. 1646–1700). After an early match with the earl of Dalkeith fell through, Douglas eventually married Colonel John Steuart of Grandtully (1687-1764), a widower and former Jacobite in 1746. To escape both debts and the dissaproval of Douglas's brother, the duke, the couple moved to Paris, where Lady Jane gave birth to twins in 1748. Cut-off by her brother once he learned of the births, Lady Jane died in 1753. Her one surviving son, Archibald, would later be recognised as heir to the Douglas estates, following a lengthy legal battle with the Hamiltons. ODNB.

Charles Douglas (1698-1778) succeeded his father as third duke of Queensberry and second duke of Dover in 1711. He married Lady Catherine Hyde (1701-1777), whose social circle included John Gay, Alexander Pope and other cultural figures. Douglas himself was lord of the bedchamber, vice-admiral of Scotland and a privy councillor under George I. ODNB.

Lady Lucie Graham (1751–1780), daughter of the second duke of Montrose. In 1771 she married Archibald James Edward, first Baron Douglas (1748–1827), who had successfully litigated against the Hamiltons to be recognied as heir to the Douglas estates. ODNB.

Margaret Douglas of Mains, duchess of Douglas on her marriage in 1758 to Archibald Douglas, duke of Douglas (bap. 1694, d. 1761). She was a supporter of her nephew, Archibald James Edward Douglas in his legal battle for recognition as heir to the Douglas lands and title. ODNB.
Elizabeth Anne Hamilton (née Burrell), duchess of Hamilton on her marriage to Douglas, the eighth duke. Sister of Peter, Lord Gwydir.
Hector, Trojan hero and son of Priam, king of Troy. Hector's killing of Patroclus and the subsequent rage of Achilles form the subject of Homer's Illiad.
Old Testament figure condemned to spend the night in a den of lions by Darius I (550–486 BC), king of Persia and miraculously preserved from harm by God in Daniel 6.

Robert Cecil (1563-1612) was a courtier of queen Elizabeth and king James VI of Scotland and I of England. Cecil was secretary of state under Elizabeth and was an opponent of Essex in the approaching crisis of Elizabeth's succession and the related issues of England's hostilities in Spain and Ireland. Towards the end of Elizabeth's life Cecil worked to bring about a smooth transition to a new regime under James. ODNB.
Raphael (1483–1520), High Renaissance painter born at Urbino and active at Florence and Rome, known throughout Europe, mainly for his depictions of religious figures and scenes.
Christian saint.
Joseph Paisley (1728-1811), the famous 'blacksmith parson' of Gretna Green, who for fifty years performed marriage ceremonies for eloped couples from England.
John Davies (1737-85), owner of Llanerch Hall.

Joseph Strong of Carlisle (1732-1798) was an organist, organ builder and weaver. Strong was reported to have been blinded by smallpox as an infant, but of sufficient manual and musical skill to both play and build organs, among other devices. He was introduced to John Stanley, the organist and composer. G.H. Wilson, the Eccentric Mirror, 4 vols. (London: 1807), ii.

John Stanley (1712-1786) was an organist and composer, blinded by a fall as a child. Stanley played organ at the church of St Andrew's Holborn and the Society of the Inner Temple. He also played at Covent Garden, wrote oratorios, organ concertos and was appointed master of the king's band. ODNB.

note.note: James Lowther, earl of Lonsdale (1736-1802) was born to a powerful aristocratic family with large estates in Cumberland and Barbadoes. Lowther's collieries in particular made him one of the richest men in England and he used his wealth to advance his political career, establishing the so-called 'Lowther interest' through the purchase of boroughs and patronage of parliamentary candidates. He married Lady Mary Stuart (1740-1824) daughter of John Stuart, third earl of Bute and prime minister. ODNB.

persName.note: The Wilkinson family of Appleby are mentioned in Eliza Dawson's journal of her 1786 tour in Scotland.

Sackville Tufton, ninth earl of Thanet (1769-1825), succeeded his father the eighth earl on 27 March 1786. In 1798 he was convicted of riot and assault for his part in attempting to free the United Irishman O'Connor who was immediately rearrested after being found not guilty by the court. ODNB.

Anne Clifford (1590-1676), countess of Pembroke, Dorset and Montgomery was a landowner and diarist. Her life was marked by an inheritance dispute caused by her father's bequeathal of his estates to his brother, and further complicated by her husband, the earl of Dorset's attempts to settle the matter for his own gain. Following Dorset's death Anne became very wealthy and was known for the restoration of several of her castles and properties, and the endowment of charities and hospitals such as St Anne's in Appleby. Parts of her diaries and financial records survive. ODNB.

Peter Crosthwaite (1735-1808), 'impresario of Lakes tourism'. In 1780 he opened a museum of miscellaneous curiosities on Keswick main street which remained open until 1870. He was a participant and co-organiser of Joseph Pocklington's elaborate annual regattas, in which a fleet of small boats staged a mock attack on Pocklington's island on Derwent Water. See Julia S. Carlson, 'Topographical Measures: Wordsworth's and Crosthwaite's Lines on the Lake District' in Romanticism, 16:1 (2010), 72-93.

Joseph Pocklington (1736-1817), the wealthy son of a banker, who in 1778 purchased an island on Derwent Water in the Lake District on which he built a large modern villa, to the later annoyance of many tourists as well as the poet William Wordsworth. Pocklington was known for the elaborate regattas that he staged on the lake in the 1780s, in which small vessels attacked the island on which his villa was built, to the accompaniment of cannon fire.

James Radcliffe (1689-1716), third earl of Derwentwater, was a committed Jacobite, distantly related to the Stuarts and with extensive estates in the north of England. He was condemned to death for his part in the rising of 1715 and the family estates were forfeited. ODNB.
Sir Michael le Fleming (1748-1806), fourth baronet of Rydal, Westmorland. He was M.P. for Westmorland from 1774-1806. History of Parliament Online.
The Waddingtons of Lerawnest, near Settle, North Yorkshire. They were visited by Eliza Dawson and her party on the return leg of their 1786 tour of Scotland.
A Miss Brown of Ilkley is mentioned by Eliza Dawson in the journal of her 1786 tour of Scotland.
A Mrs Flesher of Otley, Yorkshire was visited by Eliza Dawson and her party on the return leg of their 1786 tour of Scotland.

Agnes, wife of Thomas Salmon, maid of Beatrix, daughter of John the Bastard. Pennant mentions her alongside her mistress and provides the Latin inscription on her tomb inFrom Dover to the Isle of Wight, p. 92.

Lady Anne Hope Johnstone (d.1818), eldest daughter of James Hope Johnstone, third earl of Hopetoun. In 1792 she married the naval commander and politician Sir William Johnstone Hope (1766–1831). ODNB.
Mr Gleck, present at New Lanark in 1818 and mentioned in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of that year.

Robert Owen (1771–1858), socialist and manufacturer. Born in Newtown, Montgomeryshire, Owen entered the textile trade at a young age and quickly rose to the position of manager of a Manchester cotton mill. In 1799 he married Caroline Dale, whose father David had established the mills at New Lanark along with Richard Arkwright. Owen became a part owner of the New Lanark venture, and he famously developed Dale's philanthropic management of the mills into a socialist manufacturing community, incorporating housing, schooling and recreation. Owen's philosophy centred on his belief, expounded in his New View of Society: or, Essays on the Principle of the Formation of the Human Character (London: 1817), that an individual's character was a product of their environment, and this was reflected in the 'Institution Established for the Formation of Character' that he incorporated into the community at New Lanark. ODNB.

Sir Richard Worsley, first Baronet (1588–1621), of Appuldurcombe, Isle of Wight. The son of Thomas Worsley and his wife Barbara, daughter of William St. John of Farley Chamberlayne, Hampshire, he married Frances, daughter of Sir Henry Neville, and was MP for Newport, Isle of Wight, in 1614 and 1621. Hist P.

Ralph Wardlaw D.D. (1779-1853), was a Congregationalist minister and religious author, born and educated in Glasgow. His popularity as a preacher was such that his specially built chapel at Albion Street became too small for his congregation, and a larger one was built on West George Street to accommodate his services. He published a large number of sermons, essays and books on religious subjects. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr and Mrs Baker of Glasgow (fl.1818), mentioned in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour journal.
Mr Cazalet, shared a boat on Loch Lomond with Elizabeth Susannah Graham and her daughter, Maria, on their 1818 tour of Scotland.
Colonel Austen, shared a boat on Loch Lomond with Elizabeth Susannah Graham and her daughter, Maria, on their 1818 tour of Scotland.
Nothing more is known about the Graham who is identified as the owner of a house and sheep farm on the banks of Loch Katrine by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her 1818 tour of Scotland.

Lady Sarah Clementina Drummond (d.1865), daughter of James Drummond, lord Perth. On her marriage to Peter Robert Burrell, later lord Willoughby de Eresby and second Baron Gwydyr both parties took the name Drummond-Burrell. She became Lady Gwydyr in 1820. She was credited with the construction of shelters on a promontory at the head of Loch Katrine, to allow tourists to enjoy the view. thepeerage.com

note.note: Peter Robert Drummond-Burrell (1782-1865) was the son of Peter Burrell, first baron Gwydyr, to which title he succeeded in 1820. He was also 22nd lord Willoughby de Eresby. He married Lady Sarah Clementina Drummond, daughter of James, lord Drummond, styled lady Perth, and took her name on doing so. thepeerage.com

persName.note: Innkeeper and tenant near Loch Achray. He is mentioned in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's 1818 tour of Scotland.

James Callander (1745-1831) took the name Campbell on inheriting his cousin's estate at Ardkinglas in 1810; he also adopted the title of baronet, although it had officially lapsed with the death of his cousin. As an erstwhile military attaché, Callandar travelled extensively in Europe and Middle-East. He was married four times and was sued by his third wife whom he refused to recognise. His Memoirs were published in 1832. ODNB.

Archibald Campbell (1682-1761) third duke of Argyll on succeeding his brother John, the second duke, in 1743. Archibald was colonel of the 36th regiment of foot and governor of Dumbarton castle. He led the Hanoverian troops against General Gordon in the west Highlands in the 1715 Jacobite rising, and was wounded in the battle of Sheriffmuir. In addition to his military duties, he held a number of prestigious offices, including keeper of the privy and great seals of Scotland. In his own demesne he played the part of 'improver', and the subsequent seat of the dukes of Argyll at Inverary Castle was built under his instruction. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

John Campbell (d.1703) tenth earl and first duke of Argyll. He was an ally of William of Orange, accompanying him to England in 1688 and selected by the Scottish parliament to offer him the Scottish crown. Argyll's fealty was rewarded by membership of the privy council and the restoration of the family estates, which had been forfeited by his father. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

note.note: George William Campbell (1768-1839), sixth duke of Argyll. He held the title of marquis of Lorne until his succession to the dukedom in 1806. In 1799, he had also succeeded his brother as baron Hamilton, a title inherited from his mother, Elizabeth (née Gunning), widow of James, sixth duke of Hamilton preceding her marriage to John, fifth duke of Argyll. The sixth duke was vice-admiral over the west coast of Scotland. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

persName.note: Caroline Elizabeth Campbell [née Villiers] (1774-1835) was the daugher of the earl of Jersey. In 1810 she married George William Campbell, sixth duke of Argyll, having dissolved her previous marriage to the marquis of Anglesey, Henry Paget. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Horatio Nelson, Viscount Nelson (1758-1805) was a naval commander during the American and French revolutionary wars. In 1785 he married Frances Herbet Nisbet née (Woolward; 1761–1831) daughter of a judge on the island of Nevis in the West Indies. He commanded a squadron against the French in the Mediterranean in 1795 and against the Spanish in 1797. Nelson is chiefly remembered for major victories against the French fleet at the battle of the Nile in 1798, and against the combined French and Spanish fleet at Trafalgar in 1805, where he was mortally wounded. ODNB.

Joanna Baillie (1762-1851) was a playwright and poet, born in Bothwell, Lanarkshire. In 1783 Baillie's brother, Matthew, inherited the Windmill Street house of their uncle, the anatomist Dr William Hunter, and Joanna, her sister and mother moved there to live with him. In London, Baillie moved in literary circles and her poems and plays met with encouragement from other writers. Her three volume series of Plays on the Passions (1798-1812) presented dramatic studies of human emotion and psychology, was widely read and pieces of it occassionally staged, despite criticism that Baillie was a closet dramatist. Her 1810 play, The Family Legend was based on the history of the Macleans, and was performed at Edinburgh with additions by Walter Scott and Henry Mackenzie. ODNB.

Walter Scott (1771-1832) was a writer of narrative poetry and historical fiction, whose Waverley novels (1818-1831) profoundly shaped the Romantic period's conception of Scotland and its past, as well as the literary marketplace. Scott was admitted into the Faculty of Advocates in 1792 and held the post of sheriff of Selkirkshire from 1799 until his death. Scott's literary projects were informed by his strong antiquarian, bibliographic and collecting interests, and his Minstrelsy of the Scottish Borders (1802), based on materials gathered from oral tradition followed in the footsteps of Percy's Reliques of Ancient English Poetry (1765). Scott subsequently moved from editor to author, writing several highly successful narrative poems based on historical subjects, including The Lay of the Last Minstrel, Marmion, The Lady of the Lake and The Lord of the Isles. Published in 1814, Scott's first novel, Waverley, marked the begining of a decisive move from verse romance to historical fiction, which saw him produce 32 novels before his death. Scott's novels are marked by a distinctive combination of narrative technique, historical research and enlightenment social theory, that partly reflected the close-fought cultural politics of the early nineteenth century.
The Campbells of Knock, Mull, including a Colonel Campbell are mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham who visited them during her tour of Scotland in 1818.
A Mr Smith is mentioned in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's 1818 tour of Scotland as the writer of a letter of introduction to Colonel Campbell of Knock, Mull.

General Duncan Campbell of Lochnell (c.1763-1837), soldier in the duke of Argyll's regiment and MP for the Ayr Burghs on the sixth duke of Argyll's interest from 1809 until his death. History of Parliament Online.
A Mr Cameron is mentioned as the innkeeper at North Ballachulish in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of Scotland in 1818.

George Gordon, first duke of Gordon and fourth marquis of Huntly (c.1650-1716), soldier in the French army in the siege of Maestricht, and in the army of William of Orange in his Flanders campaign. Gordon was an adherent of James II during the Revolution, and held Edinburgh Castle for him following his abdication, possibly at the instruction of viscount Dundee. During the subsequent reigns of William and George I, he was placed under confinement for his former allegiances. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Mary II (1662–1694), queen of England, Scotland, and Ireland, was the daughter of James II and Anne Hyde. She stood to inherit the crown from her father and her marriage thus became an important political issue. She was married to William of Orange in 1677 and left for the Netherlands soon after. William and Mary were crowned in 1689, replacing her father James II, who had escaped to France during the 'Glorious Revolution' of 1688. ODNB.

John Cameron (1771-1815), son of Ewen Cameron of Inverscadale. He served with the 92nd, Gordon Highlanders in the French revolutionary wars and against Napoleon. He was killed at Quatre-Bras during the opening skirmishes of the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. ODNB.
Colonel Cameron, laird or estate trustee of Cameron estate c.1818.
Sir William Cunningham Fairlie, eighth baronet of Robertland (d.1837).
A Mr McAlpine is named as a pearl merchant in Killin in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of 1818.

John Campbell (1796-1862), second marquess of Breadalbane and MP for Okehampton (1820-26) and Perthshire (1832-34). Campbell was styled Lord Glenorchy until 1831 and Earl of Ormerlie from 1831-1834. He succeeded as second baron Breadalbane of Taymouth and fifth earl of Breadalbane and Holland in 1834. thepeerage.com

Grand duke Michael Pavolovich of Russia (1798-1849), tenth child of Paul I of Russia and Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg. He toured Great Britain and Ireland in summer 1818, visiting some of the houses of the nobility, including the Stuarts of Bute and the Campbells of Taymouth.
Mr Armstrong, a school teacher at the village of Kenmore in 1818, who received a stipend from the Highland Society. He is mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her 1818 tour of Scotland.
Sir Neil Menzies of Menzies Castle (1780-1844), advocate, succeeded as sixth baronet Menzies in 1813. thepeerage.com.
A McNaughton is named as the landlord of the inn at Aberfeldy in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of Scotland in 1818.
Sir George Stewart of Grandtully (1750-1827), fifth baronet Stewart of Blair and Balcaskie, Fife. thepeerage.com.

persName.addName: General Sir Thomas Grahame, Lord Lyndock

note.note: Thomas Graham, Baron Lynedoch (1748-1843), soldier and MP. Born in Perthsire, he was tutored by James Macpherson, translator of Ossian. He purchased the estate of Lynedoch in 1787, but moved to France in 1790 due to his wife Mary's ailing health. The despoilation of her coffin by French revolutionaries in 1792 drove Graham to join the military, and he raised the Perthshire Volunteers, 90th regiment of foot, of which he was made lieutenant-colonel in 1794. He rose to national fame as a result of his conduct during that Battle of Barrosa in 1811. He was elected MP for the county of Perth in 1794. ODNB.

persName.note: Archibald Alison (1757-1839), was a clergyman and author, known for his 1790 Essays on the Nature and Principles of Taste, an influential treatise on the association of ideas and aesthetics. After a long spell as a curate in the north of England, Alison and his wife Dorothea (née Gregory) relocated to Edinburgh in 1800, where he was minister of the Episcopal chapel in the Cowgate and later St Paul's church, York Place, until 1831. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.
The Bell family of Edinburgh, visited by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818.

Andrew Thomson, D.D. (1779-1831), minister of New Greyfriar's Church in Edinburgh, and of St George's Church, Edinburgh, from 1814. He was the leader of evangelical party of the Kirk in the General Assembly. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Charles II (1630–85), king of England, Scotland, and Ireland. He was proclaimed king of Scotland following his father Charles I's execution by the Parliamentarians in 1649, but was forced into exile after his defeat by Cromwell at Worcester in 1651. Charles returned to Britain as monarch in 1660, marking the Restoration in England, shortly followed by those of Scotland and Ireland. His rule was beset by various crises, the legacy of the bitter political and religious divides of the Civil Wars. ODNB.

David I, king of Scots (c.1085–1153), son of Malcom III and Margaret. His legacy was the consolidation of Scotland as an emphatically feudal and Catholic kingdom. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.

William Murray Nairne (1757–1830), heir to the attainted title of Lord Nairne, major-general in the army and assistant inspector-general of barracks in Scotland. In 1806 he married his cousin Lady Carolina Oliphant of Gask (1766–1845), a famous song writer, collector and editor whose compositions reflected her ancestry and the increasing popularity of Jacobite song in the Romantic period. One source holds that Nairne's title was restored by George IV following the King's Jaunt in 1824, during which he learned that the song 'The Attainted Scottish Nobles' was the work of Nairne's wife. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.

Jean-Paul Marat (1744–93) was notorious for the violent democratic opinions expressed in his journal, L'Ami du peuple, and was believed to have played a prominent role in the September Massacres of 1792. He was assassinated by Charlotte Corday on 13 July 1793. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 370.
Grandson of Peter the Great, the German-born Peter III (1728–62) ruled as Russian emperor for six months during 1762 prior to his assassination.

James Hepburn, fourth earl of Bothwell and duke of Orkney (1534/5–1578). He was a privy councillor to Mary, queen of Scots, during which time he was involved in factional disputes with other nobles and was imprisoned under suspicion of plotting to abduct the queen. In 1567, following the murder of Mary's consort, Darnley, in which Bothwell's involvement was suspected, he abducted the queen and raped her, after which she was forced to marry him. Following Mary's imprisonment at Loch Leven Castle and flight from Scotland, Bothwell attempted to escape the country, but was detained by Frederick II of Denmark. He died a prisoner in Zeeland where his mummified body was displayed in a church until its burial in the twentieth century. ODNB.
Jeweller in Princes Street, Edinburgh, visited by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818.
Saunderson, 'trinket merchant' in Hunter Square, Edinburgh, visited by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818.

Sir William Allan (1782-1850), historical painter. After a spell apprenticed to the miniaturist and coach painter George Sanders in Edinburgh, Allan left for London and then St Petersburg, from where he travelled further into the Russian Empire. He returned to Edinburgh in 1814, where his paintings of eastern European and Turkic scenes attracted attention from his contemporaries, including Walter Scott. Allan produced portraits of many notable literary figures of the day, including Scott and James Hogg, and was commissioned as an illustrator by Scott's publisher, Constable. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
David Teniers the Younger (1610-1690), Flemish painter of peasant scenes whose work was popular in the eighteenth century. https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/artists/david-teniers-the-younger

A Dr Gregory and his Danish visitor are mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818. The former may be Dr James Gregory (1753-1821), physician and medical teacher at Edinburgh. He was expelled from the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh in 1804 for publishing an account of their proceedings, but his expertise was sought both by medical students and patients throughout Europe. He was made physician to the king in Scotland in 1799, and was widely known for his 'Gregory's Powder', a laxative. https://www.rcpe.ac.uk/heritage/art/gregory-james-1753-1821-1

Alexander Nasmyth (1758-1840), landscape and portrait painter and engineer, known for his Italianate depictions of Scottish scenery and his portraits of famous contemporaries, particularly the poet, Robert Burns. His son, Patrick (1787–1831), was also a landscape painter of some renown. ODNB.

Patrick Nasmyth (1787–1831), landscape painter and son of the artist Alexander Nasmyth. In 1810 Patrick moved to London and exhibited at the Royal Academy. Despite living in London, his work, like that of his father, tended to depict Scottish scenery. He was a founding member of the Society of British Artists. ODNB.

Sir Henry Raeburn (1756–1823), portrait painter. After an apprenticeship to a jeweller for whom he produced miniature paintings, Raeburn visited Italy, and on his return to Scotland began tor produce portraits for elite figures, often working from his studio in York Place, Edinburgh. ODNB.

persName.addName: sir W. W.Watkin Williams Wynn, 3rd baronet (?1693–1749)
persName.note: Watkin Williams Wynn, 3rd baronet (?1693–1749), of Wynnstay, Denbighshire. Hist P.
Sir James Innes Ker (1738-1823), fifth duke and ninth earl of Roxburghe.
One of the two sons of John Fordyce of Ayton (1735-1809), MP and director of the Bank of Scotland, and Catharine, née Maxwell.
Mrs Forster of Berwick-upon-Tweed, visited by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in 1818.
Sir Carnaby Haggerston of Haggerston Castle, Northumberland (1756-1831).
A Mr Dinning is mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818, he may have been resident at Newham, Northumberland c.1818.
A Mrs and Mr Selby are mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818; they may have been proprietors of Twizell House, Northumberland c.1818.
A Mr N.D. is mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818. He appears to be a landowner near Warenton in Northumberland, and possibly a relative of Graham's.
Mr Pratt, a proprietor or tenant near Warenton, Northumbria, is mentioned by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in her tour of 1818.
John Sharp (1645?–1714) consecrated as Archbishop of York in 1691. ODNB.

John Sharp (1723-1792), prebend at Durham Cathedral and senior trustee of the Crewe charity trust at Bamburgh. John's brother, Thomas, was a clergymen at Bamburgh, and on his death in 1772, John assumed responsibility for the trust's operations, including the founding of a refuge for shipwrecked sailors. ODNB.

Thomas Sharp (1693-1758), author and archdeacon of Northumberland. Sharp produced several theological treatises and was a keen book collector. Much of his library was deposited after his death at Bamburgh Castle, a charitable trust established by Lord Crewe and later administered by Sharp's own son, John. ODNB.
Mainfred de Percy, ancestor of the Percy family of Northumberland.
William de Percy (d.1096x9), Norman baron.
Charles Seymour, sixth duke of Somerset (1662–1748), master of the horse under Queen Anne. ODNB.

Hugh Percy(1785–1847), Tory politician and later lord lieutenant of Ireland. He succeeded as third duke of Northumberland in 1817, shortly after his marriage to Lady Charlotte Florentina Clive, daughter of the earl of Powis. ODNB.
Charlotte Florentina Percy (d.1866) daughter of Edward Clive, first earl of Powis. In 1817 she married Hugh Percy, third duke of Northumberland. ODNB.
Alexander Davison of Swarland, Northumberland (1750–1829), government contractor. He was a friend of Horation Nelson and erected a monument at Swarland in his honour. ODNB.
Mr de Lisle or deLisle of Felton, Northumberland. Mentioned in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of 1818.
Keeper of the Turk's Head Inn, Newcastle in 1818.
An individual referred to as 'Old Hindmarsh' is mentioned as having met Elizabeth Susannah Graham at the market in Newcastle during her tour of 1818.
A Mr Thomas is mentioned at Newcastle in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of 1818.
Colonel Thomas Beaumont of Hexham Abbey (1758-1829), MP for Northumberland 1795-1818. History of Parliament Online.

Ranald MacDonald, advocate and proprietor of the island of Staffa. He was sheriff-depute of Stirlingshire and married a Miss Stewart of Allanton. Nicholas Carlisle, A topographical dictionary of Scotland, 2 vols. (Edinburgh: 1813), ii.

note.note: Marianne Maclean Clephane of Torloisk, Mull. She succeeded Lachlan MacLean to the Torloisk estate in 1799. Her husband was Major-General William Douglas Maclean Clephane (d.1803). Her daugher, Margaret, was a poet and correspondent of Walter Scott. Kathryn Sutherland, 'Walter Scott's Highland Minstrelsy and His Correspondence with the Maclean Clephane Family', Scottish Literary Journal, 9:1 (1982), pp.48-66, 52.

Lady Margaret Compton [née Maclean Clephane] (b.1793) was the oldest daughter of Major-General William Douglas Maclean Clephane (d.1803) and his wife Marianne Maclean Clephane of Torloisk, Mull. Margaret was a correspondent of Walter Scott, and frequently advised him on Highland culture, as well as providing him with Jacobite songs during the composition of Waverley (1814). In 1815, partly under Scott's auspices, Margaret married in London Spencer Joshua Alwyne Compton, Lord Compton, and she became Marchioness of Northampton in 1828. Kathryn Sutherland, 'Walter Scott's Highland Minstrelsy and His Correspondence with the Maclean Clephane Family', Scottish Literary Journal, 9:1 (1982), pp.48-66.

persName.note: Alexander Maclean of Ardgour (d.1856), lieutenant-colonel of the third regiment of Argyll militia. in 1795 Maclean married Lady Margaret Hope, daughter of John, second earl of Hopetoun. The Gentleman's Magazine, vol. 45 (1856), p.84.

George William Manby (1765–1854) was an inventor and captain in the Cambridgeshire militia. He invented an apparatus for preventing the loss of life during shipwrecks after witnessing the wreck of a naval ship, the Snipe off the Norfolk coast in 1807. His method of firing ropes to the stricken vessel from mortars stationed on the shore was adopted by the navy after its successful demonstration in 1808. ODNB.

Mary or Maria Graham, daughter of Elizabeth Susannah Graham (née Davenport) and Thomas Graham of Edmond Castle, Cumberland. She accompanied her mother on a tour of Scotland in 1818. She married a Richard Graham of Stonehouse. John Debrett, The Baronetage of England, 3rd edn. (London: 1815), vol. ii, p.1219.
No further information is available on Mr Norman of Carlisle, visited by Elizabeth Susannah Graham in 1818.
A Graham is mentioned as the joint proprietor of the Inn at Kinross Green in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of 1818.
A Blair is mentioned as the joint proprietor of the Inn at Kinross Green in Elizabeth Susannah Graham's tour of 1818.
Probably William Graham, son of Elizabeth Susannah Graham (née Davenport) and Thomas Graham of Edmond Castle. John Debrett, The Baronetage of England, 3rd edn. (London: 1815), vol. ii, p.1219.
No further information is available about the Jane who, with William Graham, accompanied Elizabeth Susannah Graham and her daugher Maria on part of their 1818 tour of Scotland.

Colonel James Eidingtoun (d.1800), proprietor of Gargunnock. The entry for Sinclair's Statistical Account notes that Eidingtoun was an improving farmer, in the process of introducing the Cheviot breed of sheep to his land. John Sinclair, Statistical Account of Scotland 21 vols (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xviii, p.92.
Colonel Alexander McGregor Murray, soldier in the army of the East India Company and later the Royal Clan Alpine Regiment.
Mr Buchanan of Cambusmore.
Captain Fairfal, former commander of an East Indiaman, visited at Callander by Sir John MacGregor Murray during his tour of 1800.

Dr James Robertson, minister of the parish of Callander. He provided an extensive description of Callander and the Trossachs for Sinclair's Statistical Account, which may have contributed to the prominence of the area as a scenic destination for tourists. See John Sinclair, Statistical Account of Scotland, 21 vols (Edinburgh: 1791-1799), xi, pp.574-627.
Mr Buchanan of Callander, visited by John MacGregor Murray during his tour of 1800; he was at that time 78 years of age.

Captain (later colonel) John Buchanan of Spittal on the side of his father, Thomas Buchanan, and Hamilton of Bardowie on the side of his mother, Elizabeth Hamilton. He seems to have resided at the family seat of Leny near Callander. John's brother was Francis Hamilton (1762-1829), a famous colonial botanist, who took his mother's name when he succeeded John to the Buchanan estate. By the time Francis inherited the estate, John was reported to have run-up debts of £15,000. Claim of Dr. Francis Buchanan, Buchanan of Spittal (Edinburgh: 1826); ODNB.

Emilius Henry Delmé Radcliffe (c.1770–1832), eldest son of Peter Delmé (1748–89) succeeded to both his father's estates and, in the right of his wife, to the estates of the Radcliffe family, whereupon he assumed that family's name and arms. He died in 1832, aged 60. Hist P;The Gentleman's Magazine, CII, part 1 (April 1832), 367.

Son of Peter Delmé, of whom he was an heir, and younger brother of Emilius Henry Delmé Radcliffe, John Delmé (1772–1809) was educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge. See https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Delm%C3%A9-12 [accessed 10 September 2018].

Lady Elizabeth Howard, daughter of Henry, fourth earl of Carlisle, wife of Peter Delmé later married Charles Garnier, a captain in the Royal Navy. Hist P;The Gentleman's Magazine, CII, part 1 (April 1832), 367. For Joshua Reynolds's portrait, Lady Elizabeth Delmé and Her Children see here.

Letitia Darby (d. 1825) was a courtesan who went by the name of 'Mrs Smith'. She was mistress to the MP Peter Delmé and to Sir John Lade (1759–1838), second baronet, among others, and married the latter in 1787. Hist P; Lars E. Troide, Stewart J. Cooke (eds.), The Early Journals and Letters of Fanny Burney: Volume V, 1782–1783 (McGill-Queen's University Press, 2012), p. 8, n. 30; Stewart Cooke with Elaine Bander (eds.), The Additional Journals and Letters of Frances Burney: Volume I. 1784–1786 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2015), p. 63, n. 318.
An unidentified Mr Buchanan of Perthshire, possibly one of the Buchanans of Leny. He is mentioned by John MacGregor Murray in his tour of 1800.
Dr Robert MacNab of Bovain (d.1814). His brother was Francis MacNab, hereditary chief of the MacNabs. John MacNab, The Clan MacNab; a Short Sketch (Edinburgh: 1907), p.23.
Thomas Roden, bookseller and bookbinder in Denbigh c.1790–1816. Evans, 'Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant', 286; Eiluned Rees, 'Bookbinding in 18th century Wales', JWBS, 12, no. 1 (1983–4), 64.

William Ellis (1747–1810), a London-born printmaker. He was apprenticed in 1760 to Joseph Ellis of the Stationers' Company, and worked from c.1770 at the studio of William Woollett, a situation which allowed for frequent sketching tours into Suffolk and led to his relationship with another pupil, Elizabeth Smith, who became his wife in 1785. The couple worked together, publishing among other things large views of London after Hearne and Charles Tomkins (1786), a series of aquatint views on the Rhine and the Maas after Revd Gardnor (1788) and further aquatints of villages outside London, The campagna of London (1791). ODNB.

Alexander III of Macedon (known as 'the Great'; 356BC–323BC). In 326BC, he began his Indian campaign, entering into the north-western Indian subcontinent. The battle of the Hydaspes River, fought during this campaign, was his last major battle. Writing of the confrontation, Pennant describes how Alexander gained a 'complete victory with a handful of men' over the Indian king Porus, whose forces included at least two hundred elephants in opposition to the horses of the Greeks. See The view of Hindoostan: Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798), p. 19.

An officer in the army of Alexander the Great, known for his voyage from the Indus River to the Persian Gulf, following Alexander's Indian campaign of 326BC. Pennant describes the feat carried out by Nearchus, whom he praises as 'a man of first rate abilities', in The view of Hindoostan: Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798), p. 27.

Tipu Sahib (1750–4 May 1799), a ruler of the kingdom of Mysore. During the third Anglo-Mysore War (1791), Sir John Chalmers, an army officer in the East India Company, defended the garrison of Coimbatore in southern India for nearly two months. A failed attempt to take it by a general of Tipu's on 11 August led to the retreat of the besiegers. ODNB, s.n. Sir John Chalmers; Mohibbul Hasan, History of Tipu Sultan (1951; 2nd edn. Delhi: Aakar Books: 1971). See also The view of Hindoostan: Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798), p. 115, where Pennant notes how, '(while I write this)', 'Carwar was wrested from [Tippoo Saib] by a detachment of our army, under Major Sartorious'.

Samuel Small of Holywell, treasurer of the Flint and Holywell turnpike districts. Newspaper references suggest that he was an attorney. See, e.g., Saunders's News-Letter, 28 August 1775. For his correspondence with Pennant, dated 6 August 1789 and 23 July 1795, on legal and antiquarian topics, see WCRO, CR 2017/TP189/361/1–2.

John Gore (1738–1803), co-founder of Gore's Liverpool Advertiser, which he owned from 1765 until his death. Other occupations in which he was involved included those of bookseller, lottery agent, music-seller and stationer. Victoria E. M. Gardner, The Business of News in England, 1760–1820 (Houndsmill: Palgrave Macmillan, 2016), p. 184.
Charles Cornwallis, first Marquess Cornwallis (1738–1805), governor general of Bengal during 1786–93. Hist P; ODNB.

Chevalier (later Marquis) Anne-César de La Luzerne (1741–91), second French minister to the United States, where he played an important role in persuading the state of Maryland to ratify the Articles of Confederation during 1780–1. Following his return from America in 1784, he was appointed ambassador to Great Britain in 1788. His death at Southampton on 14 September 1791, following 'a second stroke of the palsey', is reported in the Kentish Gazette, 20 September 1791. See here [accessed 9 October 2018].
Thomas Falconer's wife

The man named 'Pink' whom Bull claims visited him during September 1791 with a remit to carry out a survey of the Isle of Wight may have been a predecessor of Charles Pink, a land and estate surveyor, whose son, Charles Richard Pink, was born at Soberton, Hampshire, in 1853. ODNB s.n. Charles Richard Pink.
Thomas Orde-Powlett, first Baron Bolton (1746–1807), of Hackwood Park, near Basingstoke, Hampshire, was appointed governor of the Isle of Wight in 1791. Hist P; ODNB.

Daniel Lysons (1762–1834), Gloucestershire-born antiquary, was a nephew of the physician of the same name. His Environs of London, published in four volumes between 1792 and 1796, was a detailed antiquarian study of parishes located within twelve miles of the capital, and enlarged on previous studies of the localities involved. It was illustrated by drawings made and etched by Lysons and his younger brother, Samuel. Further collaboration between the brothers led to the publication of Magna Britannia, being a concise topographical account of the several counties of Great Britain, the first volume of which was published in 1806. ODNB.

The antiquary Samuel Lysons (bap. 1763, d. 1819), was the younger brother of Daniel Lysons, junior, with whom he collaborated on Environs of London (1792–6) and Magna Britannia (1806–22), contributing in particular to the etchings of drawings for these publications. ODNB .

James Fittler (1758–1835), exhibitor at the Royal Academy from 1788 to 1824, was elected an associate in 1800. He became one of John Boydell's principal engravers of marines and was marine engraver to George III. ODNB s.n. John Boydell, engravers (act. 1760–1804), printmakers.

The French orientalist, Abraham Hyacinthe Anquetil-Duperron (1731–1805), translator of the 'Avesta' (a collection of religious texts in the Avestan language) and collector of manuscripts during a journey to India between 1755 and 1761. His published translation of the 'Avesta', which appeared in three volumes in 1771, initially drew accusations of forgery from William Jones among others, but by the early 1790s Anquetil-Duperron had been vindicated through the researches of Tychsen and Heeren. See here [accessed 12 October 2018].

Author of Airopaidia: containing the narrative of a balloon excursion from Chester, the eighth of September, 1785 ... (Chester: J. Fletcher, 1786). A print depicting the ascent of Captain G. French's balloon from Chester Castle, 31 August [17]85, is included in Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), at here, p. 162/3.
Medieval MacGregor chief.

note.note: Sir Duncan 'Dubh' Campbell (1551x4-1631), or Donnchadh Dubh na Currag, first baronet of Glenorchy and a baronet of Nova Scotia. He became infamous for his ruthless expansion of his estates, and for plotting against the earls of Argyll in order to assume control of the entire Campbell clan. He was imprisoned at Edinburgh Castle for his role in feuds with the Campbells of Lawers, but purchased his freedom and later ingratiated himself with James VI by allowing stag hunting on his estates. The Black Book of Taymouth commissioned by his son recorded his deeds and the history of the Glenorchy family. ODNB.

persName.note: Cornelius Varley's father (c. 1752-91). May have been employed as a tutor by Earl Stanhope (‘Citizen Stanhope’), well known for his scientific interests and democratic politics. (See note to Samuel Varley for further connections between the Varleys and Stanhope.)
Daughter of John (1752-90) and Elizabeth (1761-1847) Bacon Schutz, and sister of Harriet (1787-1861).
Daughter of John (1752-90) and Elizabeth (1761-1847) Bacon Schutz, and sister of Susan (1783-1853).
Son of Duncan 'Dubh' Campbell of Glenorchy, according to an account related by Sir John MacGregor Murray in his 1800 tour.
Mr McNab of Innishewan.
Mr Campbell Lochdochart of Auchlyne.
Mr Campbell, tacksman of Portnellan, Loch Dochart.
An acquaintance of Sir John MacGregor Murray, possibly resident at or responsible for the farm and lands of Inverardran at the western end of Glen Dochart in 1800.
An acquaintance of Sir John MacGregor Murray, possibly resident at or responsible for the farm and lands of Inverardran at the western end of Glen Dochart in 1800.
Captain Ronald Campbell of Auchreoch, a school friend of Sir John MacGregor Murray.
Mrs Campbell, wife of Captain Ronald Campbell of Auchreoch.

note.note: Sarah Murray [née Maese; Aust following her second marriage] (1744-1811), travel writer. Murray was author of two important early contributions to guidebook literature on Scotland and the Highlands, based on information gathered during her own travels: A companion, and useful guide to the beauties of Scotland, to the lakes of Westmoreland, Cumberland, and Lancashire (1799) and A companion and useful guide to the beauties in the western highlands of Scotland, and in the Hebrides. To which is added, a description of part of the main land of Scotland, and of the Isles of Mull, Ulva, Staffa, I-Columbkill, Tirii, Coll, Eigg, Skye, Raza, and Scalpa (1803). During one journey through the Highlands in 1800 she apparently met Sir John MacGregor, who mentions the encounter in his tour journal of 1800. Murray lived most of her life in Kensington, marrying first William Murray (1734-1786) and then George Aust (d.1829), under-secretary of state for foreign affairs. ODNB.

persName.note: Mr John Campbell of Ach [Auch], school friend of Sir John MacGregor Murray.
Schoolmaster at Dalmally in 1800.
Reverend M[a]cIntyre Junior of Dalmally, mentioned by Sir John MacGregor Murray in his tour of 1800. Likely the son of Reverend Joseph MacIntyre of Glenorchy.
MacGregor chief whose grave slab lies in the church yard of Glenorchy.
Angus McDonald, acted as a guide on Sir John MacGregor Murray's visit to Kilchurn Castle in 1800.

James Francis Edward (1688-1766), only surviving son of James II and VII and Maria Beatrice d'Este of Modena. His parentship was immediately disputed by those who feared his succession would be used to reinstate Catholicism as the national religion, and on the 'Glorious Revolution' of 1688 he was moved to France with his mother and placed under the protection of Louis XIV. The death of Queen Anne in 1714 and the accession of the Hanoverian George I saw the estabilshment of a Whig supremacy which was resisted by Jacobites in Scotland and England, led by the earl of Mar.
