James (now styled the III or VIII though never crowned in any country) had arrived in Scotland in late 1715 only to flee to France early in the new year under pressure from pursuing government forces, effectively destroying his support among the Scottish nobility. He died in Rome in 1766.

note.note: Miss Elizabeth Pattisson of Witham, Essex (fl. 1780), sister of Jacob Pattisson and addressee of his 1780 'Tour Through part of the Highlands of Scotland'. No further information about this individual has been discovered.

persName.note: Mary Philipps (née Grant; dates unknown), wife of Richard Philipps
Welsh poet

Jan Gossaert (c.1478-1532), was a renaissance Flemish painter also referred to by his town of birth, Maubeuge. He was probably in the service of Philip, Bastard of Burgundy, both on missions to Rome and at his court and household at Brussels and Souburg. Gossaert frequently painted figures of myth and antiquity, however Thomas Pennant's attribution to him of a series of paintings on the life of Hercules displayed at Holyrood Palace may be unreliable. See: https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/research/biography-jan-gossaert-jean-gossart

Malcolm Laing (1762-1818), lawyer and historian. Laing was born at Stronsay, Orkney and studied law at Edinburgh. His two volume
History of Scotland
(London: 1800), incorporates a 'Dissertation on the Supposed Authenticity of Ossian', which attacks James Macpherson's translations as the product of poetic invention rather than tradition, a theme continued in Laing's 1805 edition of The Poems of Ossian, which draws attention to Macpherson's borrowings from literary sources.

Nicol McNicol is named as an authority on the poems of Ossian by Joseph MacIntyre, minister of Glenorchy, in conversation with Sir John MacGregor Murray during the latter's 1800 tour of the Highlands and Western Isles.

Donald More Ludir Macilenlan is named as an authority on the poems of Ossian by Joseph MacIntyre, minister of Glenorchy, in conversation with Sir John MacGregor Murray during the latter's 1800 tour of the Highlands and Western Isles.
John McVean (1709-1764), minister of Glenorchy and Inishail prior to Joseph MacIntyre, who married McVean's daughter, Christian.

John Home (1722-1808) was a Church of Scotland minister and playwright, best known for his historical tragedy,
Douglas
(1756), an important contribution to the shaping of Scotland's literary identity during the Enlightenment. The play was the cause of a major spat between the moderate and evangelical 'auld-licht' factions of the Kirk, and was defended by members of the Scottish literati. In a meeting at Moffat in 1759, Home was the recipient of one of James Macpherson's early translations of the poems of Ossian. ODNB.

Sir William MacLeod, Lord Bannatyne (1743-1833), judge and senator of the College of Justice. As a young man he sold his maternal estate at Kames, Bute to James Hamilton, writer to the signet and established himself in Edinburgh society, contributing to Henry Mackenzie's Mirror and Lounger periodicals. He was promoted to the bench as Lord Bannatyne in 1799, and knighted in 1823. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Sir William Neville Hart (d.1804), banker, Chamberlain to King Stanislaus Augustus of Poland and Knight of the order of St. Stanislaus. He apparently had some connection with the Campbells, dukes of Argyle, as his presence at the duke's seat, Inveraray Castle is noted in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800, and Hart died there in 1804. Frederick Copland-Griffiths, 'Sir William Neville Hart and his Descendants', Notes and Queries, Volume s10-X, 249, 3 October 1908, 263-64.
A Mrs Campbell Carrick is mentioned as being present at Inverary Castle in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.
A Mr Campbell and his brother John, of Portsonachan whom Sir John MacGregor Murray attempted to visit during his tour of 1800.
John Lloyd (dates unknown), who remodelled Trevor Hall around 1742-3.
of Chirk Castle
Mary Napier, Lady Myddleton (1598-1675).
For an account of the Thomas family of Coed Helen, see http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-THOM-COE-1500.html

note.note: Son of Hugh Lacy, Earl of Lincoln, who built Denbigh Castle and who drowned in a well.

persName.note: Maidservant to the Plymley family, who accompanied them on their journey to Anglesey in 1792.
of Aston Hall

note.note: John Butler (1740-95), 17th Earl of Ormonde and 10th Earl of Ossory, Irish peer and M.P., and father of Lady Eleanor Butler, one of the two Ladies of Langollen.

persName.note: possessor of a smart modern summer house by the ruins of Valle Crucis Abbey.
sister of the possessor of a smart modern summer house by the ruins of Valle Crucis Abbey.

John Paul Jones (1742-1792) was a Dumfries-shire born sailor and officer in the American continental navy during the War of Independence. Having served aboard slave ships between Britain and the Caribbean, he conducted a number of successful forays against British shipping and coastal defences between 1778-1780. Following the peace he entered the diplomatic service. ODNB.
abolitionist
an acquaintance of Jane Josepha Plymley.
"one of the council"
lived in Beaumaris?
Had a house at Beaumaris.

note.note: Jane Bayley-Paget (née Champagné; 1742-1817), Lady Uxbridge, wife of Henry Bayley-Paget (1744-1812).

persName.note: owner of Llandyfnan

The Isle of Wight bankers' firm Roberts and Co., which became insolvent during 1791, was managed by several partners, including Henry Roberts, John Roberts and Mark Gregory. Mark Gregory (together with Thomas Gregory) was declared bankrupt on 9 November 1791, with Henry and John Roberts following suit a few days later. Francis Vesey, Reports of cases argued and determined in the High Court of Chancery (2nd edn., London: Brooke and Clarke, Bell-Yard, Temple-Bar, 1804), IV, p. 753.

John Leyden (1775-1811) was a writer and linguist, born to a farming family in the Scottish Borders. He contributed to several literary magazines, as well as Scott's Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border (1802), and wrote on A Sketch of the Discoveries and Settlements of the Europeans in Northern and Western Africa (1801). In 1800 he accompanied two Germans on a tour of the Highlands and Hebrides, the journal of which would be published in 1903. Having failed to secure a post as a clergyman, Leyden found a post in Madras as a surgeon, and travelled into East Asia, writing a Dissertation on the Languages and Literature of the Indo-Chinese Nations (1800). Leyden died of fever in Java in 1811. ODNB.
Dougal MacGregor, innkeeper at Taynuilt, mentioned by Sir John MacGregor Murray in his tour of 1800.
Duncan Campbell of Auchinbreck.

Fergus I, a mythical Scottish king, supposed to have died in the third century B.C.E. He was likely a twelfth-century invention, whose lineage was elaborated by Scottish chroniclers in the middle ages and early-modern period as part of a national origin myth.

Angus Gregorson (his surname being an anglicisation of MacGregor) was the tacksman of Ardtornish in Morvern, part of the lands of the Duke of Argyll, from 1773 until his death in 1813, when he was succeeded by his son, John. Gregorson was a comparitively wealthy individual and paid the highest rent of any of Argyll's tacksmen; he later purchased estates at Durran and Acharn. Philip Gaskell, Morvern Transformed: A Highland Parish in the Nineteenth Century (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1980), p.28.

John Gregorson (born c. 1776) succeeded his father, Angus, to the tack of Ardtornish in 1813. He later purchased the estate from the Duke of Argyll, but sold it and left Morvern in 1844. Philip Gaskell, Morvern Transformed: A Highland Parish in the Nineteenth Century (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1980), pp.28-29.

Donald MacNicol (1735-1802) was a Church of Scotland Minister, born in Glenorchy and educated at St Andrews University. In 1765 he became minister of Lismore where he lived for the rest of his life. MacNicol was a noted Gaelicist and native speaker, who had assisted the poet Donnchadh Ban Macan-t-Saoir (Duncan Ban MacIntyre) in putting his work to paper; he also corresponded with Thomas Pennant prior to the publication of the latter's Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides in 1774. MacNicol is perhaps most noted for his Remarks on Dr. Samuel Johnson's journey to the Hebrides (1779), a fiery refutaion of Samuel Johnson's claim in his Journey to the Western Islands of Scotland (1775), that James Macpherson's Poems of Ossian was a literary fraud rather than evidence of an authentic Gaelic poetic tradition. ODNB.

note.note: Unidentified.
Person who Katherine Plymley records as regularly dining with Thomas Pennant at his house, Downing Hall; otherwise unidentified.
Unidentified.

persName.note: An Isobel Chaum Cameron is mentioned in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800. She was supposed to have died c.1795-96 at the age of 126 or 127.

James Maxwell (1759-1829), the fifth duke of Argyll's factor and chamberlain on Mull, resident at Aros Castle. He was an agent of the British Fisheries Society and involved in the planning of the village of Tobermory. Daniel Maudlin, 'Robert Mylne, Thomas Telford and the Architecture of Improvement: the Planned Villages of the British Fisheries Society, 1786–1817', in Urban History, 34:3 (2007), 453–480.
Name unknown: the fifth duke of Argyll's chamberlain on Tiree in 1800.
Mrs Maclean of Drimnin (fl. 1800).
Malcolm Fletcher of Glenforsa, Mull (c.1710-c.1790), reputed to have been an authority on the poems of Ossian; mentioned in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.
Reginald or Ranald George Macdonald, 18th chief Clanranald (1788-1873).
Inn keeper (unclear where)
"Attendants of this house"
Lachlan Maclean, of the Macleans of Coll.

Sir Alexander Macdonald, second baronet of Sleat, Skye (1773-1824). Macdonald was born in Yorkshire and succeeded his father as baronet in 1795. He was member of parliament for Saltash from 1796-1802 and colonel of a fencible regiment which was disbanded in 1802. History of Parliament Online.
Mr Macdonald of Vallay, chamberlain to Sir Alexander Macdonald of Sleat's estate on North Uist.
Assistant clerk and treasurer to the Mostyn Turnpike Trust.

James Gillespie Graham (1776-1855) was an architect, employed by Sir Alexander Macdonald to oversee the erection of new buildings on his Hebridean estates. He took the name Graham after marrying Margaret, daughter of William Graham and inheriting his estate in 1825. Gillespie Graham was responsible for the design of a number of prominent churches and private houses around Scotland. Dictionary of Scottish Architects.
Peggy Macdonald Clanronald of South Uist, cousin of Sir John MacGregor Murray.
Roderick MacNeil, laird of Barra (d.1822).
Old Testament figure.
Captain Caroline Frederick Scott, Hanoverian army officer who in the aftermath of Culloden was involved in the brutal repression of the Jacobites and their sympathisers in the Highlands.

Rachel Erskine [née Chiesley, Cheislie], Lady Grange (bap. 1679, d. 1745) was born in Edinburgh and married James Erskine (bap. 1679, d. 1754), a lord of session and MP. The marriage was unhappy, and when Lady Grange threatened to out her husband as a Jacobite, he enlisted the help of Lord Lovat and Norman MacLeod of Dunvegan to abduct her. She was initially held in Stirlingshire, before being taken to Hesker, off North Uist, and eventually to the island of Hirta in the remote archipelago of St Kilda. Rachel managed to inform her cousin of her situation, but by the time help arrived, Norman MacLeod had moved her again, to Assynt and then Skye, where she was effectively abandoned. ODNB.
Dr John Maclean of Trotternish, factor to the Macdonalds, reputedly owned a Gaelic translation of the Aphorisms of Hippocrates.
Welsh pipers

John Macpherson (1713-1765) was the Church of Scotland minister of Barra (1734-42) and later Sleat (1742-65). He married Janet, daughter of Donald Macleod of Bernera and granddaughter of the earl of Seaforth. Macpherson's son, also John (c.1745-1821), was governor-general of Bengal and author of the
Critical Dissertations on the Origin, Antiquities, Language, Government, Manners, and Religion of the Ancient Caledonians, their Posterity, the Picts, and the British and Irish Scots (London: 1768), which asserted the authenticity of Ossian. ODNB.
Reverend Allan MacQueen, minister of North Uist.
John Chisholm (1752–1814), Scottish Catholic bishop.
the Postilian

Sir John Macpherson (c.1745–1821), governor-general of Bengal and author of a Critical Dissertations on the Origin, Antiquities, Language, Government, Manners, and Religion of the Ancient Caledonians, their Posterity, the Picts, and the British and Irish Scots (London: 1768), which argued for the authenticity of Ossian. His father, also John Macpherson, was the minister of Sleat, and before that, of Barra. John studied at Aberdeen and Edinburgh with a view to following his father into the clergy, but instead left for Madras, where he entered the service of nawab Muhammad Ali Khan, who faced financial pressure from the East India Company. In collaboration with his relative James Macpherson, translator of Ossian and at that time a propagandist for the British government, John sought to advance his own and the nawab's interests, eventually securing membership of the Bengal supreme council, and, with the departure of Warren Hastings under charges of corruption, succeeding to the post of governor-general. He eventually returned to Britain a wealthy man, and represented Horsham in parliament. ODNB.

persName.forename: Cormac mac Airt [Cormac ua Cuinn, called Cormac Ulfhota]
persName.note: Cormac mac Airt, legendary king of Ireland, said to have lived in the late second and third centuries CE. His life and exploits form the subject of many medieval Irish legends and annals. ODNB.
Diarmaid or Dermid, figure in the Fiannaigheacht tradition who appears in James Macpherson's 'translations' of Ossian.
Patrick or Pádraig, patron saint of Ireland who lived in the fifth century.

Oscar, figure in the Fiannaigheacht tradition who appears in James Macpherson's 'translations' of Ossian. Oscar or Oscur was the son of the poet Ossian, who recounts his exploits and laments his eventual death in battle.

Cairbar, legendary king of Ireland whose battles with the fianna are recounted in Gaelic tradition. Cairbar features in James Macpherson's translations of the poems of Ossian, and exchanges mortal blows with the poet's son Oscar.

Hero of the legendary Ulster Cycle who appears in James Macpherson's
Fingal , which he claimed to have translated from the Gaelic poetry of Ossian.
Mr Macdonald of Boisdale, South Uist (d.1800).
Colonel Macdonald, successor of the Mr Macdonald of Boisdale who died in 1800.
Mr Ronald Macdonald, advocate, brother of Colonel Macdonald, Boisdale.

Mr MacLean of Boreray (fl. 1800). Mentioned in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).

note.note: A sixth-century British hero, Arthur is now believed to have been a historical figure who became the central character of the Arthurian cycle of tales. He is mentioned by the historian Nennius (fl. c. A.D. 800) in the Historia Brittonum and in the anonymous chronicles known as the Annales Cambriae, the earliest of which is a twelfth-century copy of a tenth-century original. DWB.

James (1714-1791), fifth baronet Foulis, soldier and antiquarian. He contributed a paper on the ancient Celtic language and the origins of the Scots to the Transactions of the Antiquarian Society of Scotland in 1781. According to Anderson, he left several unpublished papers on the origins of Scottish place names.

note.note: Thomas Gray (1716-1771) was a poet and professor at Pembroke College, Cambridge. His Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard was widely read and a highly influential.

note.note: John Milton (1608-1674), poet and polemicist best known for his epic poem in English, Paradise Lost (1667), published during the reign of Charles II following the civil wars.

descendants of the owners of Glendowers Palace.

Charlotte Margaret Mostyn (c.1767-1845), second daughter of Sir Roger Mostyn, fifth baronet, and his wife, Margaret (née Wynne). She married Sir Thomas Swymmer Mostyn-Champneys (1769–1839) at St George's, Hanover Square, on 21 April 1792. Burke: Baronetcies, p. 377; George Edward Cokayne, Complete baronetage (5 vols., Exeter: W. Pollard & co., 1900), V, p. 144.
?Charlotte? Mostyn's husband
John Wilkinson's "Negus".
of Vron.
Thomas Erskine's four sons included David Montagu Erskine (1776–1855), the eldest; and Thomas Erskine (1788–1864), the youngest.

The sons of Louisa Clarges and her husband Sir Thomas Clarges, 3rd baronet (d. 1782) included Thomas (1780–1834), who succeeded his father as 4th baronet upon coming of age in December 1802, and William (1782–1807), the former of whom would have been the same age as Pennant's younger son, Thomas. Edward A. Bloom and Lillian D. Bloom, The Piozzi Letters: Correspondence of Hester Lynch Piozzi, 1784–1821 (formerly Mrs. Thrale), vol. 4 1805–1810 (London and Toronto: Associated University Presses, 1996), pp. 95, n. 29, 251–2, n. 5; Ancestry.co.uk. The son whose death is mentioned in 1179 may be an additional one, older than Thomas.

Frederica Charlotte Ulrica Catherina [Princess Frederica of Prussia] (1767–1820) married Prince Frederick, duke of York and Albany, in September 1791. She disliked London society, and the couple did not live long together before separating. ODNB.
Clanranald chamberlain in South Uist, c.1800.
Captain MacDonald, tacksman at Milton, South Uist. Possibly a relative of Jacobite figure Flora MacDonald (1722–1790), whose father held that tack.

Hūstain, Uisdean or Hugh McDonald (fl. 1800), tacksman and genealogist at Kilpheder, South Uist. Named in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).

Described as 'the most general dealer in this game [of faro] at all the routs' and reputedly offered the office of messenger to the Lord Chancellor early in 1792, in March 1797 the faro dealer Henry Martindale was given a fine of £200 for keeping the faro table at the home of Lady Buckinghamshire. See Hampshire Chronicle, 20 February 1792; Andrew Steinmetz, 'The Gaming Table: Its Votaries and Victims – Volume I', here [accessed 5 November 2018]; Boulton, The Amusements of Old London, pp. 153–4.
William Douglas, fourth duke of Queensberry (1725–1810). ODNB.
John Foster, first Baron Oriel (1740–1828), elected speaker of the Irish Commons in 1785, 1790 and 1798. ODNB.

Fáelán Amlabar, or St Fillan (641/2-724), abbot of Iona, buried at Strathfillan where a chapel and village bear his name. His relics, a bell and crozier are in the collection of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, the crozier having spent several centuries in the hands of its hereditary keepers, the Dewars. According to a tradition probably originating with Boece, the saint's arm acquired divine properties and was carried by Robert the Bruce at the head of his army. Having been removed for safe-keeping, the arm mirarculously found its way back into its silver cask on the night before the battle of Bannockburn, auguring Bruce's victory. The Chapel of St Fillan and its environs were popularly associated with the healing of the insane and visited by pilgrims into the eighteenth-century. ODNB.
Henry Hobart (1738–99), of Intwood, Norfolk, MP for Norwich between 1786 and his death in 1799. History of Parliament on-line.

John Campbell (1634-1717), first earl of Breadalbane and Holland. He was born to the powerful Campbell of Glenorchy family, and a descendant of the feared Donnachadh Dubh. Despite taking arms against the royalists, John retained his title at the Restoration, and continued to ambitiously expand his estates, taking on large debts in doing so; a combination of scheming and bribery saw him take the title of earl of Caithness and Lord St Clair of Berriedale and Glenorchie. After the invasion of William of Orange in 1688, Campbell was involved in a number of Jacobite intrigues but his commitment to the cause was distrusted by his contemporaries: in point of fact, Campbell also had secret plans for a militia to support William in the Highlands, and built a barracks at Kilchurn Castle to house them. Following the death of Queen Anne in 1714, Campbell convened a meeting of Jacobite nobles at Kilchurn, and raised a small force of rebels. Kilchurn was subsequently captured by the government and Campbell died under house arrest at Taymouth in 1717. ODNB.

Sir Thomas Swymmer Champneys, second baronet (1769–1839), son of Thomas Champneys, first baronet, and Caroline Anne (née Cox). Husband of Charlotte Margaret Mostyn, he took the name Mostyn-Champneys on succeeding to the estates of his brother in law, Sir Thomas Mostyn, sixth baronet, in 1831. George Edward Cokayne, Complete baronetage (5 vols., Exeter: W. Pollard & co., 1900), V, p. 144.

Thomas Champneys (1745–1821) of Orchardleigh, Somerset, was the son of Richard Champneys by his second wife, Jane (née Swymmer). Sheriff of Somerset during 1775–6, he subsequently spent ten years on estates inherited by his mother in Jamaica. He married Caroline Anne Cox in 1768 and, after her death in 1791, Henrietta, daughter of Humphrey Minchin of Stubbington, Hampshire. He was succeeded by his only son, Thomas Swymmer Champneys. George Edward Cokayne, Complete baronetage (5 vols., Exeter: W. Pollard & co., 1900), V, pp. 143–4.
Colonel McDonald Lyndal, mentioned by Sir John MacGregor Murray at Oban in his 1800 tour of Scotland.

note.note: Alexander MacDougall, twenty-third laird of Dunollie, (likely the 'old' MacDougal' mentioned by John Macgregor Murray in 1800) died in 1801. He is also mentioned as a host in Jacob Pattison's journal of 1780. The MacDougalls of Dunollie were forfeited for their opposition to Robert the Bruce, clashing with him at the battle of Dalrigh in the fourtheenth century. They later sided with Charles I during the wars of the three kingdoms and joined the rebellion of 1715. The estate was restored shortly before the Jacobite rising of 1745, in which the family did not participate. Boswell noted that although he and Dr Johnson received a letter of introduction to MacDougall during their tour, they did not make use of it, believing their presence would not be welcome at Dunollie.

persName.note: A person by the name of Cameron is mentioned in John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800, reputed to be knowledgeable on Ossianic poetry.

Lloyd Kenyon, first Baron Kenyon (1732–1802), judge who rose to the position of Lord Chief Justice. Kenyon also made huge earnings from private clients and was able to rebuild Gredington Hall near Hanmer, Flintshire, where he had been born. He married his first cousin, Mary, daughter of George Kenyon of Peel Hall, Lancashire, and Peregrina Eddowes, in October 1773 and they had three sons: Lloyd (1775–1800); George Kenyon (1776–1855), later second Baron Kenyon; and Thomas (1780–1851). Hist P; ODNB.

Revd William Gilpin, junior (1757–1848), succeeded his father of the same name as headmaster of Cheam School in 1777, and continued there until 1806. William Gilpin senior (1724–1804) had a reputation as an enlightened disciplinarian, who replaced corporal punishment to a large extent by detention and fines. ODNB s.n. William Gilpin (1724–1804). Nicholas A. Hans, New Trends in Education in the Eighteenth Century (Abingdon: Routledge, 1951; repr. 1998), p. 127.
Reverend Edmund MacQueen, minister of Barra.

According to the Reverend Donald MacNicol of Lismore in his polemical Remarks on Dr. Samuel Johnson's journey to the Hebrides (1779), Olla Ilich (the doctor or physician of Islay) was one of two brothers named Bethune, active in the early seventeenth century. MacNicol claims that the brothers received a classical education in Spain and spoke no English. As part of his rebuttal of Johnson's claim that Gaelic was never a written language, MacNicol attributes Olla Ilich with the authorship of a Gaelic manuscript on medicine , which incorporated translations from the Aphorisms of Hippocrates. Nicol MacNicol, Remarks on Dr. Samuel Johnson's journey to the Hebrides (London: 1779), p.262.

According to the Reverend Donald MacNicol of Lismore in his polemical Remarks on Dr. Samuel Johnson's journey to the Hebrides (1779), Olla Ilich (the doctor or physician of Islay) was one of two brothers named Bethune (later anglicized as Beaton), active in the early seventeenth century. MacNicol claims that the brothers received a classical education in Spain and spoke no English. As part of his rebuttal of Johnson's claim that Gaelic was never a written language, MacNicol attributes Olla Ilich with the authorship of a Gaelic manuscript on medicine , which incorporated translations from the Aphorisms of Hippocrates. Nicol MacNicol, Remarks on Dr. Samuel Johnson's journey to the Hebrides (London: 1779), p.262.

William Hunter (1718-1783) was born in East Kilbride and educated at Glasgow University, though he left without a degree. Hunter studied midwifery in London under Dr William Smellie, an associate of the physician William Cullen, and during this time became assistant to the anatomist and physician James Douglas. Hunter continued his medical education in Leiden and Paris before returning to London, where he found fame as a lecturer in anatomy. At the same time, Hunter's reputation as a medical practitioner and writer continued to grow, and he was appointed Physician Extraordinary to Queen Charlotte. Throughout his career in London, Hunter maintained stronged links with the Scottish Enlightenment literati; he was also an avid collector, and on his death he left his collections and library to the College of Glasgow, along with a substantial endowment for the construction of a museum to house them. The Hunterian Museum was founded in 1807. University of Glasgow, The Hunterian.

William Harley (1770-1829), dye manufacturer. He purchased the Blythswood estate in Glasgow and used its springs to supply the city and establish a bath. He also kept a dairy herd at Blythswood and founded a bakery.

Signora or Madame Girardelli, was a scientific performer, possibly of German origin, who attracted a degree of fame during a tour of Britain in the late 1810s. According to contemporary accounts, her act consisted of exposing herself to red-hot or caustic objects and liquids, which she was apparently able to touch or ingest without injury. The Kaleidoscope: or, Literary and scientific mirror; Liverpool, 2 (1818), 6-7.
Monsr. Allen, Le Chevalier de Malt

Thomas Chalmers (1780-1847), presbyterian clergyman. Born in Anstruther and educated at St Andrews, Chalmers rose to prominence as a preacher in Glasgow in the late 1810s and early 1820s. An admirer of Thomas Malthus, Chalmers attempted to eliminate poor relief in his urban parish by establishing a system of charitable contribution and moral reform, which later formed the basis of his The Christian and Civic Economy of Large Towns, 3 vols (Glasgow, 1821-26). Chalmers was also popular for his sermons on astronomy. He was later instrumental in the so-called Great Disruption of 1843, which split the moderate and evangelical factions of the Kirk, and led to the founding of the Free Church of Scotland.

George Bubb Doddington, Baron Melcombe (1690/1–1762), politician and diarist. His disposable property, including his manuscript diary, was given to a cousin, Thomas Wyndham, following his death, and published posthumously by Henry Penruddocke Wyndham as The Diary of the Late George Bubb Dodington, Baron of Melcombe Regis: From March 8, 1748–9, to February 6, 1761 (Salisbury: E. Easton, MDCCLXXXIV [1784]). ODNB.
Margaret Mostyn (née Wynn), daughter of Revd Hugh Wynn and Catherine Wynn, was the wife of Sir Roger Mostyn, fifth baronet. She died on 14 October 1792. Burke, Baronetcies, p. 377.

Archibald-Montgomerie Williamson (d.1844) was the third daugher of Thomas Williamson (later Ramsay) of Lixmount and Maxton (1756-1838). In 1830 Archibald-Montgomerie would marry the soldier Henry Fairfax, son of the naval officer Sir William George (1739–1813), and brother of the scientific and mathematical writer, Mary Somerville. Her unusual name might suggest some sort of family connection or tribute to Archibald Montgomerie, eleventh earl of Eglinton (1726-1796). Sir Bernard Burke A Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Peerage and Baronetage of the British Empire, 27th edn., (London: 1865), p.423.

Norfolk-born Thomas Paine (1737–1809), radical author, whose influential treatise wordRights of Man appeared on 16 March 1791. He was granted French citizenship in 1792 and voted a deputy of the National Assembly. ODNB; OCRA s.n. Thomas Paine; John Keane, Tom Paine: A Political Life (London, 1995); Eric Foner, Tom Paine and Revolutionary America (updated edn., Oxford, 2004).
Thomas Williamson (later Ramsay) of Lixmount and Maxton, (1756-1838). He was the subject of a portrait by Henry Raeburn.
Jane, probably the daughter of Thomas Williamson and sister of Archibald-Montgomerie Williamson, is mentioned in the latter's tour journal of 1817.
Admiral Charles Elphinstone Fleeming of Cumbernauld (1774-1840), second son of John, eleventh baron Elphinstone. Naval officer and MP for Stirlingshire. History of Parliament Online.
George Oswald (1735-1819, banker and tobacco merchant, elected Rector of Glasgow University in 1797. Oswald inherited the estates of Scotstoun and Auchincruive. The University of Glasgow Story.

Archibald Spiers of Elderslie (d.1832), son of Glasgow merchant Alexander Spiers. He served in the dragoon guards and as MP for Renfrewshire. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)
Robert Walter, eleventh Lord Blantyre (1777-1830), soldier in the Napoleonic wars and lord-lieutenant of Renfrewshire.
John Webb Seymour (1777-1819), geologist.
Mr Hamilton, proprietor of Glenarbuck c.1817.

William Fitzwilliam, second Earl Fitzwilliam in the peerage of Great Britain, and fourth Earl Fitzwilliam in the peerage of Ireland (1748–1833). In parliament, Fitzwilliam was an influential Whig, initially hostile towards William Pitt. His earlier friendship with Charles James Fox was put under pressure during the French Revolutionary years, however, and he lent his support to Pitt from late 1793. Later positions of influence included that of lord lieutenant of Ireland (1795) and of the West Riding of Yorkshire (1798). ODNB.

A professional soldier in the years leading to the Revolution in France, Dumouriez (1739–1823) led the French to victory at the battles of Valmy and Jemappes on the Belgian frontier in November and September 1792. Later defeats, including that at Neerwinden in March 1793, eventually brought him to emigrate from France, and he made his home in Britain after 1800. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, pp. 342–3.
comte de Provence (1755–1824), later Louis XVIII
The Duke of Luxembourg, an émigré in London during January 1793, has not been identified.

A one-time member of the Third Estate at the National Assembly, Mathieu Jean Felicité de Montmorency, duc de Montmorency-Laval (1767–1826), relinquished his revolutionary ideals following the storming of the Tuileries Palace on 10 August 1792. He fled to Switzerland and then to Britain, returning in to France in 1795. He was among the émigrés who frequented Juniper Hall, Mickleham, near Dorking, where Mme. de Staël held a salon for displaced French aristocrats. Lady Constance Charlotte Elisa (Lennox) Russell, Three generations of fascinating women: and other sketches from family history (2nd edn., London, New York: Longmans, Green, 1905), pp. 65–6, 78; Wikipedia after Encyclopædia Britannica (11th edn., Cambridge University Press).

The Prince and Princesse de Léon are mentioned in an early twentieth-century collection of family sketches among a string of émigrés arriving in London in 1793, with the latter described as 'a very handsome woman, [who] held a salon, which was largely attended by the English élite'. See Lady Constance Charlotte Elisa (Lennox) Russell, Three generations of fascinating women: and other sketches from family history (2nd edn., London, New York: Longmans, Green, 1905), p. 65.

The Prince and Princesse de Léon are mentioned in an early twentieth-century collection of family sketches among a string of émigrés arriving in London in 1793, with the latter described as 'a very handsome woman, [who] held a salon, which was largely attended by the English élite'. See Lady Constance Charlotte Elisa (Lennox) Russell, Three generations of fascinating women: and other sketches from family history, p. 65.
Frederick William II, king of Prussia, 1786–97. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 134.

Thomas Hall (c.1746–1813) was a member of a family established in the business of bird stuffing and animal preservation in City Road, Finsbury. 'Thomas Hall Travelling exhibition' [accessed 12 December 2018].

Sir Charles Stuart (1753–1801), army officer, returned into the army after Britain declared war against France in 1793, having left it in 1779, disillusioned with the way the war against the American rebels was fought. ODNB. Burke (1845), p. 950, names his seat as High Cliff, New Forest, Hants., although this is not recorded in either Hist P or ODNB.
Captain of the French frigate, La Cléopâtre, killed in action off the coast of Devon on 18 June 1793. ODNB s.n. Edward Pellew.
John Pitt, second earl of Chatham (1756–1835), army officer, promoted colonel in 1793. ODNB.

Samuel Hood, first Viscount Hood (1724–1816), naval officer. He was appointed commander-in-chief in the Mediterranean on the breakout of war in February 1793, and left Portsmouth aboard the Victory on 22 May. ODNB.

Woollarawarre Bennelong (c.1764–1813), a native of New South Wales, described by contemporaries as a man of ‘ferocious and intractable manners’. A two-year stay in Britain, between 1793 and 1795, saw him 'delighted with every thing he sees, and courteous to those who know him’. The British Critic, A New Review, II (1793), 62–7; esp. 62; Kate Fullagar, 'Bennelong in Britain', Aboriginal History Journal, 33 (2009), 31–51; Keith Vincent Smith, 'Bennelong among his people', in ibid., 7–30.
Marie-Antoinette, wife of Louis XVI. She was guillotined on 16 October 1793.

Ten of the eleven children born to John Lloyd, Caerwys, and his wife Martha (née Williams) survived infancy. They included Llewelyn Lloyd (1770–1841), rector of Gwaenysgor, Flintshire, and Angharad Llwyd (1780–1866), a renowned antiquary. DWB; NLW 23944C.
Essex Gentleman
Elizabeth Stuart (28 December 1635 – 8 September 1650) was the second daughter of Charles I and his wife, Henrietta Maria.

Francis Peck (1692–1743), antiquary and Church of England rector at Goadby Marwood, Lincolnshire. His best known work, Desiderata curiosa, or, a collection of divers scarce and curious pieces, relating chiefly to matters of English history (2 vols., 1732–5), contains a letter dated 28 October 1650 from Anthony Mildmay to William Lenthall, on behalf of the surviving children of Charles I, following Princess Elizabeth's death. A footnote provides further details regarding her last weeks, including the claim that she died not at Newport, as asserted here, but at Carisbrooke castle. No mention is made of her being apprenticed to a mantua maker. ODNB; Desiderata curiosa, or, a collection of divers scarce and curious pieces, relating chiefly to matters of English history (2 vols., London: Thomas Evans, MDCCLXXIX (1779)), II, p. 423.

Jean Mary Browne Powlett (d. 1814), natural daughter of Charles Powlett, firth duke of Bolton, and Mary Browne Banks. The greater part of her father's Bolton estate was entailed on her. ODNB s.n. Thomas Orde-Powlett.
Charles Powlett (c.1718–65), fifth duke of Bolton.
Admiral Harry Powlett, sixth duke of Bolton (1720–25 December 1794).

Mrs Wise may be one of the 'Miss Wise's' named as sellers of a 1782 poetry volume. See Henry Jones, The Isle of Wight: a poem, in three cantos (Isle of Wight: printed by J. Mallett, and sold by the Miss Wise's, and Mr. Sturch, Newport, and Mr. Robert Deacon, of West-Cowes 1782).
Grandfather of Mrs Wise, Newport Bookseller.

Algernon Percy, tenth earl of Northumberland (1602–68). Charles I's daughter, Elizabeth, and her younger brother Henry, duke of Gloucester, were placed under Percy's guardianship between March 1645 and May 1649. ODNB s.n. Algernon Percy, tenth earl of Northumberland (1602–1668).

Captain Anthony Mildmay, guardian to Elizabeth and her brother Henry upon their removal in the summer of 1650 from Penshurst, Kent, to Carisbrooke Castle on the Isle of Wight to await transportation ‘out of the limits of the commonwealth’. ODNB s.n. Princess Elizabeth (1635–1650).
For the Worsley family of Appuldurcombe, Isle of Wight, see items listed here [accessed 19 December 2018], including Isle of Wight Record Office, 'Worsley of Appuldurcombe', JER/WA.

The Oglander family of Nunwell, Isle of Wight, had a presence on the island from the early twelfth-century and earlier, and held estates both there and in Dorset. ODNB s.n. Sir John Oglander (1585–1655); Isle of Wight Record Office, 'The Oglander Collection', OG, with details here [accessed 19 December 2018].

For papers relating to the Leigh family of Thorley and elsewhere on the Isle of Wight, dated 1694–1861, see Birmingham: Archives, Heritage and Photography Service, MS 3366, with details here [accessed 19 December 2018].

Revd Dr. Thomas Wharton (1728–1790), historian and author, whose publications included a work on English local history, The history and antiquities of Kiddington (1782). Chronology of Public Events and remarkable occurrences within the last fifty years: or, from 1771 to 1821 (London: printed for Sir Richard Phillips and Co., Bride-Court, Bridge-Street, n.d.).

Charles O'Hara (c.1740–1802), army officer and colonial governor, was promoted lieutenant-general with command of British forces at Toulon in October 1793. He was wounded in action and held prisoner between 23 November that year and August 1795. ODNB.

note.note: Eight children born to John and Martha Lloyd are named in the register of baptisms at Caerwys church. Mari Ellis, 'Angharad Llwyd, 1780–1866', Flintshire Historical Society publications, vol. 26 (1973–4), 52–95, esp. 56.

persName.note: John Fletcher, owner the Chester Chronicle. Löffler, Welsh Responses to the French Revolution, pp. 137–71.
'Harden' appears to have been an acquaintance of Pennant's, but has not been identified.
Thomas Pennant's agent

Sir George Cranfield Berkeley (1753–1818), naval officer and politician. When Britain declared war against France in 1793 he was appointed commander of the Marlborough, which played an important part in the British victory of 1 June 1794, but with heavy losses to its own crew. ODNB.

note.note: Sir William Henry Clinton (1769–1846), elder son of General Sir Henry Clinton and his wife Harriet (née Carter). His father's support aided him in following a military career from 1784, which led to participation in the the campaign in Flanders in 1793, and to an appointment as aide-de-camp to the duke of York between January 1796 and June 1799. Clinton was also MP for East Retford in Nottinghamshire between 1794 and 1796, and successively for Boroughbridge in North Yorkshire, and Newark, Nottinghamshire, between 1806 and 1829. Hist P; ODNB.

persName.note: Catharine Sedley, suo jure countess of Dorchester, and countess of Portmore (1657–1717), royal mistress. ODNB.
Barbara Palmer (née Villiers), countess of Castlemaine and suo jure duchess of Cleveland (bap. 1640, d. 1709), royal mistress. There are several portraits of her by Peter Lely and his studio. ODNB.

note.note: Sir Edward Lloyd (1710?–1795), of Pengwern, first baronet (from 29 August 1778), and Secretary for War. He was succeeded by his grandnephew, Edward Lloyd (1768–1854), second baronet, and first baron Mostyn (from 1831), son of Bell Lloyd, Bodfach. DWB; Hist P.
Edward Lloyd (1768–1854), second baronet, and first baron Mostyn (from 1831), son of Bell Lloyd, Bodfach. He was grandnephew to Sir Edward Lloyd of Pengwern, first baronet. DWB; Hist P.
Elizabeth, third daughter of Sir Roger Mostyn, wife of Edward Lloyd, second baronet. DWB; Hist P.
Edward Mostyn Lloyd Mostyn, second baron Mostyn, was born on 13 January 1795. He was the son of Edward Lloyd, second baronet, and Elizabeth Lloyd (née Mostyn). DWB; Hist P .

persName.note: The Buchanans of Auchentorlie were a line of 'tobacco lords', related to the Buchanans of Leny powerful in the West of Scotland in the late-eighteenth and early-nineteenth centuries, where members of the family held offices including MP and Lord Provost of Glasgow.
Messrs Mitchell, proprietors of the printfield at Milton, Kilpatrick.

Robert Colquhoun, West Indian planter and heir to the estate of Camstradden, Dunbartonshire, which was held in trust due to debt run-up by his grandfather. In 1825 the estate was sold to James Culquhoun of Luss.

Louis-Charles, duc de Normandie, then dauphin (1785–1795). He was the unproclaimed successor of his father as Louis XVII from 21 January 1793 until his death on 8 June 1795. Jones, The Longman companion to the French Revolution, p. 76.

Boyd Alexander of Southbar (1758-1825), entered the East India Company Service as a paymaster and returned home a rich man. He was MP for Renfrewshire followed by the Glasgow Burghs in the early 1800s. History of Parliament Online.

Robert Montgomery Hamilton (b.1793) succeeded his father as eighth lord Belhaven in 1814. in 1815 he married the daughter of Walter Campbell of Shawfield and Mrs Mary Hamilton. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)
Sir Michael Shaw Stewart, sixth baronet (1788-1836) on succeeding his uncle in 1812. Later MP for Lanarkshire and then Renfrewshire.

Sir Thomas Brisbane (1773-1860) was a soldier in the Peninsular War and Governor of New South Wales from 1821 to 1825. His governorship was short-lived and controversial due to financial issues and tensions between former convicts and voluntary immigrants, the latter of whom were to be favoured in land grants according to recent changes in British policy. After being shipwrecked returning from Jamaica in 1798, Brisbane developed an interest in navigation and astronomy, building an observatory on the family estate near Largs. He added his wife's name, Makdougall, to his own on their marriage in 1819. ODNB.

George Boyle, fourth earl of Glasgow (1766-1843), held posts in a number of militias and was appointed lord-lieutenant of Renfrewshire in 1810. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

Hugh Montgomery, twelfth earl of Eglinton (1740-1819), fought in the Seven Years War and held a number of titles of the realm. He was a keen improver of Eglinton Castle and its estates, and amassed a large debt in funding works at the harbour of Ardrossan. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr Cunningham of Seabank, Stevenston.

William Henry Cavendish-Scott-Bentinck (1768-1854), fourth duke of Portland. He entered politics, serving as an MP and holding a post in the Treasury under his father in the early 1800s. On succeeding to the dukedom he found the family estates heavily indebted, and devoted himself to their management and improvement. The fourth duke was responsible for the expansion of the town of Troon in Ayrshire and its harbour. University of Nottingham, Manuscripts and Special Collections

note.note: David Pennant, junior (1796–1835), only child of his namesake, David Pennant, and his wife Louisa (née Peyton). For an obituary, see the Gentleman’s Magazine, XVI, New Series (1841), 547.

Griffith Lloyd, described as ‘the hunting parson’ in Hist P s.n. Sir Thomas Mostyn, 6th bt, where it is noted that he accompanied Mostyn and his brother-in-law, Sir Edward Price Lloyd, a relation of his, in their hunting exploits.

persName.note: unidentified

note.note: Edward Cecil, Viscount Wimbledon (1572–1638), soldier and politician. Bull may have been seeking a portrait, of which there is one in oils by Michiel Jansz van Miereveldt, dated 1631, here. For a line engraving of 1618 by Simon de Passe, see here. ODNB.

persName.note: unidentified

note.note: Alexander Hood, Viscount Bridport (1726–1814), naval officer and politician. ODNB.
Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor from 12 July 1792 until 1806. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 132.
Napoléon Bonaparte (1769–1821).

Paul I of Russia, czar from 17 November 1796 until 1801. An alliance between Russia and Britain was formed on 18 December 1798, leading to the deployment of Russian troops in both Italy and Switzerland. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 134.
Mary (c.1732–1807), daughter of the physician and natural philosopher Dr James Jurin, married Richard Muilman Trent Chiswell on 27 May 1756. ODNB s.n. Richard Muilman Trench Chiswell; James Jurin.

Known as Marian, Anna Maria Apollonia Chapuset (1747–1837) married Warren Hastings in Calcutta in August 1777, following a divorce from her first husband, Baron Christoph Carl Adam von Imhoff (c.1734–c.1802). She returned to Britain in 1784, followed by Hastings the following year. An extremely wealthy woman, whose fortune was estimated at more than £100,000, she dazzled English society with her display of jewels, but suffered financial losses during 1797. ODNB; P. J. Marshall, ‘The private fortune of Marian Hastings’, Bulletin of the Institute of Historical Research, 37 (1964), 245–53.

persName.note: a nephew of Richard Bull's who died in 1797 in Santo Domingo.
a nephew of Richard Bull's in Santo Domingo. Brother of pe1792.

note.note: James Faulkner of Chester, lieutenant, father of Elizabeth Falconer, Thomas Pennant's first wife.
Harriet Maria (1761–1830), youngest daughter of Sir George Amyand, and wife of James Harris, first earl of Malmesbury. ODNB.

persName.note: Henriet Don [née Cunningham] was the sister of John, fifteenth earl of Glencairn. On John's death in 1796 the title of Glencairn became dormant and Henriet was one of several unsuccessful claimants to the earldom. She married Sir Alexander Don of Newtondon, fifth baronet. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Sir Alexander Don (d.1826), sixth baronet of Newtondon was the son of Henriet [née Cunningham] and the fifth baronet, also Alexander. He served as MP for Roxburghshire and was a friend of Walter Scott. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

note.note: Miniaturist.

persName.note: Alexander Boswell (1775-1822) was an author and antiquary, son of James Boswell and heir to the family estate of Auchinleck. Boswell published several collections of poems and songs in the Scots dialect, and installed a printing press at Auchinleck to assist their production. Made a baronet in 1821, he was a staunch Tory and died of wounds sustained during a duel with one of the victims of his political satires. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

note.note: The dean of Christ Church, Oxford, from 1783 was Cyril Jackson (1746–1819). ODNB.

persName.note: John Crichton Stuart (1767-1848), second marquis of Bute and sixth earl of Dumfries.

note.note: Luigi Schiavonetti (1765–1810), Italian-born printmaker. From about 1790 he worked in London for Francesco Bartolozzi, later moving from the latter's Fulham home to share a house with his brother Niccolò at Brompton. ODNB.

persName.note: Mr Veitch of Eliock House (d.1838).
Sir Charles Granville Stuart Menteth of Closeburn (d.1847).

Dr James Crichton (1765–1823), physician to the Governor General of India. He returned to Scotland a rich man and purchased the house of Friar's Carse near Dumfries. On his death he endowed a charitable trust, managed by his widow, Elizabeth, who founded an asylum.

Robert Burns (1759-1796), poet. The son of a tenant farmer in Ayrshire, Burns's Poems, Chiefly in the Scottish Dialect, was printed by subscription in the town of Kilmarnock in 1786 and swiftly established its author as one of the foremost literary figures in Scotland, allowing him to abandon plans to take up a post in a Jamacian slave plantation. A second edition of the Poems was printed at Edinburgh in 1787, where Burns was fêted by the nation's literati. Burns was a major influence on both his Scottish contemporaries and British Romanticism more broadly, partly due to his sophisticated use of dialect. Burns was also an important collector and editor of traditional song. After his death he was quickly elevated to the status of national bard, and widely commemorated and imitated, despite doubts raised by his posthumous biographers surrounding alcoholism.

Sir William Johnstone Hope (1766-1831), naval officer in the French Revolutionary war and subsequently a Lord of the Admiralty and MP for Dumfries. He was a member of 'Dundas despotism' of conservative power figures who used their control of public life to suppress Scottish radicals, reformers and whigs in the post-revolutionary period. In 1792 he married Lady Anne Hope Johnstone. ODNB.
Sir George Montgomery (1765-1831), born to the Montgomery family of Macbie Hill in Peeblesshire, relatives of the earls of Eglinton. Sir George was a soldier and MP. History of Parliament Online.

Basil Cochrane, sixth son of the eighth earl of Dundonald was a civil servant in the East India Company at Madras. He returned to Britain in 1807 where he purchased the estate of Auchterarder and wrote a number of treatises on the use of 'Vapour Baths'. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869)

Sir James Montgomery (1766-1839), second baronet of Stanhope. He was inherited a significant sum from his family friend, the fourth duke of Queensberry and was MP for Peeblesshire. History of Parliament Online.

note.note: Born and educated in Dundee, Adam Duncan, Viscount Duncan (1731–1804), began his naval career in 1746, becoming involved in naval expeditions during the Seven Years' War and the American War of Independence, where he worked with the Channel Fleet, assisted in the relief of Gibraltar in 1779, and in the battle off Cape St Vincent the following year. In 1793, he was appointed commander-in-chief of the North Sea, a post which led to his success at the Battle of Camperdown in 1797. ODNB.
George Monck, first duke of Albermarle (1608–70), largely credited with bringing about the Restoration of the monarchy in Britain in 1660. ODNB.
Francis Russell, fifth duke of Bedford (1765–1802), agriculturalist and politician. ODNB.
A Mr Totty, who lived at No. 4., Inner Temple, according to a note c.1797 in Richard Bull's hand, has not been identified.

persName.note: Sir John MacGregor Murray (d.1822), known as John Murray of Lanrick before the proscription of the MacGregor clan was lifted in 1784, at which point he was acknowledged as the heriditary chief of the clan. MacGregor Murray was a general in the East India Company and auditor general in Bengal, and was made baronet in 1795. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

Sir Evan MacGregor Murray (1785-1841) was the son of Sir John MacGregor Murray. He married Lady Elizabeth Murray, daughter of John, fourth duke of Atholl. He was a major general in the army and governor-general of the Windward Isles. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
An unidentified earl of Argyll, who was involved in the murder of a MacGregor, according to a story related in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800. Possibly Archibald, the seventh earl.
Unidentified chief of the MacGregors who was murdered at Inveraray Castle.
Campbell of Aberuchill, involved in the murder of a chief of the MacGregor according to Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.

note.note: MacDougall the younger of Dunollie, son of Alexander MacDougall.

persName.note: Duncan MacDougall, second son of the laird of Dunollie Castle.

The name Angus could refer to a number of semi-historical Scottish figures from whom various noble families claimed descent: the brother of Fergus I; an eighth-century king of the Picts, and a ninth-century king of Dalriada.

A MacLean of Duart, who is said to have left his wife, a daughter of one of the earls of Argyle, to drown on a rock in the Sound of Mull. According to the story related by John MacGregor Murray, the woman survived, and MacLean was killed by her brother in revenge.
An earl of Argyle whose daughter was was the victim of a murder attempt by her husband, one of the MacLeans of Duart.
MacDonald of Ardtornish Castle, one of the lords of the Isles.
A mercenary of the name MacLachlan, supposed to have lived in a cave near Ardtornish Castle in Morvern.
Angus mac Ian mhic Ruary MacDonald of Duchamus, owner of a shealing near Loch nan Uamh.
MacDonald of Borradale (fl. 1745).
MacGregor of Durrin or Durran.
Katharine MacGregor of Ardtornish, aunt of Mr MacGregor of Durrin, wife of Angus MacDonald of Duchamus.
Ferguson, a soldier in the British army involved in the search for Charles Edward Stewart and in atrocities committed against his Jacobite supporters.
Mrs McDonald, reported victim of Captain Ferguson's repression of Jacobite supporters in 1746.

note.note: Hugh Maclean succeeded his father Alexander as Laird of Coll in 1835, and was the last Maclean to hold that title, being forced to sell the island due to bankruptcy.

persName.note: Donald Cameron of Lochiel (c.1700-1748), chief of clan Cameron and Jacobite commander during the rebellion of 1745. Lochiel was wounded at the battles of Falkirk and Culloden, where his regiment suffered heavy losses. ODNB.
Neil MacEachan [Mac Eachin] Macdonald, Jacobite and attendant of Prince Charles who was tortured by Captain Scott in the aftermath of the 1745 rising. He accompanied the Prince to France.
Alexander MacDonald of Keppoch (d.1746), Jacobite commander, killed at Culloden.
MacDonald of Boisdale, part of the Jacobite envoy to Charles Edward on his arrival in Scotland in 1745.
Part of the Jacobite envoy to Charles Edward on his arrival in Scotland in 1745.
One of the MacDonalds of the Isles, probably active in the early-seventeenth century.
[?Niel], laird of Vatersay (fl.1800).
Allan MacDonald, Catholic priest in the Outer Hebrides.
Niel McNiel (born c.1720), former soldier and resident of Barra; an authority on Ossianic poetry.
Unidentified.
MacRuory Mhore of Morriston, named as an authority on Ossian.
Rory MacNiel of Barra.
Mr Taylor, tutor to the McNeils of Barra.
Mr John Evan [?John], present at a recital of Ossianic verse on Barra in 1800.
Mrs [MacNeil], possibly wife of MacNeil of Barra.
Ruory Mac Cuian [MacQueen], Ossianic source on North Uist (fl. 1800).
Donald McDonald, Ossianic source in North Uist (fl. 1800).

note.note: Edward Harley, second earl of Oxford and Mortimer (1689–1741), book collector and patron of the arts. ODNB.

persName.note: Mrs McKenzie of Boisdale, possessor of Gaelic manuscript.
Dr Peter MacLean of Glasgow (d. before 1800).

Thomas Baskerville (1630/31–1700), topographer, who was born in Sunningwell, Berkshire, and earned a reputation as an eccentric. The portrait mentioned by Bull may be that upon which a print of Baskerville after an unknown artist published by George Cruikshank in 1819 is predicated. ODNB; NPG D27361; NPG D1026.
A Miss Martin of South Uist, associated with the family of Nicolson, a tacksman on that island.
John Allan [?MacNeil], brother to one of the lairds of Barra.

note.note: Luke Hansard worked as a printer in London from 1790, trading in partnership with Henry Hughs between 1794 and 1799. Three of his sons, Thomas Curson, James, and Luke Graves became apprenticed to Hughs in 1790, 1795 and 1797 respectively, and the business passed on to Luke Hansard c.1800. Exeter Working Papers in Book History: Biographical and bibliographical information on the book trades: The London book trades 1775–1800: a preliminary checklist of members. Names H, here [accessed 23 January 2019].

persName.note: Rory MacNeil, laird of Barra (d.1634), known as Ruairidh Tartar or Ruairidh 'n tartair, the noisy or turbulent. A. Maclean Sinclair, 'The Macneils of Barra', in The Celtic Review Vol. 3, No. 11 (Jan. 15, 1907), pp. 216-223.
Rory Breachd MacNeil, laird of Barra in the late-fifteenth-earl-sixteenth century.
Colin Mackenzie (d.1633), second lord Mackenzie of Kintail, made first lord Seaforth by James VI.
Unidentified minister on South Uist.
MacDonald of Kintyre.
James IV (1473-1513), king of Scotland.
John Macodrum, Gaelic poet partonised by Sir James Macdonald of Sleat and visited by James Macpherson.

note.note: The marine painter Nicholas Pocock (1740–1821) began his career in the employment of a Bristol maritime merchants' company, but started to work as a painter from 1778. His involvement with the sea continued and he became a well-respected painter of naval action, aided in some cases by his on-board presence during battles (as in the case of the battle of the Glorious First of June, 1794). Nine watercolours by Pocock, dated 1792, are included in vol. I of Pennant's extra-illustrated 'Outlines of the Globe' at the National Maritime Museum (NMM MS P/16/1). ODNB; Evans,'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 617, 623. For twenty-one examples of Pocock's drawings, including some representing Welsh views, see 'Nicholas Pocock 1741–1821', here [accessed 24 January 2019]; and for further examples of his work, see here [accessed 24 January 2019].

persName.note: General Goddard.

Sir James Macdonald (1741-1766), eighth baronet of Sleat, died at Rome while on the grand tour, and was succeeded by his younger brother, Alexander. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr Nicolson, tacksman on South Uist (fl. 1800).
Captain MacDonald, brother to the MacDonald of Boisdale who died in 1800.

Mr Ewen MacDonald of Griminish (f. 1800). Named in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).
Donald McDonald of Balronald or Balranald.

Unidentified Mr MacDonald. Possibly James McDonald of Garyhelich named in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).
Alexander Nicolson (fl. 1800), minister of Benbecula.
Individual identified only as Borrinish in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.
Mr McEachan, Catholic priest named in John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.
Mr McDonald, a Catholic priest named in Sir John MacGregor Murray's tour of 1800.

Patrick Nicolson of Torlum, Benbecula named in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).

note.note: Lord Edward Fitzgerald (1763–98) started working for the radical United Irishmen in 1793, becoming a leader for their cause in Kildare. A betrayal of trust forced him into hiding from the authorities and he was captured on 19 May 1798 in Dublin. Wounds sustained during his arrest led to his death in Newgate gaol in the city on 4 June. ODNB.

John Jeffreys Pratt, first Marquess Camden (1759–1840), lord lieutenant of Ireland from 1795 to 1798, was responsible for ordering the arrest in Dublin of the Leinster directory of the United Irishmen on 12 March 1798. ODNB.

persName.note: Lachlan MacMhuirich or MacVuirich , descendant of the hereditary bards of Clanranald. His testimony on the Leabhar Dearg (Red Book) of Clanranald, one of the manuscript sources of Macpherson's Ossian, given on 9 August 1800 appears in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805). The book was provided to Macpherson by Lachlan's father, Niall MacMhuirich.

note.note: In December 1792 Edward Fitzgerald married Pamela (1776?–1831), illegitimate daughter of Madame de Genlis. The duc d'Orléans was reputed to be her father. ODNB s.n. Pamela Fitzgerald [formerly Anne Caroline Stéphanie Sims; Lady Edward Fitzgerald].

persName.note: Niall MacMhuirich, hereditary bard of Clanranald and keeper of the Leabhar Dearg (Red Book) of Clanranald, which he supplied to James Macpherson, translator of Poems of Ossian. See Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).

note.note: John FitzGibbon, first earl of Clare (1748–1802), attorney-general for Ireland from 1783 until his appointment as lord chancellor of Ireland in June 1789, a post which he held until 1802. ODNB.

persName.note: Mr Brown (fl. 1800), factor on Benbecula.

note.note: A list of London bankers in 1797 includes Hodsoll, Michell, and Stirling, trading near Catherine Street, Strand. The Royal Kalendar: Or, Complete and Correct Annual Register for England, Scotland, Ireland, and America. For the year 1797 (London: printed for J. Debrett, [1797]), p. 242.

persName.note: Mrs McLean of North Uist.

note.note: Sir (William) Sidney Smith (1764–1840), naval officer, was taken prisoner off the mouth of the River Seine in April 1796. With the help of a fellow-prisoner, the French émigré François de Tromelin, he secured the assistance of the royalist Colonel Louis-Edmond Picard de Phélippeaux, and managed to escape in February 1798, reaching Britain on 7 May. ODNB.

Gilbert Elliot Murray Kynynmound [formerly Gilbert Elliot], first earl of Minto (1751–1814) took up a post at Toulon, during the siege of the city by the French army in autumn 1793. During the withdrawal of British forces in mid-December, Sir Sidney Smith set fire to thirteen French vessels together with stores in the enemy's naval arsenal. ODNB s.n. Gilbert Elliot Murray Kynynmound; Sir (William) Sidney Smith.

persName.note: Ronald MacDonald, son of Sir James MacDonald.
John, son of Sir James MacDonald of Sleat.
Barbara Macpherson, relative of Sir John Macpherson; married to a MacDonald.

note.note: Captain Charles Papps Price (1750–1813), son of Rice Price, was born at Hay-on-Wye, Breconshire, and died at Hereford. He became a lieutenant in the Royal Navy in 1778 and was involved in repelling the French from the Îles Saint-Marcouf, off the coast of Normandy, which they attacked in May 1798. John Marshall, Royal Naval Biography; Or, Memoirs of the Services of All the Flag-officers, Superannuated Rear-Admirals, Retired-Captains, Post-Captains, and Commanders, Whose Names appeared on the Admiralty List of Sea-Officers at the commencement of the year 1823, or who have since been promoted . . . : Supplement. – Part III (London: Printed for Longman, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green, 1829), p. 1; Thomas Roberts, Eminent Welshmen: A short biographical dictionary of Welshmen who have attained distinction from the earliest times to the present (Cardiff: Educational Publishing Co., 1908), p. 515.
John Haygarth (1740–1827) was appointed physician to the Chester Infirmary in 1766 and continued as a medical practitioner in the city for over 30 years. He moved to Bath in 1798. ODNB.

persName.note: Mother of Thomas Philip Earl of Pembroke
Reverend James MacQueen (fl. 1800).
Raonil mhache Dhonil Herrich, a Macdonald reputedly strangled in a dun on North Uist.
[Hugh] McDonald, former landowner in Trotternish, Skye, whose lands were apparently purchased by Sir James Macdonald.
Grandfather of Sir John MacGregor Murray.
Laird of Bernera (fl. 1800), possibly a Macleod.

Roderick MacNeil the younger of St Kilda (fl. 1800). Mentioned in Henry Mackenzie, Report of the Committee of the Highland Society of Scotland, Appointed to Inquire into the Nature and Authenticity of the Poems of Ossian (Edinburgh: 1805).
Mr Gillespie (fl. 1800), possibly of North Uist.

Sir Norman Macleod (c.1606-1705) was a royalist soldier, born on the island of Berneray, off North Uist. He attended Glasgow University and received the life-long tenancy of Berneray. During the war of the three kingdoms he was lieutenant-colonel of the clan regiment, loyal to Charles II, which suffered heavy losses at the battle of Worcester. He continued to aid the Stuart cause against Cromwell, and after the Restoration both he and his brother Roderick, who had commanded the Macleod regiment, were knighted. He was buried at Rodel, Harris. ODNB.

note.note: Ruarie Macleod, royalist military commander during the war of the three kingdoms, for which service he was knighted at the Restoration; elder brother to Norman Macleod of Berneray.

persName.note: Anne Murray [née Macleod] (d.1830), married John Murray of Lanrick (later MacGregor Murray) in 1774. Her father was Roderick Macleod of Bernera.
John Livingston (fl. 1800), skipper of an Oban based cutter chartered by Sir John MacGregor Murray during his tour of the Outer Hebrides in 1800.
John McDonald of Castletown (fl. 1800), Sheriff substitute of Skye and resident of Greshornish.
Peggy McDonald [née McLeod] of Bernisdale, Skye, married John McDonald of Greshornish.
Lieutenant-colonel Macdonald of Lyndale (fl.1800).
Mrs McLean of Dunvegan (fl.1800).

Captain Cyprus Macleod (fl.1800), so-called due to having served on that island as a soldier, was an illegitimate son of Norman Macleod of Dunvegan (1705–1772). He was married twice: first to a MacLeod of Drynoch who drowned in Talisker Bay on the day of their wedding, and secondly to a neice of Flora Macdonald. Alexander Mackenzie, History of the Macleods (Inverness: 1889), p.155.

Lieutenant-Colonel John Macdonald (1759–1831), cartographer and soldier in the East India Company service, and later in the Royal Clan alpine fencibles. He was the son of Flora Macdonald, who had assisted Prince Charles Edward Stuart in his escape after Culloden. John's surveys of Bengal and Penang were of significant use to his employers, and he published several plans and treatises based on his work. ODNB.

Allan Macdonald of Kingsburgh, (1726-92), husband of Jacobite heroine Flora Macdonald (m.1750). Macdonald replaced his father as Chamberlain of the Macdonald's Trotternish land in 1765. In 1775 Allan and Flora emigrated to America, where he served in the British army, was captured and imprisoned in Novia Scotia. After his release, he and his family returned to Scotland, first to North Uist, before returning to Kingsburgh on Skye. In 22nd-23rd July 1773, played host to Pennant 'Mr MacDonald did me the favour or presenting me with three very curious pieces of antiquity: an urn, a glain naidr, or serpent-bead, and a denarius, found not remote from his house...Am lodged this night in the same bed that formerly recieved the unfortunate Charles Stuart'. Johnson and Boswell staid the following year, the latter describing Macdonald as 'completely the figure of a gallant Highlander'.
Malcolm II [Mael Coluim mac Cinaeda] (d. 1034), king of Scots.

Hengist (d. 488?) and Horsa (d. 455?), two brothers traditionally thought to have been the founders of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Kent. In all likelihood they are an invention modelled on the Roman myth of Romulus and Remus rather than historical figures. ODNB.

Hengist (d. 488?) and Horsa (d. 455?), two brothers traditionally thought to have been the founders of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom of Kent. In all likelihood they are an invention modelled on the Roman myth of Romulus and Remus rather than historical figures. ODNB.
Norse deity.
Ancient deity associated with hunting and the moon; identified with the Greek Artemis.
Celtic supreme being, according to Donald MacQueen. See MacQueen to Pennant, 28 February 1773.

Agricola (40-93) was the governor of the Roman province of Britain. He is remembered for the his campaigns against the tribes of northern Britain, culminating in the battle of Mons Graupius in modern-day Scotland. The major source on his life and military exploits the Agricola, was written by his son in law, Cornelius Tacitus. ODNB.
Gaius Julius Caesar, first-century B.C.E. Roman general, politician and author.
Ancient Armenian deity.
Marcus Antonius (83 BCE-30 BCE), Roman politician and soldier, defeated by Augustus at the Battle of Actium.
Augustus (63 BCE-14 CE), first Roman emperor.
Classical deity.
Artaxerxes II, fifth-fourth-century king of Persia.
Anatolian mother-deity and subject of ancient Greek and Roman cults.
Hannibal, second-century BCE Carthaginian general.
Antisthenes, Greek Sophist philsopher.
Attendant deity of Cybele.
accompanied Sophia Hoare to Dowdeswell springs etc.

The architect John Nash (1752-1835) restored the west front of St David's Cathedral in the 1790s. Some of his sketches for the project can be seen here: https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/12605
Sophia Hoare mentions the view (of Pembroke Castle) from Mr Merrick's house, in her 1808 tour of south Wales. For a later depiction of this view, see https://www.peoplescollection.wales/items/12211
Lady Isabella Caroline Howard (1771-1848).
Owner of Manorbier Castle.
Lord Milford's Steward.
Francis James Mathew, 2nd Earl Landaff (1768-1833).
Wife of John Stewart Marquis of Bute (pe0278)
Grandson of the Marquis of Bute (pe0278)
William Edwards (1719-89), an Independent minister and architect from Glamorgan, "common stone mason" who built the Pont y Pridd.

note.note: Classical deity.

persName.note: Classical deity.
Classical deity.
Claudius, Roman Emperor (10 BCE- 54 CE).
Captain Salt (fl. 1773), soldier and demographer.
Unidentified Skelton, commander of a military regiment.
Figure of classical mythology.

Charles Mackinnon of Strathaird, the 'Laird of Mackinnon' (c.1752-96). Boswell, who met him on Raasay on 9th Sept 1773, described him as 'a man of small size, delicate constitution, feebleness of voice and nearness of sight, but I was told had great knowledge, and hurt himself by too much study, particularly of infidel metaphysics...It was strangely offensive to hear infidelity from a Highland chief. It was like finding him toupe'd and essenced like a French fop'. His Observations on the Wealth and Force of Nations appeared in 1781-4. Married Alexandra Macleod, had three children, but separated in 1790. In 1790 sold Strathaird and died in poverty at Dalkeith. (Black, To the Hebrides, p. 501).
Somerled (d. 1164), king of the Hebrides. Several prominent Highland families traced their ancestry to him, including the Macdonalds, Lords of the Isles and claimants to the earldom of Ross. ODNB.
Ragnhild, dauther of Olaf (d. 1153), king of Man. She married the Hebridean king, Somerled. ODNB.

John MacDonald (c. 1434-1503), fourth lord of the Isles and thirteenth earl of Ross. He revolted against the monarchy of James II, and entered into a treaty with Edward IV against James III, for which his titles were forfeited. John regained his lordship of the Isles by renouncing his claims to Ross, Kintyre and Knapdale, but his authority was severely weakened. ODNB.
Edward IV (1442-1483), king of England and lord of Ireland.
James III (1452-1488), king of Scots.
Margaret of Denmark,(1456/7?-1486), queen of Scots, consort of James III. ODNB.
Hugh Macdonald of Sleat, brother to John (c. 1434-1503), fourth lord of the Isles, ancestor of the Macdonalds of Sleat.
Magnus IV, king of Norway.
Alexander III (1241-1286) king of Scots, died when he was thrown from his horse over a clifftop. His death triggered a crisis that lead to the Scottish wars of independence.
Alpin, ninth-century ruler of the kingdom of Dalriada, in what is now western Scotland.
Nero (37- 68 CE), emperor of Rome.
Donald MacDonald (d. 1420x25), second lord of the Isles and claimant of the earldom of Ross, for which he unsuccessfully fought the Albany Stewarts at the battle of Harlaw in 1411. ODNB.

Robert (1339-1420), first duke of Albany was the son of Robert II, king of Scots and in 1406, with Robert III recently dead and the future James I a prisoner in England, he was made regent of Scotland. His regency saw the battle of Harlaw in 1411, where his nephew Alexander, earl of Mar and Donald, lord of the Isles contended for the earldom of Ross. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Mr Duncan Macdonald (d.1775), legal writer in Edinburgh, buried in Greyfriar's churchyard.
Publius Quinctilius Varus (46 BCE-9 CE), Roman politician and military commander who took his own life after losing three legions to an ambush in Germania, led by Arminius.
Arminius, Germanic leader remembered for a decisive defeat of the Roman legions in Teutoberg Forest, 9 CE.
Tacitus, Roman historian, and statesman (c.55 -120 CE). His father in law was Agricola, famous for his military campaigns in Britain.
Canus, piper in service of the Roman emperor Galba.
Galba, emperor of Rome for seven months following the death of Nero in 68 CE.
Old Testament figure.
Ancient Greek poet, possibly a contemporary of Homer. His works include Theogeny and Works and Days.
Cleopatra (69-30 CE), last Ptolemaic ruler of Egypt.

Donald MacArthur (fl. 1772), ancestral piper of the Macdonald's of Sleat. According to Donald MacQueen's letter of February 19 1774, he was the piper whose house Pennant describes visiting in
A tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772
(1774), p.347.
MacArthur, thirteenth-century piper of the Macdonalds, lords of the Isles and ancestor of Donald MacArthur, whom Pennant met in 1772.

Angus MacDonald (d. 1314x18), king of the Hebrides. He fought at Bannockburn against the English and was rewarded with lands in the west Highlands. He married Aine Ni Cathan, daughter of an Irish chief, and was succeeded by his son, John, who was the first to style himself lord of the Isles. ODNB.

John MacDonald (d. c. 1387), king of the Hebrides and first lord of the Isles. He married twice: first to Amie of Garmoran, whose lands were added to John's, and secondly to Margaret, daughter of Robert Stewart, the future Robert II of Scotland. ODNB.
Margaret MacDonald [née Stewart], daugher of Robert Stewart, later Robert II and wife of John, first lord of the Isles. ODNB.

persName.addName: O Cane of the County of Colranis
persName.note: Aine Ni Cathan, daughter of an Irish chief, married Angus MacDonald, king of the Hebrides and progenitor of the lords of the Isles. ODNB.

Martin Martin (d. 1718), travel writer born on Skye. His father was chamberlain of Donald MacDonald, first baronet of Sleat. Having made important connections in London with Royal Society figures including Hans Sloane, and with Robert Sibbald in Edinburgh, Martin travelled extensively in the Western Isles, producing two highly significant accounts of the region:
A late voyage to St. Kilda
(1698) and
A description of the western islands of Scotland
(1703). ODNB.
John MacQueen, clergyman, son of Donald MacQueen.

Classical deity. Pennant's correspondent Donald MacQueen identifies one of Apollo's Greek epithets with the Gaelic Gruagach, or brownie. See Pennant,
A Tour in Scotland 1772, part II
(1776), pp.434-38.
Brittanicus (41-55 CE), son of the Roman emperor Claudius, was poisoned by Nero.

Uggerus, poet mentioned in Saxo Grammaticus,
Gesta Danorum
.
Pagan solar deity.
Euripides (c. 480-c. 406 BCE), Athenian dramatist.
King Cnut [Canute] (d.1035), king of England, Denmark and Norway.
Claudian, late fourth-century Latin poet.
Mr Macdonald of Clanranald, proprietor of Canna c.1772.
Saint Oran.
Septimius Severus (145-211) Roman emperor, mentioned in James Macpherson's translations of Ossian.
Seneca the Younger (c. 4 BCE-65 CE), Roman statesman and writer.
Domitian (51-96 CE), Roman emperor.
Porphyry of Tyre (c. 234-c.305 CE), philosopher. His Adversus Christianon, a critique of Christianity was supressed and thus transmitted only through the counter-arguments that it provoked.
Paulus Orosius, fifth-century CE theologian and historian, author of Seven Books of History Against the Pagans.
Laurence [St Laurence, Lawrence] (d. 619), archbishop of Canterbury.
Adomnán [St Adomnán] seventh-century abbot of Iona and author of the Life of St Columba.
Hanno the Navigator, fifth or sixth-century BCE Carthaginian, who according to ancient authors sailed down the west coast of Africa establishing colonies.
Cecilia [née Renton], wife of John Mackenzie of Delvine.
Unidentified daughter of John Mackenzie of Delvine (fl.1772).
Mr Campbell of Dunstaffnage castle (fl. 1772). He was Pennant's guide to the castle during the 1772 tour.

Moluag [St Moluag] (d. 592) was a Christian missionary, whose name survives in a number of dedications in the west of Scotland, in particular the medieval church of Lismore, which the centre of his cult. Rosemarkie was said by the annals to be the place of his burial, though the historical basis for this is uncertain. ODNB.
Saint Boniface or Curetan of Rosemarkie. Saints in Scottish Place-Names.
Alexander Colquhoun succeeded his brother Humphry who was killed by the MacGregors.

Archibald Campbell (1575/66-1638), seventh earl of Argyll. His life was marked by vicious clan rivalry in the Highlands, often authorised by royal warrants against rebel nobleman, and he led a protracted campaign against the earl of Huntly. Later, he made Huntly an ally against the MacGregors. Argyll was later declared a traitor, having converted to Catholicism and joined the Spanish in Flanders, though the proscription was lifted in 1621. ODNB.

Timothy Pont (c.1564-c.1614), mapmaker and clergyman. Little is known of his life beyond his cartographical work in the 1590s, which survives in manuscript and was used extensively in volume five of Joan Blaeu's
Atlas
(1654). NLS.

The Falconers of Halkerton (originally Hawkertoun) in the Mearns, derived their name and lands from the hereditary office of keepers of the kings falcons, which they had held since the thirteenth century. In 1778, the eighth lord Falconer of Halkertoun succeeded to the title of Kintore, which superceded that of Halkertoun. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

David Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (d.1803), was attainted for joining the Jacobite rebellion of 1745 with a force of several hundred men. He fled to France where he served as commander of his own regiment, and later returned to Scotland after receiving a pardon in 1783. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Sir John Ogilvy (d.1802), fifth baronet of Inverquharity.
Mr Rattray of Craighall (fl. 1774).
Creely Duff, putative ancestor of the Duffs, earls of Fife after that title's revival as an Irish peerage in the eighteenth century.
Alexander of Keithmore, son of Creely Duff.
Unknown daughter of Grant of Alachie, married Creely Duff.

John Clerk of Eldin (1728-1812) was a naval writer and etcher, son of Sir John Clerk of Penicuik. Clerk studied medicine though never completed his degree, and was an associate of Scottish-Enlightenment figures such as Adam Smith and David Hume. Clerk was interested in naval tactics, which he studied through reports and model re-enactments, leading to the publication of An Essay on Naval Tactics in 1790.
