Clerk was also an accomplished amateur artist, and had studied sketching under Paul Sandby. Clerk produced numerous topographical etchings of Scottish scenery, which he sold privately at Edinburgh. ODNB.
Alexander Sinclair, ninth earl of Caithness (d.1765).
Lady Dorothea, daughter of Alexander Sinclair, ninth earl of Caithness. She married James Duff, second earl of Fife.
Sir James Clerk (d.1782), succeeded his brother Sir John as third baronet Penicuik in 1755.
Susannah Clerk [née Adam], sister to the architects of that name, married John Clerk of Eldin in 1753.

John Adam (1721–1792), architect, born in Edinburgh, the son of the architect William Adam; his brothers Robert and James were also architects. John completed many of his father's commissions, including Hopetoun House, and also constructed the royal exchange in Edinburgh. ODNB.
Henry Scott (1746-1812), third duke of Buccleuch and later Queensberry.
Hugo or Hugh Arnot (1749-1786), antiquarian, lawyer and writer, noted for his eccentric manners and appearance; author of a History of Edinburgh (1779).
Andrew Armstrong (1700-1794), surveyor responsible (with Mostyn Armstrong) for 'A Map of the three Lothians' . See: NLS website.

note.note: Prince of Wales, who d. 1282 at Cilmeri, near Builth, probably in a battle or skirmish with English forces. Llywelyn's death largely brought to an end the long-running conflict between Edward I and the Welsh. See https://biography.wales/article/s-LLYW-APG-1200

persName.note: Daughter of Moses Griffith and his wife Margaret (née Jones).

Son of his namesake, Benjamin White, junior, was involved in his father's printing business from 1785, with the firm renamed Benjamin White & Son before the elder White's retirement in 1792, by which time a younger brother, John, had also become involved in the company. ODNB.

note.note: The abbé Emmanuel-Joseph Siéyès (1748–1836) became a prominent figure in the new French Republic from the period of the Directory (October 1795 to November 1799), when he was elected to the Conseil des Cinq-Cents (Council of Five Hundred), chosen as ambassador in Berlin (1798) and elected Director in 1799. Jones, Longman Companion to the French Revolution, p. 391.

persName.note: William Robert Fitzgerald, second duke of Leinster (1749–1804), was an elder brother of Edward Fitzgerald. The view that he was involved in the rebellion of 1798, although unfounded, was injurious to his reputation. ODNB s.n. William Robert Fitzgerald.
George Nugent-Temple-Grenville, 1st marquess of Buckingham (1753-1813), politician and owner of Stowe.

note.note: The landscape gardener and architect Lancelot Brown (1716-83), who became famous for his work on estates such as Stowe in Buckinghamshire, is better known by the nickname 'Capability Brown'.

persName.note: Mary Anne Eade (nee Vaux; 1778-1802/3), daughter of a London merchant, who married William Eade in 1800.
Noel Hill, 1st Baron Berwick (1745-89), landowner and Whig M.P.
Robert Biddulph, later Myddelton Biddulph (1761-1814), banker and Whig M.P. who acquired Chirk Castle via marriage to Charlotte Myddelton (who had inherited the Chirk estate in 1796) in 1801.
William Magee (1766-1831), Fellow of Trinity College, Dublin and, from 1800, Professor of Mathematics. Magee later became Archbishop of Dublin (1822).
Richard Wingfield, 4th Viscount Powerscourt (1762-1809)
Sir Richard Musgrave (1746-1818), M.P. for Lismore in County Waterford; see https://www.historyireland.com/18th-19th-century-history/sir-richard-musgrave-1746-1818-ultra-protestant-ideologue/
William Todd Jones (1755-1818), M.P. for Lisburn in County Antrim; see http://www.newulsterbiography.co.uk/index.php/home/printPerson/758
Charles Tottenham Loftus, 1st Marquess of Ely (1738-1806), Irish peer and politician.
Richard Newcome (1701-69), Bishop of St Asaph between 1761 and his death in 1769.
Henri IV (1553-1610) king of France and Navarre ) between 1589 and his death in 1610.
Charles I (1600-49), king of England, Scotland, and Ireland between 1625 and his execution in 1649.

note.note: Maurice Wynn (d. 1580) was the first member of his influential family to adopt the surname 'Wynn'. He was M.P. and High Sheriff for Caernarfonshire at various points between 1553 and 1578.

John Wyn Ap Maredudd (d. 1559), owner of estates at Gwydir, Nantconwy, Dolwyddelan, and Llanfrothen. He rebuilt Gwydir Castle in 1555 and was M.P. and High Sheriff for Caernarfonshire at various points between 1551 and 1557.

persName.note: Maredudd ap Ifan (or Ieuan) ap Robert (d. 1525), member of the powerful Wynn family and purchaser of Gwydir Castle in around 1500.

note.note: Dafydd ab Owain Gwynedd (d. 1203), king of Gwynedd; see https://biography.wales/article/s-DAFY-ABO-1203

persName.note: Rhodri ab Owain Gwynedd (d.1195), a prince of Gwynedd; see https://biography.wales/article/s-RHOD-ABO-1195
Emme d'Anjou (c.1140-c.1214, illegitimate daughter of Geoffrey Plantagenet, Count of Anjou (1113-51) and half-sister to Henry II.

Llywelyn ap Iorwerth (‘Llywelyn the Great’, often styled ‘Llywelyn I’, though in strictness the first prince of that name was Llywelyn ap Seisyll; 1173-1240, prince of Gwynedd; see https://biography.wales/article/s-LLYW-API-1173

Joan [Siwan] (d. 1237), princess of Gwynedd, wife of Llywelyn ab Iorwerth, was the illegitimate daughter of John, king of England, and an unknown mother. See https://biography.wales/article/s12-JOAN-TYW-1237
John (1167-1216), king of England, and lord of Ireland, duke of Normandy and of Aquitaine, and count of Anjou.
Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven (1714-78)

note.note: Henry III (1207-72), king of England and lord of Ireland, and duke of Aquitaine.

persName.note: Sir William Gerard (d. 1581), lawyer and M.P. for Chester, and, from 1576, Lord Chancellor of Ireland.
Sidney Wynn (nee Gerard; c.1560-1637), who married Sir John Wynn of Gwydir around 1578.
John Wynn (c.1584-1614), eldest son of Sir John Wynn of Gwydir and his wife Sydney (nee Gerrard). See https://biography.wales/article/s-WYNN-GWY-1300

note.note: Sir Roger Mostyn (1559/60-1642), landowner and M.P. for Flintshire; see https://biography.wales/article/s-MOST-MOS-1301

persName.note: Mary Mostyn (nee Wynn; 1581-1653), eldest daughter of Sir John Wynn of Gwydir and his wife Sydney (nee Gerrard). See https://biography.wales/article/s-WYNN-GWY-1300

note.note: Sir John Bodvel (d.1631) ; see https://biography.wales/article/s-BODV-EL0-1550

persName.note: Elizabeth Bodvel (nee Gwyn; n.d.), daughter of Sir John Wynn of Gwydir; see https://biography.wales/article/s-BODV-EL0-1550
Charles Churchill (1732-64), poet particularly known as a satirist.

John Davies (c.1567–1644) was born in the parish of Llanferres, Denbigshire, and is believed to have been educated at Jesus College, Oxford, and spent time at Llandaf, before becoming rector of Mallwyd, Merionethshire, c.1604. Involved in the publication of an edition of the bible (1620) and of the Welsh Book of Common Prayer (1621), and in further translations of religious texts, he is remembered mostly for his Welsh grammar, Antiquæ Linguæ Britannicæ ... Rudimenta (1621) and Welsh-Latin Dictionary Dictionarium Duplex (1632). His Articulau and Flores Poetarum Britannicorum were published posthumously, in 1664 and 1710 respectively. DWB.

Llewelyn Lloyd (1770–1841), the elder son of John and Martha Lloyd, was educated at Jesus College, Oxford, graduating in 1793, the year of his father's death. He was named as 'Rev. Llewelyn Lloyd, B. A. [of] Nanerch [sic], Ffl [Flintshire]' in a 1797 list of honorary members of the Gwyneddigion society, and was appointed rector of Gwaenysgor, Flintshire, on 9 January of the same year. He is named by William Owen Pughe as 'Revd Ll. LLoyd of Caerwys, Flintshire, in 1798, although there is no reason to suppose that he was rector of Caerwys at that time or any other. Richard Fenton, who met him on a visit to Caerwys in 1808, described Lloyd simply as a 'clergyman'; but by 1811 he had become rector of Nannerch, a post which he held until his death. His Welsh cultural interests are displayed by his connection with the Gwyneddigion society, his subscription to Welsh publications and involvement in promoting the publication of the Myvyrian Archaiology of Wales, and his work as an eisteddfod adjudicator. NLW 1626, I, p. 149; John Fisher (ed.), Tours in Wales (1804–1813) by Richard Fenton (London: Cambrian Archæological Association, 1917), p. 141; William Davies Leathart, The origin and progress of the Gwyneddigion society of London (London: Hugh Pierce Hughes, 1831), p. 111; Mari Ellis, 'Angharad Llwyd, 1780–1866', Flintshire Historical Society Publications, vol. 26 (1973–4), 52–95, esp. 56; eadem, 'Angharad Llwyd, 1780– 1866. Part II', in ibid., vol. 27 (1975–6), 43–84; William Owen Pughe to Iolo Morganwg, 26 April 1798, CIM, II, p. 78, and n. 2.
Eliza Vaux (1780-1862; later Eade), sister of Mary Anne Eade. Later married William Eade’s brother, Joseph.
William Eade (b. 1778), husband of Mary Anne Eade (nee Vaux), from a merchant family background in London.
William Aislabie Eade (1801-53), son of William and Mary Anne Eade.
George Capell (1757-1839) 5th Earl of Essex.
Thomas Villiers (1753-1824), 2nd Earl of Clarendon.
Drummond Smith, London banker who bought Tring Park in Hertfordshire in 1786. He became a baronet in 1804.

Robert Raikes (1736–1811) was the eldest son of a Gloucester printer of the same name. Upon the death of Robert Raikes senior in 1757, the son succeeded to the business, which included proprietorship of the Gloucester Journal founded by the father in 1722. His contribution to philanthropic causes included, from 1768, involvement in the condition of prisoners in Gloucester gaol and the establishment of a Sunday school in his home parish of St Mary le Crypt in 1780. ODNB. There is no evidence that he published a work by Pennant.

Thomas Tindal, Esq., is named in a list of 'Encouragers to this Undertaking' in British zoology. Class I. Quadrupeds. II. Birds (London: Cymmrodorion Society, printed by J. and J. Marsh, 1765), final page, unnumbered.

note.note: Cecilia Mary Feilding (Clifford), Countess of Denbigh (1860–1919), daughter of Charles Clifford, eighth baron Clifford of Chudleigh. She was the wife of Rudolph Feilding, ninth earl of Denbigh, and mother to Rudolph Feilding, Viscount Feilding.

Educated at Jesus College, Oxford, between 1720 and 1724, Richard Farrington (1702–72) held a number of clerical posts before his appointment in 1741 as vicar of Llanwnda-cum-Llanfaglan (residing at Dinas), rector of Llangybi the following year, and chancellor of Bangor cathedral in the early 1760s. Involved in securing circulating schools for his parishioners, he was also a keen antiquarian: three volumes of his antiquarian researches are held at the National Library of Wales. He was acknowledged in the Preface to British Zoology (2nd edn., 1768–80), I, p. iix [sic; recte xii], among those who contributed 'kind informations' to Pennant for the production of the book. Ibid., p. 73, gives an account of the seal in Farrington's words. In August 1772 he moved to Bath, where he died on 16 October of that year. DWB; and for a letter from Farrington to Pennant, 1 December 1768, see CR 2017/TP230.

persName.note: The Dublin-born author Samuel Derrick (1724–69) was known to both Samuel Johnson and James Boswell, by whom he was at times denigrated if not despised. He was appointed master of ceremonies (M. C.) at Bath and Tunbridge Wells in January 1763, a position which he managed to keep 'notwithstanding great opposition'. ODNB; Samuel Derrick, Letters written from Leverpoole, Chester, Corke, the Lake of Kilarney, Dublin, Tunbridge-Wells, and Bath (2 vols., Dublin: Printed for G. Faulkner et al, 1767). For a letter from Lord Chesterfield to Samuel Derrick, M. C., at Bath, dated 1767, see Longleat House, PO/VOL. XIV, 'Correspondence of Margaret, Duchess of Portland', (q).

note.note: Rice Charleton (1722/3–88), physician at Bath, was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1747. His interest in chemistry led to the publication of A Chemical analysis of Bath waters (1750), in which he gave an account of experiments carried out with a view to finding out the mineral components of the thermal waters at Bath. He later published Three tracts on Bath water (1774), which explored the restorative effects of the water on paralysis. ODNB.

persName.note: See ODNB on the physician Sir George Baker (bap. 1723, d. 1809) and his significant discovery that Devonshire colic was caused by lead poisoning due to the use of lead in presses and vats (as opposed to other materials in Herefordshire) in the manufacture of cider.
An obituary to Francis Geach, MD, FRS, senior surgeon at the Royal hospital, Plymouth, is found in the Gentleman's Magazine, vol. 183 (March 1798), 259.

Elizabeth Lysons, one of the seven children of Daniel Lysons (b. 1697, d. 1773), of Hempsted, and his wife Elizabeth, daughter of Samuel Mee of Gloucester. She married John Reeves in the parish of Hempsted on 27 September 1764. Burke (1835–8), III, p. 222; Family History Research in Gloucestershire: Some Records of Surnames L–R (Miscellaneous) (1551–1986), here [accessed 25 March 2019].
Richard Temple, 1st Viscount Cobham (1675-1749).

note.note: Birmingham merchant and friend of William Eade.
Matthew Boulton (1728-1809), Birmingham-based engineer, manufacturer and entrepreneur.

Francis Eginton (1736/7-1805), decorative artist associated with engraving, enamelling and japanning, who worked for Matthew Boulton at his Soho Manufactory in the 1760s and 70s. Eginton later set up his own glass painting business.

persName.note: William Reynolds (1758-1803), Shropshire-born ironmaster, industrialist and scientist.
Robert Burton (d. 1841), owner of Longner Hall, Shropshire.

note.note: Captain Maurice Goddard (dates unknown).

persName.note: Peter La Touche (d. 1828), landowner and M.P.

note.note: William Bingley (1774-1823), writer, naturalist and Church of England clergyman, whose Welsh travels published in 1800 as 'A Tour round North Wales, Performed during the Summer of 1798' were widely known in the period.

persName.note: Edward II (1284–1327), king of England between 1307 and his death in 1327.

Mr McViccar (fl.1810), part of the Liverpool shipping firm of McIver, McViccar and McCorquodale, based in Pownall Street. Gomer Williams, History of the Liverpool Privateers and Letters of Marque, with an Account of the Liverpool Slave Trade (London: 1897), p.403.

Mr McCorquodale (fl.1810), part of the Liverpool shipping firm of McIver, McViccar and McCorquodale, based in Pownall Street. Gomer Williams, History of the Liverpool Privateers and Letters of Marque, with an Account of the Liverpool Slave Trade (London: 1897), p.403.

note.note: A well-known guide working in the area around Cader Idris in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries. For a pencil portrait of Edwards, see http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4674097

persName.note: Mr Wallesly of Douglas, Isle of Man (fl.1810).
Sir John Piers (1772-845), Anglo-Irish baronet and famous adulterer.

note.note: Archibald Kennedy (d.1846), twelfth earl of Cassillis and first baron of Ailsa on his admittance into the Scottish peerage in 1806, taking his title from Ailsa Craig in the Firth of Clyde. He was made marquis of Ailsa in 1831. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869); ODNB.

persName.note: William Burslem (d. 1820), rector of Hanbury, Worcestershire.
Henry Cecil (1754-1804) 1st Marquess of Exeter, MP and landowner, who inherited Burghley House in 1793.
William Herbert (1580-1630), 3rd Earl of Pembroke, politician, courtier and patron of the arts. Chancellor of the University of Oxford from 1617 onwards, and co-founder of Pembroke College, Oxford.

James Capper (1743-1825), army officer and meteorologist, who spent much of his military and diplomatic career in India, settling in Cardiff in the early 1790s. He published his Observations on the Passage to India, through Egypt in 1785, and his observations on the weather in texts including Observations on the Winds and Monsoons (1801) and Meteorological and Miscellaneous Tracts (1810).
Robert Rous (d. 1806), owner of Cwrt-yr-Ala just outside Cardiff and High Sheriff of Glamorgan in 1797.

Henry Holland (1745-1806), architect who collaborated with ‘Capability’ Brown, becoming his son-in-law on his marriage to Bridget Brown in 1773. Holland and Brown remodelled Cardiff Castle in the 1770s.

note.note: Richard Crawshay (1739-1810), Yorkshire-born iron merchant and later ironmaster, who took control of the Cyfarthfa ironworks in Merthyr Tydfil in the 1780s.
Medieval cleric associated with the chapel on Eilean Mòr in the MacCormaig Isles. https://saintsplaces.gla.ac.uk/saint.php?id=80

A painter, architect and designer of gardens and interior furnishings, William Kent (bap. 1686, d. 1748) spent formative years in Italy. There he met Richard Boyle, third earl of Burlington and fourth earl of Cork, with whose household at Burlington House, Piccadilly, he became closely involved after his return to England. From 1720, he worked on the ornamentation of the house in an Italianate style, and he became drawing master to Burlington's wife, Lady Dorothy Savile. Led by Burlington's interests, Kent began work as an architect around 1730, designing temples, obelisks, and garden buildings. He worked at times in collaboration with the former, creating designs for the Painted Chamber at Westminster, for instance. Later work showed Kent disentangling himself from Burlington's influence as architect, as in the designs for screens at Westminster Hall and Gloucester Cathedral (1739 and 1741), which were Gothic in style. His work as a gardener owed less to his Italian experience than to study of published work on ancient Roman gardens on his return to England, or to observation of the transformation of Roman templescapes by figures such as Vanbrugh and Hawsksmoor at Castle Howard. ODNB.

persName.note: Principal god of Roman mythology.

William Davies Shipley married Penelope (d. 1789), elder daughter of Ellis Yonge of Byrn Yorkin, near Wrexham, in April 1777. Besides fortune to be inherited from her paternal family (she was coheir with her father), she stood to inherit from her maternal relations, the Conway family, who owned Rhuddlan Castle and a West Indies sugar plantation. ODNB.

note.note: Charles Sampson (1778–1807), a graduate of Emmanuel College, Cambridge, was appointed sinecure rector of Llansannan, Denbighshire, on 6 February 1783, and held the post until August 1806. See here [accessed 19 June 2019].

persName.note: Sir William Jones (1746–1794), orientalist and judge, son of the mathematician William Jones and his wife Mary (née Nix). ODNB.

note.note: Diana (1748–1805), daughter of Piers Wynne of Dyffryn Aled, first married Ridgeway Owen Meyrick, and subsequently, in 1782, Philip Yorke of Erddig. She is credited with arousing in Yorke an interest in things Welsh. ODNB. For a portrait of Diana as a widow, see here [accessed 21 June 2019].

persName.note: A relative of Philip Yorke's wife, Diana, who died in 1783.

Cadwaladr ap Cadwallon (d. 664/682), king of Gwynedd. Known as 'Cadwaladr Fendigaid' (the Blessed), he is credited with the foundation of the church at Llangadwaladr on Anglesey. He was also believed, probably on the evidence of Geoffrey of Monmouth's Historia Regum Britanniae and the Historia Britonnum, sometimes attributed to Nennius, to have been the last king of the Britons. ODNB.

Gimcrack (1760–c.1777) was a thoroughbred English racehorse. He is commemorated in paintings such as the 1765 Gimrack on Newmarket Heath, with a Trainer, Jockey and Stable-Lad by George Stubbs (1724–1806). ODNB s.n. George Stubbs; here [accessed 24 June 2019].
B. Williams was a friend or acquaintance of Thomas Pennant, with whom he appears to have fallen out during 1771. The two men were subsequently reconciled.

note.note: Born in the parish of Llanfihangel-y-Pennant in Merioneth, William Owen Pughe (1759–1835) moved to London in 1776. In 1783 he became a member of the Gwyneddigion society and began collecting material for a Welsh-English dictionary, the first section of which appeared in 1793. Pughe had, in the meantime, contributed to the cultural and scholarly programme of the Gwyneddigion as co-editor, with Owen Jones (Owain Myfyr) of the poetry of Dafydd ap Gwilym (1789), a work followed by an edition (with translation) of the poetry of Llywarch Hen, The Heroic Elegies and other Pieces of Llywarç Hen (1792), and the three-volume Myvyrian Archaiology of Wales (1801, 1807). Ridiculed by some contemporaries as a follower (from 1803) of the religious fanatic Joanna Southcott, and castigated by later scholarship for his innovations to Welsh orthography, Pughe was nonetheless generally well-respected as an antiquary and lexicographer during his lifetime. He assumed the surname Pughe upon inheriting a Denbighshire estate in 1806. ODNB; Glenda Carr, William Owen Pughe (Caerdydd: Gwasg Prifysgol Cymru, 1983).

persName.note: Sir Thomas Elyot (c.1490–1546), humanist scholar and diplomat. His treatise The Boke Named the Governour (1531), dedicated to Henry VIII, had run to eight editions by the close of the sixteenth century, and discussed questions of political theory and education, drawing on Plato and Aristotle among other authors. ODNB.

Otley and Owen, Mercers, 73 New Bond Street. See Roger Wakefield, Wakefield's Merchant and Tradesman's General Directory for London, Westminster, Borough of Southwark and Twenty-two Miles Circular from St. Paul's, for the year, 1794 (London: the Author, [?1793]), p. 230.

Robert Watkin Wynne (?1755–1806) of Garthmeilio, Corwen, Merionethshire, and Plas Newydd, Henllan, Denbighshire. He held the parliamentary seat for Denbighshire from 1789 until 1796, initially protecting it for the Wynnstay family during the minority of Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, fifth Baronet. Hist P.

Richard Wilding was the owner of Llanrhaeadr Hall, Llanrhaeadr-yng-Nghinmeirch, Denbighshire, from 1788. He was also appointed High Sheriff of Denbighshire for that year. See [Edmund Burke], The Annual Register, or a view of the history, politics, and literature, for the year 1788 (2nd edn., London: Printed for J. Dodsley, in Pall-Mall, 1790), p. 234; 'Llanrhaeadr Hall', here [accessed 5 September 2019].

note.note: John Wynne Griffith (1763–1834) of Garn, Denbighshire, member of parliament for Denbigh Boroughs between 1818 and 1826, and husband of Jane, daughter of Robert Wynne of Garthmeilio, Corwen, and Plasnewydd, Henllan. He was notable for his work as an agriculturalist. DWB s.n. Griffith family, of Garn and Plasnewydd, Denbighshire; Hist P.

persName.note: Robert Roberts is named as a clerk vicar of Llanrhaeadr Dyffryn Clwyd, Denbighshire, in a document dated 1757. He became a member of the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge in 1772. See A Sermon preached in the parish-church of Christ-Church, London, on Thursday June the 3d, 1773 (London: J. and W. Oliver, 1773), p. 33; Denbighshire Archives, DD/WY/2583, here [accessed 5 September 2019].

note.note: Edward Chambres Jones graduated BA and MA from Christ Church, Oxford in 1770 and 1772 respectively. He was rector of Llansannan between 17892 and 1806. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].

persName.note: William Stodart (1769–94), vicar of Abergele from 1777 to 1794. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].

Peter Williams (1775–99) held numerous posts within the diocese of St Asaph, including that of vicar choral and First Vicar Choral at St Asaph cathedral in 1775–6, 1791 and 1794. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].

Peter Whitley (1771– 1820) was Second Vicar Choral at St Asaph cathedral in 1791. He also held the post of vicar in several livings in the diocese during his career, including that of Nantglyn and Cwm. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].

note.note: Hugh Jones (d. 1825) was vicar of Northop, Flintshire, from 1785 until his death. See here [accessed 5 September 2019].

John Williams (1727–98), born in Lampeter, Cardiganshire, was appointed minister of the Independent chapel of Sydenham in 1767, where he remained until the expiry of the lease on the building in 1794 or 1795. During his tenure of this post he was simultaneously involved as curator of the Dr Daniel Williams Library in Red Cross Street, London, an important post for dissenters in the capital since its establishment in 1729. His fascination with the Madoc myth and the possibility that Welsh Indians resided in North America was expounded in An inquiry into the truth of the tradition, concerning the Discovery of America, By Prince Madog ab Owen Gwynedd, about the year, 1170 (London: printed by J. Brown, 1791) and Farther observations, on the discovery of America, by Prince Madog ab Owen Gwynedd, about the year, 1170 (London: printed by J. Brown, 1792). ODNB. The former mentions 'Mr. Pennant': 'If we could find no Word, among the Americans, similar to the ancient British, in sound and sense, but Pengwyn, I should no more depend upon that circumstance than Mr. Pennant doth; / but that is not the case: for many such words were found among the Natives of the New World, and in the West Indian Islands, which are neither obscure nor fanciful'. An inquiry into the truth of the tradition ... about the year, 1170, pp. 66–7.

persName.note: Helena (bap. 21 September 1772, d. 1844) was the second daughter of John and Martha Lloyd. She served in the families of the aristocracy, including as a personal maid to the mother of Queen Victoria, and was reputed to have strong Methodist and Calvinist leanings. Mari Ellis, 'Angharad Llwyd, 1780–1866', Flintshire Historical Society publications, vol. 26 (1973–4), 52–95, esp. 56.

Richard Jones is named in a list of the members of the Gwyneddigion society in 1775. William Davies Leathart, The origin and progress of the Gwyneddigion society of London (London: Hugh Pierce Hughes, 1831), p 15.

note.note: John Price (1735–1813), the son of a vicar from Llandegla and later Llangollen in Denbighshire, held various posts at the Bodleian Library in Oxford before his appointment as librarian there in 1768, a post which he held until his death. He simultaneously held various livings in the Church, and was the author of A Short Account of Holyhead in the Isle of Anglesey (1783). A fellow of the Society of Antiquaries, he cultivated a relationship with Richard Gough, whose collection of topographical material was subsequently bequeathed to the Bodleian. DWB; ODNB.

Dafydd Ddu Athro of Hiraddug may have been a native of Flintshire, and is associated with the earliest extant bardic grammar, alongside Einion Offeiriad (fl. beg. of the fourteenth century). He is associated with the names of four items in the Robert ap Huw manuscript (B. M. Add. 14905), only one of which survives in tablature notation. DWB; Peter Crossley-Holland, 'The Robert ap Huw Composers', in Welsh Music History 3: Astudiaethau Robert ap Huw Studies (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 1999), pp. 183–205, esp. pp. 186, 202.

persName.note: Probably a native of the parish of Cemaes, Montgomeryshire, John Roderick (or Sion Rhydderch; 1673–1735) was among the earliest printers and publishers of Welsh books. He had set up a press in Shrewsbury by 1728, printing a Welsh grammar, Grammadeg Cymraeg there that year. Further publications included, with John Williams of Witley, Shropshire, an English and Welch Dictionary (3 edns.), his own series of Welsh almanacks (1715–35) and contributions to an anthology of poetry by his contemporary, Thomas Jones, entitled Carolau a Dyriau Duwiol (1696). DWB.

note.note: John Rivington (1720–92), was the son of the printer Charles Rivington (1688–1742), who had established himself as a theological publisher in London from the 1730s. John was apprenticed to his father alongside his younger brother James, whose attempts to take possession of the American book market led to bankruptcy and emigration to America in 1760. John retained a bookselling and publishing firm in London, successfully growing the business and taking up public and professional appointments, including that of a governor of Christ's Hospital, and master of the Stationers' Company (1775–6). ODNB.

James Fletcher, junior, was the son of a successful Oxford bookseller. The father, John Fletcher, senior, published several works alongside the Rivington family of printers and publishers in 1755, and subsequently set up a joint business with James Rivington (1724–1802) at the sign of the Oxford Theatre in Paternoster Row, London. The business was brought to an end by bankruptcy in 1760, and James Fletcher's partner, James Rivington, emigrated to America. His brother John Rivington remained in charge of a successful business in London. ODNB s.n. Rivington family (per. c. 1710–c. 1760).

persName.note: Of George Street, Hanover Square, London.

note.note: Born in Gloucestershire, the poet Thomas Master (1602/3–43) graduated from New College Oxford, having contributed numerous poems in both Latin and English to Oxford University collections during his time as a student there. He worked as an amanuensis for Edward Herbert, Lord Herbert of Cherbury, during the 1630s, before taking up the living of East Wickham, near Louth in Lincolnshire. A sermon preached at New College, Oxford in March 1641 appeared in print posthumously, under the title The Virgin Mary, as did an oration on the British Monarchy, published as Monarchia Britannica in 1661. ODNB.

William Mostyn is named in Elizabeth I's commission to hold an eisteddfod at Caerwys in 1568, where the privilege granted to him and his ancestors 'of bestowing of the sylver harpe apptayning to the cheff of that facultie' is also mentioned. See A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), pp. 464–7.

Hywel (or 'Hoele') is named in The itinerary of John Leland the Antiquary (Oxford, 1710–12) as a gentleman from Flintshire, who lived at an unidentified place called Penrhyn ('or Penrine') in the county. It was he, according to this testimony, who had the privilege of bestowing the silver harp associated with Mostyn Hall to the best harpist in north Wales. Pennant identifies Hoele with Thomas ap Richard ap Howel, lord of Mostyn, a contemporary of Leland. Pennant, A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), p. 90.

The publisher of English language legal handbooks, Thomas Phaer [Phayer] (1510?–60) was, from c. 1540, a doctor and writer on medical issues. It was he, it is thought, who introduced a bill 'for the nursing of Children in Wales' at the parliament of 1547, and he published medical works including The Boke of Chyldren (enlarged edn., 1553), thereby ensuring his credentials among later generations as a paediatrician. In addition to these professional engagements, Phayer wrote and translated poetry. ODNB

persName.note: William Bedford was a clark to the Brewers' Guild from c. 1606 until his death in 1622. He was the scribe responsible for the text of the complete Chester 'mystery cycle' now held at the Bodleian Library, Oxford, as Bodley 175. David Mills, 'Theories and Practices in the Editing of the Chester Cycle Play-manuscripts', in The Chester Mystery Cycle: A Casebook, ed. by Kevin J. Harty (1993; Abingdon: Routledge, 2015), pp. 3–17, esp. pp. 12–13.

Thomas Warton (1728–90), son of a poet and clergyman of the same name, entered Trinity College, Oxford in 1744, where he began on publishing poetry. Writing in satiric and humorous vein of his alma mater, he also completed scholarly work in which biographical researches featured strongly. His most ambitious work was The history of English poetry, from the close of the eleventh to the commencement of the eighteenth century (3 vols., 1774, 1778, 1781). Pennant acknowledges a quotation from the first volume in A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), I, p. 141. ODNB.

The antiquary Roger Dodsworth (bap. 1585, d. 1654) was a native of Yorkshire. His antiquarian researches started within that county and centred, in the first instance, on records at the York Minster archives and on the pedigrees of local families, before extending to consider churches throughout the county. By the mid-1630s Dodsworth had begun to collect material on the monasteries of England more generally, an aspiration which resulted in the creation of a manuscript volume entitled 'Monasticon Anglicanum', which was published after his death as the joint creation of Dodsworth and William Dugdale (3 vols., 1655, 1661, 1673, with Dugdale the sole author of the third volume). Dodsworth later scaled down his project on an all-England study to work on a 'Monasticum boreale', centred on monasteries in the north of England. ODNB.

note.note: The historian and antiquary Sir Henry Spelman (1563/4–1641), born near King's Lynn, Norfolk, was instrumental in the foundation of the Society of Antiquaries, c. 1586. His antiquarian work included transcription of deeds and charters from monasteries in Norfolk and Suffolk, but his most enduring legacy is considered to be his work on the origins and terminology associated with feudalism. ODNB; Hist P.

persName.note: Pennant, drawing on the work of William Camden, writes that, following the time of Hugh Lupus (1047–1101) the castle of Hawarden, Flintshire, 'devolved to the barons of Mont-alto, or Mold, which they held by stewartship to the earls of Chester, and made it their residence'. A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), p. 94.

note.note: Ithel Fychan was a member of the Mostyn family. In 1301 he paid homage to prince Edward, then earl of Chester and later Edward II, for lands in Flintshire including at Northop and Mostyn. DWB s.n. Mostyn family of Mostyn Hall, Flintshire; A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (2nd edn., 1784), p. 8.

persName.note: William II (known as William Rufus; c. 1060–1100), third son of William I (the Conqueror), acceded to the throne of England in September 1087, following the death of his father. ODNB.

note.note: The grammarian and physician John David Rhys (1534–?1609), a native of Llanfaethlu, Anglesey, is famed for his Welsh grammar, Cambrobrytannicae Cymraecaeve Linguae Institutions et Rudimenta, first published in 1592. Travel on the Continent, which included a period spent qualifying as a physician at the University of Siena, enabled Rhys to attain fluency in the main European languages and to publish Latin works, including a grammar, which appeared at Venice. Further works created alongside the 1592 Welsh grammar upon his return to Wales demonstrate Rhys's interest in early British history and his skill as a translator of Latin poetry into Welsh. DWB.

Born in Berkshire, Thomas Hearne (bap. 1678, d. 1735) was appointed assistant at the Bodleian Library in 1701 but was held back from smooth career progression at Oxford by his refusal to take the oaths of the University. In spite of impediments to his involvement, as a nonjuror, with publishing ventures, such as the suppression of his edition of Camden's Annals, Hearne was able to pursue an independent career as a publisher, releasing historical material in a series of thirty-seven publications, all made up of several volumes. Also valued after his day were the details of his personal life and career as recorded in a series of almost a hundred and fifty diaries, which contain much additional bibliographical and scholarly information. ODNB.

William Hanmer of Fennes is named in an indenture dated 20 January 1542/3 and a settlement following the marriage of his eldest daughter dated 10 September 1571. See FRO, Bettisfield Estate Records, here [accessed 18 September 2019]. Cf. also Edward Hanmer, 'who succeeded to the lordship of Finnes'. William appears to have been a descendant. See The Baronetage of England, or the History of the English Baronets, and such Baronets of Scotland as are of English families, with Genealogical Tables, and engravings of their armorial bearings (5 vols, London: E. Lloyd, 1801–5), III, p. 429.

persName.note: Roger Puleston (c. 1566–1618), of Emral, Worthenbury, Flintshire, was the son of his namesake. He held several posts of note in and the parliamentary seats for Denbighshire and Flintshire. Hist P.

note.note: George Bromley (c. 1526–89), of Hallon in Worfield, Salop, and the Inner Temple, London. His daughter Susanna married Roger Puleston (c. 1566–1618) of Emral, Worthenbury, Flintshire. Hist P.

persName.note: (d. 1800), vicar of All Saints Church, Baschurch in Shropshire.

note.note: Sister (forename and dates unknown) to Robert Jeffreys, vicar at Baschurch, Shropshire.

persName.note: James Lamont esquire of Knockdow, Arran (1754-1829), factor to the Duke of Hamilton's estate on Arran. Thorbjørn Campbell, Arran: A History (Edinburgh: Birlinn, 2013).

note.note: Mr Brown (fl.1810), tenant on Lunga, Slate Islands.

Proprietor of Lunga in the Slate Isles, probably one of the MacDougalls of MacDougall, also known as MacDougall of Raray or Ardincaple (fl.1810). The MacDougalls of Ardincaple were a cadet branch of the MacDougalls of Lorne. Robert Heron, General View of the Natural Circumstances of the Hebrides (Edinburgh: 1794).

Kenneth MacLeay (fl.1789-1829) was surgeon to the 3rd regiment of militia at Oban in 1810, although it is unclear whether he had completed a medical degree at Edinburgh University. While at Oban he published an account of the Spar cave of Strathaird, Skye. An account of Rob Roy MacGregor by MacLeay appeared in Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine in 1817. ODNB.

persName.note: Unidentified Captain 'Campbel of B[...]', Tiree (fl.1810).

note.note: Mc.Donald of Dunstaffnage (fl.1810), unidentified. The writer may be confusing the MacDonalds with the Campbells, the latter being the hereditary keepers of Dunstaffnage Castle.
Dr Bayard (fl.1810), American visitor to Oban, Staffa and Iona.

persName.note: Alexander Macalister of Strathaird, Skye.

Robert Freind (1666/7–1751), referred to by contemporaries as 'Dr Freind', was headmaster of Westminster School from 1711. He composed and published a small number of Latin poems, and produced a substantial number of epigrams and inscriptions, again in Latin. ODNB.

note.note: Robert Wynne of Garthewin, Denbighshire, was the son of Robert Wynne (d. 1773) and his wife Diana (née Gosling). He married Elizabeth (d. 1816), daughter and heir of William Dymoke of Acton, with whom he had a son, Robert William Wynne (d. 1844). Robert Wynne died on 25 July 1798, aged 60. For extracts from his diary, see here [accessed 7 November 2019]. Griffith, PAACF, p. 167.

persName.note: Revd Hugh Williams was rector of Llanelidan, Denbighshire, from November 1792. He was replaced in August 1796. NLW 1626C, p. 276.
Wynne (or Wynn) of Voelas or Voylass House.
Robert Bertie (1660-1723), 1st Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven, who acquired property in north Wales via his marriage to Mary Wynn (d. 1689) in 1678.
Rev. Edward Hughes (1738-1815), owner of Kinmel Hall near Abergele. For the Hughes family, who established the Parys Mine Company in the 1770s, see http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-HUGH-ROB-1827.html

Mary Hughes (née Lewis; dates unknown), wife of Edward Hughes, owner of Kinmel Hall near Abergele. For the Hughes family, who established the Parys Mine Company in the 1770s, see http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-HUGH-ROB-1827.html
Barbara Isted (neé Percy), eldest daughter (b. 1761) of Thomas Percy, (1729–1811), writer and Church of Ireland bishop best known for his The Reliques of Ancient English Poetry (1765).

note.note: Dr Macalister of Strathaird, Skye (fl.1810). Neighbour and possible relative of Alexander Maclister, Laird of Strathaird.

Sir William Jackson Hooker (1785-1865) was an English botanist, whose early work on mosses was encouraged by Sir Joseph Banks, Sir James Edward Smith and Dawson Turner. Hooker was elected to the Linnean Society of London in 1806. In 1809 he travelled to Iceland but lost most of his work in a fire during the return voyage. He was later professor of botany at the University of Glasgow. ODNB.

Francis Mackenzie Humberston (d.1815), first Baron Seaforth, succeeded his brother to the Seaforth estate in 1783. He was elected M.P. for Ross-shire in 1784 and 1790 and raised two regiments during the wars with revolutionary France. In 1800 he was appointed governor of Barbados, where he introduced a law against the murder of slaves, rendering him highly unpopular amongst the island's white planters. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).
Unidentified individual named only as Thomas, who accompanied the author of a 'Journal of a Voyage to the Western islands of Scotland, 1810'.
Probable daughter of Alexander Macalister of Strathaird (fl.1810).
Mr Dingwall (fl.1810), landlord of a public house in Lochmaddy, North Uist.

persName.note: James MacLeod, 12th laird of Raasay.

Mariana (or Marianne) Belcombe (1790-1868) was the York-based friend and lover of Anne Lister; she married Charles Lawton in 1816. Belcombe's marriage, which she appears to have entered into substantially for economic reasons, was a source of much pain for Lister, even though the two women continued to be lovers. Lister explores some of her ongoing feelings for Mariana in her Welsh tour, where she is referred to as ‘M–'.
Isabella (or ‘Sibella') Jean Maclean (1790-1830) was the daughter of Alexander Maclean of Coll. She and Anne Lister met in York around 1820 and became friends and later lovers.
Charles Lawton, of Lawton Hall in Cheshire, husband of Mariana Belcombe (m. 1816).
Anne Lister (1765-1836), aunt of Anne Lister, who lived at Shibden Hall near Halifax with her brother, James (d. 1826)

note.note: Landlady (dates unknown) of the King's Head, Llangollen

persName.note: John Warren (1730-1800) was Bishop of Bangor from 1783. He notoriously appointed several of his nephews to livings and other posts, and was the target of a stinging pamphlet by the philosopher David Williams (writing as ‘Shôn Gwialan’), attacking his nepotism and his inability to minister in Welsh to a largely monolingual flock. See A Letter to the Right Reverend Dr Warren on his conduct as Bishop of Bangor, (privately printed, 1796). He was tried and acquitted for affray in Shrewsbury in 1796. See The Trial of the cause of the King versus the Bishop of Bangor, Hugh Owen D.D., John Roberts, John Williams, clerks, and Thomas Jones, gentleman: at the Assizes, holden at Shrewsbury on the 26th of July 1796, before the Honourable Mr. Justice Heath by a special jury. Taken in short hand by Mr. Gurney. (London: printed for John Stockdale, 1796.

note.note: Alexander Macleod, known as Crotach (Humpbacked) due to an injury sustained in battle, was eighth chief of the Harris and Dunvegan Macleods. He was long lived, being born in the mid-fifteenth century and dying in the mid-sixteenth. He presided over a bitter feud with the Macleods' rival clan, the Macdonalds of Sleat. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

persName.note: Hugh Maclean (fl. 1810), innkeeper at Tobermory.
Unidentified individual named only as Aston, who accompanied the author of a 'Journal of a Voyage to the Western islands of Scotland, 1810'.

Mary Carryl (d. 1809) was Eleanor Butler and Sarah Ponsonby's long-serving maid at Plas Newydd in Llangollen. She accompanied the two women to Wales on their flight from Ireland in 1778, remaining with them until her death.
TO BE ADDED
Uncle (d. 1826) of Anne Lister, who lived at Shibden Hall near Halifax with his sister, also Anne (1765-1836).
TO BE ADDED

note.note: Evan Lloyd was a kinsman of John Lloyd of Caerwys, who advised and occasionally travelled with Thomas Pennant. The Tour in Wales gives an evocative account of their visit to Evan Lloyd's old-fashioned house in Cwmbychan - ‘a true specimen of an antient seat of a gentleman of Wales’ - and describes the ‘Cistie Styffylog, or the great oatmeal chests’ (1784, II, 125-26).

persName.note: Philip Astley (1742-1814) and his wife Patty developed their equestrian displays in London in the 1760s and 1770s, incorporating jugglers, tight-rope walkers and other acts now familiar to the modern circus.

William Lister (1756-1830) studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh, graduating in 1781. He established a practice in London as a physician to St Thomas' Hospital. He was a member of the Speculative Society of Edinburgh, along with his fellow medical student, Jacob Pattison, whom he accompanied on an extensive tour of the Highlands and Hebrides in 1780. He submitted two essays to the Speculative Society during his membership, entitled 'Progress of Civilization' and 'Enquiry into the Activity of the Human Mind'. History of the Speculative Society of Edinburgh (Edinburgh: 1845), p.140.

note.note: Son of Roger Kynaston and Elizabeth Grey, Humphrey (d.1534) reputedly became a robber and an outlaw, living in caves above Nesscliffe, Shropshire.

persName.note: Charlotte Myddelton (1770-1843) inherited Chirk Castle in 1796. For a satirical cartoon on her status as an heiress, probably by Paul Sandby, see here.
Thomas Harrison (dates unknown) manager of the mines at Holywell.

William Griffiths of Penrhyn (d.1593) and his wife Margaret (d.1587) are depicted in effigy on a marble tomb in the Vaynol Chapel, Llanbeblig, near Caernarvon. see https://coflein.gov.uk/en/site/43801/details/st-pebligs-church-llanbeblig
Anne Susanna Warburton (1745-1816) married Richard Pennant, Baron Penrhyn in 1765.
Henry William Paget, 1st Marquess of Anglesey (1768-1854), British Army officer and M.P.

note.note: Job Weaver (dates unknown), was mentioned by Ann Lister in 1822 as the keeper of the Cernioge Inn, a popular tourist stopping point on the A5 route.
George Playforth (dates unknown), a servant at Shibden Hall in West Yorkshire, accompanied Anne Lister on her 1822 Welsh tour.

persName.note: Thomas Roberts moved to Caernarfon in 1796 and set up a successful printing business there. See Ifano Jones, Printing and Printers in Wales and Monmouthshire (William Lewis: Cardiff, 1925) 146-48.
Evan Jones was a Snowdonia guide based in Capel Curig, active between 1803 and 1828, and variously described also as a harper, barber, waiter, weaver, botanist and mineralogist; see here.
Robert Closs (1766-1833) was the innkeeper at the Vaynol Arms, in Nant Peris, Snowdonia.
A Mrs Lewis is mentioned by Anne Lister in 1822 as the landlady of the Black Bull at Aber, Gwynedd.

note.note: Landlord of the Tyn-y-Maes inn near the Nant Ffrancon pass in Snowdonia.

persName.note: George Hay Dawkins-Pennant (1764–1840), MP and second cousin (and heir) of Richard Pennant of the Penryn estate.

William Henry Rawson (1781-1865), wool merchant of Sowerby, near Halifax, and associate of Anne Lister. Rawson had visited Wales in 1817 and wrote to Lister on 4 July 1822 giving advice on touring Wales. His brother Christopher's journal of their tour is preserved in their family archive at West Yorkshire Archive Service, Calderdale.
Richard Roberts (1796-1855), harpist who had been blind from the age of 8 as a result of smallpox.
George Frideric Handel (1685-1759), German-born British composer.

George Bettiss (dates unknown), listed in 1821 as the keeper of the Uxbridge Arms Hotel; see Peter Bayly Williams, The Tourist's Guide through the County of Caernarvon (Caernarfon: J. Hulme, 1821), p. 84.
From Shrewsbury, Lloyd was also the owner of Glangwna estate on the River Seiont near Caernarfon in the late C18th.
Rhys Goch Eryri (fl. 1385 – 1448), was a poet who lived near Beddgelert in North Wales.

David Thomas (Dafydd Ddu Eryri, 1759-1822) was born at Waunfawr in Caernarfonshire, and began life as a weaver before becoming a schoolmaster and teaching across north Wales. He had learned the art of Welsh poetry from Abraham Ellis, and set up a network of local poets known as 'Cywion Dafydd Ddu' (Dafydd Ddu's Chicks). He corresponded with the London Welsh Societies and won prizes at their eisteddfodau. He drowned in 1822, crossing a ford over the River Cegin.
Roberts, G. T., (1959). THOMAS, DAVID Dafydd Ddu Eryri (1759-1822), man of letters and poet. Dictionary of Welsh Biography. Retrieved 1 Feb 2020, from https://biography.wales/article/s-THOM-DAV-1759 Cynan Evans-Jones, Tad Beirdd Eryri: Dafydd Tomos ('Dafydd Ddu Eryri') 1759-1822 , The Transactions of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion, 1969, Part I, pp. 7-23

persName.addName: Saint Helena of the True Cross

note.note: Consort of Constantius and mother of the Emperor Constantine, the Empress Helena (246/248 – c. 330) is credited with the discovery of the True Cross on a pilgrimage to Palestine, and is honoured as a saint across Europe. The claim by Geoffrey of Monmouth and English chroniclers that she was the daughter of a British prince has led to her conflation with 'Elen Lluydawc' ('Elen of the Hosts'), who appears in the Welsh medieval legend 'Macsen Wledig' as the wife of Magnus Maximus (fourth century ruler of Britain).

persName.note: Elen Llwyddog (Luydawc) or Elen (Helen) of the Hosts is a character from the medieval Welsh tale Breuddwyt Macsen Wledig, where she appears as the daughter of Eudaf Hen of Segontium (Caernarfon). She marries the Roman Emperor Macsen and is responsible for building roads across Wales, Many sections of Roman road in Wales are known as Sarn Helen. In some traditions she becomes of the mother of Saints Peblig and Cystennin (Constantine). She is frequently conflated with the Roman Empress Helena, mother of Constantine.
Greek god/hero, the son of Zeus and Alcmene, famous for his exploits of strength.

note.note: Born Marie-Jeanne Phlipon (1754-1793), she was a key player in the Girondin faction in the early years of the French Revolution. When her husband, Jean-Marie Roland de la Platiere became Minister of the Interior in 1792, she held considerable influence. Disliked by the more radical Jacobins and Montagnards, she was arrested at the beginning of the Terror in 1793 and executed in November that year. She wrote letters and memoirs while in prison, first in the Abbaie de St Germain des Pres, then in Sainte Pelagie, and finally the Conciergerie. A collection of these was published in 1795 under the title Appel à l’impartiale postérité par la citoyenne Roland; an English translation 'An Appeal to Impartial Posterity' appeared the same year, with a second edition in 1796.

persName.note: Marged Ferch Ifan (baptized 1696- d.1793) was a wrestler, inn-keeper, harpist and notable character in the Beddgelert/Llanberis region, and the subject of numerous stories, anecdotes and rhymes celebrating her enormous strength. Although Pennant did not meet her when touring in the 1780s, his description of her feats of hunting and rowing made her famous to a wide readership. See ODNB: Ceridwen Lloyd-Morgan: https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/62908

An independent boatman from Cwm-y-Glo who carried both tourists and slates on the Llanberis lakes in the late C18th. According to Catherine Hutton, he died between the summer of 1799 and the summer of 1800. See J.S. Illsley and O.T.P Roberts, ‘An 18th century boat in Lake Padarn, North Wales’, The International Journal of Nautical Archaeology and Underwater Exploration (1979), 8.1 :45-67.

John Campbell (1680-1743) became second duke of Argyll in 1703, succeeding his father, Archibald. He had a long military career, including commanding the government forces against the Jacobites at Sheriffmuir in 1715.

Frederick Augustus Hervey (1730-1803), fourth earl of Bristol and Bishop of Derry from 1768 to 1803. He was interested in the role of volcanoes in geological formation both on the continent and in the Hebrides and Ireland, visiting the Giant's Causeway and Staffa with the Italian artist Antonio de Bittio. He was elected to the Royal Society in 1782.

note.note: Gillean Maclaine of Scallastle (1724-1788), illegitimate son of John, 17th laird of Lochbuie. He trained in law at Edinburgh and held a small estate on Mull. He was described as a tacksman by Jacob Pattison, whom he hosted during his 1780 tour. In 1771, Maclaine married Maria, daughter of Lachlan Macquarrie of Ulva. Black, To the Hebrides, p.563.
Maria (née Macquarrie), daughter of Lachlan Macquarrie of Ulva. In 1771 she married Gillean Maclaine of Scallastle, illegitimate son of John, 17th laird of Lochbuie. Black, To the Hebrides, p.563.
Lady MacDougall, wife of Alexander MacDougall of Dunollie.

persName.note: Sister of Alexander MacDougall of Dunollie, described by Jacob Pattison as being around fifty years of age when he met her in 1780.

note.note: A son of the legendary Fingal, mentioned by James Macpherson in the work of that name.
Character in Macpherson's Ossian, whose daughter Everallin is courted by the eponymous bard.

persName.note: Character in James Macpherson's Ossian, father of the ill-fated Oscar's lover, Malvina.

Sir Francis Geary (1709/10-1796) was a long-serving British naval officer, who commanded a succession of vessels in the War of the Austrian Succession and Seven Years' War, eventually attaining the rank of admiral. In 1780, at the age of seventy he returned to sea to command the British fleet against French and Spanish forces threatening the English Channel. ODNB.

note.note: Lord George Gordon (1751-1793) was a son of the third duke of Gordon, Cosmo George Gordon and Lady Catherine Gordon. He served in the navy, spent a short time in pre-revolutionary America and became MP for Ludgerhall, Wiltshire. Gordon is chiefly remembered for his leadership of the movement to repeal the Catholic Relief Act, which removed the penalties paid by some Roman Catholics for land purchases, and the so-called 'Gordon Riots' which ensued. Having agitated significant support for a petition to repeal the Act, in June 1780 Gordon was accompanied to Westminster by a crowd of around 60,000. The situation escalated into a violent riot which was only suppressed after several days by the deployment of troops. Gordon was imprisoned in the Tower of London and charged with high treason for his role in provoking the riots, of which he was acquitted thanks partly to the defence of his lawyers Thomas Erskine and Lloyd Kenyon. ODNB.

Lachlan MacLean succeeded his brother Hector as the seventh laird of Torloisk, Mull in 1765. He spent several years as captain of a merchant vessel that traded between London and Jamaica. He married Margaret, daughter of Richard Smith. They had one daughter, Marianne, who succeeded to the Torloisk estate on her father's death in 1799. Marianne married general Douglas Clephane. J.P. MacLean, A History of the Clan MacLean (Cincinnati: 1889), p.314.

Margaret MacLean, née Smith, married Lachlan MacLean, seventh laird of Torloisk, Mull. Their only daughter Marrianne succeeded to the estate on Lachlan's death in 1799. J.P. MacLean, A History of the Clan MacLean (Cincinnati: 1889), p.314.

Sir Allan Maclean (c.1710-1783), sixth baronet and eighteenth laird of Duart. He hosted Johnson and Boswell on the island of Inchkenneth during their 1773 tour, and accompanied them to Iona; Boswell later succesfully represented him in a suit to regain part of his estates from the duke of Argyll in 1783. Prior to this, Maclean had no property of his own, holding only the tack of the Brolas estate from the Campbells of Argyll. Maclean commanded a company of militia against the Jacobites in 1745, and served in the Netherlands and Amerias. His wife Una, with whom he had three daughters, died in 1760. Ronald Black To the Hebrides (Edinburgh: Birlinn, 2011), p.563.

persName.note: Mr Maclaughlan (fl. 1780), landlord at Auchnacraig, Mull, mentioned by Jacob Pattison.

note.note:
John Smith (1747-1807), minister and Gaelic scholar, was born in the parish of Glenorchy and educated at Edinburgh University. He served as minister of Tarbert, Loch Fyne, and then in Lorne. In 1780 the duke of Argyll presented him to the parish of Campbeltown, Kintyre, at which time he began to publish translations of Ossianic poetry, beginning with
Galic Antiquities
, and followed by Sean Dàna in 1787. Smith also authored a number of theological and agricultural works, including the General View of the Agriculture of the County of Argyll (1798), and the Campbeltown entry for Sinclair's Statistical Account of Scotland. ODNB.

persName.note: Virgil (Publius Vergilius Maro), first-century BCE Latin poet, known for his pastoral Eclogues, Georgics, and epic Aeneid.
Character in Virgil's Eclogues.
An unidentified Mr Campbell of Inveraray, to whom Jacob Pattison had a letter of introduction during his 1780 tour.

note.note: Mrs Campbell (née MacLean?), described by Jacob Pattison in 1780 as a niece of Lachlan MacLean of Torloisk.
Maria MacLean, eldest daughter of Sir Allan MacLean of Duart, married Charles MacLean of Morvern.
Likely Charles MacLean of Morvern, husband of Maria, daughter of Sir Allan MacLean of Duart.

persName.note: Roman goddess of wisdom, associated with the Greek goddess Athena.
Flora Macquarrie, second daughter of Lachlan Macquarrie of Ulva. She later married an illegitimate son of Archibald Maclean of Lagganulva. Black, To the Hebrides, p.563.

note.note: Susanna Macdonald, née Campbell. She was daughter of Donald Campbell of Airds, and married Alexander Macdonald of Kinlochmoidart. Alexander Mackenzie, Macdonalds of Clanranald (Inverness: 1881), p.100.

Colonel Alexander Macdonald, fifth laird of Kinlochmoidart. His father, Donald, was executed for his support of the Charles Edward Stuart in 1745, and the ancestral home was burned down by British soldiers. Alexander was educated in France along with his brother Charles, whom he later fought opposite in the American wars of independence, as colonel of the 71st Highlanders. Alexander was badly wounded in action. He married Susanna, daughter of Donald Campbell of Airds in 1765, and was succeeded by their son John, to whom the estates were restored in 1786. Alexander Mackenzie, Macdonalds of Clanranald (Inverness: 1881), p.100.

persName.note: Unidentified sister of Susanna Macdonald, née Campbell (fl. 1780).
Ossianic figure. According to Macpherson the daughter of Sarno, king of Orkney.

note.note: Unidentified Macintyre (fl.1780), an associate of Sir Allan Maclean. He is identified as a clergyman by Jacob Pattison, who renders his name 'Maccanter'.

persName.note: Socrates (469-399 BCE), Athenian philosopher.

note.note: Aristides (530-468 BCE), Athenian politician and military strategist.

persName.note: Themistocles (c.524-459 BCE), Athenian politician and soldier.
Hugh Seton of Touch, born Hugh Smith, took the surname and title of his wife, Elizabeth upon marriage. He owned the Appin estate, in addition to the Seton family lands near Stirling.

note.note: Charles Cameron of Lochiel (d.1776).

persName.note: Greek goddess associated with water and the sea.

note.note: Lord George Murray (1694-1760) was the sixth son of John Murray, first duke of Atholl. He was exiled for his support of the 1715 Jacobite rising, and served as Charles Edward Stuart's lieutenant-general during the rising of 1745. He died in exile in the Netherlands. ODNB.
John Campbell (d.1775), earl of Cawdor, MP for Pembroke, appointed a lord of the admiralty and treasury. William Anderson, The Scottish Nation (Edinburgh: A. Fullarton and Co., 1869).

persName.note: King Charles XII of Sweden (1682-1718).
Mr Brodie (fl. 1780), Morayshire landowner.
James Ogilvy, seventh earl of Findlater and fourth earl of Seafield (1750-1811).
Old testament figure, the first man created by God.

note.note:
Andrew Baxter (1686/7-1750), Aberdeen-born metaphysician and author of
An Enquiry into the Nature of the Human Soul
. The theory on dreams and dreaming expounded in the Enquiry was somewhat unusual, and would later influence Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

persName.note: Old-testament patriarch supposed to have lived for over 900 years.

note.note: Charles Leslie (b. c.1785), encountered by Jacob Pattison during his 1780 tour of Scotland.

persName.note: Greek goddess of the sea and wife of Poseidon.
Greek mythological figure.

note.note: H.N.P[attisson], cousin of Jacob Pattisson referred to in the latter's 1780 tour.

persName.note: Captain Piggot, mentioned in Jacob Pattisson's tour of 1780.
Richard II (1367-1400), king of England.

John of Trevisa, was a medieval translator and clergyman born in Cornwall. He was a fellow of Exeter College (1362-1369) and Queen's College, Oxford. His 1387 translation from Latin into English of Ranulph Higden's Polychronicon is held by Aberdeen University Special Collections.
Legendary eighth-century king of Scotland.
Luke the Evangelist, ascribed author of the Gospel of Luke.

Thomas Gordon (1714-1797), professor of philosophy at Aberdeen University. He entertained Johnson and Boswell at Aberdeen during their 1773 tour, as well as the poet Robert Burns during his tour of 1787. His daughter Anna Gordon (1747–1810) was a renowned collector of Scottish ballads.

Anna Gordon (1747-1810) was one of the most important collectors of Scottish ballads. Her father was Professor Thomas Gordon of Aberdeen University and her mother Lilias Forbes of Disblair, from whose family she acquired many of her songs and ballads. She supplied ballads to Walter Scott and Robert Jamieson. In 1788 she married reverend Andrew Brown of Falkirk, and she is commonly known to scholars as Mrs Brown of Falkland. ODNB.
Zeno of Elea, fourth-century BCE Greek philosoper.
Phaethon, figure of Greek myth who died driving the chariot in which the sun was carried.
Aeolus, figure of Greek myth; keeper of the winds.
Neptune, Roman god of water and the seas; equivalent to the Greek Poseidon.

Jacob Pattisson of Witham, Essex (1758-1782), studied medicine at Edinburgh University. Pattisson held presidencies of the Speculative, Royal Medical, and Physical Societies at the time of his early death in 1782, following which the members of the three societies erected a monument to his memory in Edinburgh. During his membership of the Speculative Society, he is recorded to have contributed essays on the Crusades and 'Sleep and Dreaming'. The manuscript journal of Pattisson's 1780 tour of Scotland and the Hebrides is held at the National Museum of Scotland.

note.note: One of the 'sea-guides' who helped women bathe at Barmouth in the 1790s

persName.note: A glazier buried in Llanbeblig CHurch near Caernarfon; died 1703.
Name on a gravestone from Llanbeblig church; wife of Robert Rowland, she died in 1790 aged 80.
Name on gravestone from Llanbeblig church; husband of Elizabeth Peter.
Landlady of Tafarn Dywyrch (also known as the Cross Foxes) near Llanarmon-yn-Ial in the late 1790s; she is vividly described by Catherine Hutton

Beuno, thought to have died in the mid-seventh century, was widely revered as a saint across north Wales. A C14th Welsh-language Life, Buchedd Beuno, recounts a range of events and miracles which correspond to sites of his cult; he also appears in the Life of his niece St Gwenfrewi or Winefrede of Holywell, near Thomas Pennant’s home at Downing. See Patrick Sims-Williams, Buchedd Beuno: The Middle Welsh Life of St Beuno (Dublin: Dias Texts, 2018) and ODNB

Joan, Lady of Wales (ca 1191–1237) was the natural daughter of King John of England (1166-1216), who married her to Llywelyn ap Iorwerth (Llywelyn Fawr, Llywelyn the Great) in 1205. Often known by her Welsh name, Siwan, she is remembered for mediating between her husband and father, and for an affair with William de Braose, who was hanged by Llewelyn at Abergwyngregyn in 1230. (Pennant tells this story, as did Saunders Lewis in his verse drama, Siwan (1956)). The stone coffin traditionally thought to be hers was moved by Lord Bulkeley into the Church of St Mary and St Nicholas in Beaumaris, in 1808
